DOC.HEAD: Feds Settle Dispute Over Earthquake Money for Displaced Poor
DOC.TEXT: The federal government will pay nearly $25 million to counties hit by the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake to help displaced poor people, officials said Thursday. Federal Emergency Management Agency officials backed out of a similar agreement announced in February, saying it had been signed under a misunderstanding. Legal Aid lawyers for the poor said the new settlement had been approved by FEMA, high-level Justice Department officials and U.S. District Judge Eugene Lynch. Assistant U.S. Attorney George Stoll confirmed the agreement was reached, saying it was binding and the government should provide funding quickly. ``We are confident they will not renege,'' said Morgan Gilhuly, a volunteer San Francisco lawyer. ``This is a good deal for FEMA and a good deal for people who lost their housing.'' Under the settlement, FEMA is to distribute the funds to San Francisco, Santa Cruz and Alameda counties, said Stepehn Ronfeldt of Legal Aid Society of Alameda County. The funds will be distributed according to each county's proportionate losses in low-income housing units. San Francisco planning official Carla Javits said the city would use most of its money to renovate two centers providing 425 beds and a variety of services to the homeless. Alameda County, which lost more than 1,100 residential hotel rooms, will use some money for reconstruction and some for a newly designed housing voucher program, said Rae Mary of the county's Office of Community Development. Santa Cruz County has similar plans, Ronfeldt said.

DOC.HEAD: Old and New Xmas Specials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Yes, Virginia, it's December already. In television land that means 'tis the season to beg your parents for just one more viewing of ``Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer'' while wading through an avalanche of prime-time holiday specials. CBS boasts the oldest and most favored holiday fare, beginning with the venerable ``Twas The Night Before Christmas,'' narrated by Joel Grey, airing at 8 p.m. Dec. 8. The animated half-hour drawn from Clement Moore's poem was first broadcast in 1974. On Dec. 10, CBS will rebroadcast ``The I Love Lucy Christmas Special'' at 8:30 p.m. Lucy, Ricky, Ethel and Fred will be colorized for portions of this year's special. The segment, shown for the first time last season after being lost for 33 years, flashes back to some classic ``Lucy'' episodes, including the birth of Little Ricky. Charlie Brown and that poor, bedraggled Christmas tree trundle back for the 25th anniversary of ``A Charlie Brown Christmas,'' (yes, Virginia, Snoopy and the gang first premiered in this yuletide special in 1965), on Dec. 19 at 8:30 p.m. Charlie Brown will be preceded at 8 p.m. by 21-year-old ``Frosty the Snowman,'' narrated by Jimmy Durante. CBS celebrates the holidays on its series with eight special episodes of shows including ``Murphy Brown'' and ``The Trials of Rosie O'Neill.'' In the latter, the recently divorced Rosie, played by Sharon Gless, has her yuletide spirits dampened when she learns her ex- and his new wife are going to midnight mass at her church. At NBC, the number of holiday programs is mind boggling. From Bob Hope to the Chipmunks, NBC Christmas fare includes more than 20 specials and series episodes. Hope travels to Bermuda for a Dec. 15 Christmas show, broadcast at 10 p.m., starring Dixie Carter of ``Designing Women'' and the 1991 Rose Queen. Alvin and the ``Chipmunks 30th Anniversary'' chirp falsetto through another Christmas on Dec. 8 at 8 p.m. ``The Dreamer of Oz: The L. Frank Baum Story,'' airs Dec. 10 at 9 p.m., starring John Ritter and Annette O'Toole in a two-hour TV movie chronicling the ``Wizard of Oz'' author's unlikely ascent to fame. Holiday segments will appear on series including ``L.A. Law,'' Dec. 13, ``Quantum Leap,'' Dec. 14, ``Wings,'' Dec. 14 and ``Midnight Caller,'' Dec. 21. ABC has the fewest number of Christmas specials. Instead, the network focused its holiday energies on making yuletide installments of existing series. Dolly Parton takes viewers on a family reunion in the Smoky Mountains at 9 p.m. on Dec. 21 with ``Dolly Parton: Christmas at Home.'' Teen-age sensations ``New Kids on the Block'' have their own Christmas party Dec. 14 at 9 p.m. The 16-year-old whiz-kid title character of ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' tries to get out of a Christmas Eve hospital shift on Dec. 19, the ``Wonder Years' '' teen-age protagonist, Kevin, gets a little bummed out when dad can't afford to buy the family a color TV for Christmas and ``MacGyver'' spends the Dec. 10 episode tracking down a statue of the (Biblical) Madonna. Fox Broadcasting Co. has a Dec. 21 Christmas episode of ``Against the Law'' and a Dec. 23 special installment of ``True Colors.'' After all this is over, Virginia, get ready for ``Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve'' on ABC, when yes, once again, that guy who has been around forever but never looks old stands in a horde of crazed New Yorkers waiting for a fake apple to drop from Times Square.

DOC.HEAD: Technology Invades Toddlers' World
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Computers are challenging the sandbox and easel in preschool programs across the country, although educators have mixed opinions about introducing technology to toddlers. Youngsters should ``begin as early as possible to view computers as a tool,'' said Suzanne Thouvenelle, vice president of an Alexandria, Va., firm that developed software for young children. But John Lindley, principal of South Colby Elementary School in Port Orchard, Wash., countered, ``Children need to be involved in active learning. Computers are too passive. Computer introduction to them is something they get too much of already and that's television.'' Even Bernard Gifford, vice president of education marketing for Apple Computer Inc., acknowledged that computers in preschool may be ``a bit too early.'' ``I believe strongly in making it available to kids but I would be reluctant to impose a structured program at that age. I think the most important skills for youngsters at ages 3 and 4, frankly, are social skills.'' In a sampling of Head Start preschool classes around the country, children used computers to create animals and plant imaginary gardens. One program allowed them to combine facial features on the computer while dictating stories to their teachers. The youngsters were so excited and motivated by the computers that attendance improved, Thouvenelle said. Parents also showed a greater interest in their children's work and enthusiastically volunteered to work in the classroom. Walt Disney Computer Software, Inc. recently introduced a line of software that had been tested at two Burbank, Calif., preschools. ``Nowhere on the package does it say educational software,'' notes Sam Palahnuk, Walt Disney product developer. ``What we claim this stuff is a `fun exploratory software for your kid.''' Fun is what 3-year-old Heather Leffler, 4-year-old Emily Koleini and her 2-year-old brother Massoud were having during a demonstration of the software at an upscale Virginia mall. With parents nearby, the children watched in delight the colorful, animated graphics of Mickey Mouse and his friends and listened to the digitalized speech, fully orchestrated music and real-life sound effects. The youngsters used numbers to help Mickey Mouse plan a birthday party forGGoofy, named animals at a county fair with letters of the alphabet, and identified shapes as Mickey performed magic acts. ``It certainly isn't boring,'' said Andrea Fleury of McLean, Va., as she threatened to leave her 3-year-old, who had tinkered with the computer for nearly two hours. ``We went for the approach `let kids really have fun and they'll learn as a side effect,''' said Palahnuk. ``We don't want to claim that it's going to teach your kid anything. We think it will, but you start getting into teaching philosophy and curriculum and all that kind of thing.'' A study by the National Association of Elementary School Principals found that elementary school children are more likely to use computers in school than high school or college students, and even 15 percent of kindergartners and preschoolers in the public schools use computers. ``Research dating back to 1932 showed that technology as simple as a typewriter had significant effects on the reading and writing performance of elementary students,'' said James E. Dezel, International Business Machines Corp. vice president. ``The technology available to schools today and in the future could bring about amazing results.'' IBM sponsored the three-year study exploring classroom uses of computers with children and parents in Head Start, a popular federal preschool program that provides education, meals and health screening for poor youngsters aged 3 through 5. Eleven of Head Start's 1,300 programs participated, including four in Baltimore, Md., and one each in Winder, Ga., DeRidder, La., New York City, Lexington, Ky., Toledo, Ohio, Las Cruces, N.M., and Dayton, Ohio. Head Start was used ``because of its emphasis on providing equity for kids from low-income families,'' said Thouvenelle, vice president of Mobius Corp., which developed new software after evaluating the program. She said the software meets the guidelines of the National Association for the Education of Young Children ``as being developmentally appropriate.'' Association officials take no position on computers in preschool. ``Our major concern was whether or not computers were applicable, or would work for preschool children 3 and 4 years old,'' said Thouvenelle. A second concern, she said, was whether ``young children can use computers as a tool the same way they use blocks or easel painting.'' Each of the 44 classrooms participating in the experiment had two computers that shared a printer, mouse and a large, touch-sensitive device known as the Powerpad. Thouvenelle said the Powerpad is important to young children who often do not have the fine motor skills needed to hold a pen or pencil. The computers ran a program called KidsWay, which came equipped with voice cards in the native language of the parents of the children who participated, such as Spanish, Navajo, Swahili and Japanese. A key finding, said Thouvenelle, is that computers should be available and accessible to youngsters in the classroom, the same as reading materials, art work, blocks, sandbox and other so-called learning center areas. Preschoolers should not be marched down the hall to a computer laboratory, she said. She said a lack of teacher training and support remains a key drawback to the program. Winnie Porter, a 12-year teaching veteran of kindergarten through fifth grade in San Francisco, is against pushing academics too early in kindergarten. Computers, she said, ``are good as long as kids are allowed to explore with them and they are not forced on them.'' ``I think children could learn what they would learn from a computer as they would learn from other things,'' said Pat Wynne-Evans, who retired last year as a San Francisco teacher. With many school districts plagued by tight budgets, Lindley, the South Colby principal, said, ``If I had to make a financial decision between buying big blocks for $400-$500 and a computer for $850, I'd go with the big blocks every time. ``Kids need active learning. Computers are not multi-dimensional. Also you want children using their imagination, rather than looking at a screen,'' Lindley said.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Has Clean-Water Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: In this dusty village, progress is not a question of telephones or television. It is a matter of water. Stanislaw Szablowski and his neighbors had to truck water in every day for years. Their wells were too shallow and tainted even for their livestock and crops. Like more than 70 percent of Polish villages, Zastawie had no running water. Recent Health Ministry tests of the farmyard wells villagers depend on throughout Poland found the water in 67 percent was too polluted to use. ``I don't have to tell you the impact of the lack of enough clean water on the quality of life, on the amount of work for women, on hygiene, on farm productivity,'' said Maria Stolzman, a member of Parliament. Her Water Supply Foundation, led by the Roman Catholic Church, helped Zastawie build a deep-well pumping station that brought plentiful fresh water to the 31 farms in August. Poland's water crisis also affects urban areas, where more than half the supply comes from surface water so contaminated that experts say it should not have been collected in the first place. Of the 4,500 Health Ministry tests made on city water systems in 1989, only 37.6 percent found good water. ``We are really struggling,'' said Eugenia Koblak-Kolinska, deputy director of the Environment Ministry's water department. ``Everything that can be done on paper - regulations, theoretical research, preparation of plans and progress - is already worked out. What we lack is a way to put it into practice: the new technologies ... the money.'' Eastern Europe after communism is revealing a horror of pollution that was created by heavy industry and untamed by concern for the environment. The nations of the former Soviet bloc have neither the expertise nor money to reverse the decades of destruction, and their efforts for economic development often compete with environmental protection. There is optimism, however, that the change to market economics will provide governments newly focused on environmental hazards with the ability to fight wanton polluters. Under the old system, state-owned factories subsidized by the national treasury could afford the modest fines occasionally imposed for pollution. The fines have been increased by up to 27 times, however, and will be much more important to industries forced to survive in capitalist competition. ``Our minister made an ultimatum to a large group of factories: Either you will do something for environmental protection ... during a certain period of time, or the factory will cease to exist,'' Mrs. Koblak-Kolinska said. ``The factories still cannot believe that something like this might happen.'' Pollution fighters look with some hope at offers from Western nations to provide environmental help as part of their aid programs. ``What they offer us - credits with very low interest and some modern technologies - this is all very interesting,'' Mrs. Koblak-Kolinska said, then added: ``But credits have to be paid back.'' Years of pollution of Poland's water supply are documented in handwritten ledgers stacked in the Health and Environment ministries. In Lomza province northeast of Warsaw, for example, only 6.6 percent of 280 wells tested in 1989 had acceptable water. In Slupsk, a Baltic province, 40 percent of the 265 wells tested were polluted. Communist officials did not act on the information or make it public. A regime unable to provide jobs, housing and food tended to dismiss environmental controls as luxuries. Under communist censorship, the information about polluted water ``might have been known to a certain very narrow circle of people,'' said Alicja Lopatek, a Health Ministry sanitary inspector, but it ``could not come into the open.'' Reports by the Health and Environment ministries say: -Thirty-five percent of river water is not even fit for industrial use. Poland's main river, the Vistula running from the southern mountains to the Baltic, is unfit for any use for more than half its length. -Warsaw is the only European capital without a sewage treatment plant, and there are none in such other major cities as Lodz, Bialystock and Radom. -Nearly half the 800 small cities and towns lack water purification systems. Environmental officials estimate Poland needs 1,900 major sewage treatment plants in towns and cities and 8,300 in rural areas, at a total cost of $20 billion to $25 billion. -Half the nitrogen deposited in the Baltic comes from Poland, along with a large share of other pollutants. Poland's Baltic resorts are closed to swimmers and its fishing catch is questionable. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki said curbing the pollution ``poses many problems'' and may even be ``unrealistic without significant technological and financial support from abroad.'' -Water pumped from Poland's coal mines is so salty when it pours into rivers that it kills biological life and corrodes machinery. Lack of purification systems exacerbates the health threat of polluted water. ``The filter stations are old-fashioned,'' said Stanislaw Sadanski, a Health Ministry water expert. Some were built in the in the 1920s and 1930s, he said, and ``the one in Warsaw is 100 years old.'' Mrs. Lopatek of the ministry said: ``Local water systems ... generally don't have any equipment for cleaning water, and the worst situation is with the wells, public and private. Even on the outskirts of Warsaw, people are using wells.'' Shallow wells collect surface water that picks up chemicals, human and animal waste and other contaminants. The answer is deep-well water facilities with purification and sewage systems. ``If you are a mother with a child, it may be shocking to hear the (pollution) standard is exceeded by 10 times, but if you have no other water, what do you do?'' Sadanski said.

DOC.HEAD: Crayola Has Another Surprise: Top Crayon Maker Colorblind
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report; also on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Crayola company officials might be turning a little red, make that fuchsia, with news that its top crayon maker is colorblind. Emerson Moser, who is retiring next week after 35 years, isn't colorblind in the sense that he can't see color at all. It's just that some colors are confusing to him. That means trying to spot the difference between a cadet blue and a blue green can make him feel, well, like a shrinking violet. ``If you have a serious case of it, you could foul up a lot of materials,'' said Moser, 63, who has made a record 1.4 billion crayons. His title at Binney & Smith Co. is a crayon molder. As far as Moser and the company can tell, there's been no threat of children coloring the sky green and the grass blue - unless they were doing their Andy Warhol imitations. ``He's blue-green colorblind, but despite his handicap, he's gone to the top of his trade,'' said Brad Drexler, spokesman for the Easton-based company. Moser has made seas of salmon, pecks of plums and is a king crayon craftsman, Drexler said. Tuesday, Moser made yards of yellow and Wednesday, it was oodles of orange - colors that give Moser no trouble. ``When you have shades of one color, you get a little doubt about it. Before you go do anything, you double-check yourself,'' said Moser. It's the second technicolor shock to come out of the Crayola plant this year. In August, it retired eight traditional colors into the Crayola Hall of Fame. The company is asking Moser to donate his final pair of ankle-high boots, splashed with the waxy colorful remains of his time on the job, for inclusion in the hall. ``The colors splash a little bit when it comes out of the kettle into the bucket,'' said Moser. ``People daily clean their shoes, but I don't. I have a multicolored pair of shoes. It's probably made them waterproof. ``This pair I have now ... there's yellow on them, because I worked yellow today, and some orange and some red,'' Moser said in a telephone interview Tuesday. A company doctor detected Moser's slight vision problem during a physical conducted when he was hired Oct. 12, 1953, as a floor boy in the packing department. ``It's so slight that if the doctor wouldn't have tested me, I probably would have never noticed it,'' Moser said. Less than two years later, Moser graduated to the most colorful job in the world, pouring molten wax into 2,400-crayon molds nearly 100 times a day. Once the wax is set, crayons are flicked out of the racks and stacked in a bin for a conveyor belt to carry them to a labeling machine. At Crayola, there are subtle shades of everything. But can anyone over age 12 really tell the difference between violet and blue violet, cornflower and navy blue, blue green and cadet blue, sepia and brown, orchid and thistle, or mulberry and red violet? Other colors to worry about are the new shades of cerulean (a type of blue), dandelion, fuchsia, jungle green, royal purple, teal blue, vivid tangerine and wild strawberry. They replaced blue gray, green blue, lemon yellow, maize, orange red, orange yellow, raw umber and violet blue last summer. For less than obvious reasons, Moser likes the eight basic Crayola colors: black, white, red, yellow, green, blue, brown and orange. He even liked the eight retired colors, which now are remembered only in 5-foot-tall models at the hall of fame. But Moser says there is no reason to wax nostalgic about retiring the crayon colors. ``The new ones are nice. They really stand out when you color with them,'' Moser said. ``The other colors were nice, too. You grew up with them and got used to them, but you can't survive on sentiment. Sentiment doesn't keep a company moving forward.''

DOC.HEAD: Seattle Area Apartment Projects Delayed by Mismarked Lumber
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SE3 Dec. 5.
DOC.TEXT: A mismarked piece of lumber was a warning to Greg Clarke that something was awry in the closely-guarded business of grading wood for the construction industry. An angry Seattle lumber wholesaler telephoned Clarke's MacDonald Inspection Services in Vancouver, British Columbia, early last month. ``He found spruce lumber that was marked as hemlock,'' Clarke said. ``The next day, we were down there.'' Since then, a search for substandard lumber carrying higher-grade marks has resulted in the closure by building inspectors of dozens of apartment-building construction projects in the Puget Sound area. Up to 60 projects have been shut down. While builders, inspectors and engineers have worked to ferret out low-quality lumber and resume projects, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police has started an investigation in British Columbia to find the source of the mismarked wood. Costs to fix buildings are expected to run into the millions of dollars. However, inspectors and builders said there were no safety problems and the buildings would be built to code. ``We're not looking at this as a significant structural problem right now,'' said Mike Dykeman, commercial inspection supervisor for King County Building and Land Development. ``Rather than a health and safety issue, I think what we have is a consumer fraud issue,'' Colin Quinn, Lincoln Property Co. vice president, said Tuesday. Mislabeled studs were found in a new, 192-unit Lincoln apartment complex. Clarke and Tom Searles, executive vice president of the American Lumber Standards Committee in Germantown, Md., said the mislabeled lumber appeared to be limited to the Seattle area and to larger construction jobs. The problem is with framing lumber generally considered No. 3 quality, but graded to indicate it is of No. 1 or No. 2 quality, and with spruce marked as more desirable hemlock or fir. The lumber carries the MacDonald grading stamp, which is registered and licensed to mills. Marking lower-quality wood a higher grade can double its price. Searles said the case was the biggest he could remember. ``People have copied grade stamps before, but it's never been this blatant,'' he said, adding that the international lumber-grading system is zealously guarded and there have been few cases of fraud. The most recent he could recall involved a truss plant in south Florida several years ago, where the manufacturer had illegally copied a stamp. Searles said the mismarked wood was ``a very small percentage in the overall picture of things.'' The United States building industry imports 12 billion to 14 billion board feet of lumber a year from Canada, Searles said. Estimates of the mismarked timber involved range from 140,000 board feet to millions of board feet. Dykeman said inspection agencies have asked builders to check records, inspect buildings and dig through waste-wood piles in search of suspect wood. In some instances, plumbing, electric wiring and wallboard have had to be torn out to brace or replace mismarked lumber. The biggest problems arise with joists, horizontal beams that support floors or ceilings. Dykeman said some projects have been shut down for six weeks and could be shut down eight more weeks. Quinn said the apartment builders would go to court to push the losses they have sustained further up the chain of suppliers. In Canada, the Mounted Police has said little about its search for culprits. Chris Perkins, investigating officer, declined to provide details of the investigation, except to say it would be lengthy. MacDonald Inspection Services has retrieved its grading stamps from two firms - Moga Timber Mill Ltd. and A.P. Timber Co., which market lumber from a single mill in Surrey. The operations are owned by the Brar family. Brian Brar on Monday denied any wrongdoing. ``We will not tolerate any claims made against Moga or A.P. Timber,'' he said. Lumber carrying stamps licensed to the mill was sent to the job sites in the Puget Sound area. However, it was shipped through B.B.M. Lakeview Lumber Ltd. of Surrey, which had sold it to lumber brokers in Seattle. B.B.M. Lakeview this week did not return phone calls to The Associated Press. The company's attorney said earlier his company was a victim and ``did nothing wrong.'' In a separate case, B.B.M. Lakeview pleaded guilty May 6, 1988, to defrauding the public in a case involving mismarked wood and was fined $100,000.

DOC.HEAD: Log of Hiroshima Mission To Be Auctioned ... on Pearl Harbor Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY36 Dec. 5.
DOC.TEXT: High over Hiroshima, a navigator in a B-29 recorded the world's introduction to the power and terror of nuclear weapons. ``Bomb-Away - 09:15'' reads the simple entry from the navigator's log for Aug. 6, 1945. The log from the top secret mission of the Enola Gay goes on the auction block Friday - Pearl Harbor Day. Christie's auction house expects it will attract a price of $100,000 to $150,000. ``I think, in looking at the log, you see in effect the world moving from the pre-atomic into the atomic era. You see humanity crossing a very profound boundary,'' said Chris Coover, a manuscript specialist at Christie's. He said the timing of the sale - on the 49th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor - is a coincidence. But he said there was a ``historical symmetry'' to the attacks on Pearl Harbor and Hiroshima, ``one marking the beginning of hostilities and the other effectively the end of hostilities.'' But Martin Sherman, director of the Nuclear Age History and Humanities Center at Tufts University, called it ``an unfortunate date.'' ``It implies an appropriateness about Hiroshima - sort of a balance on the scales of justice,'' he said. ``They attacked us so we gave them any eye for an eye, so to speak, which is completely inappropriate and historically inaccurate.'' In the attack on Pearl Harbor, 18 U.S. ships were sunk or severely damaged, about 170 planes were destroyed and the American casualties numbered about 3,700. There were 130,000 casualties at Hiroshima. Christie's is selling the log for the widow of Capt. Robert A. Lewis, co-pilot of the Enola Gay. Eileen Lewis hopes she can retire on the sale price and wants no publicity herself, Coover said. ``She is very concerned she is going to catch all kinds of hate mail and flak for putting this up for sale,'' Coover said. The log recorded the Enola Gay's basic flight information - position, altitude, air speed, compass direction - on three yellow, oblong sheets during the 12-hour roundtrip mission between the U.S. base in the Marianas Islands and Hiroshima. The bomber, with 12 people aboard, left Tinian Island at 2:45 a.m. The pilot was Col. Paul Tibbets, commanding officer of the 509th Composite Group, which had been specially trained for the mission. Tibbets selected Lewis, a Brooklyn native, as his co-pilot. Lewis was one of the most experienced B-29 pilots in the Air Force; he had survived two crashes, and had a reputation for remaining calm in moments of stress. In the plane's bomb bay rested a single 9,000-pound uranium bomb. Tibbets carried cyanide capsules to distribute to each man if the plane experienced engine failure or was shot down. The log was recorded in Tinian time - one hour ahead of the time in Hiroshima - by navigator Theodore S. van Kirk. At 5:55 a.m. he noted ``Iwo'' in the left-hand column, as the Enola Gay rendezvoused with two other B-29s near Iwo Jima. At 8:30 a.m., the notation ``I.F.F. off'' appears; the plane's radar identification gear was turned off to prevent any interference with the bomb's detonation devices. At about this time, Tibbets decided on the mission's primary target, Hiroshima, over secondary choices Nagasaki and Kokura. At 9:12 a.m., the bomber was 12 miles from its target. In the right-hand column of the log, the navigator wrote, ``Eight large ships in harbor at Mishima.'' The bomb-bay doors opened three minutes and 17 seconds later. ``Bomb-Away - 09:15,'' reads the log entry. Within a minute, 80,000 people were instantly killed or seriously wounded. Two-thirds of the city was destroyed in the now-familiar mushroom cloud. ``If I live a hundred years, I'll never quite get these few minutes out of my mind,'' Lewis wrote in notes that a New York Times reporter asked him to keep during the Hiroshima mission. Asked how the co-pilot came to have the navigator's log, Coover said only that he got it from ``someone in the squadron.'' Lewis, who died in 1983 at age 65, kept the log in a safe deposit box.

DOC.HEAD: The Hogettes: Just Another Pretty Face at Redskins Games
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: What flagrant exhibitionism, what terrible identity crisis, what suicidal yearnings would compel a middle-aged man to wriggle into a woman's dress and brave the taunts of 56,000 howling fans at a Washington Redskins football game? Michael Torbert stood thoughtfully at his front-row seat at the 50-yard line at RFK Stadium. He fluffed his bright yellow tresses, smoothed the wrinkles from his polka-dot skirt and sniffed through his plastic hog snout. ``Hey, priests have been wearing dresses for years, right?'' he said. ``We just add a little color.'' Torbert and his pot-bellied buddies are familiar to millions of TV football viewers as the ``Hogettes,'' the unofficial Redskins cheerleaders who go hog-wild every Sunday afternoon in gaudy wigs and skirts, floppy hats and pink snouts. ``Our designer is Calvin Swine,'' says Ralph Campbell, who wears a bleached-blonde wig and ruffled yellow dress with red Hogette sash across his ample waist. A retired Navy helicopter mechanic, he's known as ``the pretty one.'' These bearded bimbos have nicknames like ``Pork Chop'' and ``Big Georgette'' and ``Peewee.'' They boast an average weight of 243 pounds, nurtured by plenty of hot dogs and beer. They like to chew on huge plastic cigars. And when the Redskins are rolling toward a touchdown, they wave their parasols and hoist their beefy legs over the railing, bellowing encouragement. Torbert organized the Hogettes in 1983 to lead cheers for the ``Hogs,'' the nickname of the Redskins' offensive linemen, and to raise money for their favorite children's charities. The Hogettes range in age and occupation from a 28-year-old mail carrier to a 59-year-old retired civilian employee of Army intelligence. Torbert, 45, an Energy Department engineer and longtime Redskins fan, said all the Hogettes are devoted fathers and civic activists. Since 1983, he said, the Hogettes have helped raise $30 million for sick and underprivileged children by appearing at golf tournaments, telethons, parades and other charity benefits at their own expense. Each of the 11 regular Hogettes spends as much as $1,000 out of pocket to attend Redskins games and log about 5,000 miles traveling to more than 100 fund-raising events every year, Torbert estimated. Their 17 beneficiaries include Children's Hospital in Washington, the Ronald McDonald House and a rural Virginia summer camp for young cancer patients. ``I didn't have a dress in my closet for the first 40 years,'' said George Maxfield, alias ``Big Georgette.'' ``My mom didn't raise me that way. But I'd do anything to raise money for these kids,'' he said. Campbell, who's nickname is ``Grandpa,'' says he has no qualms about looking foolish in a woman's skirt, ``if it brings smiles to the kids' faces and makes some money for the sick ones.'' The Hogettes have stolen dresses from their mothers' closets and learned how to drink beer without getting their hog snouts wet. They've been pelted with ice and game programs. They've had their snouts pulled back and snapped in their faces. Shouts of ``You're mighty cute!'' and ``What are you doing after the game?'' are commonplace. They take personal bodyguards when they travel to Philadelphia to protect them against violence. ``We know how the Israelis feel when we attend an Eagles game - four of us surrounded by an armed camp,'' Torbert said. The Hogettes have endured not only icy stadium winds but more than a few surprise pinches on their tushes from playful fans. Maxfield, who stands 6-feet-4, remembers a particularly painful grab at the Hogettes' first Super Bowl at Tampa, Fla., in January 1984. ``I was going up into the stands for lunch when somebody hogged down on my right cheek big-time,'' he said. ``I swung around, and it was a woman who must have been at least 7 feet tall. ``She said, `I'm sorry, I just couldn't resist.' I said, `If it turns you on, feel free.' So darned if she didn't do it again - real hard - and I almost went to the emergency room to see if she'd torn a chunk out of me.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Disputes Notion that Infertility is on the Increase
DOC.TEXT: Infertile couples are flocking to clinics, joining self-help groups and lobbying Congress for help. But contrary to popular perception, a new study says there is no infertility epidemic. ``The overall rate of infertility didn't change between 1982 and 1988,'' said William Mosher, a statistician who co-authored the federal report. ``This is another chapter in the life story of the baby boom, whose members have affected American society at every stage of their lives.'' One out of 12 women had an impaired ability to have children in both 1982 and 1988, a steady rate of 8.4 percent, according to the report by the National Center for Health Statistics. In 1988 that rate translated into 4.9 million women aged 15 to 44. The infertility rate for married couples actually fell from 8.5 percent in 1982 to 7.9 percent or 2.3 million couples in 1988. Nevertheless, said Mosher and co-author William Pratt, some popular descriptions of infertility have suggested there are 9 million to 10 million infertile couples, or that one in six couples is infertile, fertility is increasing rapidly or there is an ``epidemic'' of infertility in the United States. Not true, Mosher and Pratt said, based on their analysis of the 1982 and 1988 National Surveys of Family Growth. In fact, the surveys found that the percentage of women with fertility problems has decreased among baby boom women aged 25 to 44. Still, the authors said, infertility problems are plaguing more people now than ever before, due to the aging of the outsized baby boom generation and its propensity to delay childbearing. The number of childless women aged 35 to 44 jumped 64 percent over the six-year period in the study. And while the percentage of those with fertility problems did not change, the sheer size of the group added to the number afflicted - 620,000 in 1988, up from 454,000 in 1982. Mix those statistics with an explosion in infertility treatments and doctors trained in the field. Stir in a heavy dose of news coverage, including letters to syndicated advice columnists like Ann Landers. Voila: a trend. ``As the technology progresses, more stories are out and more people are learning about the availability of options. More people are seeking services and subsequently receiving help,'' said Joyce Zeitz, a spokeswoman for the 10,000-member American Fertility Society in Birmingham, Ala. But Zeitz said her group never expected the report, the first national fecundity estimate of all 57.9 million women of reproductive age, regardless of marital status, to document rampant rises in infertility. ``At one point, we thought that with the aftermath of the IUD (intrauterine device) problems and the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases, we might see a slight increase'' in the infertility rate, she said. ``In the overall scheme, that was probably not as significant as we thought it was going to be. But we never really felt there was going to be an epidemic.'' Even without the rapid rise some had anticipated, Zeitz said the disorder remains a serious concern. ``We're still talking about 2.3 million couples, 4.9 million women who have a problem,'' she said. ``We still need more research, better contraceptives, better insurance coverage, better lab regulation.'' Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., is pushing a number of those concerns in Congress. One of her bills led to money this year for the National Institutes of Health to establish several contraceptive and infertility research centers around the country. Mrs. Schroeder plans to reintroduce next year a bill that would earmark federal money for programs that screen and treat women for sexually transmitted diseases, a leading cause of infertility. Another proposal would require federal employees' insurance policies, if they offer pregnancy benefits, to also cover infertility treatment and medical or counseling expenses related to adoption. Mosher said the focus on infertility, and the visibility its victims have gained, is not surprising. ``Whatever the baby boom is concerned with gets attention,'' he said. ``When they were in their late 20s they started buying houses and pushed up the demand for housing. Now they have children or are trying to have children, so infertility, adoption and child care are issues. When they retire, retirement and Social Security will be the issues.''

DOC.HEAD: Cancer Gene's Role Identified in Worm, Could Aid Cancer Research
DOC.TEXT: A gene that aids development of a sex organ in a worm may lead to new insights into human cancer, scientists reported. Researchers have discovered that it is a so-called ``ras'' gene, a type linked to several cancers, and have figured out one of its normal roles in the worm. Those advances will give scientists their first chance to use a living animal to determine the details of what a ras gene does and how it is controlled, commented Princeton University scientist James Broach. ``We're going to have a big explosion in our understanding of what ras does in the biology of an organism,'' Broach said. ``We anticipate ... we'll be able to understand all the players that `talk' to ras and that ras interacts with.'' That may illuminate the process by which a ras gene promotes cancer, revealing new targets for therapeutic drugs, Broach said. However, any such payoff would be a long way in the future, cautioned H. Robert Horvitz, a biology professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute there. Ras genes normally help control cell growth and development, but little is known about how they do that, or how they are regulated. Abnormal ras genes are frequently observed in pancreatic, lung, colon and blood cell cancers. In today's issue of the British journal Nature, Horvitz and colleagues describe the ras gene's role in development of female genitalia in a worm called Caenorhabditis elegans. The worm gene, called let-60, was identified as a ras gene by Paul Sternberg and Min Han of the California Institute of Technology in research reported last Friday in the journal Cell. In the Nature paper, scientists report that let-60 acts as a switch, controlling signals that are supposed to tell cells to form genitalia called the vulva. The researchers showed that if let-60 is mutated such that it cannot be activated, the cells fail to form genitalia when they receive the signals. In contrast, if let-60 is mutated such that it is always ``turned on,'' the cells will form a vulva even without any signal to do so. Scientists also found that mutations that permanently activate let-60 resemble a mutation linked to cancer in humans. Such permanent activation of ras is what occurs in the human cancers with which it is associated, Horvitz said.

DOC.HEAD: Bargainers Working on Final Aspects of Nuclear Arms Treaty
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Soviet negotiators, aiming toward an early 1991 summit in Moscow, are tackling the remaining obstacles to a treaty on strategic weapons. After clearing away three major roadblocks to the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, or START, officials say experts from both sides will meet Friday in Washington to work on remaining technical issues. They involve inspections to verify treaty compliance and telemetry data from ballistic missile testing. Those areas of disagreement still could block completion of the treaty, but one U.S. official said they ``are not enough for anyone to fall on their sword over.'' The negotiators have made significant progress over the past month by agreeing to limit Soviet Backfire bombers that would be outside the START treaty itself; to allow U.S. nuclear programs with Britain to continue; and to restrict the launch and payload weight of the Soviets' modernized, ground-based SS-18 missiles, said an official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The White House is holding off on preparations for President Bush's trip to Moscow, anticipated for January, saying the president will go only if the START treaty is ready to sign. The treaty aims to cut U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear weapons by 30 percent, scrapping hundreds of warheads. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze will meet in Houston next Monday and Tuesday to hash out the remaining issues, and Shevardnadze will fly to Washington to meet with Bush on Wednesday. On the three big stumbling blocks recently resolved: -The United States agreed that the Soviet Backfire bomber can be counted separately from the overall START limits of 1,600 heavy bombers and ballistic missiles the Soviets are allowed to retain, said an official close to the talks. The source declined to say how many Backfires would be permitted under the politically binding letter that will be outside the treaty itself. The Soviets have an estimated 355 Backfires now, according to the International Institute for Strategic Studies, a London-based think tank. -The Soviets agreed to continued U.S. nuclear programs with Britain as long as those programs are not seen as upsetting the overall strategic balance. The cooperation primarily involves technology and missiles the United States provides for British submarines. -The negotiators agreed that any modernized SS-18 could not have the capability to carry heavier payloads, including warheads, than the current SS-18. The treaty, however, would not limit modernization such as improved accuracy or fuel efficiency, or alteration in the types of warheads. Under the pact, the Soviets would cut the number of SS-18s by half to 154. U.S. officials said the remaining issues involve: -Monitoring of production facilities for mobile ballistic missiles. The two nations disagree on where in the missile construction process the monitoring should be allowed. The United States wants assurances for early inspection of Soviet SS-24 missiles, which have 10 warheads, while the Soviets have insisted that inspection of final assembly is sufficient. -To what extent each side must provide uncoded telemetry from testing of ballistic missiles so that the other can interpret the data and verify compliance with the treaty's restrictions on missile performance. -Whether the Soviets will be allowed to inspect the B-2 bomber to ensure it is not equipped to carry long-range cruise missiles armed with nuclear warheads.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Panel Concerned About Bacteria Sales to Iraq, Syria
DOC.TEXT: The Commerce Department approved more than 20 shipments of bacteria and other biological agents in recent years to Iraq and Syria, a congressional lawyer says. U.S. experts said that while the agents could be intended for medical purposes, they also could be used to develop biological weapons. Both countries are believed to be developing such lethal arsenals. As a result of the shipments, Iraq could end up using U.S.-supplied goods against American soldiers if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, said Ted Jacobs, chief counsel of the House subcommittee on commerce, consumer and monetary affairs. ``We never thought that Iraq would be so dangerous,'' said Peter Chalfont, secretary of the Wiltron Co. of Morgan Hills, Calif., which sold $45,000 in electronic test measuring equipment to Iraq in 1987. ``It's easy to say in hindsight that maybe the license shouldn't have been approved.'' The Bush administration has indicated growing concern about Iraq's dangerous chemical and biological weapons since U.S. troops moved into the gulf region in August to try to force Saddam Hussein's forces out of Kuwait. American troops routinely don special anti-gas suits as part of their readiness drills and carry antidotes to counter poison gas. Jacobs said he has obtained information showing that the Commerce Department has approved about half of the license applications for shipments to the Atomic Energy Commissions of Iraq and Syria over the last three years. The subcommittee has issued a subpoena to Undersecretary of Commerce Dennis Kloske to testify about the sales to Iraq and Syria, after the Commerce Department refused repeated requests for additional information and stalled on others, said Jacobs. The department approved licenses worth $700 million to Iraq over a three-year period ending Oct. 1, Jacobs said. Licenses were required because all these goods were ``dual use items,'' meaning they could be used either for peaceful or lethal purposes. Syria is under greater export restrictions than Iraq because it is one of seven nations listed by the administration as supporters of terrorism. Still, the Commerce Department approved 120 out of 251 applications between Oct. 1987, and Oct. 1, 1990, according to information obtained by Jacobs. The approval rate, as well as information about the types of items sold to Syria, was first disclosed by the Washington Jewish Week newspaper. Jacobs said he had received limited information from the Commerce Department that showed more than 20 shipments of bacteria, protozoa and fungi from one U.S. company to a post office box in Baghdad used by that nation's Atomic Energy Commission. The agency is a government purchasing arm for weapons and technology. The Commerce Department declined to release the names of any companies granted export licenses, citing a law that defends firms' proprietary interests. A spokeswoman at the department's Bureau of Export Administration declined to discuss Jacobs' allegations on the same grounds. Most U.S. exports of biological agents require Commerce Department approval because of the possibility they could be diverted for non-peaceful use. The department, in its annual 1990 report to Congress regarding export control measures, said applications to export such agents ``will generally be denied for Iran, Iraq, Syria and Libya.'' A company that sold the agents to Iraq and Syria said it was told the germs would be used to manufacture vaccines, said a source, who asked not to be identified. But, the source said, an expert could manipulate these germs to create a stronger, lethal strain. The recipient of the biological agents in Damascus was also the Atomic Energy Commission, said Jacobs. Jacobs said the Syrian commission also was sold a U.S. oscilloscope. The device is used to measure electric impulses, and a high-speed version is vital in the development of ballistic missiles and other weapons. A California-based company, Techtronics, has said it sold an oscilloscope to Iraq last year, but Jacobs said he did not know whether it also sold the device to Syria. The Commerce Department also approved the sales of electronic, optic and photographic equipment to Syria's Atomic Agency Commission, Jacobs said. The total value of the goods licensed to Syria over the past three years was $25.5 million, according to a letter from Commerce Undersecretary Kloske to the chairman of Jacobs' subcommittee, Rep. Doug Barnard, D-Ga. The Nov. 16 letter, parts of which were obtained by The Associated Press, said most of the export applications were referred to expert opinions at the State, Defense and Energy departments. The Commerce Department's 1990 export control report said most of the goods licensed for Syria were computer-related items primarily for use in the country's petroleum industry. But critics say the use of much of the equipment in Syria, an authoritarian state where the government controls all industry, cannot be monitored. And they point to Iraq as an example of a country where U.S. goods are known to have been used to manufacture weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Cardin To Launch His Line In Romania
DOC.TEXT: French designer Pierre Cardin says he plans to produce and sell his coveted garb in this fashion-deprived land, where shops still stock poor-quality, drab and utilitarian clothes. Cardin worked out details of an agreement Wednesday in a meeting with Premier Petre Roman. He is to open a boutique selling his line in Bucharest by next September. Shops in other large towns are also to open. Under dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was executed in last year's revolution, outlandish Western fashions were actively discouraged by the secret police. Youths caught in hippie or punk garb were frequently arrested. Cardin told a news conference Wednesday that he intends to license the manufacture of his products to local companies and acould also open a branch of his Maxim's restaurant chain in Bucharest. He already has cooperative ventures in Hungary, the Soviet Union and China. Cardin-label ties, shoes and shirts are popular - and expensive - on the Romanian black market. The designer said the new boutiques would sell clothes ``a lot cheaper than in the West.'' The government will pay Cardin $298,000 as a first-stage compensation for his efforts, said Textile Industry Minister Corneliu Zaharia.

DOC.HEAD: Matthus Opera Given U.S. Premiere at Conservatory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: ``Cornet Rilke's Song of Love and Death'' is a beautiful opera by Siegfried Matthus. An hour and a half long, it was given its American premiere by students of the Manhattan School of Music. When Matthus, called the most often performed living German opera composer, had his first American opera debut, of ``Judith,'' last summer in Santa Fe, N.M., he was an East German. He attended both that premiere and ``Cornet Rilke'' on Wednesday night here. ``Judith,'' depicting a story from biblical times, is exceeding tense, musically and dramatically. ``Cornet Rilke,'' though Matthus means it as an anti-war piece, soars with youth and promise and lovely melodies. The students all had pleasing voices, capable of singing the music. But almost none of the English translation was understandable except that of the 30-member chorus. David Gilbert conducted the orchestra of 15. Matthus bases his opera on an 1899 epic poem by Rainer Maria Rilke about a person in his family tree who died at 18 fighting the Turks. Since the opera reopened the Dresden opera house in 1985, burned 40 years before, Matthus begins it with the chorus singing ``On such a night there once was a fire,'' a lament for the opera house and for the young Rilke. Tattered curtains pull away, showing the youth's body on the ground. Staging, using a diagonal ramp and imaginative lighting, was telling, throughout. Near the end, the chorus holds pieces of wall which reflect the fire. The opera is in a number of concise scenes, each ending in blackout. Every detail and bit of music works toward the whole effect. At first, soldiers on their way to battle make horseback riding motions as they sing, putting a foot down, then bending their knees twice before stepping again. They sing of mothers and wives, at one point are met by tarts. Rilke finds a man's body, a woman tied to a tree, is promoted to cornet, meaning standard bearer. The part is written for a woman; women's light voices sound younger than tenors. Christine Abraham sang Rilke and Lisa Livingston, walking behind like a shadow, sang a larger part, Rilke's thoughts. The soldiers are given a party at a castle and the countess seduces Rilke. The next morning, the boy, joyfully awakened to the possibilities of adulthood, grabs the flag and runs into battle, where he is stabbed to death. Musical styles change depending on moods of scene. Sometimes, there is melody in the orchestra but modern-sounding angularities for the singers. The love scene's music is tenderly melodic instead of passionate. At the end, drums roll.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Donors to be Quizzed About Personal Lives
DOC.TEXT: Blood banks will have to ask a broader range of personal questions of would-be donors under new regulations that recognize the growing spread of AIDS among heterosexuals. The new policy, announced Wednesday, also ends the ban on donations from Haitians and eases the ban on donations from natives of sub-Saharan African nations. The Haitian government called for a ``massive program of re-educating Americans'' about a policy it said has ruined that country's tourism industry, cost thousands of jobs and caused Haitian children to be ``snubbed and taunted.'' The regulations should be implemented at all blood ``establishments,'' including Red Cross centers, within a few months, said Brad Stone, a spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration, which oversees the safety of blood supplies. ``The strengthened program will enhance, rather than replace, the current procedures used to safeguard the blood supply,'' Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan said in a statement. The changes ``will eliminate the need for excluding certain donor populations based solely on their geographical or national origins,'' he said. Under the new regulations, all potential donors will be questioned orally as well as in writing, using terminology that is understandable, ``culturally sensitive'' and avoids sexual stereotyping, the announcement said. Potential donors will be asked about all high-risk behavior, and will be asked direct questions about whether they have been treated for syphilis or gonorrhea within the last year. The exclusion for potential donors who have either paid for or sold sex will be extended from six months to a year. The exclusion for people who have received transfusions of blood or blood products will be extended from six months to one year. This change aims at reducing the risk of hepatitis C, another blood-borne disease. Haitians were singled out in 1982, early in the AIDS epidemic, because scientists found a higher-than-usual incidence of infection among Haitian heterosexuals. The policy originally covered only Haitians who came to this country after 1977 but was extended this year to cover all Haitians, many of whom had fled to this country to escape political persecution. Closer investigation determined that the occurrence of AIDS among Haitians was due to the same risky behavior as among the population at large and there was no connection with national origin. ``The focus that is resulting from the secretary's decision would seem to be quite appropriate,'' said Dr. S. Gerald Sanders, director of medical services for the American Red Cross. The number of AIDS cases associated with heterosexual contact rose from 755 in 1988-1989 to 1,026 in the next reporting period, Sanders said, quoting statistics from the Centers for Disease Control. That jump from 2 percent of all AIDS cases to 3 percent in a single year is statistically significant, he said. Verbal screening of prospective donors is important because testing of the blood supply has a gap: the AIDS antibodies do not appear for up to six months after infection. Sanders said the screening is reliable because the kind of people to take the time out to donate blood do not want to hurt others and the process is anonymous. The policy continues the ban on donations from black Africans unless they can be tested for a form of the AIDS virus, HIV-2, that is endemic in West Africa. Such tests have been developed but are not widely used in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Arnold Schwarzenegger says Hollywood's in-the-know were sure his Austrian accent and 14-letter surname would keep him from stardom. ``They were right when they said no one with an accent has made it, or made it with a name like that,'' Schwarzenegger said in an interview scheduled for broadcast today on the Fox program ``Personalities.'' ``But I didn't feel that ought to be an obstacle, and I went ahead and did it anyway, thinking I could use all those things to my advantage.'' Schwarzenegger, who has starred in such action films as ``Terminator'' and ``Predator'' and whose latest film, ``Kindergarten Cop,'' is soon to be released, said he made it because America ``is the land of opportunities.'' ``This is the place where you still can make your dreams become reality if you're willing to work hard and if you have a positive attitude,'' he said. --- LONDON (AP) - Salman Rushdie came out of hiding for a book-signing at a London bookshop. The ``Satanic Verses'' author was accompanied by bodyguards but looked relaxed Wednesday as he signed 100 copies of his new book, ``Haroun and the Sea of Stories.'' The children's fantasy was written during his two years in hiding. ``There were a lot of customers doing double-takes when they came into the shop and saw him,'' said store manager David McRedmond. ``We were only given brief notice that he was coming and were a bit surprised he was coming out at all.'' Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini sentenced the Indian-born British writer to death two years ago for allegedly blaspheming Islam with ``The Satanic Verses.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Billy Joel says he may be a little old to be on the road for 16 months, but he needs the money. ``I was beyond broke. I was looking into the abyss,'' the 41-year-old singer-songwriter said Wednesday on ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' He claims in a lawsuit that his former manager misspent or stole millions in earnings. Joel said the tour to promote his triple-platinum album ``Storm Front'' has affected his relationship with his 4-year-old child, Alexa Ray. ``Having a child and not being there, that has hurt the most,'' he said. ``And that's the thing that makes me the most bitter about this situation. They've taken away a certain amount of time I wanted to spend with my child.'' The tour, which began last December, ends in March. --- AKRON, Ohio (AP) - Garrison Keillor remembers the backstage entrances rather than the facades when he recalls theaters he's visited. ``The way that theaters are memorable is if you come in from the other way,'' the humorist said in Tuesday's Akron Beacon Journal. ``The backstages are always kind of grungy, like somebody's basement. I always find that comforting.'' Keillor's ``American Radio Company'' show on Saturday will be broadcast live nationwide on public radio from the Akron Civic Theater, which he last saw in 1985. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Keye Luke, who was Charlie Chan's No. 1 son in the movies and went on to play Master Po in the TV series ``Kung Fu,'' was honored with a star in the Hollywood Walk of Fame. The star unveiled Wednesday in honor of the 85-year-old actor was the 1,925th dedicated. Luke played in some 150 film, including 13 Charlie Chan movies, ``Gremlins,'' ``The Good Earth'' and ``Love is a Many Splendored Thing.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Producer Cameron Mackintosh, who once canceled the Broadway version of the hit London musical ``Miss Saigon'' over ethnic casting, may be in for another squabble with an actors' union over a role in the show. Mackintosh needs the permission of Actors' Equity for Filipino actress Lea Salonga to play Kim, a Vietnamese bargirl, in the Broadway production. The union has a veto over foreign actors performing in the United States. No date has been set for a union committee to consider the request, said union spokeswoman Helaine Feldman. Mackintosh battled the union last summer when it barred the white actor Jonathan Pryce from playing a Eurasian, saying such casting would be an insult to Asian actors. The producer then canceled the show but changed his mind when the union relented. ``Miss Saigon,'' set during the closing days of the Vietnam War, has sold a record $30 million in advance tickets. It opens on Broadway in April. --- ORONO, Maine (AP) - The University of Maine student newspaper says it has decided to avoid a long legal battle and abandon its attempt to republish columns written 20 years ago by Stephen King. Doug Vanderweide, editor of the Maine Campus, said Wednesday the decision was made after an ``extremely amiable'' phone conversation with the best-selling horror writer, who lives in nearby Bangor. King had objected to republication of columns he wrote while he was a student at the university. He said he found the columns embarrassingly juvenile. Vanderweide said protracted litigation with King, who has long been supportive of the university, would be ``personally distasteful.'' ``I think it's best to be fair to the man,'' Vanderweide said, ``and the way to be fair to him is just to let this issue slide.'' --- GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. (AP) - A now run-down house President Ford once lived in was sold at auction for $3,000. George Dennis of Grand Rapids and three partners sucessfully bid on the home, where Ford lived from 1923 until 1930, when he was 17. The City Commission was expected to give final approval to the bid as early as next week. The house has been vacant for 20 years. Officials at the Grand Rapids Public Museum, which was named caretaker after the city acquired it from the Veterans Administration in 1971, estimates renovations will cost $51,000.

DOC.HEAD: Now the Administration Debunks Its Own Tactic
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In four months, the Bush administration has reversed itself on whether economic pressure can force Saddam Hussein to give up his conquest of Kuwait. The president and his people have gone from saying sanctions might work, to saying sanctions were biting, to saying they won't do the job. The turning point - the assertion that sanctions won't budge Saddam - came abruptly this week, after last week's United Nations vote imposing a Jan. 15 deadline for withdrawing. Just as President Bush and his advisers began publicly abandoning hope on the worth of sanctions, others found them to be a promising alternative to war if given time to work. Two former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Air Force Gen. David Jones and Adm. William Crowe, told the Senate Armed Services Committee last week that sanctions could achieve their goal in 12 to 18 months. ``It is dead wrong to say that Iraq is not being hurt,'' Crowe testified. ``It is being damaged severely. ... The issue is not whether an embargo will work, but whether we have the patience to let it take effect.'' Former Defense Secretary James Schlesinger said sanctions already had reduced Iraq's economic activity by 40 percent. Democrats generally endorsed those views. After Bush imposed sanctions on Aug. 2, the day Saddam's army took over Kuwait, he expressed increasing confidence that economic pressure, supported worldwide, would force Saddam back. Eight days after the invasion, Bush told reporters, ``Listen, I'd love to see the economic sanctions be so successful that the (U.S.) forces could be withdrawn. And I think they will be successful. But I just can't - my problem is, I just can't estimate the time right now, how long it will take.'' Five days later, addressing Defense Department employees during a visit to the Pentagon, Bush said, ``Sanctions are working.'' And the following day, after meeting Jordan's King Hussein at Kennebunkport, Maine, the president said sanctions were taking hold. ``I don't think one can sustain true international isolation for long, especially when you depend on the outside world for a lot of your goods,'' he said. On Aug. 28, briefing members of Congress, the president said: ``The United Nations sanctions are in effect and have been working remarkably well, even on a voluntary basis.'' And on Sept. 11, in an address to a joint session of Congress: ``Iraq is feeling the heat. We continue to hope that Iraq's leaders will recalculate just what their aggression has cost them. They are cut off from world trade, unable to sell their oil. And only a tiny fraction of goods gets through. ... I cannot predict just how long it will take to convince Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Sanctions will take time to have their full intended effect.'' Then, last Thursday, at the United States' behest, the Security Council authorized the use of force after Jan. 15 to compel Iraq's expulsion from Kuwait. Almost at once, the administration line on sanctions changed. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was first. ``There is no guarantee that sanctions will force him (Saddam) out of Kuwait,'' he testified Monday. ``He can ride them out.'' Bush, visiting Uruguay on Tuesday, elaborated on the new theme. ``I've not been one who has been convinced that sanctions alone will bring him to his senses,'' he said, while adding that the measures were ``having some effect.'' ``The best chance for peace is for him (Saddam) to understand that all means - all means - necessary ... will be used against him,'' the president said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III drove the point home Wednesday. ``Nobody can ever tell you that sanctions alone can force Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. I am personally very pessimistic that they will.'' And CIA Director William Webster said, ``Our judgment has been, and continues to be, that there is no assurance or guarantee that economic hardhips will compel Saddam to change his policies or lead to internal unrest that would threaten his regime.'' The administration's change could be intended to send Saddam the message that the United States was ruling out all possibilities except the use of force for settling the dispute. Or it could be intended to send that message to the American people, to prepare them for going to war. The change of signal is clear. Its purpose is not. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has covered events in Washington since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Supermarkets Joining Fresh Pizza Business, Other New Ventures
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for PM-Farm Scene
DOC.TEXT: OK, kids, it's pizza night. See what the supermarket has to go. Hold the anchovies. It's the coming thing, says the Agriculture Department. And one of these days the local supermarket may be delivering fresh, hot pizza directly to the front door. ``Supermarkets have been edging into the fresh pizza business for the past few years,'' says Charlene Price of the department's Economic Research Service. ``Pizza is now becoming the food of choice and is closing in on hamburgers as the most popular take-out food.'' Price, writing in the agency's National Food Review, said an estimated 43 percent of the nation's supermarkets now offer fresh pizza. As an example, she said, Bashas' Supermarkets in Arizona offer hot pizza using fresh crusts pre-baked daily at each store's bakery. Prices start at $2.99 for a 12-inch hot cheese pizza, made to order from a fully exposed work station in the deli department. Orders can be phoned in. ``For this type of service to continue to grow, supermarkets must be able to provide more customer service by offering an option of eating in as well as installing a phone solely for the pizza department,'' she said. ``They must also provide pickup or delivery service.'' Pizzas just one example of the changing services being offered by supermarkets. More than half of Safeway's stores offer prepared foods such as lasagna, pastas, barbecued chicken, salads and desserts at deli counters. Self-service salad, soup and sandwich bars, as well as yogurt and ice cream machines, are in some stores. ``Farmer Jack Supermarkets in Detroit, Mich., introduced prepared food sections, Yvonne's-To-Go, five years ago,'' Price said. ``The section offers large selection of freshly prepared entrees, imported gourmet coffee and tea, ice cream, pastries and other desserts, all prepared in-store.'' Also, she said, the store has a sit-down restaurant that serves up to 20 people. The customers have a choice of salads, soups, sauces, frozen pasta items, quiches, pates and sausages. Raley's in California has expanded its take-out food program in selected locations to offer complete specialty menus of authentic ethnic food, Price said. Some stores feature Chinese, while others go with Mexican. ``Sit-down eating areas in supermarkets have been steadily increasing,'' she said. ``More than two-thirds of the supermarkets with service delis have some sort of eating area, ranging from a few chairs and tables to elaborate sit-down restaurants.'' Most of these eating areas are quite small, however. Less than 1 percent are full-scale restaurants or cafeterias. Another trend has been the move by processors to get on the microwave bandwagon in supermarkets, Price said. The latest innovations include microwaveable fast foods such as breakfast sandwiches, hamburgers, cheeseburger and various potato products. Goodings Super Markets in Florida has set up microwaveable fast-food sections in its frozen food departments. Items include hamburgers, french fries, cheese sticks, popcorn, fish or meat sandwiches, pizza and chicken snacks - all heated and served in the store. ``Microwaveable hamburgers and cheeseburgers are competing with fast food chains for the away-from-home food dollar,'' Price said. The microwaveable sandwich business posted an estimated $130 million in sales last year, and sales are expected to grow by 20 percent annually over the next couple of years, the researcher said. ``Food service in supermarkets has come a long way, yet it represents only the beginning,'' she said. According to Schotland Business Research Inc., the value of food prepared specially for microwave heating will grow from $5 billion in 1988 to $7 billion by 1993. ``An estimated 94 percent of homes will contain microwave ovens,'' Price said. ``The number of microwaveable frozen foods will grow by 25 percent during the next four years.'' Despite the growth in supermarket food services, Price said some problems still are being worked out. ``For example, there is a shift to fewer hot foods since the first phase of ready-to-eat meals because it is difficult to maintain the quality,'' she said. ``Heat lamps and steam tables that keep foods hot also tend to dry them out and reheating causes moisture loss.'' And although microwave technology is fast and convenient, some foods do not respond well to it. Pot pies and french fries often are soggy when heated in a microwave oven. Price said designers are also producing packages that allow foods to brown better and get crisper. The new food services and microwaveable products are the hot items for the 1990s, she said. But industry officials say traditional foods won't be pushed out of the picture.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands More Reservists Called Up for Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The Army called up 13,614 more reservists for active duty in support of Operation Desert Shield, and it put an undisclosed number of others on alert. The Marine Corps said it called up 84 reservists. The call-ups were announced Wednesday, two days after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney raised to 188,000 the maximum number of reservists who can be put on active duty at one time for the Persian Gulf crisis. The previous limit had been 125,000. The additional reservists are needed to help load and transport tons of extra equipment being deployed to Saudi Arabia with about 200,000 reinforcement troops, and to perform a variety of spport roles once the materiel gets there. More than 110,000 reservists from the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps and Coast Guard have been ordered to active duty since late August. The Army said the 13,614 members of the National Guard and Reserve are being called up from 37 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and from three U.S. bases in Germany. They were ordered to report for 90 days of active duty starting Thursday. Among them are specialists in history, law enforcement, medical service, combat engineering, cargo transport and blood support. They raise to 87,204 the number of Army National Guard and Reserve members called to active duty for Desert Shield. Of the Marine Corps reservists getting the call, 14 are from a Newport News, Va., unit. They are to report Monday for salvage duty with the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force, based at Camp Pendleton, Calif. Seventy-four Marine reservists from various locations were ordered to report Dec. 15 to the Combat Service Support Detachment at Kaneohe Bay Marine Corps Air Station, Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Calls for Review of Canadian Crash Probe
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government should review Canada's findings in the crash of a military charter plane that killed 256 Americans, says a congressional panel that probed a possible terrorist link to the 1985 disaster. Canada should turn over its investigative reports on the Gander, Newfoundland, crash to the FBI while the National Transportation Safety Board analyzes the cause of the tragedy, Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J., said Wednesday. FBI agents were barred from the crash scene and the NTSB embraced Canada's findings about the cause without consulting the chief U.S. investigator who looked into the disaster, according to testimony before the House Judiciary subcommittee on crime, chaired by Hughes. A Canadian panel ruled that the plane probably went down due to ice on its wings. The FBI should have insisted on playing a role in the probe and the NTSB was derelict in its duty, Hughes said at the conclusion of two days of hearings. NTSB investigator George Seidlein was sent to Gander and concluded that the weather conditions simply weren't right for ice to have formed on the wings in sufficient amounts to cause the crash. Seidlein testified that he wasn't invited by his superiors to give his views and didn't volunteer them. FBI agents sent to Gander following the crash spent two days in a motel and left after Canadian investigators assured them there was no terrorist connection to the crash. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police handled the criminal aspects of the probe, said Nicholas O'Hara, deputy assistant director of the FBI's criminal investigative division. ``I never found your organization in 25 years to be timid,'' Hughes commented. ``I'm surprised you fold your tent after two days and go home. ... The rumors of terrorism and sabotage were rampant.'' The FBI has a high level of cooperation with the RCMP, O'Hara insisted. The families of the victims ``have a right to expect more,'' said Hughes. ``I'm disappointed with the ... FBI. ... No wonder the families are so angry.'' Hughes said the subcommittee has been pressing Canada to provide investigative reports compiled by the RCMP. The Canadian embassy says it is still working on the request. Hughes said he will urge Congress to pursue the matter and that the FBI and intelligence agencies should review the reports once the U.S. government gets them. The FBI and the State Department told the crime subcommittee there is no credible evidence the DC-8 jetliner, carrying troops of the 101st Airborne Division from the Middle East, was sabotaged or targeted with a terrorist bomb. The Canadian government findings have been challenged by other Canadian investigators, several congressmen and families of the victims who suspect terrorism as the cause. Several eyewitnesses say they saw a bright flame just before the crash. A terrorist group with ties to Iran claimed responsibility for the disaster, which occurred amid the Reagan administration's secret arms sales to Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Don't Have a Meltdown, Man, But `Simpsons' Cooling N-Plant Jokes
DOC.TEXT: There will be no more three-eyed fish on ``The Simpsons,'' whose producers say they're cooling their nuclear industry jokes after touring a real power plant. But don't have a meltdown, Simpsons fans. The prime-time cartoon show will continue to rib the industry in its third season next year, but in a more responsible way, Executive Producer Sam Simon said in an interview this week. Simon said the Fox Broadcasting Co. program had been guilty of ``cheap shots.'' The U.S. Council for Energy Awareness, a nuclear industry group, told Simon in a February letter that the show ``offended a lot of people in the energy industry.'' ``At a time when we should be concerned about where we'll get enough electricity to fuel our economy later in this decade, you are confusing and frightening your viewers by portraying nuclear power plant personnel as bungling idiots,'' the letter said. Top ``idiot'' on the council's list was Homer, father of the Simpson family and an employee of the fictitious Springfield nuclear plant. Homer seems to care less about safety than about having enough tartar sauce for his fish sticks. In various episodes, Homer gives away the plant's blueprints to a foreign exchange student, his boss tries to bribe a plant inspector with a bushel of cash and three-eyed ``Blinky'' is found swimming near the plant. ``I agree with you that in real life Homer Simpson would not be employed at a nuclear power plant. On the other hand, he probably wouldn't be employed anywhere,'' Simon said in a Feb. 5 letter to Carl Goldstein, a vice president of the energy group. Simon suggested that he and other Fox executives tour a real nuclear power plant. In April, the group converged on the San Onofre plant in San Clemente, Calif., 40 miles south of Fox's Los Angeles offices. ``We don't have any Homers at our nuclear plant,'' said David Barron, a spokesman for San Onofre's owner, Southern California Edison, who accompanied the producers and writers. Simon said the tour showed that ``The Simpsons'' had been right - and wrong - about nuclear power. Although they did little initial research, he said the ``Simpsons'' creators seemed to accurately represent worker conditions - the cafeterias, lunch pails and radiation warning signs. The writers placed Homer in a ``sector'' to illustrate an impersonal bureaucracy, then discovered some plants actually used that term. But Simon also said the tour also ``changed a lot of people's minds. I think the facts are pretty powerful that it's a clean and safe and important source of energy. While some of the shows were in the works before, we really backed off that as a source of comedy. No more three-eyed fish.'' But the show will still feature jokes about what evil Springfield nuclear plant owner Montgomery Burns terms his ``nuclear, nuclear family.'' For example, plans call for Homer to avert a nuclear meltdown. ``He's kind of asleep at the wheel and wakes up when there's an alarm, and doesn't know which button to press, so he goes eeney-meeney-miney-mo and hits a button and does avert a meltdown,'' Simon said. ``He becomes a hero and feels guilty about it.
