It's not a politically charged episode.'' And Homer is to begin a dinner grace with this: ``Thank you for nuclear power, which has yet to cause a single fatality ... at least in this country.'' The U.S. nuclear power industry has been sensitive about its image since the Three Mile Isand accident in 1979 that led to a $1 billion cleanup. And in 1987, Pennsylvania's Peach Bottom plant was shut down for a time and 33 workers fined on charges of ``sleeping and-or inattention to duty.'' Asked if she watched ``The Simpsons,'' Three Mile Island spokeswoman Mary Wells jokingly told a reporter, ``Goodbye!'' But she relented, and confessed she finds the show funny. Simon said the producers had a practical reason for placing Homer at a power plant. ``It was really just for the joke that this boob had a position where he could possibly make a mistake and destroy the world,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: California Looking For Businesses That Want Felons
LaserPhoto SC1
DOC.TEXT: California is looking for businesses willing to hire criminals, and only criminals, by the thousands. The new gang of factory workers won't have to commute. In fact, they'll be in big trouble if they try. And they won't be organizing unions, guzzling beer after work or chasing co-workers of the opposite sex. The jobs will be blue collar, literally -prison blue. Pressed by a rising prison population and tight budget, California voters decided to encourage businesses to set up shop inside prisons and put inmates to work so they can contribute to their upkeep and gain valuable job skills. If successful, it would be the largest such program in the nation. Pay will be similar to what prisoners might make on the outside, but some of their earnings will be deducted to help defray the $2 billion annual cost of feeding and housing California's 98,000 state prisoners. ``Why should law-abiding citizens have to work and pay taxes to support a free ride for convicted criminals?'' said Gov. George Deukmejian, who sponsored the ballot measure approved Nov. 6. The state prison population has more than quadrupled during Deukmejian's two terms in office. About 8,000 adults in state prison now make only minimal wages producing goods such as furniture and license plates. The products can be sold only to government agencies in order to limit competition with private industry. A separate program employs about 100 juveniles in private businesses at California youth prisons. Organizers of the new program for adult inmates hope to create 7,000 jobs with operations like recycling or clothing manufacture. Nationwide, about 1,500 prisoners work for private businesses, according to the U.S. Justice Department. Craig Brown, undersecretary of the state Youth and Adult Correctional Agency, said inmates will scramble for the new ``real world jobs'' to make money and gain skills. ``Working in the prison kitchen probably doesn't provide you too much you can use on the outside,'' he said. The California Manufacturers Association supports the program but wants to ensure it does not create unfair competition with the private sector, said president Bill Campbell. ``It's an exciting, innovative program and the manufacturing community will look upon it very favorably,'' he said. Unions oppose the measure, arguing it will ``turn back the clock of history to chain gang memories with controlled labor being exploited to the detriment of free labor,'' said John Henning of the California Labor Federation. State officials said they will try to limit any competition by targeting emerging and labor-intensive industries. In a further safeguard, companies are barred from using prison labor to replace striking workers. Brown said a task force setting up the program hopes to bring the first businesses into the men's and women's prisons sometime next year. State analysts said they don't know how much the program will save because there are too many variables, but savings will come from diverting workers' pay to cover room and board, and from early releases earned with work credits. Officials also hope the job skills learned will reduce the number of inmates who return to prison. But the state also will lose some money by giving employers tax credits. Task force member Kathy Kinser of the state Corrections Department said the program requires that inmates get paid at levels comparable to those on the outside. Proposed regulations call for 20 percent of inmates' net wages to go to room and board; up to 20 percent for restitution to crime victims, and up to 15 percent to mandatory savings. Paychecks would be subject to the usual tax withholdings and other deductions, including family support. The program for putting imprisoned juveniles to work in private enterprise has employed 1,000 youths in five years. The 100 people in the program handle overflow calls for Trans World Airlines flight reservations, assemble electronics for exercise machines, microfilm documents and form sheet metal for ducts.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Shows Economy Slowing in All U.S. Regions
DOC.TEXT: A Federal Reserve survey of the nation's economic pulse finds business conditions either declining or growing weakly in every region of the country as November came to an end. The ``beige book'' survey released Wednesday showed retail sales down in virtually all 12 of the central bank's districts. Manufacturing conditions weakened in most districts, and most districts also reported continued sluggishness in construction. Demand for business loans softened in many areas at the same time banks were tightening their standards for making loans. On balance, business conditions ``display a weaker pattern'' than a similar survey conducted in mid-October that found either slow growth or an actual decline in economic activity in the Fed districts. In one of the few bright spots, ``Agriculture is reported to have been doing very well,'' a summary of the survey said. ``Crop yields have been good and livestock prices have been high.'' The report was the latest piece of evidence that the economy has weakened in recent months to the point that many economists say it now is in a recession. Manufacturers, in particular, expressed concern about business prospects for the coming months, the survey found. ``The majority of manufacturers contacted in the Boston district expect a national recession lasting two to four quarters,'' the report said. ``Business leaders contacted in the San Francisco district expect continued deterioration in the national economy.'' Automobile sales were reported to have weakened, particularly in the Cleveland, Chicago and St. Louis districts. Dallas was an exception. The pessimism, however, was not universal. Philadelphia manufacturers expect modest improvements over the next six months and ``manufacturers in the Richmond district were less pessimistic about prospects than they had been a month ago,'' the report said. And soft domestic demand was partially offset by strong export orders. Despite the weakness, inventories were described as ``under control.'' An excessive increase in inventories could mean job layoffs as industries cut production in an attempt to reduce backlogs. Nevertheless, ``several districts report a decline in consumer and business confidence and many refer to expectations of continued diminution in economic activity,'' the survey found. ``Retail sales apparently have weakened in almost all the districts,'' the report said. ``Most districts report that retailers were pessimistic about sales prospects for the Christmas season as well as for 1991.'' Most districts also reported continued sluggishness in construction activity. ``Residential construction continued to be weak, with several districts citing a glut of houses for resale,'' the report said. ``Non-residential construction is also reported to be generally weak.'' ``However, there are bright spots,'' it continued. ``New York reports a recent pickup in office leasing activity in downtown Manhattan. Chicago reports that construction slowdowns are not universal and that development continues in communities outside major metropolitan areas ... Minneapolis reports a recent rebound in construction activity.'' But the report said activity in the financial sector generally was slower. ``Several districts report a decline in consumer and business loan demand,'' it said. ``Almost all districts also report some tightening by banks of business loan terms, particularly for construction and land development.'' None of the districts reported any major problems with inflation, although reports of price increases varied. In fact, the strong agricultural production contributed to lower crop prices, although this adversely affected farmer incomes in some areas. The report was written at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis based on information collected before Nov. 26. The report was prepared for the Dec. 17 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed arm responsible for setting monetary policy.

DOC.HEAD: Ershad Dissolves Parliament, Could Be Replaced Thursday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with explanation for Parliament's dissolution, details. Picks up 9th pvs, `Ershad, who ...
DOC.TEXT: EDITS thereafter to trim, conform.

President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, who has promised to resign after widespread protests against his government, dissolved Parliament on Thursday after lifting a state of emergency. State-run radio announced the dissolution of Parliament but gave no reason. Parliament had been expected to remain in session until Saturday to ratify Ershad's successor, who would govern in a caretaker capacity until new elections. Constitutional experts and well-placed opposition sources said Ershad would swear in his own successor. They said this method of transition of power was chosen because it appeared Parliament would not be able to summon a majority to endorse the caretaker leader, Supreme Court Chief Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed. The sources, speaking on condition of anomnymity, said the swearing-in might take place later Thursday. Two-thirds of Parliament's members belong to Ershad's Jatiya Party. Many have been reluctant to appear in public for fear of being attacked by anti-Ershad activists. Some Jatiya Party offices and officials' residences around the country have been stoned or ransacked in the past week. The dissolved Parliament was seated in 1986 elections, called fraudulent by observers, that Ershad also won. Ershad lifted the state of emergency late Wednesday, eight days after he imposed it because of increasingly violent demonstrations for his removal. But the street protests continued, despite the deployment of army troops and a curfew that was supposed to keep people indoors. On Tuesday night, Ershad bowed to the groundswell of opposition and said he would step down as soon as a temporary successor was chosen. Opposition leaders Sheik Hasina and Khaleda Zia, agreed Wednesday night on Shahabuddin, a career lawyer and judge with a reputation as a political independent. The two women led the seven-week campaign to oust Ershad, a former army general who took power in a bloodless 1982 coup. Ershad's announcement that he would resign ended an often-violent campaign for his ouster. The opposition claims at least 100 people were killed by security forces since the emergency. The government says only six people died. Ershad, who only a few weeks ago had confidently predicted he would be re-elected in the spring, caved in to the opposition's demands with an abruptness that stunned the country. Anti-Ershad demonstrations had become routine in recent years, but the latest round were marked by unprecedented unity and spontaneity. As the protests snowballed, eight years of rumors and discontent over what was perceived as Ershad's arrogance and tolerance of corruption burst out of private drawing rooms into the streets. The president's downfall was hastened by a wave of resignations in support of the opposition. Hundreds of doctors, professors, civil servants, merchant seamen and at least 19 Parliament members of his Jatiya Party resigned from their jobs in protest against Ershad. On Wednesday, a student leader was killed and two other people were injured by security guards when they attempted to storm the home of a high-ranking government official in a northern town. Several thousand people assembled at Dhaka airport demanding that airport authorities stop Ershad or other government officials if they tried to flee the country. But there was no indication that any government official was planning to leave. Ershad spent Wednesday in his home and in an office deep in the well-guarded military cantonment in Dhaka and canceled all appointments. A senior member of his Cabinet, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Ershad was still in charge of the government. Other sources said the military was still taking orders from Ershad. Mrs. Zia and Hasina appealed to their followers for calm. They said the effort to end Ershad's rule was not yet over, and they warned the president of ``the people's wrath'' if he reneged on his promise to resign. Addressing 50,000 cheering and chanting followers at a rally, Hasina said: ``Although Ershad announced that he had resigned, in fact he is still in power.'' Mrs. Zia echoed those concerns at another gathering, accusing Ershad of ``conspiring to stay in power.'' ``Let there be no doubt that people will fight until they have achieved the victory and ousted the autocratic government,'' she said. On Wednesday, state-run media let Hasina and Mrs. Zia address the people for the first time. The two women have been agitating for Ershad's ouster since he took power, but their political differences thwarted any lasting campaign. Then, in October, the opposition was galvanized by Ershad's announcement that he would be a candidate in June presidential elections. Mrs. Zia and Hasina have said they have buried their differences, but they still have not spelled out their stands on constitutional changes or on other domestic or foreign issues. Hasina is the daughter of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Bangladesh's first president. Mrs. Zia is the widow of another former president, Ziaur Rehman. Both men were assassinated. Ershad is the country's ninth president since it gained independence from Pakistan in 1971. Like all of his predecessors, he was installed by military action.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Dump Two Veteran Committee Chairmen
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats are tossing out two veteran committee chairmen in a move that reflects restlessness over an embarrassing year on Capitol Hill and a trying election season for incumbents. Wednesday's votes that ousted Rep. Glenn Anderson of California as chairman of the Public Works and Transportation Committee and Rep. Frank Annunio of Illinois from the Committee on House Administration were seen as a warning to the chamber's leaders to improve performance and efficiency. ``Neither of them saw it coming. It was a tidal wave,'' said Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio. ``The House is in a position where some shaking up is a necessary thing to do,'' said Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan. ``It's not a mutiny. But the status quo cannot prevail. There's a healthy questioning going on right now and a few chairmen are getting the boot because of it.'' In addition to the ousters of Anderson and Annunzio, several committee chairmen racked up worrisome levels of opposition in secret-ballot votes of confidence behind the closed doors of the caucus. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, chairman of the Banking Committee, kept his position on a vote of 163-89. Rep. Morris Udall of Arizona, the Interior Committee chairman, drew 47 opposition votes; North Carolina Rep. Walter Jones of the Merchant Marine Committee was opposed by 46 members; and three chairmen drew 34 ``no'' votes each: Energy and Commerce Chairman John Dingell of Michigan; Veterans Affairs Chairman Sonny Montgomery of Mississippi; and Appropriations Chairman Jamie Whitten of Mississippi. Several lawmakers described the shakeups as aftershocks from last month's elections, and others said they were an effort to weed out figures who do not convey the vigorous, clean image the party wants. ``Throughout 1990 the House was given a black eye because of the protracted budget mess,'' said Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D. ``Americans were asking, Why can't you get your work done? This is an expression of that discontent. It's laying down the law that we're not going to sit by and let it happen next year.'' Democrats sent their signal not directly to the leadership, which was all re-elected, but by knocking off what were deemed the weakest of their committee chairmen. The 77-year-old Anderson, who was the subject of complaints of ineffectiveness and passivity, was replaced by the second-ranking Democrat on Public Works and Transportation, Rep. Robert Roe of New Jersey. ``What the committee was looking for was stronger policy positions and better coordination,'' Roe said after he edged the No. 3 committee Democrat, Norman Mineta of California, 121-107, for the chairmanship. ``This is the basic committee that provides the infrastructure for the nation - roads, bridges, highways, airports. It really determines the direction, what the priorities will be in rebuilding America,'' Roe said. Annunzio, 75, who was linked to the savings-and-loan scandal during a difficult re-election campaign in his Chicago, also was described by colleagues as ineffective and too willing to let an abrasive aide run the committee for him. He was replaced by Rep. Charles Rose of North Carolina, the Administration Committee's No. 3 member. Rose prevailed over second-ranking Joseph Gaydos of Pennsylvania on a 158-64 vote. The caucus also gave the Committee on Science, Space and Technology, which had been chaired by Roe, to Rep. George Brown of California, next in the line of seniority on the panel. In other changes, Rep. William D. Ford, D-Mich., gave up his chairmanship of the Post Office and Civil Service Committee to replace the retiring Augustus F. Hawkins of California as chairman of the Education and Labor Committee. Rep. William Clay, D-Mo., moves up to Ford's old job.

DOC.BYLINE: With US-Gulf, Bjt ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: ``When naked aggression takes place, it's not a question of finding face for the aggressor.'' - President Bush saying the United States will make no effort to give Saddam Hussein a face-saving way out of the Gulf crisis. --- ``I will not be negotiating the Palestinian question or the civil war in Lebanon.'' - Secretary of State James A. Baker III telling the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that he'll only take up with Saddam Hussein subjects related to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait. --- ``There is little evidence of ... impatience or of a popular clamoring for war.'' - Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, warning the Bush administration against any rush to military action.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Denounces Recall Request as `Irresponsible'
DOC.TEXT:
Chrysler Corp. is rejecting a consumer advocacy organization's request to recall 500,000 cars and minivans with a newly designed automatic transmission, insisting its flaws have been worked out. ``We addressed those problems quickly and believe the transmission is now fully competitive from reliability and durability standpoints and ahead of the competition in many other areas,'' Chrysler spokesman Tony Cervone said. But the Center for Auto Safety says the Ultradrive transmission, introduced in 1989 models, is still plagued by sticking between gears, clutch burnout, computer controller failure and internal damage. The nation's third-largest automaker introduced the Ultradrive four-speed transmission in late 1988.
---
DOC.HEAD: Towns To Lead Black Caucus in 101st Congress
DOC.TEXT:
Rep. Edolphus ``Ed'' Towns, a liberal Democrat from Brooklyn, N.Y., was elected chairman Wednesday of the Congressional Black Caucus for the 102nd Congress. He will succeed Rep. Ronald V. Dellums, D-Calif. Towns, elected to a fifth term last month, said the caucus will meet early in the new Congress to discuss its goals. ``The civil rights bill will be something we will push very hard very early in the Congress,'' he said in an interview. The bill was defeated this year when the Senate failed, by one vote, to override President Bush's veto. Towns noted that the caucus will have 26 members next year, the most since it was founded in 1970. In addition, it will have its first Republican U.S. representative ever: freshman Gary Franks, R-Conn. Towns, 56, was elected to Congress in 1982 from a diverse district that includes the impoverished Bedford-Stuyvesant section as well as the wealthier Brooklyn Heights neighborhood.
---
DOC.HEAD: NASA Plans 27 Shuttle Flights in the Next Three Years
DOC.TEXT: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which managed to launch only six space shuttles this year, is planning 27 flights in the next three years. The schedule announced Wednesday includes seven shuttle launches in 1991, eight in 1992 and 12 in 1993. The shuttle Endeavour, a replacement for the destroyed Challenger, will join the fleet in 1992 and its first mission will be to reboost a stranded satellite. In the three-year period, NASA also plans to launch 13 rockets. Their payloads include three major scientific probes - the Extreme Ultraviolet Explorer and Geotail on Delta 2 rockets, and the Mars Observer on the larger Titan III. For the first time, there are no secret Defense Department launches on the schedule. But unclassified military cargoes are slated for three flights, including the first one next year.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar regained strength against the yen Thursday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange advanced moderately. The yen closed at 134.05 yen, up 0.63 yen from Wednesday's close of 133.42 yen. After opening at 133.90 yen, the currency ranged between 133.70 yen and 134.17 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 359.38 points, or 1.62 percent, closing at 22,553.10. The index had gained 331.11 points on Wednesday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slipped to 86.70, down from Wednesday's close of 87.22. Their yield edged up to 7.340 percent from 7.225 percent. Currency traders said traders first bought the dollar following its advance Wednesday in New York, boosted by Secretary of State James A. Baker III's remark demanding that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. ``There was a little movement on the exchange market following a round of dollar-selling on profit-taking,'' said a dealer with Sanwa Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the Bush administration would strike ``suddenly, massively and decsively'' if military force is used to try to drive Iraq from Kuwait. The dollar has gained recently after reports of possible hostilities in the Middle East. The U.S. currency is seen as a safe haven in times of international tension. The possibility of war in the Persian Gulf tends to weaken the yen because Japan imports virtually all of its oil, with about 70 percent of the imports coming from the Middle East. On the stock exchange, the Nikkei index continued to rise in a favorable reaction to signs of improvement in the Middle East following a State Department announcement that Iraq had agreed to hold talks with President Bush, securities dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leaders Have One Aim, But Many Differences
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The two women who forced a change of government this week have one thing in common: They were thrust into politics by assassinations that deprived them of the men who had the most influence on their lives. Both men were presidents of Bangladesh. Apart from that, Sheik Hasina and Khaleda Zia share little except a dogged determination to oust President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, the ninth president in 19 years and like all his predecessors, installed by military might. Their personal and political rivalry had long been a stumbling block in their shared goal of ousting Ershad. Mrs. Zia, asked once why she couldn't patch up her differences with Hasina, said frostily: ``Two days ago, I invited her to tea. She didn't come.'' Hasina and Mrs. Zia had usually boycotted national elections for the presidency and Parliament. But finally, they were forced to face the fast-approaching reality: Ershad planned to seek election in June for another 5-year term - and might win unless they mounted a joint campaign. Both women had long vowed not to run against him, charging that he would would rig the elections to ensure his own victory. Changing their minds would have meant backing down on what they had called a matter of principle. Neither was ready to run unless the other did. And even if they both ran, Ershad might have emerged the victor in a three-way contest. Since the one thing they could agree on was getting rid of Ershad, they concentrated on that as they never had before. Their street rallies and nationwide strikes took on a life of their own, drawing in people who previously had been content to sit at home and gripe about Ershad without taking public action. After seven weeks of strikes and demonstrations, Ershad said Tuesday that he would resign as soon as his replacement was chosen. The question of who will eventually emerge as Bangladesh's top leader - Hasina or Mrs. Zia or a political compromise or dark-horse candidate - is unanswered. So is the matter of what political course Hasina and Mrs. Zia will pursue while they hold the momentum. Hasina, 43, presides over the Awami League and seven allied parties which are slightly left-of-center. Mrs. Zia, 46, is the leader of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party which is grouped with six other centrist parties. Hasina inherited the Awami League leadership after her father, Bangladesh's first president, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, was assassinated in a military coup in 1975. Hasina was in Germany at the time. Except for a sister who also was abroad, Hasina's entire family was wiped out in the coup. Her father, mother, three brothers, two sisters-in-law, two uncles and a cousin were all slain by the army officers who stormed into the family home. Hasina's office is her father's library, just across the hall from the stairs where his bloodstains have been preserved and fresh flowers are placed daily. Mrs. Zia's husband, President Ziaur Rahman, was an army general who took power in a 1977 coup and was assassinated four years later. Despite their common personal tragedies, Hasina never warmed to Mrs. Zia, a charismatic woman who strikes the sort of empathy with crowds that Hasina has never achieved. Hasina harbors suspicions that Gen. Zia might have had a role in the coup that killed her father, according to her closest associates. Besides that, the two women have fundamental political differences. Hasina prefers a parliamentary system of government where power goes to the party that wins the most seats and whose leader automatically becomes prime minister. Mrs. Zia favors the presidential system, wheretthe voters elect an individual leader. Hasina's main strength is that her Awami League is believed to have a larger and better-organized grass roots following than Mrs. Zia's Bangladesh Nationalist Party. But Mrs. Zia inspires the crowds by her mere presence. She exudes warmth and glamor, with discreet make-up and jewels and silken saris. Hasina, with her wire-rimmed spectacles and practical cotton saris, appears like a lecturer facing a classroom of dutiful students. The dry wit she displays in small gatherings seldom comes across in public. Both were brought into politics by supporters of their assassinated menfolk. After her father was killed, Hasina spent six years in self-exile in India where her husband, nuclear scientist Wazed Ali Miah, was studying. She was elected head of the Awami League before she ever returned to Bangladesh, although she says she had been tutored in politics since childhood. Mrs. Zia was pressured to enter politics by her late husband's followers, who were looking for someone to unite his party. But both women evolved into dominant leaders in their own right. ``She gets her own way when the question of party decision comes,'' said a senior leader of Mrs. Zia's party, speaking on condition of anonymity. Hasina has a similar reputation within her party, where she is periodically at odds with the older leaders. She surrounds herself with young people who support her in the internal party fights against the senior leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Beats Kasparov in Game 17
DOC.TEXT: Reigning champion Garry Kasparov and challenger Anatoly Karpov resume their duel for the world chess title this weekend, Karpov having won game 17 and again brought the score to a tie. ``I feel very confident now,'' Karpov said Wednesday after winning on the 40th move. ``It was quite clear that he was not in good shape.'' The two Soviet grandmasters are now tied 8.5 points each with the next game scheduled for Saturday. A win counts for a point, a tie for a half-point. Kasparov had gone ahead Tuesday when he won the marathon 16th game after 102 moves played over four days. But Karpov, with the white pieces on Wednesday, evened the match. The first player to gain 12.5 points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. In the event of a tie, Kasparov retains the title. The first 12 games were played in New York. After forcing Kasparov's resignation Wednesday, Karpov said, ``It was a very complicated game, but I felt I always had the advantage.'' The game began with a familiar scenario. As the two previous games in Lyon with Karpov playing white, the opening was a Grunfeld with an exchange variation as Kasparov castled on the eighth move. But Karpov moved his knight into deeper territory on the 10th move. That caused Kasparov almost 30 minutes of reflection before countering with a pawn exchange, then bringing a knight forward. Each player is allowed 2{ hours for his first 40 moves. Karpov wasted his time advantage on the 25th move when he had to decide how to capture a black knight. He finally did so with a bishop. At that point, both players had less than 30 minutes for 15 moves. The game turned in Karpov's favor when he advanced a queen and established a rook deep in black territory. Kasparov tried to get out of trouble, but Karpov kept advancing. Karpov even moved a pawn to the seventh rank, blocking the black queen and attacking a rook. Kasparov gave up two moves later.

DOC.HEAD: Inmates' Collect Calls Finance Prison Programs
DOC.TEXT: Accept a collect call from a New York state inmate and you'll be helping battle AIDS, give prisoners cable TV and make conjugal visits more comfortable. Like many state prison systems, New York's keeps a share of telephone company profits from inmate calls - which are all collect because there are no pay phones behind bars. ``We've provided them with a captive audience,'' Amy Colodny, spokeswoman for the New York prison system, said of the rationale for collecting a portion of phone company profits. In New York, the state gets 16 percent of the phone company's profits on long distance calls made by inmates. For local calls, which are also collect, the state receives between 6 percent and 12 percent of the profits. This year, the state's share will be about $8.5 million, officials said. Thirty-four state prisons systems and the federal prison system contract with phone companies for long-distance service. Of those, 32 states receive a portion of the profits, ranging from 5 percent in West Virginia to 50 percent in Arizona, according a survey by the publication Corrections Compendium. Several states put the money toward inmate programs. In Alabama, prison officials said part of the money goes toward legal materials. In Indiana and New Hampshire, the money pays for inmate recreation, and in Michigan it pays for vocational education. Pennsylvania receives about $100,000 per month through the program and spends the money on inmate activities. Inmates in most New York state prisons can use the phones between 8 a.m. and 11 p.m., whenever they're not participating in a prison program. The largest portion of the money, $2.8 million, is spent on the AIDS drug AZT, and $1.5 million is spent on AIDS training for staff and inmates. Prison officials estimate that up to 8,000 of New York's 52,000 inmates are infected with the AIDS virus and about 800 have AIDS. Another $1.5 million is spent on such things as job services, reception centers for visitors and furniture for ``family reunion'' trailers, where conjugal visits take place. Approximately $76,000 is spent on cable television. About half of the state's prisons have cable. An additional $650,000 provides bus trips to prisons for inmates' relatives, and nearly $500,000 is for a program to help inmates be better mothers and fathers when they get out.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists to Rig Deep-Sea Volcano with Cameras and Sensors
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A volcano at the bottom of the Pacific that is destined to be the next Hawaiian island is going high-tech with a $4 million network of cameras and seismic sensors to document its deep-sea rumblings. ``We would love to catch an eruption,'' Fred K. Duennebier, a professor of geology and geophysics at the University of Hawaii, said Wednesday of the Hawaiian Undersea Geo-Observatory. The observatory will be installed on Loihi seamount, an underwater volcano 22 miles southeast of the island of Hawaii. Loihi rises about 11,200 feet above the ocean floor, but its cratered summit is still 3,300 feet beneath the waves. ``It will be the next Hawaiian island in about 50,000 years or so,'' Duennebier said at a meeting the American Geophysical Union. ``I wouldn't buy real estate yet.'' The observatory, which scientists hope to have in operation within two years, will be a network of 20 or more cameras and instruments draped across Loihi's summit and slopes. HUGO will be connected to the Big Island by a power cable that will also carry data from the observatory to scientists on shore. A ship will lay a network of electro-optical cable and outlet boxes, then remote-controlled submarines and manned submersible vehicles will plug in cameras, microphones, seismometers and heat and chemical sensors. It will work for at least 10 years unless it is buried by lava flows or landslides, Duennebier said. Scientists are sure Loihi is active but haven't actually observed an eruption. Intense earthquake activity suggests eruptions happened in 1986, 1988 and early this year, Duennebier said. The Hawaiian Islands were created by a ``hot spot,'' a plume of molten rock that rises from deep inside the Earth. Loihi is now over the hot spot, which also has branches feeding Hawaii's active Kilauea and Mauna Loa volcanos. Roughly 60 percent to 80 percent of the world's volcanos are on the sea floor. ``We have no idea how these volcanos are built up from the ocean floor,'' Duennebier said. ``We don't know how the lava actually makes it to the top of the volcano.''

DOC.HEAD: CNN Gives Up Fight to Keep Noriega Tape Transcripts Private
DOC.TEXT: CNN said it is giving up the fight to prevent the release of court transcripts of its Manuel Noriega prison tapes. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler, ruling in favor of four news organizations that demanded access to the transcripts, said Tuesday they would be released today unless CNN appealed. On Wednesday, CNN said it would not do so. ``CNN's main concern in opposing unsealing of the transcripts has been to protect the integrity of agreements with sources,'' CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said. But after reviewing the transcripts, network officials decided there was little danger of compromising those sources, he said. CNN has televised some of seven tape recordings of Noriega's jailhouse conversations with his legal team and had argued that the recordings of the telephone calls, and therefore the transcripts of them, were its property. Sanford Bohrer, the attorney for the news organizations that asked for the transcripts, applauded CNN's decision to drop the fight. ``I could never understand how CNN could claim to own conversations that were taped by the United States government, of an inmate in a federal prison,'' he said. Noriega is awaiting trial on charges he took $4.6 million in payoffs to allow safe shipment of cocaine through Panama to the United States. The organizations seeking the transcripts were The Miami Herald, the Associated Press, Post-Newsweek station WPLG-TV of Miami and Gannett Co. and its USA Today. They argued that the public has a right to examine the content of the tapes, which were at the center of a freedom-of-the-press dispute. The controversy began last month when CNN aired a series of telecasts based on the recordings, which it said were provided by an anonymous source. Hoeveler ordered the telecasts stopped while he determined whether the action threatened Noriega's right to a fair trial. CNN opposed the move as an unconstitutional prior restraint on the press, but the Supreme Court refused to intervene. Hoeveler eventually ruled that the tapes didn't jeopardize the case and could be aired. CNN hasn't said where it got the tapes, but Noriega's attorneys have claimed they were released to the government of Panama by the State Department or the Drug Enforcement Administration, and that Panama gave them to CNN.

DOC.HEAD: Attack on Supporters Of Priest Dims Hope of Elections
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - After gunmen attacked one of his rallies, the populist priest who is leading the race for president tearfully urged supporters not to fear casting ballots in the Dec. 16 election. The Rev. Jean Bertrand Aristide blamed the Wednesday night attack, in which five people were reported killed and 54 wounded, on the Tonton Macoutes, the private militia that enforced the brutal 29-year Duvaler family rule. The violence occurred just as a rally by about 10,000 people near Port-au-Prince was breaking up and appeared intended to intimidate Aristide supporters into staying away from the polls. It came as Haitians were feeling optimistic they could at last have democratic elections, the first in the 186-year-old history of this former French colony. ``Take heart, dry your tears, hold one another's hands,'' Aristide said in a tearful interview with Radio Antilles. ``We are going to continue walking together because on the 16th of December, whether they like it or not, the Macoutes will disappear from Haiti.'' A November 1987 attempt at elections was aborted after thugs backed by the army killed 34 voters at the polls. The government promised a probe, but similar undertakings have failed to bring arrests or charges in earlier violence. ``All necessary steps have been taken, and an investigation has been opened,'' said Minister of Interior Joseph Maxi. The violence broke out in the wealthy suburb of Petionville, about 7 miles from the capital, a half hour after Aristide had left. The 37-year-old priest, the target of three assassination attempts in the past, has been hailed as a ``prophet'' by many. He has a huge following among the country's poor, the majority in this Caribbean nation of 6 million people where violence and intimidation have traditionally pervaded politics. As Aristide supporters were dispersing, the area was hit with a 10-minute blackout that was followed by a loud explosion and then gunfire. Witnesses said they saw men in a jeep drive up moments before the blackout. ``It happened during the blackout. There was a big boom. We ran, and while we were running there was shooting. The lights went on after,'' said one witness, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Hundreds of people ran screaming down the streets after the explosion rocked the suburb. Scores of people fell to the ground. It was unknown what caused the blast. Witnesses and Radio Metropole said five people died and 54 were wounded. Aristide said the incident could have been prevented if authorities had arrested Roger Lafontant, the Tonton Macoutes chief who returned from exile to run for president but was disqualified the race. The Tonton Macoutes were formed under the late dictator ``Papa Doc'' Francois Duvalier in 1957. The family's rule ended in 1986 when his son, ``Baby Doc,'' Jean Claude Duvalier was forced into exile in France. The country has been rocked by violence since Duvalier's fall and the interim government of President Ertha Pascal Trouillot, appointed in March, is the fifth since his fall. Reinhardt Helmke, a United Nations representative, said he didn't think elections would be canceled as a result of the Wednesday attack. ``At this stage, the electoral process is not compromised,'' he said. ``This is the type of thing that everybody was expecting would happen at some point.'' More than 400 international observers from the United Nations and the Organization of American States are to monitor the elections. About 200 of them are already in Haiti.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Doctors Who Profit on X-Rays Use Them More
DOC.TEXT: The suspicion that profits influence the way doctors treat patients got some support today from a study showing that those who make money on X-rays take four times as many of them, researchers say. The study, based on a review of insurance records, compared doctors who owned their own office X-ray and ultrasound machines with those who send their patients to other specialists for X-rays. Doctors make a profit on each image they take on their own equipment but make nothing when they send patients to other experts. The study, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, found that those who owned their own machines took four times as many X-rays and ultrasound scans for such routine conditions as colds and backaches. It also found that doctors who owned their own equipment charged considerably more for them than did outside radiologists. Although the study could not determine precisely why these doctors did more X-rays, ``one has to wonder whether it's an issue of having these machines and realizing that incomes can be increased by their utilization,'' said Dr. Bruce J. Hillman, who directed the study at the University of Arizona. Ethical standards require that doctors put patients' health ahead of their own financial interests. E. Haavi Morreim, a philosopher at the University of Tennessee College of Medicine, said there may be other explanations for the higher X-ray use ``aside from the obvious possibility that frankly there is money to be made in them there hills.'' ``There is the simple fact that when something is available, it's easy to use it often,'' she said. ``When you have a hammer, everything looks like a nail.'' Physicians who own X-ray machines were critical of the study and its implications. Dr. James Weber, a family practitioner in Jacksonville, Ark., said doctors who do more X-rays may be practicing better medicine. ``The assumption is inferred that these tests are ordered to benefit the physician rather than the patient,'' he said. ``I can tell you that wherever you go in the country, that may be true of less than 1 percent of practicing physicians. The vast majority of physicians have their patients' interests at heart.'' Dr. J. Harold Morris, an internist in Kansas City, said doctors who buy this equipment may take more X-rays because they fear malpractice or simply because they are, by training, more inclined to seek test results. The study was based on computerized records of 65,517 doctor visits by privately insured patients who worked for several companies, mostly in the Midwest. The researchers compared the number of X-rays and ultrasound scans used by doctors who treated patients for stuffy noses, pregnancy, low back pain and, for men, difficulty urinating. Medstate Systems, the company that provided the computerized records, estimates that working Americans spend $290 million a year on X-ray and ultrasound scans for these four conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Disturbing News About Candidate Obscured by the Fury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT typo and rephrase, SUB 6th graf, `As a ... highest office.' Picks up 7th, `Lost in ...' ^An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Stanislaw Tyminski, an unknown emigre businessman who has not lived in Poland for the past 21 years, became a serious contender for the nation's presidency with hardly a question raised. When journalists finally started to take a hard look at Tyminski's past, he called them ``wolves'' and benefited from a wave of voter sympathy. What started as a cautious first foray into fair election coverage has ended in a virtual free-for-all as the final round of elections between Tyminski and Solidarity leader Lech Walesa draws to a close Sunday. Almost daily, newspapers and television unleash a torrent of disturbing news about Tyminski. But truth has been mixed with rumor and supposition. Some reporters, frustrated by Tyminski's evasive answers, have become so partisan that they boo and hiss him at news conferences. In a country in which Communist authorities manipulated the news media for decades, people became accustomed to believing that the opposite of what they were reading must be true. As a result, some have ignored the alarms being raised in the independent but factional press about the vague man with the mysterious past who could assume the nation's highest office. Lost in the fury were late-to-surface facts: that Tyminski has advocated arming Poland with nuclear weapons, that he is connected with long-time Communist operatives, that he claims a life-changing spiritual experience in the Peruvian jungle, that he is not the well-known magnate he claims to be. ``We have somebody coming from nowhere, and no reporter checks who he is,'' says Andrzej Szczypiorski, a senator and internationally acclaimed writer. ``Now all the fire is aimed at this puppet, because the country is in danger.'' The Communists once tried a similar all-out character assault against Walesa, Szczypiorski recalled. ``You know what effect that had: Walesa's stature only grew.'' Until the week before the Nov. 25 first round of voting, the Polish press was preoccupied with the bitter contest between Walesa and his former adviser, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. Back then, the self-proclaimed millionaire from abroad was an oddity, covered dutifully but uncritically along with other lesser-known candidates. That changed when Tyminski, who promises speedy prosperity, charged Mazowiecki with economic treason and showed up a shocking No. 2 in an opinion poll. He finished second in the election, eliminating the prime minister who was cautiously overseeing painful free-market reforms. Suddenly, Poland's press was engaged in a frantic effort to discredit Tyminski. In raucous news conferences, journalists mixed hard-hitting questions with ineffectual polemics, derisive laughter and outright condemnation. Tyminski has largely stood his ground with eerie calm and clipped replies, often refusing to answer straightforward questions. ``This is the first campaign of this sort in Poland, so our journalists do not have enough experience,'' said Maciej Ilowiecki, chairman of the Association of Polish Journalists. After a ``sluggish'' start, he said, reporters ``tried to make up for this professional neglect. I think they tipped the scale to the other side ... and forgot about valid, ethical rules.'' For example, on Tuesday night, state television broadcast an interview with a couple who said they were friends of Tyminski's wife, Graciela, in Canada. The pair said Tyminski had abused her and refused food and medicine to his children, that a child-protection agency once investigated him. But the television network never gave Tyminski a chance to respond to the allegations. On Wednesday morning, Tyminski's campaign dismissed the broadcast as ``slander.'' The media should build a solid base of facts, ``before you show he beats his wife,'' said Szczypiorski. ``Only in the second round, four days before election ends, someone goes to Canada,'' he said. ``It was their duty to do it four months earlier.'' Poland's press does not have a tradition of objective journalism, of establishing a clear line between reporting and editorializing. Tyminski has accused television of ``dealing only with filth and lies'' and the press of conspiring against him. His stance has won support. ``I will vote for Tyminski thanks to journalists,'' Warsaw resident Jerzy Krosmicki said. ``The reporters' behavior convinced me that there is no democracy.'' However, it appears some voters now are beginning to question Tyminski. An independent opinion poll Wednesday showed Walesa leading 61 percent to 20 percent, compared with 58 percent to 30 percent a week ago. Still, pollsters caution that Tyminski may do better at the ballot box. They say the current atmosphere may encourage some of his supporters to hide their preference.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rebounds, Stocks Gain
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened against the yen today, while Tokyo share prices continued to gain moderately in thin trading. The dollar closed at 134.05 yen, up 0.63 yen from Wednesday's close of 133.42 yen. It opened at 133.90 yen and ranged between 133.70 yen and 134.17 yen. Thursday's spot trading totaled some $8.68 billion, compared with $9.94 billion the previous day. Currency traders said the dollar's initial advance followed its overnight rise in New York, where it was boosted by Secretary of State James A Baker III's remark that the United States would strike decisively if it chooses to use force try to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. The dollar, which closed at 127.13 yen on Nov. 22, has gained recently amid uncertainties over the Persian Gulf crisis. The U.S. currency is seen as a safe haven in times of international tension. The possibility of war in the gulf also tends to weaken the yen because Japan imports virtually all of its oil, with about 70 percent of the imports coming from the Middle East. Yuko Fukakusa, a dealer with Tokai Bank, said sentiment favoring the dollar basically remained strong. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 331.11 points on Wednesday, added another 359.38 points, or 1.62 percent, closing at 22,553.10. Volume on the first section totaled 330 million shares, down from 350 million on Wednesday. The index rose on index-linked buying and arbitrage buying, in which investors seek profits from price gaps between the spot and futures markets, securities dealers said. ``Judging from the day's small trading volume, it is too early to say that the market actually gained confidence,'' said Atsushi Sugihara of New Japan Securities Co. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slid to 86.68 from Wednesday's close of 87.22. Their yield rose to 7.345 percent from 7.225 percent.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Ershad Resigns
DOC.TEXT: DHAKA

President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, the former army general whose eight years in power were ended by massive street protests, resigned Thursday, a spokesman in the president's house said. Fulfilling a vow he made to opposition leaders, Ershad handed over power to a caretaker vice president, Shahabuddin Ahmed, who had been nominated by the country's top opposition leaders. Ershad's press secretary, Toab Khan, said Ershad administered the vice president's oath of office to Shahabuddin, chief justice of the Supreme Court. Ershad then resigned as president, Khan said.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Anti-Crime Plan to be Partially Funded by New Lottery
DOC.TEXT: New York City has proposed a $1.8 billion anti-crime plan that would add nearly 3,500 officers to the police force and would be paid for in part by a new, city-only lottery game. The six-year program announced Wednesday also includes increases in property and income taxes and comes amid rising fear of street crime, dramatized by a string of slayings of children hit by stray bullets. The income-tax increase and the lottery need the approval of the state Legislature. The city can raise property taxes on its own. The program, which would cost about $300 million a year, was put together by Mayor David Dinkins and the City Council. It comes at a time when the city is trying to bridge a budget shortfall through cutbacks in other city agencies. ``We have had enough of crime, enough of bloodshed, enough of the suffering and the tears which flow in the wake of criminal activity,'' Dinkins said Wednesday. Officials said the lottery would bring in $50 million to $120 million each year. The police force now has about 25,000 officers. The program provides for more money for prosecutors, Legal Aid lawyers, prisons and drug treatment. The plan also calls for improving security in schools, reducing delinquency and finding jobs for high school graduates. Herb Berman, chairman of the City Council finance committee, said homeowners would pay about $10 more in property taxes in the first year and about $25 at the end of the program. The city's surcharge on personal income tax that expires in mid-1993 would be extended.

DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court Upholds Georgia Anti-Mask Law
DOC.TEXT: A Ku Klux Klansman arrested for wearing his hood in public lost a state Supreme Court bid to overturn a 39-year-old ban on masks. The court voted 6-1 Wednesday to reject arguments by Klansman Shade Miller Jr. that the Georgia law enacted to curb Klan activity is unconstitutional. The justices said the 1951 law does not violate free-speech rights and is a legitimate attempt to prevent violence and intimidation. The decision overruled a Gwinnett County judge who dismissed misdemeanor charges against Miller for wearing a mask in public. Attorney General Michael Bowers said Miller faces arrest if caught wearing his Klan hood but did not say whether the initial charge might be pursued. The offense carries up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Disguise is commonly used by those committing crimes of violence and intimidation, Chief Justice Harold G. Clarke said. ``A nameless, faceless figure strikes terror in the human heart,'' he wrote for the majority. ``But remove the mask, and the nightmarish form is reduced to its true dimensions. The face betrays not only the identity, but also human frailty.'' Miller's lawyer, Michael Hauptman, said that the high court's description of the no-mask law's range might allow for Klan members to wear hoods in explicitly non-threatening situations, such as a parade. Bowers said he didn't interpret the ruling that way. ``If his client wears a mask, it'll make my day,'' he said. The lone dissent came from Justice George T. Smith, who said he found the la unconstitutional on First Amendment grounds. It is ``a content-based restriction on political speech directed to a dissident group in a public forum, and is not narrowly tailored to serve a compelling state interest,'' he said. The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith called the rulihng ``a rejection of Klan-inspired intimidation and a blow to extremism.''

DOC.HEAD: Pilot of Plane in Runway Collision Called Careful, Capable, Friendly
With PM-Planes Collide
DOC.TEXT: Cautious in everything he did, Northwest pilot Bill Lovelace seemed like the last person who would get caught in the fiery Detroit airport crash that killed eight people, friends say. Lovelace, an accomplished magician and woodworker as well as veteran pilot, was just putting his life life back together after a bankruptcy and an illness that kept him from flying for five years. Then on Monday, the Northwest DC-9 he was commanding collided on a runway with a Northwest Boeing 727. Eight people on the DC-9 were killed and 24 injured. Lovelace, whose own injuries were minor, once was a DC-9 flight instructor. He had logged 20,000 hours of commercial flying in a career spanning 24 years, friends and Northwest officials said. ``I don't honestly believe it was his negligence'' that led to the collision, said Dave Giannini, who lives across the street from Lovelace in a moderately affluent Phoenix neighborhood whose residents range from retirees to families with young children. ``That guy was a straight guy. ... Even driving a vehicle he was really cautious.'' ``I would never hesitate to fly with him,'' added Giannini's wife, Barbara. Monday's flight would have been Lovelace's 13th since returning to work on Nov. 25 after five years on disability for treatment for kidney stones. It was also his first flight without the company of a supervising pilot. The cause of the crash is under investigation, but according to a transcript obtained by NBC, Lovelace indicated to the control tower he had become lost in the fog moments before the accident. The Federal Aviation Administration recertified Lovelace as fit to fly on Oct. 10 and he returned to the air after two weeks of ground training and 13 hours of simulator flying. ``Flying was his No. 1 love. He talked about it often,'' said Judy Wells, a friend of 3{ years. Three weeks before returning to active duty, Lovelace had been declared bankrupt under a petition he had filed in mid-July in Phoenix. Court papers listed debts of about $152,000 against assets of $106,000 and a monthly income of $4,212 in pension and retirement benefits. His bankruptcy laywer, David Engelman, said part of Lovelace's debt stemmed from an unsuccessful gift shop that he sold in 1989. Divorced and with two grown children, Lovelace remarried in September. No one answered the dor at his home Wednesday, where a neatly trimmed kumquat tree graces the front yard of the one-story stucco house. But several neighbors and friends described him as a friendly, helpful, conscientious person, as well as a talented magician and woodworker. ``Good enough to be professional,'' Jack Wall said of the magic shows Lovelace performs for schools and hospitals under the name The Great Orsini. Friends said he also turns out prize-winning wooden bowls on a lathe in his garage and in his backyard workshop. Lovelace has told of spending 40 to 50 hours on a woodworking project, getting it just right. ``His house, shop - anything he did - had to be just right,'' said Giannini.

DOC.HEAD: Police Revolt Highlights Panama's Dependence on U.S.
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a year after a U.S. invasion installed President Guillermo Endara, the government remains so weak that it needed American GIs to put down an attempted mutiny led by a disaffected officer. Wednesday's rebellion, in a Panamanian sergeant was killed, was the most serious challenge mounted to the year-old Endara government and a setback in U.S. efforts to foster a stable government. Washington agreed just over a decade ago to cede control over the Panama Canal at the end of the century. The Bush administration removed dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega last Dec. 20 in an invasion it said was justified because it put a democratically elected politician in office and fostered a return to well-being in Panama. But the economy remains depressed despite Endara's efforts to revive it. He has cut government spending, sold off money-losing state companies and instituted other belt-tightening measures. About 30,000 of Panama's 100,000 public workers held a 24-hour strike Wednesday called by the Coordinator of Unions, an umbrella group that includes Noriega supporters. Strike leaders threaten longer strikes to continue pressing for job security, easing austerity, and wage raises, which Endara says Panama's economy - based on small canal revenues and a meager agriculture - cannot afford. Workers' pay is still low, about 200,000 people out of a population of 2.4 million remain jobless. At $3.5 billion, Panama's foreign debt is the highest per capita in Latin America. On Tuesday afternoon, while about 40,000 public workers were holding a street demonstration, the former deputy national police chief escaped from jail on the Pacific island of Nao. Retired Col. Eduardo Herrera Hassan, who was awaiting trial on charges of plotting against the government, flew to his former Panama City headquarters, where the government says he tried to organize an uprising. Herrera accused the government of humiliating members of the National Police, the entity created in January to replace Noriega's disbanded Defense Forces. The 13,000-strong force includes many former Defense Forces soldiers. Herrera had been named national police deputy chief but was removed in August and jailed in October. After his escape, he radioed units nationwide for support. But except for a few dozen supporters, the National Police remained loyal to Endara. Endara summoned a special joint U.S.-Panamanian task force to quell the mutiny. The force of 500 troops, led by American soldiers, had been helping the hitherto untrustworthy police keep order since the invasion. Their attempts to rally Panamanian troops unsuccessful, Herrera and his co-conspirators tried to flee military headquarters and a Panamanian sergeant was killed and three civilians wounded in the shooting that followed. Herrera, a hard-nosed veteran trained in Israeli and the U.S. military schools, was captured along with 35 others. Fifteen rebels were at large. Some 120,000 U.S. troops are stationed in the country, and the joint patrolling agreement they have with the Panamanians expires at the end December. Due to the political uncertainty and questions about the loyalty of the National Police, it appears that agreement could be extended. Tuesday was the first time since 1925 that a Panamanian president formally asked U.S. troops to help restore order. The last time, they helped quell riots to protest increases in housing rents. U.S. troops weren't invited last December. They just roared in from bases inside and outside Panama, crushed the Defense Forces and flew Noriega to Miami to stand trial on drug trafficking and money laundering charges. Some 370 Panamanians were killed in the fighting then. Endara, who had won handily in May 1989 elections that Noriega annulled, was sworn in as president just as U.S. troops made their move. Corruption remains widespread in Panama, having thrived during the years of military rule that began when Gen. Omar Torrijos seized power in 1968. Military-dominated regimes succeeded his dictatorship when he died in a mysterious plane crash July 31, 1981. Seven puppet civilian governments came and went at Noriega's whim while he wielded power as Defense Forces chief in the 1980s. A cousin close to Torrijos, Herrera was also a Noriega crony until the two had a falling out and the dictator packed him off as military attache to Israel. When Herrera returned in January, Endara put him in charge of demilitarizing the police. Herrera told reporters shortly before his arrest Wednesday that he was not leading a coup but trying to dramatize the disaffection of the former military turned policemen. Many of them are known to miss the power and the perks they once had. No military force was created after Noriega's Defense Forces were disbanded. Panama seized independence from Colombia in 1903 with U.S. warships standing off its coasts by to help. After that, the U.S. government built, ran and owned the Panama Canal. In 1978, the treaties ceding the canal to Panama 2000 were ratified and Panama became its titular owner. The two governments now jointly administer the waterway, and the U.S. Southern Command keeps its troops on 11 military bases along the canal's shores. Under the treaties, the bases are to be eliminated by the year 2000.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Alina Guerrero is Panama correspondent for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Minister To Meet Bush Dec. 17
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz will meet with President Bush in Washington on Dec. 17 in an effort to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis peacefully, diplomats disclosed today. Speakingon condition of a anonymity, the sources said the date was fixed after a series of meetings this week between U.S. Charge D'affaires Joseph Wilson and Deputy Foreign Minister Nizar Hamodun. Bush had invited Aziz to Washington during the week of Dec. 10 and said he would later send his secretary of state, James A. Baker III, to meet with President Saddam Hussein in a last attempt to avert war over Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bush announced on Friday that he was willing to ``to go the extra mile'' for a peaceful settlement to the crisis. But he said he will not accept anything short of a complete Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, the release of all foreigners held hostage by Iraq. Bush made the diplomatic overture a day after the U.N. Security Council passed a resolution setting a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face the possibility of being forced out in a military strike.

DOC.HEAD: Boston City Council Votes to Abolish School Board
DOC.TEXT: The City Council voted to abolish Boston's 13-member school board, accusing it of ``ripping off the taxpayers'' and failing to educate the city's children. The move needs the approval of the governor and Legislature. The City Council approved 10-3 Wednesday a measure to put education of the city's 57,000 public school children under the direct control of the council and Mayor Raymond Flynn. Flynn said legislative approval would put Boston in the forefront of education reform. The School Committee, as the elected board is known, had been criticized for failing to find a new superintendent. Last week it called off its eight-month search. The quality of the city's schools had also come under attack, as had the board's failure to close a $12 million deficit in this year's $389.5 million budget. ``The School Committee over there has been ripping off the taxpayers unmercifully,'' said Councilman Albert ``Dapper'' O'Neil. ``Today is D-Day.'' ``No matter what the particular issue, nothing happens, or if it happens, it's done in an incorrect way,'' said Councilman James Byrne, who proposed abolishing the board. School Committee president Daniel Burke said the move was politically motivated and not in the school system's best interests. Committee member Robert Cappucci said Flynn is involving himself in an issue he cannot handle. ``For the mayor to assume that he is going to be the answer to quality education is ridiculous,'' Cappucci said. If the move is approved by the state, School Committee members will be forced to step down at the end of the current school year. Flynn said he was optimistic about passage because he expected lawmakers to see the correlation between Boston's high homicide rate and its poor schools. ``We're seeing turmoil in our city because public education has failed the schoolchildren,'' he said. Councilman Charles Yancey, who voted against the measure, said, ``We are depriving the right to vote by the people of Boston. It was ramrodded through, and I think my colleagues will regret this decision.''

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Town Tries to Find Killer of Retarded `Walking Man'
DOC.TEXT: Richard Dunne was known as The Walking Man. He loved to borrow classical music tapes from the library and listen to them through headphones as he wandered the streets. Then he was killed by a hit-and-run driver. The death of the 51-year-old retarded man has suburban Northlake neighbors up in arms. The mayor is offering a reward out of his own pocket in hopes of tracking down the driver who hit Dunne last week. ``He got cheated by life when he was born, and now he's been cheated out of the rest of his life,'' said Jerry Dunne, who cared for his retarded brother. Northlake Mayor Reid Paxson, who is offering a $500 reward, lamented the lack of witnesses to the fatal collision. ``Sometimes people have their memories jogged if there's a reward involved, Paxson said Wednesday. ``I think the family could accept it if it were an accident. They can't accept this.'' Dunne's death brought an outpouring of grief from Northlake residents. They had come to expect to see Dunne walking the streets in a sport coat and tie, headphones on, listening to classical music as he had for the 11 years he lived in town. ``The wake was loaded with people,'' his brother said. ``He knew more people in this town than I did, and I've lived here 27 years.'' Dunne and another brother, Gene, were born retarded, Jerry Dunne said. They moved into Jerry's upstairs bedrooms after their mother became too old to care for them. The pair became known for their habit of walking everywhere. ``We accepted them as they were, and they accepted us `sane' people for what we are,'' Paxson said. Dunne visited the Northlake Public Library almost daily, although he couldn't read or write. He spent hours copying pictures out of the Bible and listening to music. Tchaikovsky's works were among Dunne's favorites, said research librarian Karen Ryeacki, who met him when she began working at the library six years ago. ``He was one of our regulars. He would come in during the day, leave for dinner or lunch, then come back in the evening,'' Ryeacki said. ``There were some things he did not have. But he had gifts. He could tell when someone was having a bad day, and he always had a kind word.'' Dunne did not visit the library the night he died, Nov. 29. A police officer spotted him standing on a street corner about 6:45 p.m., Police Chief Seymour Sapoznik said. Twenty minutes later, a factory worker on break found him sprawled on the ground, Sapoznik said. No witnesses have come forward, although the corner usually is heavily traveled at that time of night, police said. Police are distributing fliers to businesses in the community of about 12,000 people in the search for clues, Sapoznik said. ``He was the town walker, and everyone knew and liked him,'' Sapoznik said. ``Why would someone run when it's just an accident?''

DOC.HEAD: AP and Wire Service Guild Reach Tentative Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press and the Wire Service Guild reached tentative agreement on a two-year contract covering more than 1,300 employees nationwide. The agreement, which would replace a contract that expired Friday, provides for raises of 2.8 percent in the first year and 2.3 percent in the second. ``I think it's a realistic contract and I think that given the economic climate in the industry and its obvious impact on us, that's what makes it realistic,'' D. Byron Yake, AP director of human resources, said Wednesday. ``The other side of that is that we're pleased we can offer a contract that has raises and not freezes and cuts.'' Kevin Keane, Guild president, said, ``Obviously, the bargaining committee is disappointed with the size of the wage increase. But they worked hard, and we're convinced that this is the best contract we can get, given the labor and economic climate.'' He said the Guild was recommending ratification by the membership. The contract calls for pay increases that would raise top scale for newspersons and photographers from $720 to $740 weekly in the first year of the contract, and from $740 to $757 in the second year. Economic differentials also would go up in the second year of the contract. News staff employees in New York and Washington would receive a $10 a week increase in the differential, bringing it to $97. The differential in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Boston and Chicago would go up $15, to $60. The contract also offers improved retirement benefits for those already retired and service credits for active participants in the pension plan. The tentative pact cuts paid maternity leave for women from four weeks to one week while keeping one week paid paternity leave for men, and changes unpaid leave time from 18 months to 12 months for both men and women. Under the old contract, men were not given unpaid paternity leave. In addition, women on maternity leave will be allowed to use eight weeks' full-pay disability regardless of their length of employment.

DOC.HEAD: Freezing Weather in Deep South
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dipped into the 20s in the Deep South early today, and most of the nation had dry weather. Snow fell in Colorado early today, and flurries were forecast in Michigan. A cold front was expected to reach from the Ohio Valley south through Memphis and across Louisiana and into the Rio Grande Valley in Texas. Some rain was likely along the southern tail of the front. The Northwest was expected to have a respite from recent heavy rains. An overnight freeze warning was posted for northern Florida and Georgia. It was 27 degrees early today in Macon, Ga. Strong gusts were likely today in Southern California and Arizona. The nation's high for Wednesday was 83 degrees at Woodland Hills, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were mixed. Traders predicted the dollar would remain weak in the absence of any conflict in the Persian Gulf. ``The down trend has not been broken,'' said David Deakin, foreign exchange manager at Nikko Bank (U.K.) Ltd. Dealers said trading was quiet ahead of the holiday season. ``Many banks have already finished their business for the year,'' said a trader in Frankfurt. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.63 yen to a closing 134.05 yen. Later, in London, it was unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Transplant Drug Will Be Tested on Diabetics
DOC.TEXT: Doctors say a drug taken by transplant recipients to prevent organ rejection will be tested on diabetics to see if it helps them fight the disease. The drug, FK-506, already has shown promise in reversing the effects of some types of skin diseases, leading researchers to study whether it will halt the onset of a related type of diabetes, said Dr. Thomas Starzl. Starzl heads the University of Pittsburgh's transplant program, where about 800 patients since February 1989 have taken the drug to prevent their white blood cells from rejecting donor organs. He said Wednesday that the drug also shows promise in treating auto-immune diseases, in which the body's white cells destroy healthy cells. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved a two-year test of the drug on 60 Type 1 diabetes patients, Starzl said. FK-506 has already reversed the effects of psoriasis, a skin disease that creates unsightly lesions, in all six patients who took it, Starzl said. The drug also reversed the effects of pyoderma gangrenosum, a rare skin ulcer, in six of seven patients, he said. ``We're seeing some very dramatic recoveries,'' said Starzl who performed the world's first successful human liver transplant in 1967. He said researchers want to move ahead quickly with the tests on people with Type I diabetes, in which a person's white cells destroy their pancreas' insulin-producing factories, requiring that the person take insulin shots to survive. ``We are anxious to get the information out that there is something that could switch off this disease,'' he told reporters. At least 11 million Americans suffer from Type 1 diabetes, which can cause blindness and kidney failure. Its symptoms are excessive thirst, frequent urination, rapid weight loss and blurred vision. FK-506, which is derived from a fungus, is taken orally twice a day. It is manufacturered by the Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Co. of Japan. Transplant patients using the drug have displayed such side effects as dizziness and excessive dreaming, said Dr. Patricia Carroll of the university's medical school. But she said side effects haven't shown up in people who have taken the drug but who have not undergone transplants.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Says High-Impact Aerobics May Cause Vertigo
DOC.TEXT: High-impact aerobics enthusiasts bouncing their way to trim tummies and tight tushes may also be jolting their inner ears into episodes of vertigo and inviting hearing loss from loud workout music, a doctor says. Dizziness, ringing in the ears and loss of balance were found among aerobics teachers and others who do the popular form of exercise frequently, Dr. Michael I. Weintraub of New York Medical College wrote in today's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine. Five recent cases prompted him to question 37 high-impact aerobics instructors at two fitness clubs, Weintraub said. Results suggested a link between the exercising and shock to the ears that could be causing damage to the inner ear, he said. Aerobics exercising, popularized by actress Jane Fonda in the 1980s, features repeated jumping and running in place. High-impact aerobics exercising is an advanced, more intense form of aerobics workouts. Among the five cases that alerted Weintraub was a 29-year-old woman aerobics teacher who suffered vertigo, skewed balance that caused her to inadvertently to veer to the right and hearing loss. In another case, a 20-year-old aerobics enthusiast suffered vertigo and general dizziness after exercising. A 42-year-old instructor suffered reduced hearing in one ear. A 35-year-old instructor reported a muffled sound in one ear and sense of imbalance that worsened after exercising, and a 26-year-old enthusiast had a 7-month history of dizziness and hearing problems during and after exercises. ``The hearing loss ... was thought to be related to exposure to the loud music played during the exercise routine,'' Weintraub wrote. Of the 37 instructors questioned, Weintraub said five reported episodes of vertigo and some hearing loss, and eight reported tinnitus - ringing or buzzing in the ear. The injuries came despite the use of specially cushioned shoes, he said. Vertigo is a loss of balance commonly accompanied by a whirling feeling or the feeling that things surrounding the sufferer are spinning. Possible dangers from aerobics need more study, Weintraub said. ``In calling attention to this potential association, I do not intend to discourage high-impact aerobics but rather to urge an increased awareness among clinicians as well as exercise instructors and enthusiasts,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Who Wouldn't Report to Persian Gulf Discharged; Court-Martial Dropped
DOC.TEXT: The first Marine to refuse orders to go to the Persian Gulf says now that he's won a military discharge he'll fight to keep his former colleagues out of war. The Marine Corps agreed Wednesday to grant Jeff Paterson an administrative discharge and drop court-martial proceedings against him in exchange for his dropping legal action against the military. ``I think now I'll be in a better position to mobilize support against the war,'' said Paterson who attended a celebration at a local coffehouse late Wednesday. ``I'll continue speaking out and being very vocal against the war.'' In a related development Wednesday, Army Spec. Sebastian Correa sued the military and President Bush for extending his active-duty enlistment because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Correa's four-year active-duty tour was to have ended Nov. 24. In early September he was asked if he wanted to re-enlist; he declined. Two weeks later, Correa, 24, was sent to Saudi Arabia, and two weeks after that he learned his tour was extended until December 1991. Paterson, 22, was accused of violating orders for refusing to board a plane for Saudi Arabia with his unit on Aug. 29. He also was charged with unauthorized absence on Aug. 16, when he failed to report for duty to hold a news conference announcing his plans to seek conscientious objector status. The Marines denied that request, saying it was based on political and not moral considerations and they didn't believe it was sincere. Paterson said Wednesday he might have helped the anti-war movement more if he had fought the charges at a court-martial. ``But the government probably would have won their case and I would have been in jail,'' he said. ``I have no desire to be a martyr.''
