He and his lawyer, Eric Seitz, said the military decided to drop the court-martial to avoid negative publicity. But Paterson's commanding officer, Brig. Gen. R.L. Phillips, said it would have been too disruptive to the military's Operation Desert Shield to have soldiers in the Persian Gulf take time to file depositions in the case. ``The expeditious discharge of Lance Corporal Paterson ... was in the best interests of the United States government and the U.S. Marine Corps.,'' Phillips said in a statement Wednesday. Seitz said Paterson will be sent to Camp Pendleton, Calif., within the next few days to be formally discharged. As part of the discharge he is being reduced in rank from corporal to lance corporal. In two other conscientious objector cases: -Pvt. Alfred Edwin Esquibel Jr., who refused to carry a gun to Saudi Arabia, was discharged Tuesday from the Army on grounds of fraudulent enlistment, said Bill Harralson, Army spokesman at Fort Campbell, Ky. -A special court-martial, which carries a lighter sentence than a general court-martial, was recommended for Sgt. George Morse of Fort Riley, Kan., who was charged with refusing orders to prepare military equipment for transport to Saudi Arabia. Esquibel and Morse requested conscientious objector status.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Wants All Foreigners Freed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series, ADDS background, byline.
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein today called for the release of all foreign hostages, saying recent diplomatic moves have prompted him to ``respond to positive changes,'' the Iraqi News Agency reported. Saddam also said the hostages' presence was no longer needed to deter attack because his forces were fully deployed in Kuwait. Saddam, who rules parliament with an iron hand, asked the body to approve the hostages' release, the official report said. It was assumed the hostages would be freed immediately after parliament's approval. The report did not say exactly when he wanted the estimated 2,000 Westerners, including 1,000 Americans, to be freed. About 90 of the detained Americans have been held at strategic sites to deter an attack on Iraqi forces. Saddam previously had said he would free all hostages over a three-month period beginning Christma Day, ``if nothing mars the atmosphere of peace.'' His decision was apparently a reaction to a decision by President Bush last week to propose direct U.S.-Iraqi talks on the Persian Gulf crisis. Iraq has accepted the offer for high-level negotiations. Saddam's message also comes exactly one week after passage of a U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq by Jan. 15 if its fails to withdraw from Kuwait. The United States also recently announced it would dramatically boost its forces in the Persian Gulf region. The Iraqi New Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Saddam urged parliament to act in a letter he sent to the National Assembly Chairman Sadi Mehdi Saleh. The agency quoted Saddam as saying in the letter: ``We deem it necessary that our National Council convene to take a final and irrevocable stand toward a humanitarian issue which you and the rest of the world are aware of.'' He said the most annoying factor of the gulf standoff was that ``some people with no confrontational or evil intentions were caught in the middle. ``Some of the foreigners who have been prevented from travel fall under that category.'' Saddam said that when the travel ban was first announced, Iraqi forces ``had not completed their mobilization in Kuwait to confront a potential military aggression. ``Any measure that could delay war at the time was appropriate ... so that we use the opportunity to complete preparations for that possibility,'' Saddam said, according to the Iraqi News Agency text. ``But now our forces, with the blessings of the almighty, are fully prepared to defend our values and principles against the traitors and infidels ... and to defend our national, regional and humanitarian wealth,'' he said. ``We had suggested different timing,'' for the release of hostages, Saddam said, referring to the previous offer to allow the foreigners to leave in batches over a three-month period starting Dec. 25. But, he added, that recent overtures have prompted him to ``respond to positive changes.'' Iraq this week accepted a Bush administration proposal to hold talks on the crisis, which began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. CNN on Wednesday quoted a ranking Iraqi source it did not identify as saying, ``All issues are on the table, everything.'' It said Saddam was feeling enormous pressure to withdraw from Kuwait. Saddam told Parliament: ``I invite you to take a just decision to end the travel ban imposed on foreigners and restore to all of them the freedom to travel. We apologize to those who may have been harmed, and from God we seek forgiveness.''

DOC.HEAD: Wide Gap Remains Even Though Iraq Has Agreed to Talks With U.S.
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new grafs 3-4 to UPDATE with Iraqi announcement; hearing resumes 10 a.m. EST; pre-noon lead expected
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is accepting President Bush's offer to hold talks on the occupation of Kuwait, but the gap between the two sides remains wide as Secretary of State James A. Baker III testifies on Capitol Hill. Baker plans to use his trip to Baghdad to reiterate three U.S. demands - that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait, free all foreign hostages and permit the return of the ousted Kuwaiti government. Iraq today appeared to move closer to accepting one of those demands when President Saddam Hussein called for the release of all foreign hostages, saying recent diplomatic moves have prompted him to ``respond to positive changes.'' The Iraqi News Agency reported that Saddam said the hostages' presence was no longer needed to deter attack because his forces were fully deployed in Kuwait. Saddam, who rules parliament with an iron hand, asked the body to approve the hostages' release, the official report said. It was assumed the hostages would be freed immediately after parliament's approval. Sadiq al Mashat, the Iraqi ambassador, told reporters Wednesday that the Palestinians' dispute with Israel is the ``backbone'' of Iraqi policy. ``It has to be addressed some way or another,'' he said. ``Let us negotiate and arrive at a peaceful settlement which would be in the interest of everybody in the region.'' Al Mashat coupled that statement with a warning to the United States: ``If you are going to war you are going to receive ashes and animosity.'' Baker, who appears today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, would go to Baghdad after Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister, comes to Washington for talks with Bush. Testifying Wednesday to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Baker appealed for broad support for the administration's Persian Gulf policy. Amid rising dissent, Baker said, ``we ought to send a clear signal here that there is a willingness and a resolve to threaten the use of force in a credible way so this man (Saddam) will know if he doesn't leave peacefully force could be used against him.'' Taking a tough line, Baker said his message to Saddam would be: ``Get out of Kuwait or risk all.'' He said he would not negotiate with Saddam, and added a new warning: ``If force must be used, it will be used suddenly, massively and decisively.'' Meanwhile, Bush said in a news conference in Buenos Aires, Argentina, that the United States would make no effort to give Saddam a face-saving way out. ``When naked aggression takes place, it's not a question of finding face for the aggressor,'' the president said. ``When a country is literally raped and pillaged, should the world go out and try to find a way to save face for he who has raped and pillaged that country?'' Baker, meanwhile, said a trade embargo and other economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations Security Counil after the Aug. 2 invasion had not worked. He said he was ``very pessimistic'' they would compel Saddam to withdraw, and said that also was the judgment of intelligence experts. ``Put bluntly, this is the last best chance for a peaceful solution,'' Baker said of his forthcoming trip to Baghdad, which Iraq has accepted in principle with the details still to be worked out. He said he would not negotiate with the Iraqi president on subjects unrelated to the seizure of Kuwait. ``I will not be negotiating the Palestinian question or the civil war in Lebanon,'' he said. ``Saddam did not invade Kuwait to help the Palestinians. He did it for his own self-aggrandizement.'' If Baker made any converts on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, they were not evident. Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., said sanctions have not been given adequate time to work. His mail is running ``eight or nine to one to slow down'' the rush toward military action, Pell said. ``There is little evidence of ... impatience or of a popular clamoring for war.'' And Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., said, ``This is a time for the qualities of the long-distance runner: perseverance, stamina, determination. Lashing out may be less courageous than to stick the course, particularly when you're talking about a significant loss of life.''

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani: Men And Women Should Get Together More Often
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 17th graf, `Rafsanjani's anti-Western...' with 1 graf to CORRECT typo. Pickup 18th, `They demand...' Subs 21st, `A day...' with 1 graf to CORRECT typo. Pickup 22nd, `Growing nervous....'
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Eleven years after the Islamic revolution forced women under veils and banned social contact between the sexes, President Hashemi Rafsanjani is championing a freer attitude toward sex and social interaction. ``We imagine that it is good if we suppress ourselves, endure frustrations and be patient in our sexual desires. This is incorrect. It is wrong,'' Rafsanjani said last week at Friday Prayers, an important forum for political statements. ``God has created certain needs in the human being, and he does not want them left unanswered,'' he said, addressing thousands of worshippers at Tehran University and millions of his countrymen listening on radio. The efforts are part of a broad political and social liberalization Ransanjani has pressed, despite sharp opposition, since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini died in June 1989. Rafsanjani's moves have ranged from such major policy steps as encouraging private businesses and expanding ties with Western countries to permitting more contemporary music and even making television more lively. ``Why is it improper for a lady to marry twice in her lifetime? Or to have a temporary relationship - a temporary marriage - with someone else?,'' Rafsanjani said in his sermon. ``Sigheh'' or temporary marriage, according to Shiite Islam - the branch of Islam in Iran - can be verbally contracted between two consenting adults. They take a temporary ``vow'' before engaging in sex. Attempting to make the idea of ``sigheh'' as loose as possible, Rafsanjani said in his sermon that ``some people imagine that for a temporary marriage we have to find a turbaned man (cleric),'' Rafsanjani said. ``None of this is necessary,'' he said. ``They can make a contract for themselves, if they want to be together for a month or two.'' It wasn't clear whether Rafsanjani's comments Friday would quickly lead to a liberalization of popular attitudes toward sex. Social and moral codes are often interpreted differently from city to city, and some religious and government leaders still hew to Khomeini's ascetic line. Under Khomeini, Iran's 55 million people endured a rigidly enforced Islamic social and religious code that outlawed even pre-teen boys and girls from sitting together in classrooms. In many places, the all-pervasive neighborhood Komitehs, or revolutionary committees, still swoop down on women who defy the dress code that decrees they must always wear a head-to-toe robe. Armed, uniformed Komiteh militants still raid parties where both sexes are allowed to mingle. Rafsanjani's sermon drew wide attention. ``He is calling for men and women to mingle in public, to eat together in restaurants, to walk around in the parks, to be normal,'' a university professor in Tehran said on condition of anonymity. ``In my opinion, this temporary marriage thing is to wrap these relationships in an Islamic cloak to silence opponents,'' the professor said. Rafsanjani's anti-Western, hard-line rivals, locked in a power struggle with him, claim to be the real heirs of Khomeini, spiritual leader of the 1979 Islamic revolution. They demand unflinching adherence to the patriarch's strict teachings. Using Khomeini's parlance, the hard-liners have accused Rafsanjani of favoring ``American Islam'' - a diluted version of the real thing. The more open atmosphere encouraged by Rafsanjani is palpable in the streets of Tehran, where pretty young women made up with lipstick and eyeliner push back their headscarves to show a peek of their carefully coiffeured hair. A day after Rafsanjani's sermon, a crowd in central Tehran's Ferdowsi square pleaded on behalf of a chic young woman being arrested for showing a lock of hair - still considered a violation by Komiteh revolutionaries. Growing nervous because of the size of the crowd, the revolutionary ``sister'' attempting the arrest relented. She returned to her patrol car, muttering, ``One day we'll get your American president, then you'd better watch out.'' Hard-liners, led by former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi and Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi, are vehemently opposed to Rafsanjani's steering of the revolution in a more liberal direction. They have been the target of a purge by Rafsanjani, and have gone on the defensive since Khomeini's death. They agonized when Rafsanjani moved toward normalizing ties with a number of Western countries. They endured when he said he favored private enterprise over the stifling, government-run economy. But Rafsanjani's latest statements - a call to reverse what his rivals consider the revolution's most visible ``achievements'' - has them up in arms. ``I hope we will never undermine the dignity of women. We should never hurt their feelings,'' Karrubi said in Parliament Monday.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Soldier Dies In Accident
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A soldier with the Army's 20th Engineer Brigade died when he was trapped between a truck and a pallet of construction materials, American military officials said today. The accident happened at about 6 p.m. Wednesday in the 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault) area of reponsibility in eastern Saudi Arabia. The Army withheld the soldier's name until relatives could be notified. An investigation was under way. On Tuesday, a Tennessee National Guard officer was found dead in his tent. A Pentagon spokesman said no foul play was suspected in the death of Lt. Col. Joe Hancock, 49, of Nashville, Tenn., but that it was being investigated. Since Operation Desert Shield began in early August, 52 U.S. servicemen have died, including 47 in accidents, according to U.S. military officials in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: President Ershad Resigns, State Of Emergency Lifted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with new quotes from Shahabuddin, CORRECTS site of ceremony to president's office sted residence. Picks up 10th graf, `Ershad, 60, ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Hussain Muhammad Ershad resigned today and surrendered power to an opposition-nominated political independent who will lead the country until elections promised for within three months. Ershad, a former army general who held power for eight years, agreed on Tuesday to step down after a seven-week campaign of large street protests that grew only fiercer when he imposed a state of emergency last week. Fulfilling a vow he made to opposition leaders, Ershad administered the oath of office to Shahabuddin Ahmed, chief justice of the Supreme Court. Ershad then resigned as president of this impoverished nation of 107 million people. ``Allah bless you,'' Ershad told Shahabuddin. ``You have our blessings. I want peace to return to the society.'' Shahabuddin, sworn in as vice president, will serve as acting president and preside over new elections that are to be held within 90 days. ``I have no political ambition. I shall not stay here beyond the mandated 90 days,'' Shahabuddin told opposition leaders after the ceremony. ``During this period I shall try to ensure peace and stability, hold free and fair elections and hand over power to the elected representatives of the people,'' he said. The transfer of power was shown on state-run television. Ershad, wearing a black suit and looking grim, was flanked by the chiefs of the army, navy and air force. It was the first time he had appeared on television since Monday night, when he first expressed a willingness to resign. The ceremony took place at the president's office inside Dhaka's military cantonment, a well-guarded complex of offices and houses. Ershad, 60, was an army general when he seized in a 1982 bloodless coup. He resigned his military commission before running the 1986 presidential election that opponents said he stole through massive vote-rigging. Shahabuddin, 62, met the opposition leaders later in the day. Originally, his nomination was to be approved by Parliament on Saturday, but Ershad unexpectedly dissolved the lawmaking body this morning. Constitutional experts and opposition sources said Ershad dissolved Parliament because it was doubtful a majority of legislators would emerge in public. Two-thirds of Parliament belonged to Ershad's Jatiya Party. Many deputies were reluctant to appear in public for fear of being attacked by anti-Ershad activists. Some Jatiya Party offices and officials' residences around the country have been stoned or ransacked in the past week. Ershad lifted the state of emergency late Wednesday, eight days after he imposed it because of increasingly violent demonstrations for his removal. Emergency measures had included a curfew and press censorship but street protests continued despite the deployment of troops. On Tuesday night, Ershad bowed to a seven-week groundswell of opposition and said he would step down as the opposition had chosen someone to run the country until new elections. The top opposition leaders, Sheik Hasina and Khaleda Zia, agreed Wednesday night on Shahabuddin, a career lawyer and judge. Ershad has not been seen in public for nearly a week. But longtime aides said he remained at his home and office inside a Dhaka military base. The opposition claimed at least 100 people were killed by security forces since the emergency was declared on Nov. 27. Ershad's govenment said only six people died. Mrs. Zia and Hasina have been agitating for Ershad's ouster since he took power. But their personal and political rivalries had long thwarted any lasting campaign. Then, in October, the opposition was galvanized by Ershad's announcement that he would be a candidate in June presidential elections. Hasina, leader of the left-of-center Awami League, is the daughter of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Bangladesh's first president. Mrs. Zia, head of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, is the widow of another former president, Ziaur Rahman. Both men were assassinated. Ershad is the country's ninth president since it gained independence from Pakistan in 1971. Like all of his predecessors, he was installed by military action.

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Young Politician Quits Right-Wing Party
DOC.TEXT: One of the rising political stars of the French right wing, Mayor Michel Noir of Lyon, quit his party today, describing the entire political system as ``sick.'' His resignation from the Rally for the Republic, the nation's largest conservative party, came a day after its leader, Jacques Chirac, denounced the concept of an integrated Europe. Noir, 46, loses his seat in the National Assembly by the resignation. He had been seen by many as a potential heir to Chirac, a former prime minister and now the mayor of Paris. At a news conference in Lyon, Noir accused all French political parties of failing to provide leadership as the country faces disturbing social ills and tough choices for its future. ``France is sick. Sick of the crises ... in justice, education, safety, health,'' Noir said. ``Sick of no longer holding its historic role on the international stage.'' France has been rocked in recent months by strikes by students demanding better education, protests by judges angry at political interference, and riots by youths in suburban ghettos. Chirac broke a national consensus Wednesday on further integrating the 12 countries of the European Community, declaring Paris was ceding too much sovereignty. The denunciation came as President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany discussed proposals on political union ahead of next week's EC summit in Rome. ``We reject the conception of the French Socialists, as well as of the Germans and of the Italians, for a federation of the 12,'' Chirac declared. Chirac, who lost the 1988 presidential race to Mitterrand, is one of the most prominent politicians to oppose further EC integration since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain resigned last month. His comments in many views echoed her views. Noir did not address the change in policy toward Europe, but his break with Chirac appeared certain to again steep the party in the confusion it has experienced ever since the 1988 election loss. The Rally for the Republic's main political ally, the Union for French Democracy led by former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, strongly supports European integration. It was not immediately clear what effect Chirac's proposals would have on the alliance. The resignation deprives the Rally for the Republic of its most charismatic young leader. Noir has fared consistently well in opinion polls and has resolutely denounced moves by party bosses to form an electoral pact with the extreme-right National Front of Jean-Marie Le Pen. Political analysts predicted that Noir would seek some sort of national role outside the Rally for the Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Colleges Urged To Help Minorities Succeed
DOC.TEXT: America's economic future will be jeopardized unless colleges and universities develop strategies to recruit, retain and graduate more minorities, a report by a national task force said today. The Education Commission of the States' task force said an 18-month study of colleges and universities in 10 states found there are too few minorities in higher education and those who do attend college often don't graduate or go on to graduate-level programs. In comparison, labor statistics show that in less than 10 years, one-third of workers entering the work force will be members of minority groups and that a majority of all new jobs will require postsecondary education. America's economic future will be ``severely jeopardized'' until all colleges and universities place the same priority on educating a much higher proportion of minority citizens, said the report, entitled ``Achieving Campus Diversity - Policies for Change.'' ``Indeed, diversity can be a source of America's strength rather than a force that divides,'' said Garrey Carruthers, outgoing governor of New Mexico who is chairman of the National Task Force on Minority Achievement in Higher Education. To increase campus diversity, the report said states should set two goals against which to measure their progress. Minority enrollment in higher education should be at least proportional to the minority population in each state. Also, minority graduation rates should be comparable to those of other students, the report said. The report studied every four-year institution in California, Florida, Illinois, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New Mexico, Ohio, South Carolina, Tennessee and Texas. The states represented 42 percent of the nation's 1985 population and enrolled 39 percent of Native American, 42 percent of African American and 72 percent of Hispanic college students. The states showed declines in enrollment for all the groups. According to the report, colleges must ``remove barriers to participation'' by recruiting more underrepresented students, providing adequate financial aid, using broadened admissions criteria and scheduling classes at convenient times for employed adults. Colleges and universities also must help students achieve by making it clear what they expect and taking steps to help students reach academic standards. Institutions should develop partnerships with public schools and work with community colleges to ease the transition from two-year to four-year institutions. Institutions also must increase the use of mentors and academic advising. The final step for colleges and universities is to use assessment, learning assistance, better teaching strategies and curricular reform to ``change learning environments for all students.''

DOC.HEAD: TWA Jet Evacuated Because of Smoky Odor
DOC.TEXT: A TWA jet that had just taken off from Greater Cincinnati International Airport this morning was brought back and evacuated because of an odor that smelled like smoke, an airline spokesman said. TWA flight 563, headed from Cincinnati to St. Louis, took off at 7:51 a.m. and was brought back to the airport at 8:20 a.m., said Donald Morrison, a TWA vice president in St. Louis. The 38 passengers and six crew members were evacuated from the DC-9 jet by the stairs, not emergency chutes, Morrison said. The move was only a precaution because ``there was never any fire,'' Morrison said. Mechanics were trying to determine the origin of the smoky odor.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Killing Kahane Says Jewish Man Did It
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of killing Rabbi Meir Kahane says he believes a Jewish man shot the militant Jewish leader to death, according to reports published today. State Supreme Court Justice Alvin Schlesinger set bail Wednesday at $300,000 for El Sayyid Nosair, 35, of Cliffside Park, N.J., during a hearing in Manhattan Criminal Court. Nosair is accused of shooting Kahane to death Nov. 5 as the rabbi finished speaking to a Jewish group at a midtown Manhattan hotel. He also is accused of wounding two other men and threatening a third while fleeing. He was stopped when a U.S. Postal Service police officer shot him in the neck a block from the hotel. New York Newsday and The New York Times reported today that Nosair gave a statement to police in which he said he believed a Jewish man did the shooting. Newsday said Nosair claimed the gun was placed next to him as he lay wounded in the street. Nosair also said in the statement that he went to see Kahane's lecture because he agreed with much of Kahane's anti-Arab rhetoric. Groups of Jews and Arabs nearly came to blows in a raucous confrontation outside the courtroom at Wednesday's hearing. ``No bail for murderers!'' yelled the Jews, and the Arabs shouted, ``God is great! Thanks be to God!'' as they met in the 13th-floor hallway. Nosair's lawyer, Michael Warren, was accompanied by an Egyptian lawyer, Abdel Halim Mandour, who said he was helping in the case. Nosair came to this country from Egypt in 1981. ``We will raise the bail as quickly as we can,'' Warren said. Warren had asked that bail be set at $100,000. He said Nosair had never been arrested before, has a wife and child and other relatives here, and was a responsible city employee. Nosair, a university-trained engineer, worked as a boiler tender. Assistant District Attorney William Greenbaum opposed bail, telling Schlesinger that the prosecution had witnesses, the murder weapon and ballistics evidence to tie the defendant to the crimes. Schlesinger scheduled another hearing for March 4.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Britain Ask NATO Help in Shipping GIs to Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with quotes by British defense secretary, NATO holding informal discussions with France on coordination of military operations. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Britain asked their NATO allies today for more help in transporting and equipping their forces in the Persian Gulf. At a NATO defense ministers meeting, British Defense Secretary Tom King urged his colleagues to provide more ammunition, medical equipment and chemical-warfare gear as well as ships and planes to transport troops to the gulf. King told reporters Defense Secretary Dick Cheney made a similar request on the opening day of the two-day meeting at the NATO headquarters here. ``He (Cheney) expressed his appreciation for allied support'' to date, King said. ``But we both said we were looking for further support and contributions from other members of the alliance.'' The United States, with about 300,000 soldiers in the gulf region, has the largest force facing Iraq, followed by Britain, whose total deployment will reach 30,000 over the next few weeks. All 16 NATO members except Germany, Iceland, Luxembourg and Turkey have sent forces to the gulf. King said he received ``one or two'' informal commitments from other NATO nations for new aid to support the British military presence in the gulf. In recent weeks, Washington issued two separate appeals to its allies for help in flying and shipping American forces to the gulf. While the response generally has been good, officials said more help was needed in view of the scope of the U.S. military buildup. The NATO defense ministers meeting comes a week after the adoption of the United Nations resolution authorizing military action against Iraq unless it leaves Kuwait by Jan. 15. He said public support for an attack on Iraq and western credibility in the Middle East could ``slide away'' if the 27-nation force fails to stick to that deadline. ``The idea that you could somehow drift longer is not a credible option,'' King said. Also today, the defense ministers reviewed work to date on a new NATO defense strategy to reflect the dramatic changes in East-West relations. German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg told a news conference there was ``a general wish'' among the allies to involve France more closely in allied military operations. France, although a NATO member, does not take part in the alliance's integrated military structure from which it withdraw in 1966. Stoltenberg said ``it is very important to strengthen the European security element'' in NATO through a new defense strategy focusing on multinational force formations with links to French troops. Without elaborating, he said, ``informal'' talks with France had already been held and were continuing. King said NATO's new defense strategy, due to be adopted next year, must reflect changes in Eastern Europe yet provide the allies with adequate defenses. ``Quite clearly the scale and nature of the threat has changed but there are considerably ... instabilities remaining, not least the rise of nationalism'' in Eastern Europe, King said. Officials said the new strategy will call for smaller forces, the maintenance of some nuclear arms as well as the continued pressence of American troops in Europe but in far smaller numbers than has been the case since the Second World War.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister: 35,000 Evaded Draft in 1990
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet defense minister said 35,000 young men have evaded the draft this year, most in republics where independence movements have fostered anti-military sentiment, the official Tass news agency reported today. In addition, more than 4,300 deserters from the army are at large, aided in their flight by local authorities, Tass quoted Defense Minister Dmitry Yazov as saying at a conference of military officials held Wednesday. Two thousand soldiers died in the first 11 months of 1990, and a quarter of those were suicides, the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda said in a report on the same conference, citing figures given by Col. Gen. Nikolai Shlyaga, the head of the main political directorate of the armed forces. The report did not specify how the other soldiers died, but many deaths apparently were the result of hazing of draftees by veteran soldiers. Many draftees refuse to serve outside their home republics because they fear the vicious hazing that often is ethnically motivated. Yazov said the draft was disrupted in the republics of Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Georgia, Armenia and the western Ukraine, Tass reported. As independence or nationalist movements have strengthened in these and other republics, sentiment against the Soviet military has been growing. Some of the breakaway republics have proposed setting up their own armed forces. The Soviet military does not reveal how many youths are drafted each year, citing state security. But every Soviet man 18 or older must serve in the military. Addressing the conference of junior and middle-level officers in the armed forces, the KGB secret police, the Interior Ministry and the railroad troops, Yazov said that attacks on the army, its prestige and combat traditions are directed against the integrity of the Soviet state, Tass reported. ``Can you jest with the army? Well, you can insult it once or twice, but after all, this is a man with a gun,'' Yazov said in an interview Wednesday night with Soviet television. ``Some people fail to understand that it is they who the army defends,'' he added. Yazov also said civilians were involved in the slayings of 69 officers and 32 warrant officers, Tass reported without further elaboration. Last week, Yazov ordered a crackdown on assaults against Red Army units, saying such actions are endangering national security. He ordered soldiers to use weapons if any military installation is attacked, and he urged the protection of installations from officials who would cut off power, water or other services. The Soviet military announced last month it was embarking on a 10-year restructuring program to cut manpower and weaponry. The plan includes cutting personnel from the current 4 million to about 3 million to 3.2 million. The draft will continue, but alternative service will be allowed for those who object on religious grounds.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Wants All Foreigners Freed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more quotes from Saddam, Iraqi Parliament to meet Friday, White House, hostage relative comment. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein today called for the release of all foreign hostages from Iraq and Kuwait, saying recent diplomatic moves helped prompt the decision, the Iraqi News Agency said. Saddam also said the hostages' presence was no longer needed to deter an attack by the U.S.-led multinational forces in the Persian Gulf because his forces were now fully deployed in Kuwait. Saddam urged his compliant Parliament to approve the hostages' release, the official report said. It did not say when the captives would be freed, but it was assumed they would be allowed to leave after parliament's vote. The 250-seat National Assembly, which has no record of ever challenging Saddam, scheduled a meeting for late Friday morning to debate Saddam's request, the state radio later announced. Relatives and friends of American and British hostages were overjoyed when they heard their loved ones could be freed soon. ``This has been the hardest thing I've ever had to go through in my life,'' said Doris Whatley of Shreveport, La., whose husband, Donald, has been held in Iraq. ``Now ... to know he'll be coming home, well, I'm a changed person.'' Patricia Hale of Spring, Texas, whose husband, Ed, was seized from an oil rig in Kuwait by Iraqi troops, said: ``This surprise is delightful. Truly delightful. It's all we ever wanted: for the hostages to go free.'' In Britain, relatives of hostages in Iraq and Kuwait were also excited. ``I'm over the moon. It's what we've prayed and prayed for,'' said Sue Dorrington, whose husband David is being held in Baghdad. Saddam's announcement coincided with a report that his foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, will meet with President Bush in Washington on Dec. 17 to discuss a possible settlement of the 4-month-old gulf crisis. There are thousands of Western hostages in Iraq and Kuwait, including about 900 Americans. Some 90 of the detained Americans are believed held at strategic sites to deter attack by the 330,000-strong multinational forces. Despite warnings by the U.S. State Department, dozens of Americans have traveled to Baghdad trying to win freedom for their family members and friends. Saddam previously had said he would free all hostages over a three-month period beginning Christmas Day, ``if nothing mars the atmosphere of peace.'' The White House today welcomed the offer as ``a hopeful sign.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``It shows that Saddam Hussein realizes that his position on the hostages has earned him the outrage of the world.'' Britain also applauded the move. ``We greatly welcome this news. We have been pressing throughout for the return of all our hostages. The sooner they are back the better,'' said a statement for the British Foreign Office. A Foreign Office spokesman said, however, that the government has received no confirmation that the approximately 1,300 British citizens in Iraq and Kuwait will be free to leave. Saddam's message came one week after passage of a U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq by Jan. 15 if its fails to withdraw from Kuwait. The Iraqi New Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Saddam urged parliament to act in a letter sent to National Assembly Chairman Sadi Mehdi Saleh. In his letter, Saddam said his decision was prompted by recent consultations with his ``Arab brothers,'' a reference to a meeting with King Hussein of Jordan, Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat, and Yemeni Vice President Ali Salem al-Baidh on Tuesday. He said recent overtures prompted him to ``respond to positive changes.'' Saddam said ``the reason for which the foreigners were prevented from travel have dinmished and have been replaced by something more powerful - a change in the American public opionion which will impose restrictions on the decisions and intentions of the evil ones, led by Bush, the enemy of God.'' But, despite this change, he said, the ``Iraqi armed forces should maintain the highest degree of alert and vigilance because the forces of aggression remain on our sacred soil in Saudi Arabia, fanning the flames of fire.'' Iraq banned foreigners from leaving in response to the allied troop buildup in Saudi Arabia. The United States has contributed 230,000 troops and promised another 200,000. Iraq has deployed 430,000 troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait. Saddam said that when the travel ban was first announced, Iraqi forces ``had not completed their mobilization in Kuwait to confront a potential military aggression. ``Now that the Iraqi military is battle ready,'' Saddam said, the foreigners should regain their ``freedom to travel.'' ``We deem it necessary that our National Assembly convene to take a final and irrevocable stand toward a humanitarian issue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says Iraq Promise Hopeful; Baker Presses Congress for Support
DOC.NOTE: EDs: COMBINES pvs; INSERTS 2 grafs Solarz reax after graf 13 pvs, bgng, ``Let the...; minor editing; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today welcomed Iraq's dramatic announcement that it would free all foreign hostages as evidence ``our strategy of diplomatic and military pressure is working.'' Still, the administration pressed its efforts to win congressional support for using force against Iraq if Saddam Hussein does not order his army to quit Kuwait soon. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said releasing hostages was not enough. ``It does not lessen, nor should it, our determination that Iraq's aggression against Kuwait should be reversed,'' Baker said in his second straight day of congressional testimony. Baker and White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration had received no official word from Baghdad. ``Nevertheless, this is a welcome and significant development but we do want to see it actually happen,'' Baker told the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``I think this is a sign that our ste of the British journal Nature. Discovery of the gene, called Sry, was announced in July along with some evidence for a sex-determining role. Sry lies within the bundle of genes called the Y chromosome, which is usually inherited only by males. The new studies ``provide fairly strong support for the role of Sry in sex determination,'' Dr. David Page of the Whitehead Institute of Cambridge, Mass., said in a telephone interview. The European scientists said they failed to find any Sry mutation in most women they tested who carried the gene. In those cases, a mutation may lie in a part of the gene that was not examined, or there may be a defect in some other gene that helps determine gender, they suggested.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Dec. 10

DOC.HEAD: S&L Regulator: Senators' Pressure Led to Greater Lincoln Losses
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf pvs, bgng, Chairman Howell... with 2 grafs to UPDATE with committee announcing new schedule for interviewing Grogan and senators, extending the hearings further; picks up 7th graf pvs, Black, in...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: William K. Black, a blunt-spoken savings and loan regulator, once prompted financier Charles H. Keating Jr. to write, ``Kill him dead.'' Lawyers for the so-called Keating Five senators didn't go that far, but they clearly were unhappy with Black's testimony Wednesday before the Senate Ethics Committee. Black offered the most dramatic and damaging testimony so far in the panel's hearings into allegations that the senators improperly intervened with S&L regulators on behalf of Keating, a financial contributor. ``It is the most fundamental smear,'' declared William Taylor, attorney for Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Black, a red-bearded senior attorney with the federal government's thrift regulatory agency, was returning to the witness stand today for more cross-examination by the defense lawyers. After hearing Black on Wednesday, the Ethics Committee disclosed it had voted to grant limited use immunity to compel the testimony of James Grogan, the former top aide and lobbyist for Keating. The panel met in private for two hours today, and afterward said Grogan would produce subpoenaed documents in an executive session next Wednesday and undergo questioning again on Monday, Dec. 17. The new schedule will extend the schedule of he public hearings, now in their 13th day, and leave the date of their conclusion further in doubt. Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., the committee's vice chairman, said Grogan would be questioned in public after the executive sessions. The senators under investigation will be questioned in public session after Grogan's appearance, Rudman said, meaning the hearings may run until close to Christmas. Black, in his first day on the witness stand, supported earlier testimony that the senators pressured regulators to help Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan. And he raised new allegations, saying that pressure by the senators prompted the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to delay and relax regulatory controls on Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln, which subsequently was taken over by the government. The result, Black said, was greater losses - which taxpayers eventually must bear - than otherwise would have occurred. ``This ... is probably the worst institution in America, and instead of people trying to help bring it under control, five U.S. senators were pushing us in the opposite direction,'' he testified. None of the five senators was present for Black's testimony. Besides Cranston, they are Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, John Glenn of Ohio and Donald Riegle of Michigan. Keating had targeted Black as a problem to be eliminated long before. The Ethics Committee released copies of a memo Keating wrote to Grogan, his lobbyist, on July 15, 1987, making clear he wanted Black removed. In it, Keating referred to the then-House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, as an ally. The memo began: ``Highest Priority - Get Black,'' with the last two words underlined. ``Good Grief,'' Keating wrote. ``If you can't get Wright and Congress to get Black - kill him dead - you ought to retire.'' Throughout Black's testimony, the defense lawyers objected, paced, stammered and complained. ``Innuendo,'' said James Hamilton, attorney for DeConcini. ``... Reckless and irresponsible.'' ``What this witness testified to are not facts,'' said Taylor, Cranston's attorney. The lawyers tangled with the committee's special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, who called Black as a witness. Committee Chairman Heflin settled the dispute in his unruffled drawl, saying: ``Now, he's got wide latitude to address the witness.'' Black said Lincoln operated like a ``Ponzi scheme,'' or financial pyramid dependent on an ever-increasing churning of assets. Its parent, Keating's American Continental Corp., was no more than a ``shell'' that siphoned dividends from Lincoln and distributed them through inflated salaries to Keating, his family members and associates, Black said. ``We call it a scam,'' Black said. ``I think most people do.'' Keating, the Arizona high-flier who contributed $1.3 million to the senators' campaigns and favored causes, is under indictment in California. The cost to taxpayers of paying off Lincoln's insured deposits are estimated at more than $2 billion. Black testified the bank board backed off its tough position on Lincoln in May 1988. After first taking a hard line on May 5, he said, a Cranston aide, Carolyn Jordan, ``called two senior officers at the bank board ... and indicated severe displeasure.'' The board revised its policy, Black said, to let Lincoln make new speculative investments and expand its sale of junk bonds. ``This led to greatly increased losses'' for the taxpayers, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysia's First Prime Minister Dies
DOC.TEXT: Tunku Abdul Rahman, who won independence for Malaysia from Britain in 1957 and was the nation's first prime minister until he retired in 1970, died tonight. He was 87. A team of five doctors tried to save him from intestinal bleeding and other problems for the past two days. He had been in a coma since Wednesday. The chief secretary to the government, Ahmad Sarji Abdul Hamid, made the announcement at the government's General Hospital. He said the Tunku would be accorded a state funeral with a gun-salute, honor guard and other tributes. In keeping with the Tunku's wishes, he will be buried according to Moslem rites at the Langgar Royal Mausoleum in Alor Star, 240 miles northwest of Kuala Lumpur, Sarji said. It was customary to refer to the prime minister as the Tunku, which means prince, because of his royal ancestry. Sarji said today would be a national holiday and all official celebrations would be canceled as a mark of respect for the Tunku. Flags were to be flown at half staff and the government's TV and radio stations began broadcasting readings from the Koran. The Tunku was a Moslem. The Tunku was prime minister from the time of independence until 1970. He then became secretary general of the Organization of Islamic Conference comprising about 40 nations and served at the headquarters in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, for a few years. For the past few years he had been moving around in a wheelchair because of poor health and had been in and out of hospitals many times. But he had been active, writing books and writing a column for the Star Daily, of which he was chairman. He also had criticized the government. His last major public appearance was during the campaign for the October general elections, when he urged people to oust Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and vote in the opposition Semangat 46 party. Although he helped found the United Malays National Organization party, of which Mahathir is the president, Tunku backed the Semangat 46 and called Mahathir a dictator. The Tunku was president of the party when he was prime minister.

DOC.HEAD: More Shuttle Trouble: Computer Shuts Down After Overheating
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with suspension in observation expected to last into the evening; first computer crash laid on clogged air vents, other detail. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `It was...'.
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronauts today lost the only working computer terminal for operating their $150 million observatory, once again shutting down their star-gazing efforts. In the latest glitch on the problem-prone scientific mission, the flight deck computer overheated and shut down automatically this morning. The same thing happened Sunday with the only other similar termimal. It has remained off since then. Although the crew smelled something burning each time, no smoke was reported in the cabin. There was no danger to the crew, but their observing was halted by the second computer shutdown. The suspension in observations by the three ultraviolet telescopes was expected to last until late tonight, if not longer, as NASA scrambled to devise a plan to control the instruments from the ground. ``We know it's going to be difficult,'' said mission scientist Ted Gull. ``But we're not giving up.'' The telescope lenses were covered for protection as ground controllers tried to get either of the problem computer terminals working. At the same time, they quickly developed a plan in which the telescopes would be brought back up one at a time. At least one of the computer terminals is needed for the astronauts to operate the Astro observatory's three ultraviolet telescopes. When the computer that crashed Sunday was opened today, its air vents were found to be clogged with lint, the astronauts said by radio. The reason for today's problem with the second computer was not immediately determined. Columbia's commander, Vance Brand, said other computer screens, unrelated to the malfunctioning ones that guide the ultraviolet telescopes, still were working well. The astronauts' manual star-tracking system also appeared to be fine, and the crew planned to use it with commands sent from the ground while efforts continued to restore a computer. ``When we first start up, we're going to be slower than the crew simply because we haven't trained or practiced it anywhere near the way they have,'' said flight director Bob Castle. It was the latest setback in a flight that has already been plagued by technical problems. As a result, the crew's astronomers have missed roughly half the celestial targets they had hoped to observe by now. Earlier, during intermittent failures of the automatic pointing system, the astronauts wiggled a video-game-like joystick and used a computer keyboard - the one that has since malfunctioned - to position the telescopes manually, and got more proficient at aiming the observatory, NASA said. NASA said the crew had charted just 45 of 86 intended targets through early Wednesday. Updated figures were not immediately available, but officials were optimistic after Wednesday's showing, mission spokesman Al Jordan said. ``We expect to show an improvement,'' he said. Scientists had planned to begin using the observatory late Sunday, the day the shuttle lifted off. The schedule for the 10-day mission is tight, but NASA said the crew might be able to make up a few hours' viewing time toward the end of the flight if things go well. An X-ray telescope with its own pointing system was unaffected by the computer problems. NASA halted X-ray observations as a precaution but planned to resume work later this morning. An alignment problem was corrected Wednesday, and the instrument was working well today. About 250 celestial sources of ultraviolet light and X-rays were supposed to have been studied during the mission. Such rays, which are emitted from galaxies, quasars and stars, cannot penetrate Earth's atmosphere. The automatic system has been successful in directing the telescopes toward a target's general area but has often failed to find the specific object. When that occurs, an astronaut uses the joystick and keyboard to guide the system. Mission scientist Ted Gull could not say when the observatory might reach peak efficiency, but he was confident that fine-tuning would increase viewing time. ``We're just learning more and more about how to use the spacecraft,'' he said. Successes included observations of a white dwarf star, a star near the end of its life; a galaxy 41 million light years away that is believed to contain a black hole, ad Crab Nebula, a remnant of a supernova that occurred more than 900 years ago. Scientists from Johns Hopkins University, principal investigator for one ultraviolet telescope, also studied one of their main targets - a bright quasar 1 billion light years away in the constellation Virgo - for 30 minutes. Astronaut Samuel Durrance operated the system manually to find the quasar, the brightest in the sky. ``It's his steady hand to which we owe our success with this one,'' said Arthur Davidsen of Johns Hopkins. The automatic system ``finds the target very closely, but not close enough to do a beautiful job - that's where the astronaut comes in,'' he said. The crew took some time out Wednesday night to sing ``Happy Birthday,'' to Beverly ``Bev'' Brand, Brand's wife, and Barbara Hoffman, wife of mission specialist Jeffrey Hoffman. The mission is scheduled to end with a night landing Tuesday. It had been scheduled for 1986 but was postponed after the Challenger accident and was delayed six months more this year, largely because of shuttle hydrogen leaks.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Hits High School; At Least 12 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last 3 grafs with 5 grafs to UPDATE with general saying plane developed engine problems, was aiming for vacant fields, CORRECTS destination.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: An Italian military jet crashed in flames into a suburban high school today, killing at least 12 people and injuring 70, officials reported. Students jumped out of windows of their two-story, red brick school to escape the smoke and flames, witnesses said. Others trapped on the top floor were rescued by firemen on ldders. Rescuers found one teen-age girl uninjured under the plane's wing and continued to dig for bodies four hours after the midmorning crash. Bologna prosecutor Mario Forte said he expected the death toll to remain at 12. Officials said all the dead were believed to be students. Many of the injured suffered serious burns. About 200 students, aged 14 to 18, were in school at the time. Police said the pilot bailed out and the plane crashed minutes later into a classroom of the school, smashing a 12-foot-wide hole in the wall on the second floor. ``I saw this plane in flames coming down slowly, it seemed to level off and then it turned suddenly and crashed into the school,'' a witneses told state RAI television. Students rushed in panic escape as flames and smoke swept through the building, witnesses said. ``The upper floor was full of flames and students who were immersed in the smoke were jumping out,'' a young woman said. Another student was quoted by the Italian news agency ANSA as saying: ``I was in class and saw through a window this low-flying plane coming at us and only had time to say: `This is crazy.''' The plane, a Macchi 326 trainer, came down in Casalecchio di Reno, three miles outside of this central Italian city, and crashed into the Gaetano Salvemini technical high school. Air force Gen. Carlo Brandini said the plane was on a mission to test radar effectiveness for anti-aircraft readiness. The aircraft took off from Villafranca military airport near Verona, 55 miles north of Bologna, and was scheduled to return there. The pilot ``reacted according to regulations,'' the general said. Brandini said the pilot, whom he identified as 2nd Lt. Bruno Viviani, hoped to make an emergency landing at Bologna's airport after the engine trouble developed. ``When he saw he couldn't do it, he directed the plane toward an open area. If the plane had cleared the school, it would have crashed in an area of open fields,'' Brandini said from air force headquarters in Rome. Brandini said the jet's only engine had developed some sort of problem and caught fire. The 24-year-old pilot suffered fractured vertebrae and was questioned by a prosecutor in the hospital, the Italian news agency ANSA said.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Says He Didn't Hear Co-Pilot Say DC-9 Was on Runway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with NTSB saying `walkthrough' may not be needed after all, move that angle lower. Picks up 9th graf, `Lauber said...'.
DOC.TEXT: The co-pilot of a DC-9 involved in a collision that killed eight people told controllers he thought the plane had strayed onto a runway in use, but the captain told investigators he didn't hear him. National Transportation Safety Board investigator John Lauber said Wednesday that the DC-9 co-pilot, James Schifferns, radioed the Detroit airport control tower moments before Monday's crash to say he thought his taxiing plane had wandered onto an active runway. The fiery collision when a Northwest Boeing 727 struck the DC-9 also injured 24 people. Lauber added that pilot William Lovelace reported he didn't hear what Schifferns said. ``Had the captain heard that, he said, `I would have headed for the weeds,' meaning he would have turned off the runway immediately,'' Lauber said. A control tower supervisor who did hear Schifferns shouted, ``Stop all aircraft! Stop all aircraft!'' Lauber said. But it was too late to halt the 727, which was on its takeoff roll. NTSB investigators said today they were putting on hold their plans to retrace the route that led the DC-9 onto the foggy runway. Board spokesman Brent Bahler said the ``walkthrough'' might not be needed because a videotape had been made of the runway area since the accident. Using a DC-9 to retrace the route would require that the runway be shut down, and the agency didn't want to disrupt airport operations unnecessarily, he said. In Monday's collision, the 727's right wing clipped the DC-9, tearing off its rear engine and sparking a fire that incinerated the DC-9. No one aboard the 727 was hurt, but toxic fumes from the fire killed eight of the 43 people aboard the DC-9. Lauber said investigators know the DC-9 made two wrong turns in the fog as it prepared for takeoff. The first time, the crew missed a turnoff and asked the tower for a new taxiing route, Lauber said. Then, Lauber said, Schifferns radioed the tower, saying, ``We may be on the active runway.'' Northwest said Lovelace, 52, of Phoenix, was making his first flight without another pilot observing since his return last week from a five-year medical leave. Schifferns, 43, of Spokane, Wash., joined the airline in March. Improved ground radar equipment designed to prevent planes from straying onto the wrong runways was on order for the Detroit airport and 28 others when the crash occurred, said Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Fred Farrar. But Farrar said it was not certain whether the new equipment, which tracks vehicle and aircraft movement on runways, would have prevented the accident. Lauber said investigators are also examining reports that some of the airport's runway lights may have been out at the time of the accident. He said a control tower supervisor reported that all lights on active runways were working, but the 727 crew reported that the center lights on their runway were out. One DC-9 survivor, Milio Rinna, a 60-year-old health and safety official for the United Steelworkers, on Wednesday filed the first lawsuit over the crash. He sued Northwest in state court for at least $10,000. Rinna was treated at a hospital for injuries to his hands, head and knees and was released, said his lawyer, William L. Martens.

DOC.HEAD: Multiparty System Would Bring Cease-Fire, Rebel Leader Says
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the U.S.-backed UNITA rebels says he would sign a cease-fire in the 15-year-old civil war if Angola's ruling party approved a multiparty system at its current congress. But rebel leader Jonas Savimbi on Wednesday reiterated his call for international forces to monitor a cease-fire, a condition opposed by the Soviet-backed Angolan government. ``If they (the government) approve the multiparty system now...what we do is sign a cease-fire,'' Savimbi told a news conference in the country's extreme southeast corner, headquarters for his National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA. In Luanda, more than 600 miles to the northwest, President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos' ruling party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, suspended its weeklong congress Wednesday. The congress was expected to debate constitutional amendments to convert the one-party state to a multiparty system. Officials blamed printing problems that delayed distribution of documents, but observers said party hard-liners opposed to the reforms may have caused the suspension. Dos Santos opened the gathering Tuesday by calling for political and economic reforms, saying hanging on to its Marxist ideals would be ``rowing against the tide.'' He predicted the party's 15-year political monopoly would end and said resolving the civil war was essential to restoring economic growth in the southwest African nation. Angola is a potentially wealthy nation, with substantial oil deposits and diamonds. But the civil war that began after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975 has killed more than 300,000 people and devastated the economy. Despite the end of the Cold War, the United States and the Soviets still provide assistance to the competing factions. The United States is giving UNITA $60 million in aid this year. The government controls Luanda, the capital, and other cities in the north and central parts of the country. UNITA claims control over much of the southeast. The government and UNITA have held five rounds of peace talks this year, with a sixth round scheduled for late January in Portugal. Progress toward a cease-fire has been reported, but there have been snags over recognition of UNITA as a political party, the mechanics of a cease-fire and integrating the two armies. The government rejects recognizing UNITA before a cease-fire. It also has rejected any international peacekeeping force to monitor a cease-fire as a violation of Angolan sovereignty. Savimbi called on the government to carry out the proposed change to a multiparty system. ``Then from there, there will be no need to say recognize UNITA or not,'' he said. Savimbi continued to call for an international force to monitor any cease-fire, similar to the U.N. force deployed in Namibia to oversee a cease-fire and elections. Namibia gained independence from South Africa in March under an agreement reached by Angola, Cuba and South Africa, with backing from the United States and the Soviet Union. The agreement also called for Cuba's 50,000 troops supporting the Angolan government to withdraw by July 1991. At least 35,000 have left so far. A similar U.N. force would give UNITA guarantees of protection during the transition to a multi-party system and free elections, Savimbi said. It also could provide stability when the rebel and government armies merged under an elected government, he said. Savimbi also called for ``just, fair and verifiable'' elections within a year after a cease-fire. The government has said it would take three years to set up voting.

DOC.HEAD: Dog Called As Witness In Cruelty Case
DOC.TEXT: A dog appearing as a witness in a cruelty case against his owner helped the defense considerably when he licked his master's face in court, the prosecution acknowledged Thursday. King, a beagle-pointer crossbreed, ``was led in because the judge had asked to see him, and taken out after a while,'' said prosecutor Clas Erik Ause in the central town of Namdal. ``He seemed very unoffended (against his owner) and at one stage licked his face,'' the prosecutor said. The local Animal Protection League had reported King's owner, Inge Skomsvold, to the police. The league said it had received reports from Skomsvold's neighbors that he beat King. Along with the evidence from King, the court heard testimony from neighbors who gave conflicting reports on how the dog was treated. The prosecution asked the court to give Skomsvold a $500 fine and ban him from keeping animals for five years. But Ause said that after Wednesday's hearing the outcome of the case was ``open.'' The verdict was due this week.

DOC.HEAD: Greece Plans To Sell Yacht Donated By Onassis, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: The government plans to sell the luxury yacht that shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis donated to it in his will, a magazine reported Thursday. The 325-foot yacht once hosted royalty, heads of state and leading jet-set personalities. Onassis also used it as the base of his shipping operations. Opera singer Maria Callas, once romantically involved with Onassis, had her own suite on the yacht. And Jacqueline Kennedy, who later married Onassis, was another frequent guest. Onassis died in 1975. He stipulated in his will that if his daughter Christina did not want the yacht - named after her - it should go to the Greek government. Christina Onassis died in 1988. The yacht was handed over to the Greek navy in 1978 and was renamed the Argo. It has seldom been used since. The weekly magazine Tahydromos reported Thursday that Greece was preparing to auction it. The former Canadian submarine chaser was bought by Onassis in the 1950s and was converted into a luxurious palace, complete with priceless works of art and faucets of gold.

DOC.HEAD: Stateside Preparations Include Lecture on Arab Culture
DOC.TEXT: Troops bound for Saudi Arabia are getting a one-week course from an Army unit based here so they can learn the Arab world's cultural and legal taboos before their boots hit the desert sand. ``We can't be sending people to Desert Shield if they're only halfway prepared,'' said William Allbritton, deputy director for Plans, Training and Mobilization at Aberdeen Proving Ground 40 miles northeast of Baltimore. ``Often their home post has taken care of a lot, but we still have to make certain everything is in order. If it isn't they won't go. No ifs, ands or buts.'' Much of the program is consumed by routine processing - dental examinations, the issuance of gas masks, and help in preparing wills. And there are classified briefings on anti-terrorists measures and the rules of engagement. Wednesdays are for lectures on Arab culture, law and climate, as well as the international rules of war. Jerry Hurst, a civilian Army employee who has lived in Saudi Arabia, recounted in a lecture on Arab culture his shock when a member of the Saudi National Guard held his hand as they left a meeting in Riyadh. Hurst said his Saudi friend told him, ``Don't get the wrong idea. It's part of our culture.'' Hurst and others in the orientation warned against insulting the Saudis' Islamic beliefs and their women. Capt. R. Pete Hasterton, who lectured on Saudi law, said the U.S. command has issued a general order forbidding gambling, drinking or drug use for the troops and civilian workers. All are crimes in Saudi Arabia. Hasterton also advised the servicemen that adultery is a capital offense and premarital sex carries a long prison sentence. None of the seven women in the audience said they were put off by the subordinant status of women in Saudi Arabia. ``It doesn't worry me at all,'' said Cindy Martinez of Corpus Cristi, Texas, a civilian whose job status is classified. ``I'm ready to comply. I don't want to get into any trouble. Basically, I'll stay in my area and not wander off.''

DOC.HEAD: Top Noriega Co-Defendant Pleads Guilty To Giving Payoffs To Deposed Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Del Cid, who...', with 2 grafs to ADD that sentencing date not sent, UPDATE with quote from U.S. attorney's office. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `The defendant's..'. CORRECTS style on del Cid throughout.
DOC.TEXT: A top co-defendant in the Manuel Noriega case today pleaded guilty to giving drug payoffs directly to the deposed Panamanian leader. Luis del Cid, a former lieutenant colonel under Noriega, entered his plea this morning before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler, capping almost a year of plea negotiations with the government. ``Yes I transported the money, but, well, I am repented of having done so,'' del Cid told the judge. ``What I was doing was following orders of a superior officer.'' Del Cid acknowledged making at least three separate cash transactions for Noriega. He admitted to the government's contention that he gave Noriega $100,000 in cash from drug pilot Floyd Carlton Caceres in November 1982. He also delivered an envelope with $150,000 cash from Carlton nd later picked up a suitcase stuffed with cash - all of which was delivered to Noriega. Among the admissions by del Cid was agreement with government claims that he accompanied Noriega to a meeting with Fidel Castro in Cuba in the summer of 1984 to discuss the seizure of a drug cartel lab they had paid the Panamanian leader to protect. Del Cid's plea negotiations stalled in March because of his fear that following a U.S. sentence, Panama would demand his return for criminal prosecution. The plea agreement was signed Wednesday. ``The Department of Justice has now agreed to oppose deporting or extraditing my client,'' defense attorney Sam Burstyn said. Del Cid was an aide to Noriega at the time of their capture following the U.S. invasion in 1989. Prosecutors have charged he acted as a liaison and money courier between drug traffickers and Noriega. Del Cid, who faced up to 70 years in prison, could be free under the agreement after serving as little as two years, Burstyn said. No sentencing date was set at today's hearing. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, released a statement that said that del Cid's the admission of guilt today is significant. ``We will carefully consider any cooperation and truthful testimony before making a recommendation (regarding sentencing) to the court,'' the statement said. The defendant's testimony could back up that of government witness Floyd Carlton Caceres, a former drug pilot who served 4{ years in prison. Del Cid is accused of accepting $200,000 in cocaine profits from Carlton, who prosecutors said had cut a deal with Noriega at a meeting in 1983 to pay the money in exchange for Panamanian protection of a U.S.-bound drug shipment. The government has said that the money was then passed on to Noriega. A Noriega attorney professed little concern about del Cid's possible testimony. ``He's just another witness who is getting paid for his testimony,'' said Jon May. ``Del Cid is just one among many witnesses who are getting the keys to the jailhouse door from a government that's desperate to shore up its case.'' The defense previously disputed prosecution claims that del Cid was a key aide to Noriega, forcing the U.S. attorney's office to acknowledge he was not head of Panamanian intelligence, as they first asserted. Noriega is accused of taking $4.6 million in bribes to ship cocaine through Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Medieval Painting Stolen from Prague Gallery
DOC.TEXT: A 16th century painting by Lucas Cranach the Elder worth $200,000 was stolen from Prague's National Gallery, a newspaper said Thursday. The daily Mlada Fronta Dnes said ``An Enamored Old Man,'' painted by the German master in 1531, disappeared on Wednesday. Czechoslovak radio and television announced the theft in news bulletins, describing the missing picture. Customs authorities also were alerted, the daily said. The Gallery's 13,500 paintings in several locations in Prague include Rubens' ``Gathering of the Olympic Gods'' and Titian's ``Lady at her Toilet.'' They make up what is considered one of the finest collections of medieval art in central Europe. Czechoslovakia has become a popular target for international crime after the revolution last year that lifted travel restrictions and eased police controls. ``Problems with guarding valuable works of art in the National Gallery have apparently not yet been solved,`` the daily said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Offer to Release Hostage Welcomed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 10th pvs, `Swiss Foreign...' to UPDATE with U.N. secretary-general also cautiously optimistic. Pickup 11th, `In Belgium...'
DOC.TEXT: Several governments quickly welcomed Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's announcement today that he intends to release all foreigners detained in his country and Kuwait. However, governments were waiting for confirmation and details of how the release would be organized. ``We greatly welcome this news. We have been pressing throughout for the return of all our hostages. The sooner they are back the better,'' said a spokesman for the British Foreign Office. Irish Foreign Affairs Minister Gerry Collins said in Dublin that he was very pleased by the report, but ``we are somewhat cautious and will be so until such time as the news is confirmed.'' There are nearly 1,200 Britons held in Iraq and Kuwait, and about 250 Irish citizens. A spokesman at the Kuwaiti Embassy in London said, ``Let's hope this is a prelude to him (Saddam) leaving Kuwait altogether.'' Denmark's Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen commented: ``The decision underscores how crucial it has been to seek a united solution on the detained foreigners by means of international solidarity and efforts within the U.N. framework.'' ``We must now hope that the coming diplomatic efforts lead to Saddam Hussein's unconditional withdrawal of his troops out of Kuwait,'' Ellemann-Jensen said. Sixteen Danish hostages remain in Iraq. Swiss Foreign Minister Andrea Reichlin said the government was reacting cautiously to the news. Switzerland has seven citizens detained in Iraq. At the United Nations in New York, Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar was also cautiously optimistic. ``If all the information is confirmed, it will be a very good development, but I always need the proper official information about it,'' he said. But the U.N. chief said Iraq had not contacted him about the hostages. In Belgium, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization termed Saddam's call for the release of all foreign hostages ``very good news'' but stressed Iraq must abide by all other United Nations demands. ``If he (Saddam) really does what he says he is going to do, it will be very good news,'' said a NATO official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. At the headquarters of the Gulf Support Group in London, spokesman Andy Charles said the relatives of the hostages were ``cautiously optimistic and cautiously delighted, but we've had a lot of similar announcemnts in the past which have not borne fruit.'' Some relatives, however, were more excited. ``I'm over the moon. It's what we've prayed and prayed for,'' said Sue Dorrington, whose husband, David, is being held in Baghdad. ``I have been in tears all morning since I heard the news. I just hope it is true,'' said Linda Grant, part of a group of 30 women related to British Airways employees who planned to go to Baghdad this weekend. ``I am ... shaking like a leaf with relief and high hopes,'' said Deborah Pepper, who was also planning to go to Baghdad to seek the release of her husband John, a British Airways employee.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities: Bird Blows Whistle on Thief
DOC.TEXT: Frankie LaDel was sitting pretty until Coco the cockatiel blew the whistle on him, authorities said. LaDel, 20, was arrested Tuesday on charges of breaking into a home in this Florida Panhandle city and taking Coco, $100 in change and $4,715 worth of camera gear, electronics equipment, jewelry, shoes and food, police said. After the break-in, LaDel left Coco with the owner of Tats Are Us Tattoo Emporium, asking him to keep the bird, which he said he intended as a gift, until Christmas, according to a police report. But Coco couldn't keep his beak shut when police officer Jim Walker stopped by the parlor Tuesday night. ``All of a sudden the bird started singing, and I remembered the burglary,'' Walker said. ``He'd just been squawking and making bird screams and then he started whistling.'' It was the theme song from television's ``The Andy Griffith Show.'' Walker recalled that Phillip Blankenship, Coco's owner, had told an investigator his bird could whistle the tune from the comedy show about a small-town sheriff. The tattoo parlor owner told police the bird had been brought in by LaDel. A customer told police that LaDel could be found at a nearby department store. LaDel was arrested in a parking lot, where he was having car trouble, and confessed to Monday's burglary as well as an earlier break-in at the same house, Walker said. The case was a first for the officer. ``I've never had a bird squeal on somebody,'' Walker said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Rally Against Communists, Days Before Key Vote
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of supporters of the main opposition to Communist power in Serbia defied a police ban Thursday to hold a final rally in the bitter campaign for control of Yugoslavia's largest republic. Opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, a candidate in Sunday's election for the Serbian presidency, charged that a supporter of his Serbian Renewal Movement had been shot and killed by a rival Communist. The charge further escalated tensions in the republic. The crowd of 15,000 to 20,000 people chanted ``Down with Red Bandits,'' and ``Down with Red Fascists'' after Draskovic announced the death of Slobodan Ivanovic, 30, in the southern Serbian town of Vranje late Wednesday. Sunday's election in Serbia and in the republic of Montenegro is considered the crucial last act in a decade-long struggle for control of Yugoslavia's future following the death in 1980 of Josip Broz Tito, who governed with an iron hand for 35 years. The leaders of Yugoslavia's diverse regions have waged an increasingly bitter battle since Tito's death, with tensions now so high that the CIA has predicted the country may disintegrate within 18 months and civil war could break out. The Serbian election, the republic's first free vote in 50 years,pits the ruling hard-l in other republics. Croatia, Bosnia-Hercegovina and Macedonia deeply oppose any such expansion of the power of the Serbs, the largest of Yugoslavia's many ethnic groups. In the struggle to shape the country, the Western republics of Croatia and Slovenia, where center-right parties ousted Communists in spring elections, want more independence from the federation. They threaten to secede if they don't get it. They are pitted against Serbia and the poor southern republics who favor a strong central government. As Sunday's elections approach, Draskovic and Milosevic have been running virtually even in polls. Many Serbs, frustrated by Milosevic's attempts to block political and economic reforms, apparently have turned to center-right parties that promise Western-oriented changes. Milosevic repeatedly has refused to negotiate with Croatia and Slovenia on the country's future. Draskovic, on the other hand, has said he would ``negotiate with the devil'' if it benefits Serbia. Milosevic and Draskovic face 30 lesser rivals running for Serbia's president. Also at stake are 250 seats in the republic's Parliament, which will be contested by 53 parties. In districts where there is no clear winner, runoff elections will be held on Dec. 23.

DOC.HEAD: 3-Year-Old Takes Loaded Gun To Nursery School
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, `Officials confirmed...', to UPDATE with quote from teacher at school. Picks up 4th graf pfs, `The child...'.
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old boy whose nursery school teacher found a loaded gun sticking out his jacket told police he took the gun to school to show his friends.
