Isolyn Hong, an aide at the College Community Child Care Center in the borough of Brooklyn, said she noticed the butt of the gun sticking out of the boy's jacket Wednesday. School officials thought the gun might be a toy but called police anyway. Officers confirmed it was a Raven .25-caliber automatic. It had one round of ammunition in the chamber and three rounds in the clip. ``It was an upsetting situation, yet we are thankful we were able to discover the gun and no one got hurt,'' said Gail Dubins, a teacher at the College Community Child Care Center. ``There were no tears to be shed.'' ``It makes you open your eyes,'' she said today. ``Everybody has to be aware with children; you can't take anything for granted. It was a scary experience.'' The child, who was not identified beccause of his age, was placed in city custody and the owner of the gun was arrested, said Sgt. Grace Ridley, a police spokeswoman. Police Wednesday charged Lloyd Flowers of the borough of Brooklyn with criminal possession of a weapon and endangering the life of a child. Flowers, 27, a friend of the child's family, drove the boy to school Wednesday, Ridley said. The child told police he took the gun off the front seat of Flowers' van. Ridley said the Department of Child Welfare Services will decide if the child will be returned to his parents. Other children have been found with loaded weapons at school, but the 3-year-old was believed to be the youngest in the city's history. In January 1989, a 5-year-old kindergarten student in the Bronx took a loaded handgun into his school cafeteria and a 6-year-old took a .25-caliber gun to his class for show and tell.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Rejects Linking Iraqi Pullout to Palestine Issue.
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 6 grafs new with Bush rejecting linkage to Palestinian issue. Editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today renewed its opposition to a Mideast Peace conference as the idea surfaced anew in the United Nations. President Bush said there is ``no linkage'' between an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait and Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian territories. The United States will not give Saddam Hussein ``some face-saving way out of something he shouldn't have gotten into in the first place,'' Bush told a news conference in Santiago, Chile. ``The question is the aggression against Kuwait. There will be and is no linkage to the Palestinian or the West Bank question,'' he said. With backing from the Palestine Liberation Organization and Arab governments, a group of neutral nations has been trying to persuade the U.N. Security Council to approve a resolution calling for a peace conference that would discuss Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The United States has sought in the past to resolve Palestinian demands for national rights and to end Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, captured in the 1967 Mideast war, Bush said. ``And we continue to be very interested'' in moving forward the search for a solution, he added. But, he said, Saddam has tried from the start to justify his invasion of Kuwait by saying it would lead to a solution for the Palestinians. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told the House Foreign Affairs Committee that U.S. policy on te question of an international conference has not changed. ``We've taken the position for a long time that an international conference, properly structured, at an appropriate time, might be useful. That has been the policy of the United States for a long time. We are not now recommending that an international conference on the Arab-Israeli conflict be held,'' Baker said. He added: ``Nor are we supporting a resolution in the Security Council that would seek to convene such a conference. Precisely because of our consistent position that we will not link the gulf crisis and the Arab-Israeli dispute, this is certainly not an appropriate time for an international conference.'' Diplomatic sources said U.S. diplomats in New York were trying at this point to modify the proposed text to make the call for a peace conference more a long-range goal than an immediate demand. ``We are against an international conference,'' said Avi Pazner, spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. ``We favor face-to-face negotiations with the Arabs. Peace with Egypt did not come as a result of an international conference. We hope there will be no such resolution.'' Pazner was in Washington preparing for a visit next week by Shamir. The prime minister will meet with President Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and key members of Congress. As the Bush administration seeks to maintain Arab support against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, supporters of the Palestinians have seized the occasion to promote a peace conference and other measures designed to force concessions from Israel. Although Bush and Baker have said they would not link their campaign to force Iraq out of Kuwait with the Palestinian issue, Baker said last week the problem must be addressed. He also said he had made no commitments in exchange for support of the resolution approved by the Security Council last Thursday to authorize force if Iraq does not withdraw its troops voluntarily by Jan. 15. Shamir intends to stand by his proposal that Palestinians on the West Bank and Gaza vote to choose leaders who would negotiate with Israel five years of limited self-rule, Pazner said. It was approved by the Bush administration earlier this year. But when Baker added provisions to permit Palestinians expelled from the territories to participate in the negotiations, the Israeli Cabinet refused to go along. Pazner said Shamir's visit to Washington was initiated by the president. The Israeli spokesman described relations between the two countries as good. Bush and Baker have excluded Israel from the diverse coalition they organized in an attempt to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Pazner said Israel has no objections to that arrangement. part of the decision-making process and our policy is very clear - we want to stay out of it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: White House Sees Saddam Hostage Offer as 'Hopeful sign'
EDs. Top 20 grafs new with details from Bush, Aylwin news conference; picks up pvs graf 15, 'Bush arrived; edits at bottom for length.
DOC.TEXT: Amid a spate of bombing incidents carried out by leftist guerrillas, President Bush arrived here today and hailed Chile's ``democratic renaissance'' and pro-growth economic policies. The bombings apparently were designed to dramatize guerrilla opposition to Bush's call for conservative economic policies throughout the hemisphere. No injuries were reported. Bush, at a news conference after talks with President Patricio Aylwin, also pledged to go ``as far as we can'' to bring the killers of Orlando Letelier to justice, and sought to deflect anger over last year's ban on Chilean grapes in a poison scare. Bush said his Enterprise for the Americas initiative to spur trade with the continent ``is not going to be an empty slogan'' and will not be thwarted by his own bureaucracy. Here as elsewhere in Bush's week-long goodwill tour of South America, the latest news from Iraq stole the headlines. Bush learned aboard Air Force One on his flight here from Buenos Aires of Saddam Hussein's change of heart on holding foreign hostages. Bush said he hoped it was true, but ``no single hostage should have been taken in the first place.'' He said Hussein ``needs to get out of Kuwait without trying to complicate this matter'' with his call for a Middle East peace conference. Before Bush arrived, leftist guerillas exploded a half-dozen bombs overnight at sites with U.S. ties, including four Mormon chapels, a new McDonald's restaurant and a downtown park outside a hotel where some officials in Bush's advance party were staying. Police reported no injuries. One dissident scored a bull's eye with an egg on Bush's limousine, splattering it over the door next to the presidential seal. Most of the crowds that lined Santiago's streets were friendly, however. Bush and Aylwin faced the press in the small garden outside the president's private home before Bush flew by helicopter to the Pacific port city of Valparaiso to address Chile's Congress in its new home. At the red-carpet welcome for Air Force One at the airport, Aylwin said, ``Mr. President, we welcome you with joy.'' ``We value your presence in our land. We share common ideals,'' said Aylwin, elected last December as Chile restored democracy after the 17-year military rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. ``No where among the nations of this continent has the pace of free market reform gone farther, faster than right here in Chile,'' Bush said. ``Chile's return to the ranks of the world's democracies is cause for pride and celebration,'' he said. Bush said, ``These past few days from Brasilia to Montevideo to Buenos Aires, I have witnessed first hand the irresistible power of the democratic ideal. Around the world, across the Americas, a democratic renaissance is under way.'' Letelier, a former Chilean foreign minister and staunch foe of strongman Gen. Augusto Pinochet, was killed by a bomb on a Washington street in 1976, along with an American associate Ronnie Moffitt. A U.S. court indicted three Chilean army officers and secret police members, but the Chilean Supreme Court blocked extradition. Aylwin has promised to reopen the case with a special civilian prosecutor and to compensate the families. Bush said, ``I think the president (Aylwin) has moved ...to get that contentious matter cleared up. ... As far as we can, we want to cooperate fully.'' Aylwin promised that ``a full clarification of truth and justice'' will be made. On the grape embargo, imposed after Food and Drug Administration inspectors reportedly found two grapes laced with cyanide in the hold of a ship in Philadelphia, Chilean growers are demanding compensation for losses estimated at $330 million. Bush said he planned to ``discuss this very sensitive question'' later with Aylwin, but asked for understanding. Citing the deaths of several people who ingested poisoned Tylenol in the early 1980s, Bush said, ``It isn't the Chilean grape that was singled out. This is the way in the United States we approach matters that can adversely affect the health of our people.'' Bush arrived at a time when U.S. economic and military ties have been restored to normalcy with the removal of sanctions imposed during the years of military rule. On Wednesday police used tear gas and water cannons to scatter 400 demonstrators marching through the streets and chanting anti-Bush slogans. The Bush administration prefaced the visit by lifting sanctions imposed during the dictatorship of Pinochet. In late November, Washington allowed Chile back into the General Preferences System, which grants tariff concessions to exports from various countries. Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley said that should allow Chile to increase exports to the United States by around $100 million from the present $1.45 billion a year. The Reagan administration excluded Chile from the system in 1988 to protest Pinochet's repression of the Chilean labor movement. Last weekend, the administration lifted a ban on military aid and the sale of military equipment imposed in 1976 following the Letelier and Moffitt murders. According to protocol, the 75-year-old Pinochet, who is still army commander, should attend several ceremonies with Bush. But Pinochet has long accused the United States of interfering in Chilean affairs. When King Juan Carlos of Spain, another strong supporter of democratic changes, visited Chile in October, Pinochet snubbed him by leaving Santiago for what were officially described as military activities.

DOC.HEAD: Former Havana Archbishop Dies at Age 62
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Francisco Oves Fernandez, the retired Roman Catholic archbishiop of Havana, Cuba, died of an apparent heart attack. He was 62. Oves was among hundreds of priests driven from Cuba in the early 1960s as Communists led by Fidel Castro consolidated power. At the time of his death Tuesday, Oves was pastor of Santo Nino de Atocha Catholic Church in El Paso. ``He was a man who suffered a lot in his life, particularly after he went back to Cuba,'' said Irma Cordova, who heads a youth group at Santo Nino de Atocha. Oves was allowed to return to Cuba in the late 1960s, and in 1969 was ordained auxiliary bishop of Cienfuegos, Cuba. Oves was named archbishop of Havana - the capital of a nation that was officially atheist - in 1970 by Pope Paul VI. Oves generally avoided conflict with the government. He retired as archbishop in 1982 and came to El Paso at the request of the Vatican, said the Rev. Edward Roden-Lucero, spokesman for the El Paso Catholic Diocese. A funeral Mass was held Thursday. He is survived by two brothers and two sisters.

DOC.HEAD: President Resigns, Hands Over Power
LaserPhotos NY10,DHA1
DOC.TEXT: President Hussain Muhammad Ershad resigned Thursday after ruling the country for eight years, handing power to an interim leader chosen by the opposition. Ershad, a former army general who took power in a 1982 coup, had faced seven weeks of often violent nationwide protests against his government. On Tuesday, he promised to step down as soon as a replacement was named. Earlier Thursday, Ershad lifted the state of emergency in effect since Nov. 27. Later, he administered the oath of office to Shahabuddin Ahmed, a political independent nominated by the country's opposition parties as caretaker vice-president. Then he signed a letter of resignation, making him acting president. ``Allah bless you,'' he told Shahabuddin after the 15-minute ceremony in the president's office. ``You have our blessings. I want peace to return to society.'' Originally, Shahabuddin's nomination was to be approved by Parliament on Saturday, but Ershad unexpectedly dissolved the lawmaking body early Thursday. Constitutional experts and opposition sources said it had been doubtful that a majority of legislators would emerge in public for a vote. Two-thirds of Parliament belonged to Ershad's Jatiya Party, and many were reluctant to appear in public for fear of being attacked by anti-Ershad activists. Shahabuddin, 62, chief justice of the Supreme Court, will supervise elections to Parliament, which must be re-constituted within 90 days. The new body will decide whether to retain power or hold presidential elections. ``I have no political ambition. I shall not stay here beyond the mandated 90 days,'' said Shahbuddin, 62, after he was sworn in. ``During this period, I shall try to ensure peace and stability, hold free and fair elections and hand over power to the elected representatives of the people.'' Reporters who attended the transfer of power ceremony said Ershad's eyes were filled with tears as he bade farewell to chiefs of the country's army, navy and air force and his personal staff. Army chief Lt. Gen. Nooruddin Khan played a pivotal role in persuading Ershad to resign, according to well-placed sources. He acted as a middleman between the president and the opposition after junior army officers advised Khan they would not support a man opposed by the people, the sources said. After Thursday's ceremony, Ershad and Khan shook hands and embraced. Ershad then left for his home. Ershad was the army chief when he took power in a bloodless coup eight years ago. He resigned from the army after winning presidential elections in 1986, which the opposition claimed were rigged. Charges of vote fraud also dogged the 1986 and 1988 elections to parliament, which were won by Ershad's Jatiya or People's Party. The opposition made vote fraud the pivotal point of their protest campaign when Ershad announced his candidacy for the June 1991 presidential poll. Ershad's resignation capped a dizzying reversal of his political fortunes. Three weeks ago, he was confidently predicting success in next year's presidential elections. The opposition campaign to oust him had long been little more than an irritation during his rule of this impoverished nation of 107 million people. But it gained new impetus with the end of longstanding political differences between Sheik Hasina and Khaleda Zia, the opposition leaders. Its growth continued even after Ershad declared the state of emergency in late November and called out the army to quell street protests. Hundreds of doctors, professors, merchant seamen, civil servants and some Jatiya Party members of Parliament resigned to back the opposition call. On Monday, Ershad offered to resign 45 days before the next presidential polls. The opposition rejected the offer and intensified its protest campaign. Then, on Tuesday night, Ershad promised to resign immediately. One of his last acts before resigning was to withdraw the state of emergency and restore civil rights. The opposition claims that at least 100 people were killed by government troops during the emergency. Ershad's administration said only six people had died. The choice of Shahabuddin to head the interim government was made by Ms. Hasina and Mrs. Zia. Ms. Hasina, leader of the left-of-center Awami League, is the daughter of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Bangladesh's first president. Mrs. Zia, head of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, is the widow of another former president, Ziaur Rahman. Both men were assassinated. Ershad is the country's ninth president since it gained independence from Pakistan in 1971. All were installed by military action.

DOC.HEAD: Outgoing Soviet Spokesman Cited by U.S. Communicators' Group
DOC.TEXT: Gennady I. Gerasimov, whose statements of ``new thinking'' in Soviet foreign policy made him a familiar figure on the world stage, has been named ``communicator of the year'' by a group of American public affairs officials. Gerasimov, chief spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, lost much of his visibility earlier this year when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev named his own presidential spokesman. The 60-year-old former Soviet journalist has been replaced by Vitaly Churkin, an aide to Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Gerasimov is expected to be named ambassador to Portugal. The National Association of Government Communicators, whose members include public affairs employees of federal, state and local governments in the United States, will present its annual award Friday. The group's announcement said the selection of Gerasimov marks the first time the organization has selected a foreign communicator. ``It would have been unthinkable to consider a Soviet official as recipient of this award just a few short years ago,'' the announcement said. Previous winners have been one-time State Department spokesman Bernard Kalb, former U.S. Surgeon General C. Everett Koop and Voice of America Beijing correspondent Al Pessin, who covered the 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. As the Kremlin emerged from its hostile, secretive stance in the latter 1980s, Gerasimov rose to prominence as a spokesman for the new leadership. His frequent press briefings, fluent English and acerbic wit made him an oft-cited source in news stories about developments in the Soviet Union. He was criticized, however, for his inability to manage the exploding public affairs operation of the Soviet government as Gorbachev captured the world stage.

DOC.HEAD: Zoo Loses Rhinoceros in Attempt To Trim Her Horn
DOC.TEXT: Lewis Greene, flecks of blood clinging to his glasses, still looked a little dazed as he watched workers hose down the rhinoceros house at the Audubon Zoo. Greene had just lost - if not a loved one - a longtime companion. Jessie, a 32-year-old African white rhinoceros, died as veterinarians removed part of her horn in hopes the operation would enable them to breed her before she was too old. ``Both of our males have very small horns and both females have large horns. We think that prevented them from mating. The females with larger horns would spar with the males and were able to keep them away,'' said Greene, the zoo keeper in charge of rhinos. ``Other zoos that have had the problem have had good luck reducing the female's horn,'' Greene said. ``Putting them on equal footing, so to speak.'' Because rhinoceroses in the wild are disappearing, zoos are trying to breed those they have in accordance with an international species survival plan. All of the five surviving species are endangered because of habitat destruction and illegal hunting, especially for their horns, said Curt Burnette, Audubon's general curator. The horns, made of matted hair, are considered an aphrodisiac in the Far East, where they sell for as much as $18,000 a pound. ``Their situation in the wild is from bad to critical,'' Burnette said. ``Of the five species, the white is the most plentiful. There are probably several thousand of them. The Sumatran rhino probably numbers in the dozens. In 10 years I doubt there will be any rhinos existing in the wild.'' Jessie's biological clock was ticking away and officials hoped to breed her before it was too late. Since the four rhinoceroses at Audubon were all caught in the wild, adding their genes to the genetic pool of captured rhinos would improve the long-term chances of the species surviving, Greene said. ``Short term there will be rhinos in zoos, but long-term their survival, even there could be in jeopardy. If only 20 percent of the captive rhinos breed, as the years go by, there'll be fewer and fewer that can reproduce,'' Greene said. The operation to reduce Jessie's horn was considered safe, Burnette said. The animal had been anesthetized previously without difficulty, he said. ``It was low risk and we were willing to take a small risk because we have to,'' Burnette said. ``Her genes weren't crucial, but they were important. Since she was captured in the wild ... the offspring would be new to the captive breeding stock.'' After the horn was trimmed, the four veterinarians were doing some blood tests and an ultrasound test on the animal's reproductive organs when she stopped breathing, Burnette said. A 12-hour necropsy was done to determine what caused the rhino to die. Burnette said it might take weeks before results were known. Jessie still might contribute to the overall genetic pool, Burnette said. Veterinarians harvested unfertilized eggs, which will be frozen in hopes of fertilizing them and implanting them in another rhinoceros. ``That's just a hope at this time,'' Burnette said. ``The technique hasn't been perfected. It's kind of like having your body frozen when you die and hope they'll be able to bring you back later. But, when something is so close to disappearing, you take every chance you can to prevent that.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Pop diva Madonna was ordered by a judge Thursday to trim a hedge and pine tree at her Hollywood Hills home. Superior Court Judge Sally Disco ruled Madonna violated an agreement with neighbor Donald Robinson requiring her to keep her shrubbery trimmed so it wouldn't interfere with his view. The judge rejected Robinson's claim of $1 million damages for the loss of his view, but she ordered Madonna to pay Robinson's attorney fees. Liz Rosenberg, publicist for the singer, was out of the office Thursday and couldn't be reached, a receptionist said. Madonna's lawyer, Meghan Serwin, and Robinson's attorney, Robert Rigdon, were not in their offices Thursday for comment. Madonna said in a deposition she bought the house above the Sunset Strip because of its spectacular view and privacy. But after she moved in, she said she noticed gardeners peering through her hedges. Disco ruled there was insufficient evidence to support Madonna's cross-claim against Robinson that said he had harmed her by infringing on her privacy. --- SEVIERVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Dolly Parton's younger sister has filed a worker's compensation lawsuit against the theme park the entertainer owns. Freida Parton, 33, said she injured her back closing a dressing room door at Dollywood, in the foothills of the Smoky Mountains. In the lawsuit filed this week in Sevier County Chancery Court, Freida Parton says she sustained the injury on June 10, 1989, and underwent back surgery. She seeks unspecified benefits under the state's worker's compensation act. Barbara Headla, marketing manager at Dollywood, did not return a telephone message left at the park. Freida Parton and her twin brother, Floyd, are the next-to-youngest of the 12 Parton siblings. Dolly Parton opened Dollywood in 1985. She co-starred in ``Steel Magnolias'' last year and was host of 1987's short-lived variety television series ``Dolly.'' --- AUSTIN, Texas (AP) - Former congresswoman Barbara Jordan has agreed to serve as special counsel on ethics for Gov.-elect Ann Richards. ``Barbara Jordan is recognized throughout the country as one of the most important voices in ethics and government that one could possibly have,'' Richards said Wednesday. In 1966, Jordan became the state's first black state senator. In 1972, she was the first black elected to Congress from the South since Reconstruction. Once considered a possible Democratic vice presidential candidate, Jordan ended her political career after three terms in the House. She became a professor at the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs at the University of Texss. Richards said Jordan would counsel members of her administration on ethical conduct and help draft legislation on ethics. Bill Cryer, Richards' press secretary, said Jordan was taking the post on ``an unpaid, voluntary basis'' and would continue teaching. --- LONDON (AP) - Dame Joan Sutherland is coming out of retirement after just two months, but for only one performance: a New Year's Eve farewell to Covent Garden, the Royal Opera House said Thursday. Sutherland, the coloratura soprano with amazing voice range, will be joined by Italian tenor Luciano Pavarotti and U.S. mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne. ``Although Dame Joan has retired, she wants to make this one - and only one - exception, to come to London to say goodbye to Covent Garden where she began her opera career in 1952,'' said Kathleen Wilkinson, the Royal Opera spokeswoman. Sutherland, 64, will play the ``star guest'' at Prince Orlofsky's party in Act II of ``Die Fledermaus'' by Johann Strauss. The opera will be conducted by her husband, Richard Bonynge and will be televised live by the British Broadcasting Corp. Pavarotti and Horne will appear as fellow party guests. Sutherland, known as ``La Stupenda'' (the magnificent one), retired Oct. 2 with a performance in her hometown of Sydney, Australia. In October, Sutherland withdrew from performances at Covent Garden, saying she wanted people to remember her voice in its prime. --- SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Beach Boys' reclusive founder Brian Wilson made a private concert appearance before a group that included political cartoonist Garry Trudeau as the two joined in an AIDS fund-raising effort. Looking uncomfortable in a dark suit and tie, a nervous Wilson played piano and sang Wednesday at the private reception. A few dozen patrons paid at least $125 each for the 15-minute performance. ``I enjoyed it,'' Wilson said after the performance. ``I had to close my eyes. That's the only way I can really feel my music, closing my eyes.'' Wilson had said before the show that he was ``scared to death.'' Trudeau, creator of the comic strip ``Doonesbury,'' sat cross-legged on the floor during the concert. Among other tunes, Wilson played selections from the Beach Boys' 1966 ``Pet Sounds'' album, which recently came out on compact disc. Andy Lippincott, a character in ``Doonesbury'' who died from AIDS, had looked forward to the disc's release. Before the reception, Wilson and Trudeau attended the opening of an art galley with 59 original drawings of editions of the comic strip that dealt with Lippincott's death. The drawings are being sold to raise money for the NAMES Project, which is coordinating the construction of a huge memorial quilt dedicated to AIDS victims.

DOC.HEAD: Liz Taylor Jurors Asked About Alcoholism and Perfume
LaserPhoto LA16 of Dec. 5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, `Jury selection ...,' to UPDATE with jury selection resuming today.
DOC.TEXT: Potential jurors in Elizabeth Taylor's legal battle with an ex-boyfriend over dollars and scents were asked about alcoholism, AIDS and what type of perfume they wear. Miss Taylor's former beau, Henry Wynberg, is suing the actress for a share of the profits from her perfume, Passion, claiming she breached a contract with him to market the fragrance. During jury selection Wednesday in Superior Court, two potential jurors disclosed they splash on Passion but said it wouldn't affect their objectivity. Today, two potential jurors said they had never seen the Academy Award-winning actress on film; a third said he had seen most of her films, since he had been going to movies since the silent film era. Miss Taylor reacted with a mock expression of horror, then laughed along with others in the courtroom. Wynberg, a former used-car salesman who courted Miss Taylor between her two marriages to Richard Burton, claims he created the fragrance. Miss Taylor signed a contract with Wynberg in 1975 but in 1986 struck a deal instead with Chesebrough-Ponds Inc., the company that ultimately launched Passion. Wynberg then sued for 72 percent of the some $70 million a year Passion generates in profit. He also argued that her alcoholism and weight gain destroyed the glamorous image he counted on to market the cosmetics. Miss Taylor contended that Wynberg's criminal record led her to abandon their business deal, and on Wednesday she won permission from Judge Coleman Swart to tell jurors about her former boyfriend's criminal past. Wynberg's attorneys had tried to bar, as irrelevant and prejudicial, evidence that he once pleaded guilty to statutory rape, providing drugs to underage girls in return for sex and taking pornographic photos of girls. Miss Taylor's attorney, Neil Papapiano, asked the 50 prospective jurors whether they knew alcoholics and had any views about rehabilitation programs. Most said they knew alcoholics and approved of efforts to help them. ``It has been fairly well publicized that Miss Taylor at one time had an alcohol abuse problem and went to the Betty Ford Clinic and since that time has had no problem,'' Papiano said. The lawyer also also asked potential jurors if they knew about Miss Taylor's work for AIDS research and how they felt about it. He said a percentage of her perfume profits go toward AIDS research.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Joins Children's Hospital Christmas Celebrations
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush brought some holiday cheer to Children's Hospital on Thursday and shared with the youngsters her fondest wish for a Christmas gift: ``Peace.'' ``We just started decorating the White House today,'' said Mrs. Bush. ``And now I've come here and I feel like Christmas has really started.'' It was Mrs. Bush's second Christmas visit to the Children's National Medical Center. Former First Lady Nancy Reagan visited every year during her eight years at the White House. The children vied for seats next to Mrs. Bush while the Peace Piper madrigal singers from Chopticon High School of Maryland regaled them with songs ranging from Elizabethan Christmas carols to The Reindeer Rap - ``Without us, Santa ain't nothin'.'' Gifts were presented to Mrs. Bush by two of the hospital's patients, Lorin Gerhardt, 9, of Waldorf, Md., and Jason Webster, of LaPlata, Md., 11. ``Just what I wanted,'' cried Mrs. Bush as she unwrapped a ribbon-bedecked rawhide dog bone. ``You were supposed to tell her it was for Millie,'' said the hospital's president Donald Brown, referring to the First Family's springer spaniel. The children also give her a teddy bear ornament for the White House Christmas tree and introduced her to the hospital's mascot, Ted E. Bear. Before joining the festivities in the hospital lobby, Mrs. Bush read ``The Wild Christmas Reindeer'' by Jan Brett to a group of young patients. The storytelling was taped for NBC-TV's special ``Christmas in Washington'' and will be aired on Dec. 19 at 10:00 p.m. EST. The First Lady chatted easily with the children who clamored to be picked up and held. ``My friend just asked me how old I was,'' she said, pointing to 10-year old Ryan Cotnoir of Fairfax, Va. ``I told him I was 65 ... and I told him George Bush was 66. `You're almost twins,' he said!'' Lorin said she was chosen to present the gifts to Mrs. Bushbecause she'd ``been around a long time.'' Lorin has been receiving treatment at Children's Hospital for cystic fibrosis since she was five weeks old. ``I like Mrs. Bush because she comes here not just because people ask her to, but because she really cares,'' said Lorin. And what did the First Lady want Santa to bring her? ``Peace,'' she said as she waved good-bye to the children.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Embraces Hostage Release, Warns Iraq to Leave Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts grafs 3-4, The State Department, on preparations for evacuation.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today welcomed Saddam Hussein's dramatic promise to free American and other hostages but insisted ``the man must leave Kuwait without reservation, without condition'' before the Gulf crisis can end. In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States had received official notification in Baghdad that the hostages - 900 Americans among them - would be set free. It was unclear when. The State Department, in a message for broadcast by the Voice of America, advised U.S. citizens in Iraq and Kuwait it was making preparations for their evacuation as soon as they are permitted to leave. ``Until that time, stay where you are, stay in touch with the U.S. embassy, and monitor the VOA closely,'' it said. ``We will let you know as soon as we have more information.'' Bush stressed that no deal with Saddam was in the works - or would be considered. ``There are no secret negotiations, direct or indirect with Iraq over this question,'' Bush said. ``None. And there will be none.'' He said he hoped the Iraqi decision to release the hostages from Kuwait was ``credible,'' and stressed, ``no single hostage should have been taken in the first place.'' Iraq invaded and occupied Kuwait on Aug. 2, triggering a crisis that involved a sequence of hostage-taking and partial releases. The Americans, and thousands others, continue to be held as part of Saddam's effort to use hostages as human shields against a possible attack. Saddam was quoted today as saying that diplomatic and military developments made the hostages unnecessary. Bush is in Chile as part of a five-nation swing through Latin America, but his attention was forced back to the Gulf crisis with word of Saddam's initiative. ``We are not going to get diverted from the full implementation of the United Nations resolutions in order to give him some face saving way out of something he shouldn't have gotten into in the first place,'' Bush said, again rejecting Saddam's calls to link resolution of the current crisis with the Arab-Israeli conflict. ``He doesn't need any face - he needs to get out of Kuwait without trying to complicate this matter. ... It is clear what his ploy is and that ploy is not going to be successful.'' Iraq on Wednesday accepted Bush's offer to send Baker to Baghdad for a face-to-face meeting with Saddam. In his testimony, Baker also rejected Iraqi demands that the talks include discussion of other Mideast crises. ``I will not be negotiating the Palestinian question or the civil war in Lebanon,'' Baker said. Bush made that point as well, saying: ``There will be and is no linkage.'' Nor, Bush said, would there be any concessions to Iraq. Of the hostage development, he said: ``This would be welcome if true but it will not change my thinking on his need to comply, 100 percent, without conditions, to the U.N. resolutions.'' ``I hope it shows that the strategy is working and that Saddam understands that his hostage policy has incurred the condemnation of the whole world,'' Bush said. He tempered his praise for the announcement with harsh criticism of Saddam's hostage taking. Like Baker, he said the promised release of hostages was far short of what needed to be done to end the crisis. ``We've got to continue to keep the pressure on,'' Bush said. ``The release of all hostages would be a very good thing but the problem is the aggression against Kuwait and the man must leave Kuwait without reservation, without condition.'' On Capitol Hill, Baker embraced the announcement from Baghdad but said nothing short of a complete withdrawal from Kuwait and restoration of its government would end the 4-month-old standoff. ``This is a welcome and significant development, but we do want to see it actually happen,'' Baker told the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``...It seems to me no coincidence that this comes just one week, just one week, after the international community has authorized the use of force.'' The initial administration reaction to the hostage announcement came from spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, who said, ``If it's true we'll do what is necessary to get our people out.'' Baker said anew that Bush hopes for a peaceful solution and has not decided whether to use force immediately should Saddam ignore a United Nations resolution demanding that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15. But he gave yet another pessimistic administration account on the impact sanctions have had against Iraq over the past four months and said waiting too long was not in the United States interest. ``At some point delay carries a very high price for all of us,'' said Baker, including higher casualties among the U.S.-led forces in the event of war should Iraq be given much more time to fortify its positions in Kuwait. ``He has to be stopped, peacefully if possible, but if necessary by force,'' Baker said. ``A willingness to use force against Iraq remains essential.'' Baker was following Defense Secretary Richard Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in a weeklong administration effort to silence congressional critics of Bush's gulf policy. ``Let the United States speak with one voice,'' Baker said during one of several animated exchanges with lawmakers. Baker's won support from one liberal Democrat on the panel, Rep. Stephen Solarz of New York, who said it must be made clear that ``unless he withdraws a war will be inevitable and unless he withdraws he and his military machine will be destroyed.'' Baker is to go to Baghdad after Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister, comes to Washington for talks with Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Begin Getting Crop Payments
DOC.TEXT: Farmers who participated in the 1990 wheat, barley and oats program will receive more than $1.7 billion in cash payments, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Keith Bjerke, executive vice president of the department's Commodity Credit Corp., said the subsidies would be paid by county offices of the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service. The payments are due farmers when market prices in a specified period average below established target levels. Nearly all the payments, expected to begin next week, will go to wheat farmers. Barley producers will get about $35 million and oats producers about $8 million.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Families React With Joy, Caution to Promise of Loved Ones' Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final three grafs to CORRECT spelling from Vallekoop to Vellekoop; Anderton cq in 10-11th grafs
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Foreigners, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The families of about 900 American hostages held in Kuwait and Iraq awoke today to the promise of an end to the frustration and fear that have haunted them since Saddam Hussein sparked the Persian Gulf crisis four months ago. ``There were times I couldn't eat, I couldn't sleep,'' said Doris Whatley of Shreveport, La. ``All of a sudden I am a changed person ... because my husband is coming home.'' Mrs. Whatley's husband is an oil worker among about 90 of the Americans who are being used as ``human shields'' at strategic sites. He called from Baghdad this morning to share in his wife's elation. But for the friends and relatives of other hostages it was a time of restraint. ``We'll celebrate when we see them coming out and not before. At my age, you learn to have a little equanimity about these things,'' said Margaret Williams, whose son and daughter-in-law were working in Kuwait when Saddam's troops invaded Aug. 2. The couple's daughter, Jennifer Williams, was among a group of about 20 Americans who, against State Department recommendations, traveled this week to Baghdad to seek their loved ones' release. ``You can't give up hope - there's always hope,'' Mrs. Williams said this morning from her home in Germantown, Tenn. ``But this could well be just another one of (Saddam's) cat-and-mouse games.'' Saddam called for the release of all foreign hostages in a directive to the Iraqi parliament, a decision he said was prompted by recent diplomatic moves that may include President Bush's proposal for direct U.S.-Iraqi talks. The directive, which did not say when the captives would be freed, followed Saddam's previous offer to release all hostages over a three-month period beginning Christmas Day, ``if nothing mars the atmosphere of peae.'' ``So far we've heard a lot of rhetoric, double-talk and half-truths,'' said David McDonald Jr., whose old friend and client is among the Americans who have been hiding in Kuwait. ``But this seems like the first serious break.'' Bonnie Anderton of Larkspur, Colo., whose husband has been holed up at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, agreed Saddam's directive was a potential turning point in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``But (Saddam) has a habit of putting real nasty catches on things,'' said Mrs. Anderton, who was among the wives and children released several weeks after the invasion occurred. ``It looks good, but we still need more details.'' Still, families could not help but cheer the long-awaited early-morning news. Around the country, relatives stayed home from work to follow the story and celebrate the first glimmer of hope they'd seen in weeks. ``It's an answer to our prayers. We have been praying him home for Christmas ... and it looks like our answer is coming,'' said Rande Vallekoop, whose husband has been stranded at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. ``I feel freed too ... but none of us are ever going to be the same,'' she said this morning from Minneapolis. ``There will be emotional and mental stuff in becoming a family again. ``I'm sure it will take some time,'' Mrs. Vallekoop said. ``But I don't mind that at all. Not one bit.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A senior Energy Department official accused Japan on Thursday of hoarding crude oil in the months after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, despite agreement among most consuming nations to draw down stockpiles and ease supply problems. Linda Stuntz, an Energy Department deputy under secretary for policy and planning, said she expects the issue to be raised next week at a meeting of the governing board of the International Energy Agency. The Paris-based agency is responsible for coordinating responses by oil consuming nations in an oil supply emergency. ``If everybody in the world did what Japan is doing we would have a much more serious problem than we do. Prices would be a lot higher,'' said Ms. Stuntz in remarks to a group of reporters. She later said in an interview that she did not want to overstate the concern, but added that Japan's actions raise questions about the success of future cooperative activities among consuming nations in response to oil supply shocks. Ms. Stuntz said that in the months after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last August, U.S. oil companies and most companies in Europe drew down crude oil stocks in order to keep supplies adequate without having to dramatically increase imports. But, she said, the Japanese, rather than drawing down crude oil stocks after the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, elected instead to continue importing at high levels and, in fact, increased imports to meet additional demand. ``That is stockpiling,'' she said, something the United States and other consuming nation's had sought to prevent to ease the immediate shock of losing 4.3 million barrels of oil a day as a result of the Iraq-Kuwait crisis. Ms. Stuntz said that despite increasing consumer demand, U.S. imports were 12 percent lower in September and 25 percent lower in October than they were last July, before the Iraqi invasion, because U.S. refineries were relying on existing stocks. In October, Japan imported 33 percent more oil than it did in July, she said. ``What does this mean for future cooperative activities?'' she asked.

DOC.HEAD: Peanut Farmers Vote on Price Supports
DOC.TEXT: Peanut farmers will vote in a mail referendum Dec. 10-13 on whether to continue government controls and price supports for five years, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. If two-thirds or more vote in favor of poundage quotas, no referendum will be held in the second, third, fourth and fifth year, and the federal program will remain in effect for crops in 1991 through 1995. But if the vote falls short of the two-thirds margin, the quotas and price supports won't be in effect for the 1991 peanut crop. However, another referendum would be held next year to determine whether the program would be in effect for the 1992 through 1995 crops. In a 1986 referendum, more than 97 percent of the 21,456 peanut growers who cast ballots voted in favor of the program for 1986 through 1990, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Vacations ``Class,'' NBC Cancels Sitcom
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Head of the Class'' is going on hiatus after its Christmas Day broadcast and will be replaced on Tuesdays by a new situation comedy, ``Davis Rules,'' the network announced Thurday. NBC, meanwhile, said it has canceled ``Working It Out,'' its new comedy that co-stars Jane Curtin and Stephen Collins. No replacement has been picked yet for the low-rated show, which appeared Wednesdays. ABC's new series stars Randy Quaid as an educator who is a single parent with three sons. The show co-stars Jonathan Winters as Quaid's eccentric father, a retired Marine gunnery sergeant. ``Head of the Class'' will return to ABC's schedule later in the television season, the network said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Welcomes Release Pledge, Says Kuwait Still Must Be Freed
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday welcomed Iraq's surprise promise to free all foreign hostages but said the United States must not relax its war footing in the Persian Gulf. ``We've got to continue to keep the pressure on,'' he said. Iraq officially notified the United States that all 900 Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait would be released, Secretary of State James A. Baker III disclosed in Washington. It was unclear when, but Americans in the area were told to be ready. The State Department said the Voice of America was broadcasting a message Thursday night saying, ``We are making preparations to evacuate all U.S. citizens as soon as they are permitted to leave.'' Bush, citing the promised release of the hostages and the easing of Iraq's pressure on the American Embassy in Kuwait, said, ``It seems to be a little movement here, a little movement there,'' Yet, he said, Saddam Hussein still ``must leave Kuwait without reservation, without condition.'' Bush spoke at a news conference at the next-to-last stop of his five-nation South American tour while Baker, 5,000 miles away, testified before Congress to win support for a possible military strike against Iraqi forces. Baker said of Saddam's announcement, ``It seems to me no coincidence that this comes just one week, just one week, after the international community has authorized the use of force.'' Yet, the dramatic move - if carried out - could well strengthen demands in Congress that Bush allow more time for sanctions to work before resorting to force. Facing Baker at a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing, Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., asked, ``Why should we not wait for this policy of sanctions, diplomacy and putting in place a credible military force ... to work?'' ``What is working,'' Baker responded, ``is that we are beginning finally to get the clear message across to Saddam Hussein. ... If we want a peaceful solution, it should be crystal clear to them that force is not going to be ruled out as an option.'' Bush promised there would not be any secret deal with Saddam to end the Persian Gulf crisis. ``There are no secret negotiations, direct or indirect with Iraq over this question,'' Bush said. ``None. And there will be none.'' Bush dismissed proposals circulating at the United Nations for a Middle East peace conference, renewing his rejection of Saddam's attempt to link resolution of the crisis with the Arab-Israeli conflict. ``We are not going to get diverted from the full implementation of the United Nations resolutions in order to give him some face-saving way out of something he shouldn't have gotten into in the first place,'' Bush said. ``I don't care about (saving) face; he doesn't need any face. He needs to get out of Kuwait without trying to complicate this matter by talking about some Middle East peace settlement or peace conference. ``It is clear what his ploy is,'' Bush said, ``and that ploy is not going to be successful.'' The news of Saddam's pledge to release the hostages reached Bush on Air Force One during a bumpy flight over the Andes from Argentina to Chile on his salute-to-democracy tour. On Friday, he will fly to Caracas, Venezuela, for an overnight visit before returning to Washington. Release of the hostages has been a key demand of the United States and the global coalition against Iraq, along with the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, the restoration of the exiled emir and a guarantee of security in the gulf. At a joint news conference with Chilean President Patricio Aylwin, Bush said he hoped the Iraqi decision to release the hostages could be believed. Some of the foreigners are being held as shields to prevent attack against strategic targets. ``No single hostage should have been taken in the first place. And I hope that it shows that the strategy is working and that Saddam understands that his hostage policy has incurred the condemnation of the whole world, the president said. ``And we've got to continue to keep the pressure on,'' said Bush, who has authorized the deployment of more than 400,000 Americans to the gulf. The Pentagon said Thursday that Iraq had moved an additional 30,000 troops into Kuwait and southern Iraq, and that 10,000 U.S. reinforcements had arrived in the Persian Gulf. There are now more than 480,000 Iraqi troops in the region and more than 250,000 American troops, including at least 130,000 U.S. Army soldiers in Saudi Arabia. Bush said his planned meeting with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, and a meeting between Baker and Saddam, would not be negotiating sessions in which concessions might be offered to Iraq. ``What I want to do is be sure, by going this last, extra step for peace, that the Iraqis know from me, and Aziz knows from me and Saddam Hussein knows directly from the secretary of state, what is at stake in this matter and how supportive the United States is of the consolidated U.N. position,'' Bush said. ``And that's what it's about.'' On Capitol Hill, Baker also rejected Iraqi demands that the talks include discussion of other Mideast issues. ``I will not be negotiating the Palestinian question or the civil war in Lebanon,'' Baker said. Baker said anew that Bush hopes for a peaceful solution and has not decided whether to use force immediately should Saddam ignore a United Nations resolution demanding that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15.

DOC.HEAD: FCC To Launch Search for Spectrum for New Radio-Based Technologies
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Federal Communications Commission announced on Thursday an endeavor to squeeze future technologies such as high-definition TV, personal phones and digital radio onto the nation's crowded airwaves. FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes, noting that Congress and his agency are making decisions today that will affect American lifestyles and economic competitiveness well into the 21st century, said the FCC will initiate a search next year for frequencies to satisfy the voracious appetites of new radio-based technologies. ``My ultimate goal will be to create a new spectrum reserve for emerging technologies,'' Sikes said in what was good news for a host of would-be broadcasters and telecommunications companies that are waging a fierce battle for wave space. But in a bit of bad news for existing licensees, Sikes warned that locating spectrum to accommodate new technologies could not be done without some pain to incumbents. ``If we are to have sufficient spectrum to meet projected new technology needs, some of the incumbents will have to find new homes,'' Sikes said in a speech to the Practicing Law Institute. He added, however, that the legitimate needs of incumbents must be considered and that ``any comprehensive program will have to be implemented over a period of years.'' New technologies such as HDTV and pocket-sized, go-anywhere telephones are expected to arrive worldwide by the end of the decade and dramatically change today's communications systems. Digital broadcasting is another area of promise, in which compact-disc quality sound may be available from traditional radio stations or from new satellite companies. These technologies will require a radical overhaul of existing transmission and receiving systems, creating new jobs and business opportunities, and are expected to play a crucial role in determining the nation's economic well-being in the next century. The House this year passed a bill by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., that would force the government to relinquish for private use about a third - 200 MHz - of the radio spectrum that is allocated exclusively for government use. The bill did not get through the Senate. Advocates of high-definition television, personal phones and digital broadcasting are squabbling over spectrum now held by UHF broadcasters, cellular telephone companies and microwave users such as police and fire departments, mobile radio dispatchers, the space industry, railroads and utilities. New and more spectrum-efficient radio technology promises to ease the pain somewhat of reallocation of spectrum, and technological advances also promise the ability for different users to share space. But something will have to give somewhere, as Sikes noted, since there is only so much wave space. ``The creation of spectrum reserve will not be without costs,'' Sikes said. ``But the benefits to the public of facilitating new communications services will be dramatic.'' He noted that in Europe and Japan, important chunks of the airwaves already have been set aside for these emerging technologies. ``We need to do at least as much as our international trading partners,'' Sikes said. Sikes said the commission also will be looking at how to deal with proposals to create new multiple-use technologies, such as linking satellite and cellular systems together; allowing telephone companies to provide cable TV service over phone lines; or allowing cable and mobile communications companies to link up as an alternative to private or public phone networks.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are questions and answers dealing with the Persian Gulf crisis, excerpted from President Bush's news conference: Q. Mr. President, do you view Saddam's - do you view this promise by Saddam Hussein to release the hostages as credible? And will it affect the U.S. war footing in the Persian Gulf? A. One, I hope it is credible. Two, no single hostage should have been taken in the first place. And I hope that shows that the strategy is working and that Saddam understands that his hostage policy has incurred the condemnation of the whole world. And we've got to continue to keep the pressure on. And this would be welcomed, if true, but it will not change my thinking on his need to comply 100 percent without condition to the U.N. resolutions. --- Q. Mr. President, thank you. I wonder if you'd take te context of what's going on since you got the U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force. You know, you made the announcement last week that they were resupplying and helping to resupply the U.S. Embassy. Now, the announcement on the hostages. My question, Mr. President, is whether you believe Saddam is serious about defusing the tension, or if he is playing chess? A. Well, first, I don't consider a couple of cases of Pepsi-Cola a serious release on our beleaguered embassy in Kuwait. I hope, though, in response to the broader aspects of your question, that Saddam Hussein is getting the message, the message so clearly stated in the last U.N. resolution. And the release of all hostages would be a very good thing. But the problem is the aggression against Kuwait, and the man must leave Kuwait, without reservation, without condition. And the whole world is united in this, and I will not speak for Chile, but I believe the Chileans agree with that. --- Q. Mr. President, there were reports this morning, out of New York apparently, linking American diplomats to a suggestion that the U.S. might go along with a U.N. resolution backing a Mideast peace conference. This was linked with Saddam's latest statement about the hostages. Since then, we understand that Secretary Baker has denied any change in the U.S. position. Certainly you have said there should never be any linkage, and you're aware that Saddam is trying to link them. However, having said that there is no linkage, can you offer any hope that the United States might take a favorable position toward a Mideast peace conference? A. The question is the aggression against Kuwait. There will be and is no linkage to the Palestinian or the West Bank question. And to help clarify, I would refer people to Secretary Baker's statement today, to my comments at a press conference in Helsinki with Mr. Gorbachev, and to what I said at the United Nations in my speech. And I hope that will make clear there is no linkage. And the United States, of course, remains interested in a solution to that other question. But there is no linkage with what has to happen in Kuwait, or what will happen in Kuwait. --- Q. Mr. President, in making his announcement today, Saddam Hussein said he was moved to release these hostages by what he called ``positive diplomatic changes.'' Are there any secret negotiations, back-door negotiations going on now between the Iraqis and the U.S.? And when you sit down with Foreign Minister Aziz, will you be laying down the law, or will you be offering further incentives to encourage Iraq to leave Kuwait? A. One, there are no secret negotiations, direct or indirect, with Iraq over this question. None, and there will be none - secret negotiations of that nature. Secondly, I am not looking for incentive or further incentive. What I want to do is be sure, by going this last extra step for peace, that the Iraqis know from me, and Aziz knows from me, and Saddam Hussein knows directly from the secretary of state what is at stake in this matter and how supportive the United States is of the consolidated U.N. position. And that's what it's about. And I said that before, and I'll keep repeating it because I don't want any people to think there are secret negotiations going on, or that I, on behalf of this worldwide coalition, will even consider making a concession, if you will, or you can call it incentive, if you will. That is not what these meetings are about. --- Q. Mr. President, I'd like to come back to John's question about a Middle East peace conference. ... A. From the very beginning, Saddam Hussein has tried to justify his illegal aggression against Iraq basdd on an overall Middle East problem that involves the West Bank and the Palestine question. And we are not going to get diverted from the full implementation of the United Nations resolutions in order to give him some face-saving way out of something he shouldn't have got into in the first place. As you know, Jim Baker has been very active up until quite recently in trying to move that whole peace process forward and we continue to be very interested in moving the peace process forward. But it will not be linked in any way with Saddam Hussein's aggression. I don't care about face, he doesn't need any face, he needs to get out of Kuwait without trying to complicate this matter by talking about some Middle East peace settlement, or peace conference. And it is clear what his ploy is, and that ploy is not going to be successful.ssed on. That's the way the companies take advantage of changing market conditions.'' The oil industry, which maintains that prices are set by supply and demand, says pricing is not such a simple thing. The American Petroleum Institute has acknowledged there are times when savings have not been passed along promptly to consumers, but it has also pointed out trends in which crude oil prices were rising at the same time the pump price of gasoline was falling. ``If the price of crude oil goes down and stays down, then the price of gasoline will undoubtably follow,'' Institute spokesman Gus Ensz said. ``It's difficult to analyze each and every situation, because thousands of people are running service stations, and the people who run those service stations make the ultimate decision.'' The industry has asserted that all recent probes into petroleum pricing have given oil companies a clean bill of health, but Rothschild said a comparison of recent prices shows that consumers are paying too much. ``From the beginning of November to December, there's been a 20-cent-a-gallon drop in the spot price of gasoline, and yet there's been barely any decrease at all in the (pump) price of gasoline,'' Rothschild said. ``My suspicion is, if anything, we should now be much more concerned about oil companies ripping consumers off.'' On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the leading market for petroleum contracts, wholesale gasoline prices fell below 65 cents Thursday, to the approximate level they were at right before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and caused a spike in the price of oil. But the latest nationwide survey by the American Automobile Association found the average price of a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded to be $1.387. That's 31.2 cents higher than the price on Aug. 1, and just .1 cent less than AAA's highest recorded price of $1.388, just before the Easter holiday in 1981, the AAA said when the survey was released Tuesday. Gasoline was up 2.1 cents for the week, and AAA pointed out that it probably would have fallen a few cents for the week had it not been for the imposition of an additional 5.1-cent federal tax, which took effect Saturday. Rothschild agreed that the tax had an impact and that otherwise pump prices could be coming down, although he insisted any decrease will take too long. Early in the latest oil crisis, the petroleum industry said prices shot up quickly because companies were worried about paying higher replacement costs for their overseas supplies. The industry has also maintained that it showed restraint and never passed on the complete cost increase to consumers. ``The replacement cost for crude has been steadily falling and we have not seen steadily falling prices for gasoline and heating oil,'' Rothschild said.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Set in Bias Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A judge Thursday set bond at $50,000 for a man charged in the fatal shooting of Jay Bias, the brother of the late collegiate basketball star Len Bias. Jerry Samuel Tyler, 24, surrendered to authorities Tuesday night, about seven hours after James Stanley ``Jay'' Bias III died. Bias, 20, died at the same hospital where Len Bias was pronounced dead of a cocaine overdose in June 1986. Police said the shooting occurred in the parking lot of a mall after an apparent argument between the victim and Tyler. Witnesses said Tyler accused Bias of flirting with his wife, a saleswoman at a jewelry store where Bias was making a purchase. Another suspect in the shooting remains at large.

DOC.HEAD: Owner of City Hall Seeks Eviction of City Workers for `Rent'
DOC.TEXT: The secret trust that owns City Hall is trying to evict about 200 City Hall workers because, claiming the city owes nearly $500,000 in back rent on the building. Eviction notices for City Hall employees are only the newest knot in a tangle of money troubles and lawsuits started when a judge decided to give away City Hall to settle a damage suit. The latest development occurred when attorney Patrick M. Young filed a lawsuit in St. Clair Circuit Court Nov. 21, saying East St. Louis owes the private trust he represents $447,300 in rent unpaid from Sept. 30 through Nov. 30. The city says it's nonsense. ``We don't owe any rent,'' City Attorney Eric E. Vickers said Thursday. ``The city still owns the property.'' But Vickers has also appealed the ruling by St. Clair County Circuit Judge Roger Scrivner that awarded the City Hall building to Walter DeBow. DeBow had been severely beaten in the city's jail several years ago and won a $3.4 million damage award against the city, which refused to pay. DeBow sold the building and two accompanying pieces of property to the private trust for less than $200. The identity of the trust remains a secret. Young estimated the value of City Hall at $7.5 million and the daily rent at $7,100. Young was out of his office Thursday and could not be reached for comment. Vickers said he hadn't seen a copy of the lawsuit, but doubted it was enforceable. He also said he wasn't aware of the city being warned that eviction was likely, which is customary. ``We may try to seek an injunction,'' Vickers said. ``I don't think anyone will be evicted.'' On Wednesday, Vickers filed a countersuit in U.S. District Court in St. Louis against Police Sgt. J.W. Cowan and his attorney, Amiel Cueto. That was a week after Cowan sued Vickers for $12 million for allegedly failing to file a timely appeal of the ruling that gave away City Hall. Vickers called Cowan's suit ``political garbage'' aimed at Mayor Carl E. Officer. ``I think with the city election coming, you've got shots being taken at the mayor through me,'' he said. ``I didn't start this nonsensical legal warfare, but I'm going to end it.'' The city attorney is also seeking $25 million for the damage he claims Cowan's lawsuit did to his reputation.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Panel Calls for More Research on Female Biology
DOC.TEXT: Ignorance about female biology still impedes the treatment of breast cancer and other diseases of women, a panel of scientists said Thursday. ``There's no research on the normal breast,'' said Dr. Susan Love, an author and professor of surgery at Harvard. ``Therefore, we don't have a clue when carcinogens are acting.'' Yet breast cancer will strike one woman in 10 in her lifetime, and will kill 44,000 this year, she said. ``It is appalling that in 1990 we have little or no information on the natural course of the endocrine and tissue changes that occur during menopause,'' said Barbara Sherwin of McGill University. The two medical expas that medical professionals consider closely but also look beyond the biological factors unique to women - such as the menstrual cycle, pregnancy and hormonal differences. They said professionals also need to gather data on individual patients' social and economic status as risk factors - poverty, raising children alone - and on ``psychosocial'' factors such as depression, occupational stress and the multiple demands on women as mothers, workers and spouses. Special centers should be established at academic research facilities to study the ``interactions and complexities'' that have an impact on women's health, said Dr. Susan Blumenthal, chief of the Behavioral Medicine Program at the National Institute of Mental Health. That women generally live longer than men poses challenges in itself, noted Dr. William Hazzard, chairman of the medical school at Wake Forest University and spokeswoman for the cardiovascular panel. For example, he said, heart disease accounts for more than a quarter of all deaths in women in the United States. But women suffer heart attacks and heart disease later in life, and often they must endure their suffering alone while men usually have their spouses for support, he said. The growing longevity of women also exacerbates ignorance about menopause, said Sherwin. Changes brought about by menopause account for an estimated 250,000 hip fractures a year. Another problem that follows menopause, urinary incontinence, accounts for billions of dollars in costs not to mention the ``human misery'' that results from the problem, she said. Panelists in all four fields also agreed on the need for further understanding of hormones, especially hormonal therapy, because of their impact on diseases and treatments. ``We desperately and urgently need prospective studies of post-menopausal hormones and their effects on cardiovascular disease, on atherosclerosis, breast cancer and endometrial cancer,'' said Love. ``Otherwise, women cannot make the decisions that they need to make. ``It may be worth the small increase in breast cancer to eliminate the large number of women dying of heart disease, but until we know what risks we're weighing, we can't make those kinds of decisons.'' The panelists reiterated the criticism raised in recent months in Congress that women are being excluded from clinical research, and they noted efforts within the federal National Institutes of Health to monitor research grants to be sure women are included.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson, D.C.'s `Shadow Senator,' Hints Statehood Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS year for Alaskan statehood to 1959, sted 1960, in 6th graf, Jackson aides.
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson said Thursday he is considering suing the federal government on behalf of citizens of the nation's capital in an effort to gain statehood for the District of Columbia. ``We're weighing a lawsuit on this matter,'' said Jackson, who won election in November to an unofficial ``shadow'' Senate seat from which he will lobby Congress to grant the district statehood. ``We are restricted to paying taxes without representation; we serve up our sons and daughters in times of war, yet we have no voting representation in Congress. That is fundamentally undemocratic.'' In outlining his lobbying strategy for statehood, the two-time Democratic presidential contender said he will attempt to combine litigation, lawmaking and mass protest in the fashion used by the civil rights movement. Jackson did not provide specifics on the lawsuit. ``We're still researching this, but the whole thing would center on the question of taxation without representation,'' said a top Jackson aide who asked not to be named. ``It might well end up as a standard, civil rights lawsuit.'' Jackson aides said they are also trying to learn whether any districts or territories have ever sued the federal government to gain admission to the union. The ``shadow'' concept was first used by the Tennessee territory prior to its admission to the United States in 1796; the concept was last used by Alaska, which in 1959 became the nation's 49th state. The federal government would be the target of the lawsuit since Congress governs the admission of states to the union, the aide said. Another goal of the lawsuit would be to gain Jackson the right to set up a separate office for statehood purposes if he so chooses, Jackson aides said. Earlier this year, the General Accounting Office concluded that ``shadow'' congressional delegations could not use either public or private funds to acquire office space without congressional approval.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Declared State House Winner by Just One Vote
DOC.TEXT: A Republican logging supporter defeated the incumbent for his legislative seat by one vote after a recount, but she didn't gloat in the ``campaign from hell.'' ``You can bet I'm not going to be running up and down the street yelling, `Hey, I'm Representative Goos.' I'm not going to act like an idiot,'' said Ann Goos, whose name rhymes with dose. State Rep. Evan Jones, D-Sequim, said he'll contest Wednesday's results and demand a new recount. There is no legal limit to the number of recounts and the Legislature could be asked to decide which candidate to seat, said David Brine, spokesman for Secretary of State Ralph Munro. ``It ain't over 'til it's over,'' Jones said. Going into the recount, Jones led the race for the 24th District seat by five votes. But when new tallies were added from three counties, he trailed by one vote. The new total: Goos 16,167, Jones 16,166. Jones said he's evaluating which precincts and counties to include in his demand for a recount, and whether to seek a hand recount or a computer recount. He has to pay five cents a ballot for the recheck. ``The one silver lining is that ... everyone thinks it is their vote that made the difference - and they're all right, of course,'' Jones said. ``People can know that literally one vote makes a difference.'' Goos summed up the race as the ``campaign from hell.''

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Establishes Diplomatic Relations with Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican restored diplomatic ties with Bulgaria Thursday, thus achieving ties with all members of the former Warsaw Pact and formally ending an era in which the church and the East bloc were foes. The former hard-line Communist nation had been implicated in an attempt to kill Pope John Paul II. In a brief statement, the Vatican said ties between the Holy See and Bulgaria would be at the ambassadorial level. Diplomatic links were broken in 1949 when the Communist government prevented the Vatican's representative from re-entering the country. Since democratic revolutions swept Eastern Europe in the past 18 months ousting Communist governments, the Vatican has also restored ties with Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Romania and Pope John Paul II's native Poland. Also this year, ties were forged for the first time with the Soviet Union. The pope has been invited to visit Bulgaria. He has already made a brief trip to Czechoslovakia and is to travelt to Hungary in 1991. Relations between the Vatican and Bulgaria reached a particularly low point after the 1981 assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II. Italian prosecutors said the plot involved Bulgarian agents and the Soviet KGB. A Rome court, however, acquitted three Bulgarians of conspiracy to murder the pontiff, citing lack of evidence. Bulgaria denied involvement in the shooting, which was carried out by a Turk. Catholics make up only around 1 percent of Bulgaria's population of about 9 million. Under Bulgaria's previous Communist government, freedom of religion was guaranteed by law. However, most Bulgarian Christians were at least nominal members of the Bulgarian Orthodox Church, which avoided antagonizing authority. The country has a large Moslem minority, but many discontinued practice of their religion under pressure from the Communist government.

DOC.HEAD: Pearl Harbor Attack Remembered on 49th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: The 49th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor will be marked Friday with a memorial service. he service at the USS Arizona Memorial Visitor Center will honor the 2,403 people killed in the Dec. 7, 1941, attack that drew the United States into World War II. Ted Mason, a Pearl Harbor survivor and author of the book ``Battleship Sailor,'' will be the keynote speaker. A special prayer will be offered by a representative of the World Federation of Japan Religious Committee. The ceremony also will include a flyover by F-15 jets from the Hawaii Air National Guard, a 21-gun salute by U.S. Marines and taps played by the Fleet Marine Force Band. During the day, American flags will be briefly raised, then lowered at the USS Arizona Memorial. They later will be offered to the 50 states, the White House and U.S. territories to be flown as part of next year's 50 anniversary.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Reports Homicide Explosion for Young Black Males
With AM-Deadly Year, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Homicide, the leading cause of death among young black males, has increased by two-thirds among that group in four years, researchers with the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. Nationwide, 2,741 black males aged 15 to 24 were homicide victims in 1988, CDC epiemiologist Dr. Robert Froehlke said. The killings represent a rate of 101.1 for every 100,000 black males in the age group, up 67 percent from the 1984 rate of 60.6. The new figures indicate a reversal in a trend that saw homicides decrease among young black men in the early 1980s, the CDC said. Meanwhile, rates for females and white males in that age group ``have either stayed essentially the same, or in fact decreased a little bit,'' Froehlke said. ``The disparity between black males and other groups has widened even more.'' In 1987, the latest year in which complete statistics are available, young black males' homicide rate is some six times greater than the rate for all Americans aged 15-24; among blacks, the rate was 84.6 per 100,000, compared with 13.8 per 100,000, Froehlke said. The nation's overall homicide rate in 1987 was 8.5 per 100,000. That year, homicides accounted for 42 percent of the deaths of black males in that age group. The CDC's analysis is based on 1987 figures. The 1988 statistics, released just last week, have not yet been analyzed in-depth, Froehlke said. The homicide problem is getting worse faster for black teenage males, the CDC said. The 1988 homicide rate for black males 15-19 was 76.8 per 100,000, up 99 percent since 1984. The rate for black males 20-24 was 127.2 per 100,000, up 53 percent since 1984. Firearm homicides accounted for more than 95 percent of the 1984-87 increase in killings of young black males, the CDC said. Six areas - California, Florida, Michigan, Missouri, New York and the District of Columbia - accounted for 51 percent of the deaths of young black males in 1987. Those six locations have 29 percent of the nation's population of black males aged 15-24, the CDC said. In its weekly report, the CDC called for more research into ways to stop the killings. ``Research and evaluation efforts have not demonstrated effective programmatic approaches to prevent homicide,'' the Atlanta-based agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Prospective Jurors: Liz Who?
LaserPhoto LA8
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor pretended she was horrified, then joined the courtroom in a hearty laugh Thursday when a prospective juror said he's seen most of the star's silent films. During the second day of jury selection in her court contest with her ex-beau Henry Wynberg, a majority of potential panelists said they have only vague memories of the 58-year-old Miss Taylor as an actress. Wynberg claims he conceived the actress' popular perfume Passion, and he's seeking a hefty share of some $70 million a year in profit. Two prospective jurors said they had never seen the Academy Award-winning actress on film and one associated her with the silent-film era, which predates her career. ``I go back to the silent movies, so I've seen most of her films,'' the panelist said when asked if he had ever seen Miss Taylor on the screen. Miss Taylor, wearing a black dress and a thick gold necklace, bracelet and earrings, reacted with a mock expression of horror, then laughed along with others. When jury selection began Wednesday, Miss Taylor's bout with alcoholism was raised as her lawyer probed prospective jurors' feelings about the actress.
