The issue is relevant to her court contest because Wynberg claims her alcoholism and related weight gain destroyed the glamorous image he counted on to market cosmetics under her name. As Miss Taylor sat facing jurors, attorney Neil Papiano said: ``It has been fairly well publicized that Miss Taylor at one time had an alcohol abuse problem and went to the Betty Ford Clinic and since that time has had no problem.'' The attorney asked the prospects whether they knew others with such problems and had any views about rehabilitation programs. Most said they knew alcoholics and approved of efforts to help them. Miss Taylor claims Wynberg's criminal record led her to abandon their planned business deal and turn to the major cosmetics company. She won permission to tell jurors about Wynberg's statutory rape conviction. The legal dispute pits Miss Taylor against Wynberg, a former used car salesman who courted her between her two marriages to Richard Burton in the 1970s. Wynberg and Miss Taylor signed an agreement in Burton's presence in 1975 for Wynberg to market cosmetics under Miss Taylor's name. She says he breached the contract by doing nothing to fulfill it. He says she breached it when she agreed to sell Passion through another company. During jury questioning, Papiano asked panelists if they knew about Miss Taylor's work for AIDS research and how they felt about it. ``I support it,'' said one woman. ``I think it's a great cause,'' said another. The attorney explained later that the question was asked because evidence will show that a percentage of Miss Taylor's profits from Passion go to benefit research for acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

DOC.HEAD: Phony Student Paper Headlines Scream of War With Iraq, Draft
DOC.TEXT: A fake edition of the student newspaper carried a headline proclaiming ``U.S. Invades Iraq,'' and caused some panic on campus. Students and staff at the State University of New York at Binghamton hugged each other and cried. A dining hall worker whose son is stationed in Saudi Arabia ran screaming from the building. The school's radio station began broadcasting that the United States had gone to war. One of the headlines announced, ``SUNY Binghamton Students Drafted.'' But both Page One stories Wednesday had disclaimers in their last paragraphs on inside pages: ``The events described above have not happened. Yet. But they may.'' Editors of the real paper, called Pipe Dream, said a student group, Looking Left, known for its radical politics, had published the phony issue to make an anti-war statement. ``We were inundated with several hundred phone calls,'' said junior Matthew Furman, managing editor of Pipe Dream. The editors rushed to distribute 4,000 printed fliers by midafternoon that said war had not begun and that Pipe Dream had not published the issue. University President Lois B. DeFleur called the publication ``a grossly insensitive hoax.'' David Anderson, interim vice president for student affairs, said the publication violated the code of campus conduct. University officials said the incident would be investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demand Interim Government in South Africa
LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress pressed its demand for an interim government Thursday in rallies that drew 18,000 supporters, and it threatened to increase pressure if its demands are not met. A stepped-up campaign of rallies and other mass action could heighten tensions with the government, which considers such tactics detrimental to the nation's stability, and delay talks on reform. In Johannesburg, ANC leader Mac Maharaj blamed the government for the slow pace of talks with black leaders. About 40 miles north in Pretoria, Winnie Mandela and Communist Party chief Joe Slovo blamed security forces for violence in black townships. A third march was in Bloemfontein, 180 miles south of Johannesburg. ``We say to the government: `Stop stalling on negotiations!''' Maharaj told about 10,000 people in downtown Johannesburg. ``We want an interim government now.'' Maharaj said those who have presided over the apartheid system must not be allowed to oversee change. President F.W. de Klerk has pledged to end apartheid and negotiate a new constitution, but he rejects demands for an interim government to oversee the changes. Demonstrators demanded the government speed up talks with the ANC; make good on promises to release all political prisoners and permit exiles to return; and take action to stop black factional violence. Mrs. Mandela, the wife of ANC deputy president Nelson Mandela, said in Pretoria that the peace process could be derailed if township violence is not stopped. Mrs. Mandela repeated allegations that security forces have sided against ANC supporters in township battles - a charge the government denies. Since August, nearly 1,000 people have died in Johannesburg townships. Most of the unrest involves backers of the ANC and its main rival, the Inkatha Freedom Party. The 5,000 protesters marched to de Klerk's offices and handed over a letter stating the demands. Security was tight, with soldiers in riot gear and police dogs lining the route. At one point, three Air Force Mirage fighter jets flew overhead. Demonstrators in Johannesburg marched several blocks to City Hall and then to a police station with a list of demands. The ANC said if the demands were not met, a program of boycotts and rallies would be called. The government has denounced such actions, saying activities such as marches and strikes lead to violence. Black leaders accuse security forces of causing the violence by interfering in peaceful protests. The demands presented Thursday included freedom by Christmas of all political prisoners, an interim government, and the integration of Bophuthatswana into South Africa. Bophuthatswana is a black homeland considered independent by the South African government but not recognized as such by other nations. The ANC considers the homeland system an attempt by the government to perpetuate apartheid by keeping blacks and whites apart. About 3,000 people rallied peacefully in Bloemfontein. The ANC supporters were joined by members of the closely allied South African Communist Party and ANC-aligned trade unions. The Johannesburg demonstration was the first mass rally in the city since Nov. 17, when two people died in clashes with police after an illegal march. No violence was reported Thursday, and police presence was not heavy. All three marches had official permission.

DOC.HEAD: Soaring Deficit Will Test Voters' Tolerance of Red Ink
DOC.TEXT: New estimates that the budget deficit is soaring past $300 billion will test voters' tolerance for federal red ink, but analysts are divided over whether the record shortfalls will blunt Congress' spending appetite. The Congressional Budget Office projected Thursday that next year's budget gap will be at least $337 billion. The non-partisan budget office blamed the slowing economy and the expensive bailout of the nation's savings and loans. That would easily set a record - despite the Nov. 5 enactment of a five-year package of tax increases and spending cuts designed to shrink the deficits by $496 billion in that period. The record deficit ``puts one more arrow in the quiver of those who would oppose higher spending,'' said Carol Cox, president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a bipartisan group that studies budget issues. ``There is a political constraint in an era of $300 billion deficits when somebody wants to spend even more money.'' Others noted that new budget procedures virtually eliminate the current system of across-the-board spending cuts if the deficit is too high. As a result, they said, large budget gaps may not dissuade Congress from seeking new spending programs. ``With the new system, we're suddenly being told that the deficit is not the real enemy,'' said Stanley Collender, a budget analyst for the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse. ``The last decade has shown that the average American doesn't want spending to stop.'' But Collender said that with deficits expected to hit record levels for the next few years, it was unclear how Americans would react. ``We'll be really testing the mettle of the American people on this stuff,'' Collender said. ``If they get riled up, a person who proposes new spending will at a disadvantage. But that's a big if. We haven't seen that before.'' CBO Director Robert Reischauer warned the House Budget Committee that with the economy continuing to worsen, next year's shortfall could well be even worse than $337 billion. As the economy declines, the government collects less revenue and spends more for unemployment and other programs, driving up the deficit. Reischauer told the lawmakers that he expected the economy to shrink during the last three months of 1990, and that the same thing would probably happen during the first quarter of 1991 if the large U.S. troop deployment in the Middle East continues. But he did predict an improving economy beginning in 1992, and a shrinking federal deficit. ``It looks like a period of weakness, followed by a rebound,'' he said. This year's budget gap should be $320 billion, the CBO said. Fiscal 1991 runs through next Sept. 30. The deficit for fiscal 1990 was $220 billion, just below the record $221 billion shortfall in 1986. Those figures cannot be directly compared with the $320 billion projection for next year. Past years' deficits included the huge and growing Social Security surplus, expected to reach $66 billion this year. Under new budget rules, that surplus is no longer included in federal deficit calculations. The fiscal 1990 budget gap would have been $277 billion had the Social Security surplus not been included in the deficit figures. The new deficit calculations also do not include the costs of Operation Desert Shield, which will be counted separately. Reischauer said U.S. operations in the Persian Gulf this year will probably cost $12 billion if fighting does not break out. He had no figures on the costs if war erupts.

DOC.HEAD: Welcome to Her Parking Nightmare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6:30 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Her car was never mistakenly towed. She was never charged with someone else's unpaid fines, never billed for a ticket she'd already paid. But Barbara James has won the competition for the city's ``worst parking nightmare.'' ``You're kidding,'' the 33-year-old advertising consultant from Clifton, N.J., said Thursday when informed she had won the $100 grand prize. Her skepticism was understandable, for this is the city where the parking nightmare was invented. An ever-growing number of vehicles and an ever-shrinking number of parking spaces has created a happy hunting ground for quota-burdened ticket agents and tow truck crews. In such an environment, Mrs. James' nightmare sounds more like an unpleasant daydream. But welcome to it: Eight years ago Barbara was single, living in the city and dating Bob James, who would become her husband. He was living in New Jersey, where she refused to go, and drove ``a snazzy, sporty Mustang.'' She persuaded Bob, against his better judgment, to drive into the city for the last night of the San Gennaro festival in Little Italy, a cramped old neighborhood. But Bob and Barbara found what looked like a parking space just two blocks from the festival. There were other cars parked on the block, none were ticketed, and a sign said, ``No Parking Until 6 p.m.'' It was 5:55. They asked a policeman standing on the corner if they could park there, and he said go ahead. The couple giddily walked off. Here's the rest of the story, according to Mrs. James: ``We came back, stuffed with cannoli, and almost threw up when we found a $35 parking ticket on the car - issued at 5:59, not 30 seconds after the cop assured us it as OK to park!'' Bob wrote out a check, smeared the ticket with marinara sauce, and mailed both to the city. However luckless in parking, Mrs. James does well in contests. Several years ago she won a Caribbean cruise by composing a poem of 25 words or less on the topic ``What I'd Do for a Miller Beer.'' But she was surprised that her entry won the parking nightmare competition, which was staged by Glenn Bolofsky, publisher of a calendar that charts the days when the city's byzantine alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules are suspended. Bolofsky said he received more than 200 entries. There are many local drivers with a better claim on the $100, and who need it more than Mrs. James: -Michael Cutrone, who had to pay $8,240 in parking tickets even though copies of the tickets showed they were not issued to his car. He paid after the city's Parking Violations Bureau obtained a lien on his house. -Carlos Gonzales, whose Nissan was seized while he was in church because the bureau claimed he owed about $5,400 in fines and interest. But the car to which the tickets were issued was a Pontiac belonging to another Carlos Gonzales, who had the same birthday as the Nissan owner. -JoAnn DiDomenico, who paid the same parking ticket twice: $20 on Sept. 1, 1987, and $45 (including penalty) the following spring after the bureau changed computers, lost record of her first payment, and billed her a second time. None of these unfortunates entered the contest, however. ``Maybe they just want to forget,'' Bolofsky mused. Mrs. James feels sorry for them, but she'll take the $100. She'll also take her free copy of the parking calendar, even though she never drives into New York. ``I've learned my lesson,'' she said. ``I take the bus.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Tells Hostages: `Stay Where You Are, Keep In Touch' ^With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government advised American hostages in Iraq and Kuwait on Thursday to ``stay where you are'' until arrangements can be worked out for their safe return to the United States following an Iraqi pledge to release all foreigners. The Iraqi ambassador said he hoped all could be out by Christmas. U.S. officials say there are fewer than 1,000 American citizens still in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. At last count, 88 were being held at strategic installations as human shields to ward off attack by the U.S.-led international forces massed around Iraq. Many more have remained in hiding, unable to leave the country and unwilling to be rounded up for possible assignment to Iraqi military bases. The State Department said Thursday it was making arrangements to evacuate all Americans and their foreign-born family members as soon as they obtain exit permits or waivers allowing them to leave. In a message for broadcast to the region over Voice of America, the department acknowledged Iraq's announced intention to release all foreigners and said, ``We have asked for, but not yet received, information from the Iraqi government on when and how such releases can take place.'' In the meantime, the message said, ``Stay where you are, stay in touch with the U.S. Embassy and monitor the VOA closely. We will let you know as soon as we have more information.'' A U.S. official, who asked not to be identified by name, said once the hostages are permitted to leave, they can be home in two or three days. Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat suggested in Washington that people would be leaving ``within days.'' He added, ``Of course I cannot now tell how long it will take to provide all the necessary things for departure but I hope that they will be all of them out for Christmas.'' The United States has evacuated 2,250 U.S. citizens and foreign-born family members since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Generally, they have been flown out of the country by Iraqi air charters that start out in Baghdad, fly to Kuwait to pick up passengers, return to Baghdad, then fly on to Amman, Jordan. From there, the Americans are flown either to Frankfurt or London, where they stay overnight en route to the United States. The official said the State Department and a team of federal officials from the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Customs and other agencies meets each evacuation flight at its port of entry to smooth the hostages' return. The State Department has expressed particular concern for 49 Americans, including 21 of those held at strategic sites, who are said to have medical conditions that require special attention. In addition to those who have been unable to leave, eight U.S. diplomats have been holding out inside the American Embassy compound in Kuwait in defiance of Iraqi orders to close down all foreign embassies in the territory it annexed after the invasion. Nineteen private citizens, the last of more than 100 who sought refuge initially, are believed to remain with them.

DOC.HEAD: Problems Delaying Ground Radar System
With Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Testing of equipment designed to help airliners avoid collisions on runways has uncovered flaws that could delay by a year plans to use the radar system at 29 airports nationwide, the system's maker said. Among those to receive the new ground radar system is Detroit Metropolitan Airport, where two jets collided on a runway Monday, killing eight people and and injuring another 24. The system, which uses radio waves to relay images of ground traffic to the the control tower might have averted Monday's accident, said Phil Leman, an Federal Aviation Administration electronic engineer involved in testing. But a key component in the ground radar system being tested at Greater Pittsburgh International Airport is falling apart and must be replaced before it can be used, said Scott Brinckerhoff, a spokesman for the manufacturer, Norden Systems Inc. of Norwalk, Conn. A reflector in the system antenna atop the airport's control tower separates from the antenna's outer surface when the unit spins, said Brinckerhoff. Norden plans to replace the antenna before testing continues, he said. The problems with the antenna and software have delayed use of the so-called Airport Surface Detection Equipment 3 at Pittsburgh and installation of similar systems at 28 other airports. A new prototype should be in operation by fall 1991, about one year later than expected, said FAA spokesman Dick Stafford. Norden had wanted to install all systems by July 1992, said Brinckerhoff. It will ask the FAA for a one-year extension, he said. Of the airports to receive the system, 13 have older ground radar systems and 16, including those at Pittsburgh and Detroit, have no ground radar, the FAA said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Supports Program to Combat Anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Thursday voiced support for a plan to combat rising anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe, but Vatican officials declined appeals by a Jewish delegation to recognize Israel. A Jewish leader, Seymour Reich, said two days of talks between the Jewish delegation and the Vatican marked ``the beginning of a new chapter'' in the Catholic-Jewish relationship. But he said delegates of the International Jewish Committee on Interreligious Consultations were ``somewhat disappointed'' the pope did not go further in his comments. The Vatican's new foreign minister, Monsignor Jean-Louis Tauran, cited the Vatican's traditional reasons for not recognizing Israel, including unsettled borders, the status of Jerusalem and the Palestinians' lack of a homeland. The pope hailed progress in relations between Jews and Catholics in his speech to the 30-member Jewish delegation and top Vatican officials. In particular, he praised a September plan drawn up by Jews and Catholics in Prague, Czechoslovakia, for fighting anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe. The six-point plan included calls for setting up courses for priests to counter anti-Jewish sentiment, and omiting religiously divisive material from textbooks. The Prague meeting also branded anti-Semitism a sin. Jewish leaders have expressed concern about an upsurge of anti-Semitism in the former Communist countries of Eastern Europe, including the pope's native Poland. The pope praised the Prague meeting for coming ``to conclusions that are of great importance for the continuation of our dialogue and cooperation. It is my hope that these may be widely recognized and that the recommendations then formulated will be implemented wherever human and religious rights are violated.'' Besides the pope's endorsement for the plan to combat anti-Semitism, the Jewish delegation had sought the Vatican's formal recognition of Israel. But Reich, of Great Neck, N.Y., said they saw no change in the Vatican position on the Jewish State. Reich said the Jewish delegates told Vatican officials, ``there can be no full normalization of relations between the Catholic and Jewish communities until the Vatican has full normalization of relations with the Jewish state.'' Nevertheless, delegates said the one-hour papal meeting was warm. Lisa Palmieri-Billig of the Anti-Defamation League, quoted the pope as reiterating his wish to visit the Holy Land. ``I hope one day to be able to visit the holy sites, beginning with those of Abraham'' in Jerusalem, he said, according to Palmieri-Billig. ``That would be our joy,'' replied Rabbi David Rosen, according to Palmieri-Billig. Rosen is a representative of the Anti-Defamation League in Jerusalem. The Catholic-Jewish meetings were held to mark the 25th anniversary of Nostra Aetate, adopted during the Second Vatican Council. The document, considered a turning point in Catholic-Jewish relations, withdrew the accusation that the Jews were responsible for killing Christ.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavia Lifts State of Emergency, Russia Criticizes Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: Moldavia loosened restrictions Thursday on an ethnic minority within its borders, but Russian officials complained that its nationals were being harassed, news reports said. As the country's fragmentation continued, a newspaper also criticized local officials in Uzbekistan over Sunday's clashes in Namangan that left five soldiers and three civilians dead. The Moldavian parliament lifted emergency rules in the southern corner of its republic where a Christian Turkish minority, the Gagauz, triggered tense standoffs in October when they demanded autonomy, the official news agency Tass said. The lawmakers, indicating the situation had improved, said the Soviet Interior Ministry should leave the area within three days and special administrators should hand control back to local officials, Tass said. Meanwhile in Moscow, one chamber of the Russian republic legislation approved a resolution appealing to the other 14 republics to stop the ``pressure'' on ethnic Russians living in non-Russian republics. The chamber charged that ``our compatriots are compelled to leave their homes,'' and urged republic parliaments ``to settle inter-ethnic problems through negotiations and with due regard for the interests of all people concerned,'' the independent Interfax news agency reported. Ethnic Russians, who make up more than half the population of the country, have sizable communities in every non-Russian republic, sometimes outnumbering the indigenous population. Some of the ethnic groups within republics have sided with the Kremlin against republic leaders, leading to intra-republic tension and sometimes violence. The clashes in the Central Asian town of Namangan came between local residents and Soviet troops. Witnesses told the labor newspaper Trud that the clashes were not spontaneous, but were planned in advance by residents who had stockpiled stones, metal bars, and pipe cutters. Local authorities had said the soldiers were drunk and harassing women on a bus when the clashes broke out. But the newspaper said investigation has shown the dead soldiers had no alcohol in their blood. It also complained that all information about the clashes came from national broadcasts and newspapers, and that local media were silent on the deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Guts University Press Headquarters, Destroying Rare Books
DOC.TEXT: Fire gutted the University of North Carolina Press headquarters, destroying rare books and irreplaceable manuscripts, officials said. The fire broke out about 6 p.m. Wednesday at the building near the university's Chapel Hill campus and caused some $500,000 in damage, authorities said. No injuries were reported. Richard Hendel, the university press' associate director, said he believed some items destroyed in the fire were irreplaceable, adding: ``There were some new manuscripts in the editorial department, and those would have to be edited all over again. There also were a few rare books in our library. I'm sure there are copies elsewhere, but they will be difficult to find.'' Many computer files also were lost, he said. Hendel was the only person in the building when the fire erupted. He said two men - apparently university students - knocked on his office window and alerted him to the blaze. The fire's cause was under investigation Thursday, a fire department spokesman said. The university press, founded in 1923, specializes in topics relating to North Carolina and the South. It has published books on subjects including black history, botany and literary criticism. One book the press published, ``The Transformation of Virginia, 1740-1790'' by Rhys L. Isaac won the Pulitzer Prize for history in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel Prepares to Hear Keating's Congressional Liaison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 4-6 ``In testimony'' to update with further Black testimony. FYI, the committee has recessed for the night; no further leads planned.
DOC.TEXT: In compelling James Grogan to testify, the Senate Ethics Committee is summoning the person who probably knows more than anyone but Charles H. Keating Jr. about Keating's relationship with five powerful senators. At the start of Thursday's 13th day of hearings, the committee announced Grogan will begin closed-door testimony on Dec. 17, followed by his appearance at an open hearing. Grogan was Keating's main liaison with Congress. He's the man who can tie together any relationship between the money Keating raised for the Keating Five and their intervention with thrift regulators on his behalf. Documents released in the case show that Grogan, who earlier declined to testify on Fifth Amendment grounds, had often arranged for Keating's political donations and had enlisted the senators' backing for Keating's failing Lincoln Savings and Loan. In testimony Thursday, a career counsel for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, William K. Black, said the five senators mounted ``defense after defense after defense'' of Lincoln at a 1987 meeting when examiners informed them of massive violation's at Keating's thrift. And the senators did so, Black said, ``despite use laying out in the starkest terms ... exactly what was wrong, and it didn't impress them.'' But four members of the ethics panel appeared skeptical about whether the senators had been as aggressive as portrayed by Black. Sen. Terry Sanford, D-N.C., accused the witness and his fellow regulators of having a ``siege mentality'' when they entered the meeting with the five lawmakers. The committee is trying to learn whether the $1.3 million Keating raised for the five influenced their conduct. The senators are Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; Alan Cranston, D-Calif., and John Glenn, D-Ohio. Grogan was the corporate counsel for Keating's American Continental Corp. and vice president of Lincoln. He undertook several activities that could spark the committee's interest. For instance, he: -Arranged for Keating's contributions to three voter-registration projects supported by Cranston. Keating donated $850,000. -Set in motion a complaint by a Cranston aide to regulators about a tough enforcement action planned against Lincoln in May 1988. -Played a role in arranging two crucial meetings with regulators. One, on April 2, 1987, involved all of the five senators except Riegle; the second, a week later, included all the senators. -Was told in a memo from Keating to try to get Black fired for his tough stance against Lincoln. In that July 1987 memo, Keating wrote: ``Highest priority - get Black. Good grief - If you can't get Wright and Congress to get Black - kill him dead - you ought to retire.'' Wright is a reference to former House Speaker Jim Wright. Black, testifying Thursday, repeated his assertion that political pressure by the senators caused the bank board to loosen its regulatory control on Lincoln. He blamed the senators' pressure for the decision by top regulators in Washington to take San Francisco-based regulators off the examination of Lincoln. The examination, he said, would have disclosed phony transactions and a ``tax-sharing scam'' that sent false profits to Lincoln's parent company. ``This is the most likely explanation for this completely unprecedented and grossly improper action of halting the examination that would have blown all of these thing so wide open,'' Black said. The committee's vice chairman, Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., announced Thursday that, under a grant of limited immunity, Grogan will be asked to produce key documents Wednesday - five days before his closed-door testimony. There could be more private testimony after Dec. 17, and then public testimony by Grogan after that. The revised schedule will delay testimony from the five senators until they hear what Grogan has to say, Rudman announced. Seven witnesses, including Grogan and Keating, have refused to testify on Fifth Amendment grounds. Rudman said Keating would not be offered immunity and is not expected to appear. Documents abound on Grogan's role in dealing with the senators and their aides. On Oct. 6, 1987, Cranston wrote Keating, ``I am very grateful for your willingness to contribute $250,000 this year, and have asked Joy to discuss with Jim Grogan the states in which you would most like to help.'' Joy is Cranston fund-raiser Joy Jacobson. The money was for voter-registration projects. In the same letter, Cranston expressed his pleasure that Keating's meeting with M. Danny Wall, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, ``had gone so well.'' On May 6, 1988, Cranston aide Carolyn Jordan wrote the senator that she had just received a call from Grogan, who said the board had ``decided to take an enforcement action against Lincoln,'' including placing an overseer at the institution. Black testified that Ms. Jordan then complained to the regulators - causing a weakening of the action and eventually delaying the takeover. Glenn, in his opening statement, said Grogan, who once worked for the senator, had influenced his attendance at the April 2, 1987 meeting with regulators. Grogan, according to Glenn, ``had told my staff that Lincoln was being harassed and was receiving unfair treatment by federal banking regulators.'' Glenn said he then asked his staff for additional evidence of unfair treatment - a corroboration he said was routine even though the staff ``knew and trusted Jim Grogan.''

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says Carter Agreed Not to Intervene in Liberia
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Thursday former President Jimmy Carter agreed last summer that beleaguered Liberian President Samuel Doe's appeal for Carter's intervention to halt a civil war was unworkable. Carter, in a broadcast interview published Wednesday, said the State Department asked him not to play peacemaker in the bloody Liberian civil war and he obeyed. The former president said Doe, who was later killed by rebel forces, appealed to him last summer to come to Liberia to negotiate a peaceful solution to the civil war. ``I called the State Department and told them that I had this invitation, that I thought horrendous bloodshed was going to take place in Liberia,'' Carter said in a recent interview conducted for Alabama Public Television. ``After a day or two, they called back and asked me not to go, so I didn't.'' David Denny, a State Department spokesman, said Thursday that Doe asked the department last June to deliver a letter to Carter ``in which Doe asked for President Carter's assistance for holding early elections in Liberia.'' ``At that time, Doe's executive mansion was already under siege,'' the spokesman said in a department response to a query from The Associated Press. ``His calls for an election were rejected by the other parties. U.S. policy was to encourage Doe to enter into serious negotiations with other political and military forces to try to bring about a settlement to the Liberian crisis.'' Denny said Carter was briefed by telephone on the situation and ``our view of the essential unworkability of Doe's appeal.'' ``At that time, President Carter agreed with our approach,'' the spokesman reported. Doe, a 40-year-old master sergeant who had seized power in a bloody coup in 1980, was slain in September by a break-away rebel force after being lured to what was billed as a meeting to discuss a peaceful settlement of the conflict. Tribal massacres in the wake of the bloody power struggle have claimed more than 10,000 lives, and about half of Liberia's 2.3 million people are estimated to have sought refuge in neighboring countries. Carter, who was the only American president to visit Liberia, said he now devotes his efforts to ``waging peace'' in troubled areas of the world. He has acted as mediator in two of the African continent's most intractable wars, in Ethiopia and the Sudan. He cited the Liberian case as an example of his willingness to back away from sensitive issues and accept the advice of the State Department. Spokesmen for the department declined comment Wednesday on Carter's remarks. Carter said he routinely shares his invitations with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III, whom he described as very supportive. ``Sometimes they request that I not undertake a project where I've been invited in, and invariably I defer to their request,'' he said. He did not say who asked him to turn down Doe's request to visit Liberia, which was founded by freed American slaves in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer for Jim Bakker Donors Blames PTL Accountants
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for thousands of PTL contributors suing to get their money back argued Thursday a fraud scheme that put Jim Bakker in prison worked only because he had help from his accountants. Tom Anderson, an attorney for former Bakker believers in a $757 million lawsuit, blamed the accounting firm Deloitte, Haskins & Sells for his clients' troubles. ``If Deloitte had not aided and abetted, we would not be here,'' he said. Anderson made the remarks during his closing argument in a six-week civil trial. About 145,000 people are seeking reimbursement for money they paid to stay at Heritage USA, PTL's now-defunct religious theme park in Fort Mill, S.C. Lodging at the park entitled donors to be ``lifetime partners'' in PTL, Bakker's bankrupt ministry. Bakker, 49, is serving a 45-year prison sentence on conspiracy and mail fraud charges for overselling lifetime partnerships. The lawsuit said Bakker, other PTL officials and accountants including those of Deloitte conspired to set up secret bank accounts that were tapped to give huge bonuses to the Bakkers and ministry officials. The case could go to the jury Friday. Attorneys for Bakker and Deloitte argued that when it came to using donations, no harm was intended by the televangelist, his wife, Tammy, and other PTL officials. ``Jim Bakker did not intentionally wrong his people,'' said his lawyer, Jim Toms. ``Like all men, he was flawed and he made mistakes. But he gave every ounce of his strength to build his dream.'' ``Corporate America will be listening to your verdict, whatever it is,'' Anderson said. ``The auditing profession will be listening.'' Jim Williams, representing Deloitte, told the jury: ``I'm not representing corporate America.'' In his opening argument, Anderson sought to simplify the case, which has generated volumes of evidence and brought dozens of witnesses to the federal courthouse here. ``This is a case in which Jim Bakker stole from the church. This is a case in which Jim Bakker defrauded the lifetime partners and he went to jail for this,'' Anderson said. ``Deloitte knew all about the fraud. This is a case in which Deloitte didn't tell anyone.'' Toms said there was nothing simple about PTL or Bakker. ``This was not a simple man. This was not a simple place,'' he said. ``It was not a simple task he was undertaking.'' Toms described Bakker and his PTL followers as people of faith and vision. ``Visionaries may not always be practical, but they're people of faith who in their day did great things,'' Toms said. The lawsuit also named the accounting firm of Laventhol & Horwath as a defendant. The firm has since filed for bankruptcy protection and last month its attorneys withdrew from the trial. The other defendants are David Taggart, Bakker's former personal aide, and Aimee Cortese, a minister from New York who served on PTL's board of directors in the mid 1980s. Bakker did not testify at the trial. Mrs. Bakker was never charged. Three othe PTL officials have gone to jail for charges related to the case.

DOC.HEAD: New Contraceptive Expected To Be Approved Soon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 13-14 pvs, beginning `The contraceptive ...' with 9 grafs to detail on pricing and availability. Picks up 15th graf pvs, `The National...'
DOC.TEXT: The government is expected to give American women their first new birth control option in three decades when it approves a hormonal implant that prevents pregnancy for up to five years, officials said Thursday. The implant, called Norplant, was expected to win government approval within days, according to government and industry sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The method involves implanting in a woman's upper arm six silicone rubber capsules, each about the size of an inch-and-a-half-long wooden matchstick. The procedure is done with local anesthesia and the implant isn't noticeable. The capsules contain a hormone called levonorgestrel, a synthetic progestin, that is released slowly over time. The contraceptive effects are reversed immediately upon removal. ``Norplant is one of the most significant advances in contraception we've had in the last 30 years,'' since the birth control pill and intrauterine device became available, said Dr. Samuel A. Pasquale of the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Brunswick, N.J. ``It's the most effective, reversible method of contraception'' available in the United States, with a failure rate of less than 1 percent, said Pasquale, a principal investigator in the Norplant studies. It also would be the first long-acting, hormonal contraceptive available in this country. ``It's a new choice women have and there haven't been any new choices in the United States in a long time,'' said C. Wayne Bardin, vice president and director of medical research for the New York-based Population Council, which began researching the method in 1966. ``It offers them a new choice which is long-lasting and convenient, uses the lowest dose of hormone that's used in any (hormone-based method) and it doesn't contain estrogen,'' which can cause problems for some women, he said. Norplant has been approved in 16 countries, the council said. In the United States, it would be marketed by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories of Philadelphia. The company was reluctant to talk about Norplant without formal approval from the Food and Drug Administration. However, Wyeth-Ayerst spokeswoman Audrey Ashby said that assuming the drug is approved soon, the contraceptive would be available commercially in February. The company will train physicians on how to implant the capsules, but ``there will be some lag time,'' she said. Ashby declined to discuss the cost of Norplant, saying that pricing was being evaluated. However, she said expected it ``will be priced significantly below oral contraceptives over five years.'' Birth control pills cost about $15 to $20 per month. Bardin said he had been told the price for Norplant would be $200 to $300, which does not include the fee for implanting the device. That cost worries Lisa Kaeser of the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a research and education group that deals with reproductive health issues. ``I'm not sure it's going to be available for low-income women,'' she said. The contraceptive contains nothing new - the silicone rubber and the hormone have been used for many years, according to the council's literature. However, the delivery over a long period of time is a new technique. An FDA advisory board recommended approval of Norplant in April 1989, saying the method was at least as safe and effective as any other contraceptive on the market. The National Women's Health Network has expressed concern about the long-term safety of the implant and wants post-marketing surveillance to be conducted for 15 years to get more data. The contraceptive is more than 99 percent effective overall, meaning that for every 100 women who use Norplant for one year, at most one will become pregnant, according to the council's literature. During the first two years, the pregnancy rate for women on Norplant was one per 200 to 300 per year, Pasquale said. In the third year, however, women weighing more than 154 pounds had a higher pregnancy rate, about five per 100, he said. Its major side effect is menstrual irregularities, including prolonged periods and spotting between periods. About 15 percen of women who have the implant have it removed because of bleeding, Bardin said. ``It's been very popular in other countries,'' Bardin said. ``If you ask women what they like about it most, they say convenience.'' Norplant seems to be more popular when compared with oral contraceptives, he said. Among women who discontinue either after less than a year, 15 percent stopped using Norplant compared with 50 percent who stopped using the pill, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lung Cancer Continues to Rise Faster Among Women
DOC.TEXT: Deaths from lung cancer are continuing to increase faster among women than men, said health researchers who predict the trend won't slow down until 2013. The federal Centers for Disease Control said Thursday that lung cancer incidence and death rates for 1987 sustained a pattern of the 1980s: increasing steadily for women and fluctuating slightly for men. Previous studies have blamed increasing lung cancer rates among women on their giving up smoking less readily than men. CDC researchers estimate that 85 percent of lung cancer cases are caused by smoking. That excludes cases in non-smokers caused by second-hand smoke, said Dr. Ronald Aubert, a CDC epidemiologist. ``The whole passive smoking issue has been recognized more and more recently, and that's something to take into account,'' he said. The lung cancer death rate in this country rose slightly from 1980 to 1987, from 42.5 per 100,000 population to 47.9. The rate for males - who still suffer the most lung cancer, despite the increases among women - rose by fewer than 5 percentage points, from 71.6 to 75.0. But the lung cancer death rate for women increased by more than one-third in seven years, from 20.9 in 1980 to 28.2 in 1987, Aubert said. Similarly, lung cancer incidence nationwide increased from a rate of 52.4 in 1980 to 55.5 in 1986 - the latest year available for those statistics - and increased faster for women than for men. The increases in lung cancer incidence and death rates among women ``are consistent with historically increasing trends in smoking,'' the Atlanta-based CDC said. CDC researchers cautioned that because peaks in smoking are historically followed by peaks in lung cancer as much as 35 years later, today's lung cancer increases in women will continue for decades. ``Based on these trends, the increases ... for females are not expected to plateau until after the year 2013,'' the CDC said, citing a math-model projection taking into account smoking prevalences and progression of disease. ``That's our best guesstimate,'' Aubert said. ``I don't think it's fully understood why you have some more rapid growing cancers for some people, and not for others.'' In general, lung cancer death rates in the 1980s have been higher for black men than for white men, but did not differ significantly between white and black women, the CDC reported. Surveys have shown that smoking prevalence is higher among black men, who also tend to smoke brands higher in tar and nicotine, the CDC said.

DOC.HEAD: Now Powerless, Old Pals Thatcher and Reagan Sip Tea, Reminisce
DOC.TEXT: Not long ago, Margaret Thatcher rolled out the red carpet at 10 Downing St. for Ronald Reagan. But on Thursday the two old and now powerless pals just had a cup of tea at his hotel. Then Reagan had to hurry off to Downing Street to see the prime minister, John Major, and Mrs. Thatcher headed back to suburban London where she moved last week after her ouster in a governing Conservative Party revolt. ``They reminisced about their years together,'' said Reagan's spokesman, Mark Weinberg. ``They have many, many memories of their years in office. And they talked about what it is like to have been in office and then return to private life, and about current world affairs.'' Reagan, on a four-day British visit, had been scheduled to see Mrs. Thatcher at Downing Street - just like so many previous times when their great friendship made the U.S.-British relationship more special than at any time since World War II. Instead, the 65-year-old ex-prime minister showed up at Claridges Hotel in a chauffeur-driven Jaguar. A dozen passersby stopped to clap and wave. She was a few minutes behind four police escort vehicles. But they were for someone else, a visiting president from one of Africa's tiniest nations, Dawda Jawara of Gambia. When Reagan's second term was drawing to a close in 1988, Mrs. Thatcher laid on a magnificent farewell with motorcades and fanfares for a ceremony in the splendid setting of London's ancient Guildhall. She hailed him as the president who restored the American dream; he called her ``an inspiration to the world.'' But when British leaders, who have no fixed terms, fall, it is swift with no time for farewells. So the pair who governed through the 1980s met again with a handshake and a kiss before a clutch of photographers outside the hotel's second floor royal suite. Reagan, his wife, Nancy, and Mrs. Thatcher then headed in for tea. Reagan lauded Mrs. Thatcher, the fellow conservative who stood with him in the days of Cold War, saying, ``I salute you.'' At Downing Street, Reagan arrived just as visting Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was leaving. And he came out with Major when the new British leader spoke to reporters to welcome Iraq's decision to release Western hostages. A Downing Street spokeswoman said Reagan and Major spent about 45 minutes together. ``It was extremely amiable,'' she said. Earlier, the 79-year-old former president and his wife made the royal rounds, lunching with Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace after a meeting with the Queen Mother at nearby Clarence House. The queen, who gave Reagan an honorary knighthood in 1989, came out to meet him, apologizing that her husband, Prince Philip, had been delayed by fog on his way home from Australia. The Reagans are due to return to Los Angeles on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Masterpiece Paintings, Stolen in 1985, Returned to Paris
DOC.TEXT: Nine paintings that vanished in a brazen 1985 theft, including the Monet masterpiece that gave impressionism its name, returned to Paris on Thursday after police found them in a Corsican villa. Police said recovery resulted in part from information gathered from gangsters in Japan. ``It's the best Christmas present we could have,'' said Arnaud d'Hauterives, curator of the Marmottan Museum. He said Claude Monet's ``Impression Sunrise'' and the other works might be ready for re-display at the Marmottan by the end of the month after specialists treated them for damage caused by humidity. D'Hauterives joined Culture Minister Jack Lang in praising the persistence of a special police art theft unit, headed by Commissioner Mireille Balestrazzi. Balestrazzi, one of the highest-ranking women in the national police force, said the key breakthrough in the case came during a 1987 trip to Japan to bring home four paintings by Camille Corot that had been stolen in 1984 from a museum in eastern France. She said her team learned that a Japanese collector had been considering the purchase of one of the nine Marmottan works, although the transaction did not take place. She said additional information was obtained through contacts with the ``yakuza,'' or members of Japan's organized crime network. Some of the gangsters were approached by representatives of the thieves, she said, but refused to get involved. Balestrazzi provided few other details about the five-year investigation. Authorities said one man had been arrested in Corsica and about a dozen other people had been questioned, but they indicated that the thieves themselves remained at large. The nine paintings from the Marmottan, along with an as-yet-unidentified 17th century painting, were found Tuesday in a villa in Porto-Vecchio in southern Corsica. Balestrazzi said the theft was committed solely in hopes of profit and was in no way linked to any of Corsica's militant separatist movements. She said the works were in good condition, although a few had suffered slightly from humidity. Experts were to conduct a thorough examination to assess their condition. Five armed, masked men carried out the theft on a Sunday morning in October 1985, getting away easily because the Marmottan's alarm system had been disconnected the previous night. About 30 visitors and nine guards were held at bay by the gunmen. They were in the museum for only about 10 minutes, and drove away after putting the paintings in the trunk of a car. The stolen paintings included five Monets, two by Pierre Auguste Renoir and one by Berthe Morisot, as well as a portrait of Monet. Their total value was estimated at the time at $12 million, but one official described ``Impression Sunrise'' as priceless. The 1872 work shows the port at Le Havre in a mixture of blues and browns, with an orange sun shining through the morning fog. It was first displayed in 1874, and derisive critics dismissed it as ``impressionist.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Jet Plows Into High School, 12 Students Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE injury toll, number of people at school, new survivor quotes, other. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BO2,3,MIL7
DOC.TEXT: A burning, pilotless military jet plowed into a classroom at a suburban high school Thursday, killing 12 students, officials said. Many survivors jumped from upper windows and were among the 87 injured. The pilot of the Italian air force jet had been trying to land his disabled plane in fields near the school, and ejected minutes before the crash, Gen. Carlo Brandini said. The pilot suffered injuries. Some survivors, engulfed by heavy smoke, were rescued from the third floor by firemen on ladders. Police said 87 people suffered burns, broken bones or smoke inhalation and were taken by ambulance or helicopter to hospitals in Bologna. One fireman was hurt. At the time of the crash, 285 students, 28 teachers and four monitors were at the Gaetano Salvemini vocational high School in Casalecchio, three miles from Bologna, authorities said. ``I heard a lot of students screaming and I saw at least eight of them jump in panic from the third floor,'' said Giovanna Degli Esposti, who watched from her home in a nearby condominium complex. ``Luckily the firemen arrived in a few minutes.'' She said it was recess time and some students were already outside Gaetano Salvemini High School in Casalecchio, three miles from Bologna. A paramilitary official said all 12 dead were students in the classroom hit by the jet, which tore a 12-foot-wide hole in a wall on the second floor of the three-story building. A teacher who was giving a German lesson to the 16 pupils in the class was hospitalized in Parma, in critical condition with burns, the officer said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Fireman Tonino Pavoni said he heard the cries of a girl in the class who was trapped under wreckage of a wing, and pulled her free. The girl, Federica Tacconi, 16, suffered a crushed pelvis, said ANSA. ``The German lesson was almost over. The teacher was giving us homework. I heard a very loud noise, I saw the airplane come down, then it was the end of the world. I found myself on the floor, in pain, and now I'm here,'' ANSA quoted her as saying from her hospital bed. Brandini said the plane was on a mission to test the effectiveness of an anti-aircraft radar system and had taken off from Villafranca military airport near Verona, 55 miles north of Bologna. He said the Macchi 326 trainer was flying at about 280 mph when trouble developed in its single engine, which then burst into flames. Brandini said the pilot ejected ``according to regulations.'' He identified the pilot as 2nd Lt. Bruno Viviani and said Viviani first thought he could make an emergency landing at Bologna's airport. ``When he saw he couldn't do it, he directed the plane toward an open area. If the plane had cleared the school, it would have crashed in...open fields,'' Brandini said from air force headquarters in Rome. ANSA quoted a student as saying, ``I was in class and saw through a window this low-flying plane coming at us and only had time to say `This is crazy.''' The 24-year-old pilot suffered fractured vertebrae and was questioned by a prosecutor in the hospital, ANSA said. Brandini said the plane was flying low when the pilot ejected, but he didn't know the exact altitude. A helicopter, alerted to the pilot's distress, was following the jet and rescued the pilot after he parachuted to safety. The Italian-produced jet, a two-seater, had only the pilot was aboard, Brandini said. The plane, which has been purchased by several other countries' military forces, has a wingspan of 35 feet and can be used for training or for attack. In addition to the prosecutor's office, a military commission is investigating the crash. Opposition parliamentarian Filippo Berselli demanded the government explain why a military jet was on a training mission over a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Bathes With Pig and Noodles For Free Tickets.
DOC.TEXT: A country music fan was in hog heaven after a bath with steaming noodles and a 6-month-old pig won her tickets to see her favorite star. ``I'm a big Clint Black fan,'' said Karen Herring, who wallowed Wednesday in a noodle-filled bathtub for 30 minutes.``I just wanted to go see him.'' Ms. Herring, 38, came up with the idea for the stunt after Jackson country music station WJDX held a contest offering free tickets to see Black Thursday night at the Mississippi Coliseum. Listeners were asked what they would do for the tickets. Ms. Herring's proposal was the most unusual one, disc jockey Scott Mateer said. ``We felt this was the most daring, most creative thing she could do,'' he said. So while about 100 people looked on, Ms. Herring, clad in a French maid's costume, plunged into the bathtub with a pig named Clint. ``She's crazy,'' said her 15-year-old daughter, Mindy. ``Is this a crazy town or what?'' spectator David Grayson asked.

DOC.HEAD: AU Trustees Rescind $1 million Offer to Berendzen
DOC.TEXT: The trustees of American University voted unanimously Thursday to rescind its controversial offer to pay nearly $1 million to buy out the contract of former president Richard Berendzen, who pleaded guilty to making obscene telephone calls. Berendzen had asked the trustees to withdraw the offer after he was offered a chance to return as a full professor on the physics faculty in the spring of 1992. That agreement puts Berendzen, 51, on administrative leave with pay at his faculty salary for the 1990-91 academic year and the fall 1991 semester. His annual salary would be in the range of $70,000, officials said. He has continued to draw his annual salary of about $140,000 since resigning as president in April. Berendzen, named president in 1980, pleaded guilty to making obscene telephone calls to a woman from his office. Two 30-day jail terms were suspended in lieu of psychiatric treatment. Students, faculty and staff members representing various groups were harshly critical of the proposed $1 million settlement. Although Edward Carr, chairman of the trustees, declined to discuss specifics, the initial buyout offer reportedly would have reached $1 million, including more than $600,000 in appreciation for Berendzen's contributions in raising the school's image and prestige. Carr said that agreement would not affect severance payments to Berendzen provided for in his presidential contract. Carr estimated the amount at slightly less than $400,000. Carr said the trustees supported the agreement allowing Berendzen to return to teaching. Gayle Abbott, president of the school's Alumni Association, said her group felt ``that the best interests of American University mandate that A.U. sever all ties'' with Berendzen.'' Abbott urged that Berendzen not be allowed to return as a member of the faculty. Betty Bennett, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, said originally the deans did not support Berendzen returning to teach. ``If he does decide to return, then we will welcome him back ... and we would take it from there,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Dallas Votes Saturday On Changing City Council Structure
DOC.TEXT: Voters in the nation's eighth largest city are divided over a referendum designed to help minorities win seats on the City Council. Supporters of the proposal to create single-member districts say the plan would help ease racial inequities that make it difficult for minorites to get elected. Opponents say the referendum would actually re-segregate Dallas. They back a plan voters approved last year that called for some candidates to be elected by district, others by region and one at large for the 11-member council. The referendum, up for vote Saturday, has heightened existing racial tension in the ethnically diverse city, community leaders said. ``To some, this election represents the last chance for peace in Dallas,'' said Roy Williams, one of two former City Council candidates who sued the city over its election system, saying it was discriminatory. ``It would be a serious mistake for the city to ignore the warning signs - widespread frustrations and cynicism in the community,'' Williams said. Under the existing system instituted in 1975, eight council members are elected in individual districts and another three, including the mayor, are elected by voters citywide. The system voters approved by a 2-1 margin in August 1989 called for 10 candidates to be chosen by district, four by region and one at large. That system was never implemented because a federal judge suggested he would rule it unconstitutional. The system proposed in the referendum calls for the creation of 14 single-member districts, with a mayor elected at large. The referendum is being held as part of the settlement of the 1988 federal lawsuit brought by Williams and Marvin Crenshaw, who failed in their at-large council bids. The men, who are both black, charged the existing election system made it difficult for minorities to win election. Black and Hispanic leaders nationwide have long charged that at-large elections dilute minority candidates' political power and make it difficult for them to win office. They maintain minorities have a better chance of winning office under a political system in which candidates are elected by individual districts. The city proposed the referendum on the newest plan when it reached a settlement with Williams and Crenshaw in August. Although minorities are estimated to make up more than half the city's population, only two of 11 City Council members are black, and there are no Hispanics. Only one minority - a Hispanic who no longer serves on the council - has won an at-large City Council election. If a simple majority of voters approve the plan, a commission will be set up to draw new district lines next year, using 1990 Census figures. Almost 17,000 of the city's 451,411 registered voters cast absentee ballots as of Thursday. Former Dallas Cowboy quarterback Roger Staubach is among those who support the change. ``You've got to look at where Dallas has come and how it has treated the representation of minorities,'' Staubach said. ``It has not been fair.'' Opponents include City Councilman Glenn Box, who said the plan is a token quota system that re-segregates the city. ``We don't become an integrated city with 14-1,'' Box said. A poll The Dallas Morning News published last weekend indicated voters were not unified on the issue. Half of the likely voters the newspaper contacted said they would support the measure. Another 30 percent said they would vote no and 20 percent were undecided. There have been no formal estimates of the city's racial makeup since the 1980 census, when Dallas' 904,078 population was 61 percent white, 26 percent black and 12 Hispanic. The racial breakdown of the 1990 Census count of 982,250 people is expected to show a majority black and Hispanic population.

DOC.HEAD: Twenty-Year Sentence in Capitol Bombing
DOC.TEXT: Leftist radical Laura Whitehorn received a 20-year sentence Thursday for bombing the U.S. Capitol and conspiring to set off seven other explosions that a prosecutor called acts of terrorism. Whitehorn was sentenced along with co-defendant Linda Sue Evans, who was ordered to serve five years for her role in the bombing conspiracy after completing a 35-year term she is already serving for illegally buying firearms. The two women, who pleaded guilty in a plea bargain Sept. 7, were sentenced by U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene at a proceeding punctuated by the cheers and applause of supporters who packed the courtroom. ``You have committed acts of violence which are not excused by good purposes or political purposes,'' Greene said. ``The effect of these kinds of violence are just as devastating to the victims and to society at large as if they were motivated by greed.'' ``The defendants Linda Evans and Laura Whitehorn are terrorists,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Margaret Ellen told the judge. ``They are people who by their actions have sought to coerce others by means of threats or violence.'' The Nov. 7, 1983 bonb blast that blew a hole in the wall outside the Senate chamber and the explosions at seven other locations in Washington and New York City ``were not symbolic gestures; they were distinct acts of terrorism,'' Ellen said. ``Only chance prevented serious harm'' to people, she said. Over boos of the defendants' supporters, she said, ``The government has not and does not view these actions as political crimes.'' Evans' involvement in the bombing conspiracy was part of ``a pattern of escalating violence'' that includes a 1987 conviction for buying firearms and ammunition, Ellen said. FBI agents who raided a Baltimore apartment where Whitehorn and Evans, 43, lived found components for more bombs and written plans to set off explosives at other locations. Whitehorn, 45, who raised her right fist to greet supporters as she entered the courtroom, described her involvment in what she called a radical struggle against racism, militarism and oppression of poor people. ``This government put us in a difficult position of choosing between morality and the law,'' Whitehorn. ``How did Martin Luther King achieve progress without violence?'' Greene asked at one point during the proceeding. ``The struggle of Martin Luther King is not divorced from other struggles that because of necessity had incorporated violence,'' said defense attorney Nkechi Taifi. ``This whole country is built upon violence,'' the lawyer said, evoking cheers and applause from the crowd. Whitehorn received the maximum term for each of three charges to which she pleaded guilty: conspiracy, malicious destruction of government property and possession of equipment to make false documents. In sentencing Evans, Greene said he was taking into account the fact that she was already serving a 35-year prison term. Greene dismissed all charges against Susan Rosenberg and Timothy Blunk, who are both serving 58 years for possession of explosives, as part of the plea bargain. A Supreme Court ruling on double jeopardy precluded their prosecution. Charges against Alan Berkman, who is undergoing chemotherapy for Hodgkin's disease, will be dismissed at another, unscheduled, proceeding. Another defendant, Marilyn Buck, was given a 10-year prison term on Nov. 16 to run concurrently with a 60-year term she is serving for other crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor, Ex-Beau Reach Out-of-Court Settlement Over Passion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with out-of-court settlement, both sides agree to drop lawsuits; EDITS to conform. No pickup. CHANGES byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA8
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor and an ex-beau reached an out-of-court settlement Thursday in a battle over Passoon perfume profits, ending what promised to be a revealing peek into the star's personal life. Both sides agreed to drop their lawsuits in the middle of jury selection. The judge announced the actress and former boyfriend Henry Wynberg reached a settlement that leaves Miss Taylor in control of the perfume line. Wynberg sued Miss Taylor for a share of $70 million in profits, claiming she breached a contract with him to market the highly popular fragrance. She had countered Wynberg's lawsuit with claims that his criminal record led her to abandon their planned business deal and turn to a major cosmetics company that began marketing Passion. Miss Taylor won permission to tell jurors about Wynberg's statutory rape conviction. Miss Taylor's lawyer, Neil Papiano, said no money would change hands and each arty would pay its own legal expenses. ``It means I'm vindicated and it proves the perfume, Passion, is something I worked for a year and a half for. ... It has nothing to do with Henry Wynberg,'' Miss Taylor said afterward. Miss Taylor said she didn't relish the idea of being on the witness stand, but didn't say that was the reason for reaching the settlement. ``It's not like on television. It's not over in an hour. It's not something I was looking forward to, but I was willing to fight as long as I had to,'' she said. Wynberg said: ``I'm pleased it's all over with.'' He said his decision wasn't based on fear a trial would reveal too much about his criminal past. ``That turns out to be a two-way street. Anything they wanted to ask of me we could have asked also of Elizabeth,'' Wynberg said. His lawyer, Quentin Kopp, refused to discuss how the settlement came about or any details. They also refused to acknowledge that Wynberg wouldn't receive any money. Attorneys had been negotiating for some time, but were unable to reach agreement until Thursday, Papiano said. Jury selection had been under way for a day and a half, highlighted Thursday by a prospective panelist's assertion that he had seen most of the 58-year-old star's silent films, provoking laughter in the packed courtroom. Under questioning by attorneys, a majority of potential panelists said they have only vague memories of Miss Taylor as an actress. Most said they best remember Miss Taylor as the child star of ``National Velvet.'' Two said they had never seen the Academy Award-winning actress on film and one associated her with the silent-film era, which predates her career. ``I go back to the silent movies, so I've seen most of her films,'' the prospective panelist said when asked if he had ever seen her on the screen. Miss Taylor, wearing a black dress and a thick gold necklace, bracelet and earrings, reacted with a mock expression of horror, then laughed along with others in the courtroom. Prospective jurors were asked about alcoholism, AIDS, what kind of perfume they wear and their taste in television and movie viewing habits. Miss Taylor's past bout with alcoholism was raised because Wynberg claims her alcoholism and related weight gain destroyed the glamorous image he counted on to market cosmetics under her name. The entire jury pool said they weren't biased by Miss Taylor's work raising money for AIDS research. Wynberg is a former used car salesman who courted Miss Taylor between her two marriages to Richard Burton in the 1970s. Wynberg and Miss Taylor said they had been hurt deeply by personal attacks during the litigation. But Wynberg said they left the courtroom as good friends. ``It's just like old times,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Developments at a Glance
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is some of the reaction to Saddam Hussein's promise to free foreign hostages held in Iraq and Kuwait: --- President Bush welcomed Saddam's freedom promise but insisted ``the man must leave Kuwait without reservation, without condition'' before the Gulf crisis can end. --- Secretary of State James Baker III told Congress that releasing the hostages ``does not lessen, nor should it, our determination that Iraq's aggression against Kuwait should be reversed.'' --- Wall Street reacted with a brief rally and an initial sharp plunge in oil prices. Bond prices, the dollar's value and gold all fell. Oil prices dropped more than $2 a barrel, but ended with an 89-cent loss, closing at $26.40 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The Dow Jones average finished down 7.92 points to 2,602.48. The average had been up over 30 points in the first 15 minutes of trading. --- Relatives reacted with joy and caution: ``There were times I couldn't eat, I couldn't sleep,'' said Doris Whatley of Shreveport, La. ``All of a sudden I am a changed person ... because my husband is coming home.'' ``The news is very welcome, but we're not throwing a celebration,'' said Margaret Williams, whose son and daughter-in-law are among ``human shields.'' ``We'll celebrate when we see them coming out - and not before,'' she said from her home in Germantown, Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Ignores Bombings, Praises Chile Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to include further anti-Bush incidents, SUBS 20th graf prvs, `Last weekend...' to say that 1976 sanctions imposed over human rights, not over Letelier case
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, unfazed by a spate of bombing incidents that greeted his arrival here Thursday, hailed Chile's peaceful transition to democracy and its pro-growth economic policies. Bush received a generally friendly welcome on the first visit by an American president in 30 years. He hailed Chile's ``democratic renaissance'' and said ``Chile's return to the ranks of the world's democracies is cause for pride and celebration.'' But the bombings and other anti-American incidents were a reminder that Chile has not yet escaped its fractious political past. Before Bush arrived, leftist guerrillas exploded a half-dozen bombs overnight at sites with U.S. ties, including four Mormon chapels, a new McDonald's restaurant and a downtown park outside a hotel where some officials in Bush's advance party were staying. The incidents, however, seemed designed more to make a political statement than to cause harm. Police reported no injuries. The president's limousine was also hit by an egg thrown from the crowd as his motorcade passed through Santiago streets. Police used tear gas and water cannon to scatter scores of university students who threw rocks at police and blocked traffic during a two-hour anti-Bush protest at a campus in the southern section of the city. They burned at least two U.S. flags and waved several Cuban flags. Later, shortly before Bush's arrival for a dinner at the presidential palace, police dispersed demonstrators who were shouting anti-American slogans. But generally the visit - Bush's fourth stop on a week-long South American tour - went smoothly. At a colorful airport arrival ceremony, at a news conference and at a speech to the national congress, Bush heaped praise on Chile not only for its peaceful return to democracy but its ability to generate economic growth rates that are the envy of Latin America. Many Chileans have viewed the United States with suspicion and hostility for years because of suggestions that the United States subverted Chile's democracy in 1973, paving the way for 17 years of military rule. With the restoration of freedom and economic growth, much of the passion against the United States has dissipated. At the red-carpet welcome for Air Force One at the airport, President Patricio Aylwin said, ``Mr. President, we welcome you with joy.'' ``We value your presence in our land. We share common ideals,'' he said. Also on hand at the airport was former military ruler Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who is still commander in chief of the army. After shaking hands with Bush, the smiling Pinochet told reporters: ``I want to thank President Bush because he recognized that the previous government encouraged free market policies.'' It was the first time Pinochet met a visiting head of state after handing over power last March. In his speech to the Congress in Valparaiso , Bush said that Chile ``has moved farther, faster that any other nation in South America toward real market reform.'' He said there has been an increase of 15 to 20 per cent in the value of exports in each of the last five years. One issue dividing the United States and Chile is a four-day grape embargo imposed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration against Chile last year. Inspectors reportedly found two grapes laced with cyanide in the hold of a ship in Philadelphia. Chilean growers are demanding compensation for losses estimated at $330 million. The issue was taken up during Thursday's talks here. Bush said the FDA decision was based purely on health considerations and was not intended to punish Chile. The Bush administration prefaced the visit by lifting sanctions imposed during the dictatorship of Pinochet, who ousted Chile's leftist president, Salvador Allende, in 1973. In late November, Washington allowed Chile back into the General Preferences System, which grants tariff concessions to exports from many countries. The move could mean a $100 million increase in Chile's U.S. exports, according to Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley. The Reagan administration excluded Chile from the tariff preference system in 1988 to protest Pinochet's repression of the Chilean labor movement. Last weekend, the administration lifted a ban on military aid and the sale of military equipment imposed in 1976 to protest alleged human rights violations in Chile. Bilateral relations further deteriorated that year following the murder on a Washington street of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile who was an arch foe of military rule in Chile. The United States has said that Chilean security officers were responsible for the incident, in which an associate of Letelier's, Ronni Moffitt, also died. Aylwin, speaking at the news conference with Bush, promised ``a full clarification of truth and justice'' in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Dry Weather Prevails With Rain and Snow in Some Areas
DOC.TEXT: Dry weather prevailed Thursday across most of the nation, with rain from Oklahoma to Missouri and snow lingering over Colorado and western New York state. A cold front brought strong southerly winds to the south-central sections of the United States and wind advisories for most of Texas and Oklahoma. Strong, gusty winds also developed over parts of Southern California, including the Tehachapi Mountains in Kern County. High temperatures ranged from the 20s in Colorado, Wyoming, Minnesota, Wisconsin and upper Michigan, the 60s and 70s over Florida and southern Texas and the lower 80s in Southern California. The nation's low was 1 degree in McCall, Idaho. Flooding resulting from earlier heavy rains continued Thursday in South Carolina and in portions of the Kankakee and Wabash rivers in Indiana. Officials announced that record flooding in Washington state last month ravaged wilderness areas in the state's western sections, with damage to Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest alone estimated at $12 million. The Wenatchee, Olympic and Gifford Pinchot forests also suffered. Damage to roads, homes and businesses has been estimated at tens of millions of dollars and some counties were declared federal disaster areas. Two men died in Thanksgiving weekend floods. California farmers got some bad weather news Thursday. The state told farmers, who already face a grim water outlook as California enters its fifth dry year, that they may get only one-third of their scheduled supplies in 1991. ``This is not absolutely the worst case scenario, but it's close to it,'' said Don Long, the state Department of Water Resources' top water analyst.

DOC.HEAD: Fugitive American John Hull Settling Down in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: A fugitive American linked to the Iran-Contra scandal is building a new life in this provincial capital with the support of some powerful patrons and former rebel leaders. Hull fled neighboring Costa Rica in July 1989 after posting bail following his arrest on charges of drug trafficking and ``hostility to the security of the state of Costa Rica.'' The last charge stems from his allegedly letting air strips at his farms near the Nicaraguan border be used by the CIA to resupply Contra rebels inside Nicaragua in 1984 and 1985. The U.S.-born Hull has been identified by federal prosecutors as a point man in former National Security Council aide Oliver North's efforts to funnel aid to Nicaraguan rebels. The program, which turned into the Iran-Contra scandal, involved the selling of weapons to Iran and the illegal diversion of proceeds to help Nicaragua's Contra rebels. Since his arrival five months ago, Hull, who is about 70, has been living in modest rented homes in Juigalpa with his adopted daughter, Emily. Former top Contra leader Israel Galeano, known as ``Commander Franklyn,'' said Hull is deciding whether to stay. ``We have known him for a long time, and he always has helped us when we were in our most difficult moments,'' Galeano is quoted as saying in Barricada, the official Sandinista newspaper. The Contras abandoned their war after the leftist Sandinistas were voted out of ofiice and replaced by a U.S.-backed administration earlier this year. Hull avoids the press. But in interviews with friends, associates and neighbors, a picture of his new life has emerged. According to local officials, Hull intends to get involved in cattle ranching, lumber exporting and citrus plantations. Nicaraguan officials say they have not received any extradition requests from Costa Rican and that there are no charges against him in Nicaragua. Costa Rica presented an extradition request to the United States, where Hull initially fled after jumping bail. But Hull vanished again, later turning up in Nicaragua. In Costa Rica, the Foreign Ministry has asked the Supreme Court to change the extradition request from the United States to Nicaragua. ``By pure chance I saw Hull (Tuesday) in Managua. He drove past me in his pickup truck,'' said Carlos Aguilar, Costa Rica's ambassador in Managua. Juigalpa Mayor Isaac DeLeo says he did not realize who Hull was when he first met him. ``Some little time ago, he came here and he was introduced to me by a gentleman from the Resistance, who said that Hull had protected the boys and given them food when they were in Costa Rica,'' said DeLeo. ``He said he wanted to buy a ranch in Chontales and that he has a friend from California who wants to set up a shoe factory here.'' In addition to his links to resupplying Contras, Hull has been implicated in Costa Rica in the 1984 assassination attempt against former Contra leader Eden Pastora.
