A bomb at a news conference at Pastora's jungle camp in La Penca, Nicaragua, killed five people, including an American journalist. ``He (Hull) said to me, `I swear I had absolutely nothing to do with La Penca','' DeLeo said. Hull is one of 29 people named in a civil suit in the United States filed over the bombing. The suit claims the bomb was the work of the CIA. ``He's a very quiet man, very well educated and of few words,'' DeLeo said. ``I have no commitments with Mr. Hull, I only have helped him look for housing.'' Hull has also reportedly sponsored humanitarian donations, earning the gratitute of Dr. Leonel Rosales, director of Juigalpa's hospital. ``We all knew exactly who he was when he came here,'' Rosales said. ``But I'm not interested in all that. If the devil comes to donate medical materials - of if God comes - I'll take it and don't ask questions.'' In November, Hull introduced Dr. Verne Chaney, president of the New York-based Dooley Foundation, to Rosales. Chaney was to bring two containers full of donations, including X-ray and blood analysis machines, for a Contra clinic near the Honduran border. ``Hull ... came back saying that he (Chaney) did not think that place met the conditions for the machines to work,'' Rosales said. ``Then Hull said the donations would instead be given to our hospital.''

DOC.HEAD: Bensonhurst Defendant Vento Acquitted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 5th graf, `He faced ...' to UPDATE with comments from prosecutor, juror. Pick up 6th graf, `The trial ...
DOC.TEXT: A Bensonhurst defendant whose first murder trial ended with a hung jury was acquitted Thursday of murder and manslaughter in the racially motivated slaying of a black youth. John Vento, 22, was found guilty only of riot. He was the third defendant acquitted of major charges this week. As the verdict was read, the defendant banged his hands on the defense table and screamed, ``Yes, yes, yes!'' Vento, crying, then grabbed and hugged his lawyer before he was restrained by court officers. The jury in state Supreme Court returned the verdict during the second full day of deliberations. The riot conviction carries a maximum term of one and one-third to four years in prison. He faced 25 years to life in prison if convicted on the murder charge. ``It's always hard to convict someone when he was not the triggerman,'' said Assistant District Attorney Paul Burns. ``This jury was a smart jury, and I have absolutely no criticism of their verdict whatsoever.'' ``All I will tell you is it was a very, very difficult case and a very difficult decision,'' said juror Gay Fallows, reached by telephone. The trial was the second for Vento, the former star prosecution witness turned defendant. Vento backed out of a deal to testify against his friends after he and his family received threats. In July, a jury convicted Vento of unlawful imprisonment and menacing, but acquitted him of the most serious charge he faced, intentional murder. The panel deadlocked on a second murder count and riot. A few weeks later he was also indicted on second-degree manslaughter. He is serving a sentence of up to eight years in prison for the convictions. Prosecutors described Vento as a major participant in the Aug. 23, 1989, slaying of Yusuf Hawkins in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Hawkins, 16, was in the predominantly white neighborhood to look at a used car. He was cornered by a gang of whites and fatally shot in the chest. ``He was there, he helped organize and recruit a mob,'' Assistant District Attorney Paul Burns said of Vento. ``He was there when the mob armed itself and he was there as one of the leaders of the mob.'' Defense attorney Gerald J. DiChiara defended Vento as a young man drawn into what he thought would be a brawl to protect his friend Keith Mondello and to keep outsiders from his neighborhood. ``Kids fight. Kids who are 17 and up who hang out at luncheonettes and candy stores fight, but they're not murderers,'' DiChiara said. He argued that Joseph Fama, who has been convicted of murder in the case, acted alone and that there was no evidence proving Vento shared the killer's mental culpability. Prosecutors did not say Vento shot Hawkins, but maintained that in helping Fama corner and then shoot the teen-ager he acted in concert with the shooter and was equally guilty of murder. In the weeks following the shooting, Vento agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in exchange for immunity and appeared before a grand jury. He subsequently backed out of the deal and fled the city after the threats against his family, DiChiara said. Vento surrendered in Ohio, but opted to face a trial rather than resume his cooperation. Fama, convicted of murder and other crimes, is serving 32 and two-thirds years to life. Mondello, the organizer of the mob, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter, but was sentenced to up to 16 years in prison for his conviction on several leser crimes. Three other defendants are scheduled to stand trial early next year for their alleged roles in the slaying.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam: Hostages Should be Freed, U.N. Ambassador Says by Xmas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with releases could begin as early as Saturday. Picks up 5th pvs `Saddam said...' ^LaserPhoto AMM1
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein told his parliament Thursday to free all foreign hostages in response to ``positive changes'' in the Persian Gulf crisis, and he said Iraq should apologize to the thousands who were held. Baghdad wants all the hostages released and home by Christmas, Iraq's U.N. ambassador said Thursday. ``Definitely, we would like to see everyone with his family by Christmas, because that is a very joyous and happy occasion, and it is time for family reunions,'' Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari said at the U.N. headquarters. There are an estimated 900 U.S. hostages among the thousands held by the Iraqis in Iraq and Kuwait in the aftermath of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of the neighboring oil-rich emirate. Their release could begin as early as Saturday, Iraqi officials said late Thursday, though processing of visa applications and other papers could take days. Saddam said the reason for holding foreigners - to deter an attack - had diminished. He also said Iraqi troops had been given the time to become battle ready. The Iraqi leader also noted there had been growing opposition in the United States to President Bush's efforts to form a consensus for military action to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. The 250-seat National Assembly, which routinely backs the ruling Baath party leader, scheduled a meeting for 11 a.m. Friday. If it approves Saddam's proposal as expected, it would be the first time Iraq has agreed to abide by a U.N. Security Council resolution on the crisis sparked by Iraq's invasion. President Bush welcomed the announcement but said Saddam should not have taken people hostage in the first place. And Bush insisted: ``The man must leave Kuwait without reservation, without condition'' before the standoff can end. Iraq holds thousands of foreigners, whom it refers to as ``guests.'' Some 600 of them - mainly Americans, Britons and Japanese - have been moved to strategic military and industrial sites to serve as human shields to ward off military action. Saddam said the foreigners were people ``who do not want to fight'' and who got ``trapped in the space between the two trenches.'' In all, there are an estimated 950,000 foreigners in Iraq and occupiedKuwait, but Saddam earlier said most Asians and Arabs - the majority of the foreigners - were free to leave. There was a spontaneous celebration Thursday at the Al-Mansour Melia Hotel in downtown Baghdad, where several hostages were brought to meet with visiting family members. ``We did it at last and now we can go home for Christmas,'' said Susan Dring, who traveled to Baghdad last week to try to win her husband's freedom. Michael Dring stood behind her, celebrating with a can of imported beer. Saddam's decision coincided with a report that his foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, will meet with Bush in Washington on Dec. 17 to discuss a possible settlement of the crisis. Bush had said he would receive Aziz during the week of Dec. 10, then dispatch Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad. The announcement also came as a source in Paris said ambassadors of the five permanent members of the Security Council - including the United States - had agreed on a resolution seeking an international peace conference on the Middle East. Since 10 days after the invasion, Saddam has stressed a linkage of other Middle East problems, particularly the Israeli occupation of Palestinian lands in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, to a withdrawal from Kuwait. The United States rejects such a linkage, insisting that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait before the Arab-Israeli conflict is discussed. In his letter to parliament speaker Sadi Mehdi Saleh, Saddam said his decision was prompted by recent consultations with his ``Arab brothers,'' a reference to a meeting Tuesday with King Hussein of Jordan, PLO chief Yasser Arafat and Yemeni Vice President Ali Salem al-Beidh. Saddam said ``the reason for which the foreigners were prevented from travel have diminished and has been replaced by something more powerful - a change in the American public opinion which will impose restrictions on the decisions and intentions of the evil ones, led by Bush, the enemy of God.'' Iraq stopped foreigners from leaving in response to a U.S.-led multinational troop buildup in Saudi Arabia and the gulf region which followed the occupation of Kuwait. About 400,000 soldiers have been deployed in the multinational force. The United States alone has 250,000 and nearly 200,000 more on their way. The Security Council told Saddam last week that he must leave Kuwait by Jan. 15 or face a military onslaught. That resolution, the 12th against Iraq since the crisis erupted, also demanded that he free all hostages. Saddam told Saleh the foreigners were interned to ``delay war'' and provide Iraqi forces with enough time to prepare for a possible war over Kuwait. Now that the Iraqi military is battle ready, Saddam said, the foreigners should regain their ``freedom to travel.'' ``We deem it necessary that our National Assembly convene to take a final and irrevocable stand toward a humanitarian issue,'' he said. He referred to his earlier offer to allow the foreigners to leave between Dec. 25 and March 25, which is the most likely period for an attack to drive Iraq from Kuwait. He added that recent overtures prompted him to ``respond to positive changes.'' Among the positive changes, he cited a drive within the United States to avert war and give sanctions imposed on Iraq more time. Several witnesses appearing before Congress this week have urged caution. Saddam referred briefly to Bush's offer for talks with Iraq. ``Bush's calls for dialogue are still concealing war intentions and we must be aware not to fall into such traps,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir: Israel Won't Accept Peace Conference
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel rejected Thursday the idea of an international Mideast peace conference, and he vowed to ask Washington about reports it is backing the idea at the United Nations. Shamir labeled as ``rumors'' the reports that the United States will ask the U.N. Security Council to consider convening the peace conference. In a speech at a Joint Israel Appeal fundraising dinner, Shamir also reassured Israel's supporters that the country is ready to deal with threats by Iraq's leader. Saddam Hussein has said Israel would be the first target in any Persian Gulf conflict. ``Saddam Hussein must surely know that if he resorts to violent action against Israel, he will pay dearly for such action,'' Shamir said. ``The days when people could attack defenseless Jews with impunity are over. This is what Israel is all about.'' About 6 million Jews were killed in the Nazi Holocaust. The Israeli leader, who is on nine-day trip to Britain and the United States, noted that his country is not part of the multinational force opposing Iraq in the gulf. ``But by our very presence in that area - thanks to our steadfastness and capacity - we have been, and continue to be, a force for stability, a barrier that has prevented many military adventures and muand in a civil clomplaint charged Cartisano and his Challenger V Foundation with violation of five Hawaii laws. The complaint said Challenger V violates child welfare licensing laws, compulsory school attendance laws, operates without a business license and is avoiding state taxes, is an unlicensed practice of psychology and has engaged in unfair and deceptive trade practices. Tom Farrell, Hawaii's assistant attorney general, said he believed Cartisano was with the teen-agers either near Kona on Hawaii Island or floating in the seas. Repeated telephone messages left with Challenger V's answering service in Honolulu were not returned. Cartisano's wife, Debbie, said Wednesday her husband is in Guadalajara, Mexico, where he is attempting to set up another wilderness therapy program. She said she had no way of contacting him. The Utah program, founded in 1988 by Stephen Cartisano, sought Chapter 11 protection this summer. State officials say it owed more than $279,000 in federal and state taxes. A creditors' hearing showed the program owed more than $1.1 million and had assets of about $260,000; the program claimed assets of $63,000. Cartisano, 33, and his company are awaiting trial in May on charges of negligent homicide and child abuse in connection with the hiking death June 27 of Kristen Chase. Athorities closed down the program in August. An offshoot of a popular wildrness program offered at Brigham Young University in the 1970s, Cartisano claimed therapeutic value in forcing unruly teen-agers to cope and succeed in an unforgiving environment. In Utah, Challenger charged $16,000 for the 63-day program, which many parents swore by, including the mother of the dead teen-ager. Mrs. Cartisano accused Hawaii officials of pursuing a vendetta passed on by Utah officials. ``They called over here with all that gossip,'' she said. She said company attorneys told them that Challenger V is operating legally. She declined to name the lawyers. ``Those people (in Hawaii) haven't had any complaints,'' she said. ``There's no reason to be doing these things.''

DOC.HEAD: Food Aid Pours In, But Moscow's Real Need: Empty Bottles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with additional shipments received, distributed, SPECIFIES metric tons. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: While government officials squabbled Thursday over who was to blame for Moscow's food shortages, a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman reported that humanitarian aid from abroad had topped $160 million. But if Western nations really want Muscovites to have a happy holiday season, they should send empty bottles. A shortage of the glass containers threatens to leave the city without vodka, wine and champagne to toast the New Year. In the latest round of finger-pointing over shortages in Moscow that have raised fears of a hungry winter, authorities from regions that supply the capital with meat, milk and other foodstuffs denied they are withholding stocks. There is ``no need to start a witch-hunt where there are no witches,'' said V. Syrovatko, an official of the Bryansk region southwest of Moscow, in an interview published in Thursday's Sovietskaya Rossiya newspaper. Last month, Moscow Deputy Mayor Sergei B. Stankevich accused the regions of Bryansk, Penza and other areas of violating delivery contracts to the capital. A. Kovlyagin, executive committee chairman of the Penza regional council, said his region fulfilled its delivery plans by 97 percent the past 10 months. He said Penza supplied 18,087 metric tons of meat, of the contracted 19,463 metric tons, and either surpassed or nearly met all its dairy contracts, the newspaper reported. The neighboring Tver region sent 347 metric tons o meat to Moscow, exceeding the state plan of 275 metric tons, Sovietskaya Rossiya said. Kovlyagin blamed any shortages on Moscow city officials for failing to establish contact with regional authorities, it reported. Moscow's milk supply is down 15 to 20 percent the last 11 months, Soviet television reported Thursday. It said 20,000 metric tons of powdered milk is being sent to the capital. Soviet officials say food production is no lower than last year, including a record grain harvest this year. Many blame barren store shelves on a crumbling distribution system and panicked consumers. Many regions halted shipments of food and consumer goods to other areas to protest Kremlin policies. Rather than obey central government demands for food deliveries to the cities at state prices they consider too low, farmers are trading directly with factories and other consumers for other scarce supplies. Aid from abroad kept arriving Thursday. The second of two Israeli jetliners filled with fruit, vegetables, medicine and 15 metric tons of powdered milk arrived in Moscow Thursday night. The powdered milk was trucked from the airport to Khimkenskaya Hospital in Moscow and to Soltikovsky Children's Home outside the city, officials said. About 20 metric tons of food arrived Thursday from the United States, Tass said, without specifying who sent it. Leningrad received more than 12 metric tons and Moscow 17 metric tons from Germany, Tass said. More shipments were announced from Norway and Germany on Thursday, officials in those countries said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin told a briefing $160 million worth of food has been sent to this country or is in the pipeline. He said governments and charitable organizations from 21 nations have promised or delivered aid. Tass said any information about distribution of foreign food aid may be directed to the government commission responsible for overseeing the shipments, headed by Deputy Prime Minister Lev Voronin. By Dec. 15, more than 200,000 food parcels, each weighing 22 pounds, will start arriving here, containing such items as milk, macaroni, meat, vegetables and fruit, Churkin said. Churkin said Spain, Italy, France and Canada offered financial aid for food purchases, and negotiations are under way with Austria, Britain, Australia, Greece, South Korea, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran. He praised Tuesday's comments in Britain by former President Ronald Reagan, who called Mikhail S. Gorbachev a ``friend in need'' and said the West must offer assistance. But the newspaper Moskovskaya Pravda said Moscow's latest need is empty bottles - half-liter containers, preferably - to hold holiday spirits. The city faces a ``dry'' New Year because consumers are not returning empties, though stores now pay about 90 cents a bottle, more than twice the usual price. The newspaper did not say why people apparently are holding onto the bottles. Some stores won't sell a bottle of wine or vodka unless the buyer surrenders an empty. One reason for the shortage is that bottle production was curtailed during Gorbachev's anti-alcohol campaign three years ago. Although some enterprises will fill jars with wine or vodka, Moskovskaya Pravda suggested the practice ``won't look nice on the holiday table.''

DOC.HEAD: Daughters of King and Malcolm X to Visit Arizona
DOC.TEXT: The daughters of slain civil rights leaders Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X have decided to keep a commitment to perform a musical play at the University of Arizona, a minister said. The Rev. Warren Stewart of Phoenix said Yolanda King and Attallah Shabbazz will perform the play Sunday. Arizona voters rejected a referendum that would have created a paid state holiday honoring King. The Nov. 6 vote triggered a backlash against the state, including a recommendation by National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue to move the 1993 Super Bowl out of Arizona. The play, ``Stepping Into Tomorrow,'' was booked months before the general election, said Jesse Hargrove, the university's assistant dean of African-American Student Affairs. Stewart, pastor of the First Institutional Baptist Church, said Ms. King called him Monday to ask his advice. ``Some people were telling her to come and some were telling her to stay away and to boycott Arizona. She said she wanted to be a pro-active force rather than a reactive force, and I told her that coming at this time could contribute to the healing of the state,'' Stewart said. Ms. King, 34, would not discuss the controversy. ``She wants to make a prepared statement Sunday in order to be fair to everyone,'' publicist Jahna Cole said Wednesday. Ms. Shabbazz was on tour Wednesday and could not be reached for comment. Ms. King, who lives in Los Angeles where she is pursuing an acting career, was 12 years old when her father was assassinated in 1968. Since the Nov. 6 election, five organizations have canceled conventions that would have brought a total of about $7.1 million to the state, said Larry Hilliard, vice president of the Phoenix Convention and Visitors Bureau. The Harlem Globetrotters basketball troupe also canceled an appearance. The Phoenix Gazette reported Thursday that acting Gov. Rose Mofford may ask the Legislature in January for temporary authority to declare a paid King holiday by executive order. The newspaper, quoting an unidentified source, said the holiday would be referred to Arizona voters in 1992 under Mofford's proposal. Then-Gov. Evan Mecham stirred controversy in 1987 when he rescinded a paid King holiday declared by his predecessor, Bruce Babbitt, by executive order. Attorney General Bob Corbin had said Babbitt lacked the authority to declare the holiday. Mofford and key aides left Wednesday for Washington and planned a private meeting Friday with Tagliabue to discuss the Super Bowl. ``We'll certainly discuss things with him, and I'm sure he'll listen to what we have to say,'' Mofford said.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Wrapping Up Probe of Detroit Runway Crash
With AM-Planes Collide-Radar
DOC.TEXT: Investigators used a DC-9 on Thursday to retrace the misguided route taken by one of two jets that crashed and killed eight people on a runway at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. National Transportation Safety Board spokesman Brent Bahler said the walkthrough in the same kind of plane involved in the accident was among the final steps in the agency's investigation. ``We've gotten to the point where the factual part of this is starting to wind down. Now it's all analyzing the data,'' Bahler said. As with other investigations of fatal crashes, a final NTSB report could take up to a year. Eight people were killed and 24 injured Monday when a Pittsburgh-bound Northwest Airlines DC-9, carrying 39 passengers and four crew members, wandered through thick fog into the path of a Northwest Boeing 727 roaring toward takeoff. None of the 727's 145 passengers and eight crew were injured. Earlier Thursday, investigators in a car videotaped the route the DC-9 took that put it on runway 3-C, where it was clipped by the Memphis, Tenn.-bound 727. The 727's right wing gored the right side of the DC-9 from just behind the cockpit, knocking off one of the DC-9's aft engines and igniting jet fuel. NTSB investigator John Lauber said the second walkthrough was ordered ``primarily to get ... all taxiway markings, runway markings, the lights, the signs: all the relevant ground markings'' from the DC-9 pilot's point of view. Lauber said investigators had gathered data on the runways and taxiways involved and from interviews with crew members of both planes and other pilots working Monday. ``We wouldn't, at this stage, rule out anything,'' he told reporters at the group's final news briefing before wrapping up work at the suburban Detroit airport. Wednesday, Milio Rinna, a passenger on the DC-9, filed suit against Northwest in Wayne County Circuit Court. It was the first lawsuit filed against the airline following Monday's accident. Rinna, a 60-year-old health and safety official with the United Steelworkers, suffered burns and other injuries to his hands, head and knees. He was treated and released at a hospital, said his lawyer, William L. Martens. About 140 lawsuits were filed against Northwest and airplane manufacturer McDonnell Douglas Corp. after Northwest Flight 255 crashed at Detroit Metro on Aug. 16, 1987, killing 156. About 12 cases were settled before trial, and payouts have totaled about $150 million, ranging between $300,000 and $5 million apiece.

DOC.HEAD: Antarctic Treaty Countries Agree on Environmental Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: Members of the 32-nation Antarctic Treaty ended an 18-day meeting Thursday but failed to ban exploitation of the vast, frozen continent's resources. The group did agree on a draft of guidelines for an international agreement on the protection of the continent's environment, said meeting president Oscar Pinochet, a Chilean. The draft will be discussed in Madrid next April, he said. The document, written by Rolf Anderssen, head of the Norwegian delegation, was not made public. But Pinochet said the issue of exploitation of the southern continent's potentially rich resources, including oil, was not included. Pinochet said that while negotiations were continuing on the issue of minerals extraction, ``a gentlemen's agreement'' remains banning all mineral activities in Antarctica. Alternatives are to ban minerals extraction forever, which has been proposed by Australia and several European nations including France, or impose a long moratorium. Most member nations apparently support the moratorium option but details must be worked out, officials said. A communique issued at the end of the meeting in this Pacific resort city said: ``The decision was made to prepare, as soon as possible, a new international instrument for the protection of the Antarctic environment, and negotiations have already begun.'' ``The meeting showed that a consensus exists on the necessity of protecting the Antarctic environment,'' the communique said. ``I'm convinced that we are going to have a protocol or a convention for the protection of environment in Antarctica,'' said Pinochet, who is not related to former ruler Gen. Augusto Pinochet. ``We will have it subscribed during the first half of 1992,'' he predicted.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Asks NATO Allies to Lend More Help Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The United States asked its NATO allies Thursday for more help transporting, equipping, and reinforcing the multinational force in the Persian Gulf, officials said. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was joined by Tom King, his British counterpart, in welcoming the help given so far and urging the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies to provide still more. The two officials made the appeals during the first day of a two-day session of NATO defense ministers. Officials said Cheney also told the ministers a post-Cold War NATO should focus on four potential threats to its security: the Soviet Union as Europe's largest military power, political instability in Eastern Europe, the spread of chemical arms and ballistic missiles in the Middle East, and threats to Western supplies of energy. King told reporters Britain wants its allies to provide more ammunition, medical equipment and staff, chemical warfare gear, and ships and planes to transport troops to the gulf. A senior Cheney aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States did not present a detailed list of its needs nor did it ask for an immediate response. However, the aide said Cheney cited ``categories'' of assistance that other officials described as air and sealift help and protective gear for chemical warfare. He also said, ``The United States would welcome such additional support as the allies could supply,'' including troops. The aide said several nations ``indicated considerable ways in which they might offer additional support.'' But there were no details. The United States has almost 300,000 troops in the gulf region. About 100,000 more U.S. troops are now being sent, and Britain is bringing its deployment to 30,000 over the next few weeks. A NATO official termed ``very good news'' an Iraqi announcement Thursday that President Saddam Hussein had called for releasing all foreign hostages. The release could begin as early as Saturday and is hoped to be completed by Christmas, Iraqi officials said. However, the NATO official, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said Iraq ``must completely withdraw from Kuwait and restore the legitimate government.'' On other matters, the defense ministers reviewed work on a new NATO defense strategy to reflect the dramatic changes in East-West relations. The Cheney aide said the defense secretary told the allies NATO no longer faced a ``single threat'' but a combination of dangers, especially from an unstable Eastern Europe and turbulent Middle East. ``Quite clearly the scale and nature of the threat has changed, but there are considerable ... instabilities remaining, not least the rise of nationalism'' in Eastern Europe, said King, the British minister. The new defense strategy, to be adopted next year, will stress greater reliance on smaller, more flexible multinational forces. It will also commit the NATO allies to continue relying on a mix of conventional and nuclear arms and to maintain a U.S. military presence in Europe, though at a sharply reduced level. Officials said discussions continued about whether NATO should operate as an alliance outside its own territory, a politically sensitive issue in many allied capitals. German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said a consensus had emerged to rid Europe of short-range nuclear weapons. However, U.S. officials were more cautious. They stressed a need for negotiations with Moscow on reducing, not eliminating these weapons with a range of up to 310 miles.

DOC.HEAD: Cellmate Says Accused Nurse Claimed Killing 23
DOC.TEXT: A former nurse accused of killing a nursing home patient with a tranquilizer told a cellmate he had killed 23 people, pretrial documents show. Brian Rosenfeld, who has worked for at least 10 Pinellas County nursing homes before his arrest in August, said he selected victims who were about to die anyway, said the cellmate whose testimony was inadvertently included in a packet of pretrial discovery material made public Monday. David Allen Greenway, held at the Pinellas County Jail on a grand theft charge, made the statements to sheriff's Detective Chuck Vaughn. After a St. Petersburg Times reporter read an account of Greenway's statements and asked for a copy, Assistant State Attorney Marie King removed it from the packet, the newspaper reported Wednesday. Confessions are not supposed to be released, she said, and Greenway's statements had been included in the packet by mistake. Greenway's testimony is crucial evidence linking Rosenfeld to multiple deaths, Assistant State Attorney Fred Schaub said Tuesday. Greenway knows things about Rosenfeld that weren't in any news accounts, Schaub said. For example, Greenway said Rosenfeld told him the names of five or six of his alleged victims. Schaub confirmed those nursing home patients died while under Rosenfeld's care. Rosenfeld, 32, was helit shows that the strategy is working and that Saddam understands that his hostage policy has incurred the condemnation of the whole world, the president said. ``And we've got to continue to keep the pressure on,'' said Bush, who has authorized the deployment of more than 400,000 Americans to the gulf. The Pentagon said Thursday that Iraq had moved an additional 30,000 troops into Kuwait and southern Iraq, and that 10,000 U.S. reinforcements had arrived in the Persian Gulf. There are now more than 480,000 Iraqi troops in the region and more than 250,000 American troops, including at least 130,000 U.S. Army soldiers in Saudi Arabia. Bush said his planned meeting with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, and a meeting between Baker and Saddam, would not be negotiating sessions in which concessions might be offered to Iraq. ``What I want to do is be sure, by going this last, extra step for peace, that the Iraqis know from me, and Aziz knows from me and Saddam Hussein knows directly from the secretary of state, what is at stake in this matter and how supportive the United States is of the consolidated U.N. position,'' Bush said. ``And that's what it's about.'' On Capitol Hill, Baker also rejected Iraqi demands that the talks include discussion of other Mideast issues.

DOC.HEAD: District Attorney Will Move to Get Kahane Suspect's $300,000 Bail Revoked
DOC.TEXT: A judge suspended a $300,000 bail Thursday for the man accused of killing extremist Rabbi Meir Kahane and set new bail arguments for Monday. State Supreme Court Justice Alvin Schlesinger set the bail Wednesday for El Sayyid Nosair over Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau's objections. ``We had asked that the defendant continue to be held without bail,'' Morgenthau said. ``We pointed out to the court that he is accused of committing a number of exceptionally serious crimes, including both the murder of Rabbi Kahane and the wounding of a federal police officer.'' The judge's suspension of Nosair's bail means he would not be freed even if he came up with the money, Morgenthau's spokesman Gerald McKelvey said. Schlesinger said the bail issue will go back to court Monday. Morgenthau said bail should be revoked because the case against Nosair is strong and because he has foreign contacts who could help him flee. Nosair, 35, is accused of shooting the Zionist radical through the neck Nov. 5 as Kahane finished speaking to a Jewish group in a midtown hotel. He is also accused of wounding two other men and threatening a third as he allegedly tried to get away. In a statement to police, attached to a disclosure form filed in court, Nosair said he went to see Kahane's lecture because he agrees with much of the rabbi's anti-Arab rhetoric. Nosair also told police he believes Kahane was shot by a Jewish man. He said he was wounded when he was caught in the crossfire between the killer and the U.S. Postal Service police officer who fired a bullet into his neck. The gun police recovered and accused him of using on Kahane was placed next to him as he lay wounded in the street, according to Nosair's statement.

DOC.HEAD: Populist Priest Blames Tonton Macoutes for Haitian Rally Killings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with priest visits hospital, schools close, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAP1,2
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Populist priest Jean-Bertrand Aristide on Thursday blamed the Tonton Macoutes, the private militia that terrorized the people during the Duvalier rule, for killing seven people at a campaign rally. Fifty-three people were wounded in the Wednesday night gun and bomb attack on his rally in Petionville, a suburb seven miles from the capital. Aristide, considered front-runner in the Dec. 16 presidential elections, said he and the 10 other candidates would not let such violence derail the campaign. The attack appeared intended to keep Aristide supporters from the polls. It was the first violence since campaigning began in October and came as Haitians were optimistic they could hold the first democratic elections in the history of the former French colony. ``Take heart, dry your tears, hold one another's hands,'' Aristide said in an emotional interview with Radio Antilles. ``We are going to continue walking together because on the 16th of December, whether they like it or not, the Macoutes will disappear from Haiti.'' Aristide demanded the arrest of Roger Lafontant, reputed leader of the Tonton Macoutes who returned from exile to run for president. The independent Electoral Council, however, later disqualified his candidacy. A warrant for Lafontant's arrest has never been served. Lafontant denied responsibility for Wednesday's violence. Interior Minister Joseph Maxi promised an investigation. The capital was quiet Thursday. Traffic was normal and people went to work. Radio reports said schools closed early for the Christmas holidays because of the attack. They were supposed to close Dec. 19. The attack came as the rally was breaking up, starting with the explosion of a homemade bomb during a brief blackout. Men in a jeep then fired into the crowd. Most of the injured treated at Port-au-Prince's General Hospital suffered burns and bullet, shrapnel and shotgun pellet wounds. Some had limbs amputated. ``Too bad for those who want war and not peace; we who defend the rules of democracy, who refuse the language of violence, will continue our struggle and go on with the electoral campaign as before,'' said Hubert De Ronceray, conservative candidate of the Mobilization for National Development Party. Louis Dejoie Jr., candidate of the moderate National Agricultural and Industrial Party, said: ``We will not ee intimidated, but will go ahead with our campaign. To establish democracy is to honor the memory of the victims of dictatorship.'' Aristide visited the wounded at the hospital. Hundreds of cheering supporters greeted him. Later, Dejoie arrived and the two candidates embraced. The United Nations representative in Haiti, Reinhardt Helmke, said he believed the elections would stay on track. ``At this stage, the electoral process is not compromised,'' he said. ``This is the type of thing that everybody was expecting would happen at some point.'' Ismael Diallo, spokesman for the U.N. Election Verification Mission, said the elections would proceed because the Electoral Council, the army and Haitians ``are determined to go ahead and make a success of these elections.'' The 37-year-old Roman Catholic priest, target of three previous assassination attempts, had left the rally shortly before the attack. He has been hailed as a ``prophet'' by many and has a huge following among the country's poor, the majority in this Caribbean nation of 6 million people where violence and intimidation have traditionally pervaded politics. ``After what happened it's normal our blood is boiling,'' Aristide said in the radio broadcast. ``It could have been prevented ... all they had to do was arrest Roger Lafontant ... We demand the immediate arrest of Roger Lafontant.'' Lafontant denied responsibility in an interview broadcast on Radio Lumiere. He insinuated Aristide was behind it, saying, ``the crime profits Aristide,'' apparently a reference to the public sympathy it will generate. The Tonton Macoutes were formed under the late dictator Francois Duvalier in 1957. The family rule ended in 1986 when his son, Jean-Claude Duvalier was forced into exile by a popular uprising. This month's elections will be the first democratic presidential vote since Haiti's slave population rose up and won independence from France 186 years ago. More than 400 international observers, including former President Carter, along with unarmed military security advisers, have agreed to monitor the balloting.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Casts Doubt On Prospects For January Summit In Moscow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material throughout
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday cast doubt on prospects for a January summit in Moscow with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and sources said the meeting might slip to February. The Persian Gulf crisis is one reason for the uncertain timing, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``It's not an easy time to be traveling,'' he said, referring to the Jan. 15 deadline set in a U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq unless it withdraws from Kuwait. Both the United States and Soviet Union are unsettled about summit timing, Fitzwater said. ``I think we're saying, let's wait a little bit longer before we set a date,'' he added. Bush said at a Santiago news conference that plans for a meeting next month were ``not totally'' abandoned. Asked if the trip were being canceled, he replied, ``Not as far as I'm concerned.'' Sources said January was the target date for the trip but that scheduling difficulties and logistical problems had cropped up. ``As a result, it's possible it could slip to February,'' one source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Bush has said he would like to visit Moscow early next year, but has insisted that his trip be linked with the signing of a U.S.-Soviet treaty to slash long-range nuclear weapons. A White House advance team was supposed to have left for Moscow in mid-December to begin planning for Bush's visit, but the trip was unexpectedly called off. One source familiar with Bush's schedule said it showed no foreign travel in January. Fitzwater said the advance trip was put off because of the lack of a date for Bush's visit. He said Jan. 6 had been mentioned as one possibility, and that mid-January had been another. ``It's all tied to the START (nuclear arms negotiations) treaty,'' he said. As president, Bush has held summits with Gorbachev in Washington, Malta and Helsinki. The two leaders met for more than two hours in Paris last month during a 34-nation summit on the future of Europe after the Cold War.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0756 to ADD dropped AP logo
Iraq: We Want All Hostages Home by Christmas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Baghdad officials saying some could begin leaving as early as Saturday, detail, background. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Baghdad wants all the hostages it has been holding to be released and home by Christmas, Iraq's U.N. ambassador said Thursday. ``Definitely, we would like to see everyone with his family by Christmas, because that is a very joyous and happy occasion, and it is time for family reunions,'' said Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari. Foreigners may begin leaving as early as Saturday, Iraq officials in Baghdad said late Thursday, though visa processing may take days. There are an estimated 900 U.S. hostages among the thousands held by the Iraqis in Iraq and Kuwait in the aftermath of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of the neighboring oil-rich emirate. The Iraqi ambassador said it might speed the release of the detainees if the United States sent planes to Jordan to pick them up. ``Definitely, they could send the planes to Amman, and from Amman it would be a short flight,'' al-Anbari said. ``It is a matter of logistical things,'' he said. Iraq President Saddam Hussein said Thursday that all hostages would be released, but he did not say when. The United States applauded the announcement, but said it still wants all Iraqi occupation forces out of Kuwait by Jan. 15, as spelled out in a U.N. Security Council resolution passed last week. If not, multinational forces are authorized to take military action against Iraq. Saddam's dramatic announcement signaled the removal of a major obstacle to resolving the 4-month-old Persian Gulf crisis. The State Department, in a message for broadcast by the Voice of America, advised U.S. citizens in Iraq and Kuwait it was making preparations for their evacuation as soon as they are permitted to leave. Several governments and relatives of hostages quickly welcomed Saddam's announcement, which the Iraqi leader called a response to the ``positive changes'' of recent diplomatic moves. In all, there are an estimated 950,000 foreigners in Iraq and occupied Kuwait, but Saddam earlier said most Asians and Arabs - the majority of the foreigners - were free to leave. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States had received official notification in Baghdad that the foreigners would be set free. Saddam's announcement was made by the official Iraqi News Agency, which published a letter from him instructing the National Assembly to approve the release. Parliament routinely accepts his recommendations, and the release was expected soon after the vote - which could come as early as Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Irishmen Convicted of Planning Bomb Attacks
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Thursday convicted two suspected IRA members of planning a bombing campaign on the British mainland, and they were sentenced to 30 years each in prison. Damien McComb, 22, and Liam O'Dhuibhir, 28, gave clenched-fist salutes and shouted ``Victory to the IRA!'' as they were taken away after sentencing. Judge Simon Brown told McComb and O'Dhuibhir they were ``ruthless, dangerous, merciless men intent on carnage.'' ``There is no doubt whatever you are a pair of IRA terrorists who were intent late last year upon a bombing campaign here on the mainland which would have wreaked death and destruction, very probably singling out men of public service, worth and honor as your victims,'' he said. Earlier, the jury of eight women and four men convicted the pair of conspiring with persons unknown to explode bombs in Britain on various dates before Dec. 22. The men denied the charge. Police arrested McComb and O'Dhuibhir at gunpoint Dec. 21 last year as the pair removed weapons and explosives from hiding places on the Welsh coast. Police said the men's hit list, discovered later, included the entire British Cabinet. At the start of the trial, prosecutor John Nutting said late in 1989 the pair were in the ``preparatory stages'' of a British bombing campaign. All the equipment seized with the men ``bore the hallmarks of Provisional IRA material,'' he said. The so-called Provisionals, now the only active Irish Republican Army faction, grew out of a 1969 split in the militant movement, which has engaged in a bombing and shooting campaign to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Nutting said in November last year that police recovered 10 guns, more than 1,300 rounds of ammunition, 88 pounds of Semtex explosive, hand-grenades and bomb timers and detonators at two hiding places at St. Bride's Bay in the southern Welsh county of Pembrokeshire. They replaced the caches and staked out the hiding places until McComb and O'Dhuibhir returned Dec. 21, he said. In a house in Luton, southern England, where O'Dhuibhir had rented a room, police found ammunition, radio equipment, false identification documents and a list of people prominent in British public life ``including a full list of the Cabinet and the names of a number of middle-ranking and junior ministers,'' Nutting said. McComb, from Belfast, told the court he and O'Dhuibhir had agreed to bring something back to Ireland from Britain for friends, but had not realized it was arms and explosives until they got to Wales. Dubliner O'Dhuibhir, who did not give evidence, was jailed for five years in Dublin in 1984 for attempted kidnapping, illegal possession of arms and using a gun to resist arrest. He was released in 1987 for good behavior.

DOC.HEAD: Police Find 25 Pounds of Cocaine Aboard American Airlines Plane
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-five pounds of cocaine was found Thursday by security forces aboard an American Airlines plane at Bogota's airport, police said. Drug smugglers placed the cocaine in a hole they drilled under a seat in aisle 28 of the airplane bound for Miami, an airport police report said. During a routine inspection, police found the drugs, which had fallen from the cabin into the baggage department, the report said. Police said they were investigating how traffickers managed to board the plane and open up the floor. There were no arrests, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa: Tyminski Must Apologize Before Leaving Country
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Tyminski news conference in which he refuses to provide damaging papers. Picks up graf 7 pvs `In particular' and edits to trim thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa said in an interview Thursday that if he wins the presidency, his challenger should be barred from leaving the country until he proves his campaign allegations or apologizes for ``abusing Poland's good name.'' Walesa told the government-owned daily Rzeczpospolita that recent charges by emigre businessman Stanislaw Tyminski ``cannot be overlooked, even in the name of democracy.'' The election will be held Sunday. Walesa refused to hold a televised debate with Tyminski on Thursday night, as requested by his opponent after Tyminski backed out of a confrontation last week. Walesa showed up for that debate to find he faced only an empty chair. Tyminski said he wanted to face Walesa Thursday night to ``sum up'' the campaign. But Walesa accused him of plotting a last-minute smear to which he would not be able to respond because of the ban on campaigning after noon on Friday. The challenger has insinuated repeatedly that he has damaging material about Walesa that would force the Solidarity labor leader into exile. Walesa has demanded proof and says no such documents could exist. At a news conference later Thursday, Tyminski again refused to release the damaging material he claims to have. ``There are many documents, but I don't think (it is) in the best interest of the country to state them,'' he said Thursday night. He later promised to reveal the information during his final campaign stop Friday morning in Szeczin, but then said he had not made the ``political decision'' whether to do so. At another point, Tyminski read from a magazine interview with Walesa, focusing on Walesa's contention that civil unrest will develop if Tyminski failed as president to fulfill promises for speedy economic improvement. Tyminski said those were the words of a ``terrorist, an assailant.'' In his interview Thursday, Walesa said, ``Tyminski must not be allowed out of the country.'' ``He must account for everything that brought Poland harm, for abusing Poland's good name in the world.'' In particular, Walesa said, Tyminski must apologize to Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, whom he accused of treason by creating economic chaos. Mazowiecki, who was picked by Walesa to be the East bloc's first non-Communist government head and lead the country's dramatic reforms, resigned after Tyminski defeated him in the first election round on Nov. 25. His government's resignation has not yet been accepted by Parliament. After a bitter first-round campaign battle with his former adviser, Walesa has appealed for Mazowiecki's government to stay on to stabilize the country and has asked the prime ministers' supporters to vote for him Sunday. The Polish-born Tyminski also has passports from Peru, where he says he underwent a spiritual transformation during the early 1980s, and Canada, where he is the leader of the fringe Libertarian Party. Tyminski has refused to reveal his plans for after the election, saying he is concentrating on winning. Interior Minister Krzysztof Kozlowski said at a news conference Thursday that no evidence has emerged for holding Tyminski in the country if he loses. But, he added, the ministry remains convinced after repeated checking of its passport records that Tyminski was issued Polish visas in Libya seven times between 1980 and 1989. Tyminski has denied ever being in Libya. Tyminski won support from Poles with his promises of a quick fix for Poland's shattered economy. Two polls on Wednesday showed Walesa widening his second-round lead, however. One conducted by the private Demoskop agency put Walesa ahead 61 percent to 20 percent, while state television pollsters said he led 58 percent to 23 percent. Both surveys put the undecided at 19 percent. Tyminski has threatened a suit against state television, which interviewed a Canadian couple who said he abused his wife and denied his children food and medicine. Tyminski denied the allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Loss Halts Columbia's Star-Gazing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS four grafs after 3rd graf, `We've got ...' to UPDATE with method of operating telescopes devised and tested. Pick up 4th graf, `It was ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN1
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Columbia's star-gazing mission suffered yet another major setback when the astronauts Thursday lost their only working computer terminal for operating a $150 million observatory. Observations, already lagging far behind, were halted as a frustrated NASA scrambled to devise a plan to control three of the telescopes from the ground. ``We've got to bootstrap ourselves from ground zero,'' said mission scientist Ted Gull. Controllers developed a procedure in which the telescopes and their pointing system could be guided by commands from the ground. The astronauts, aided by data from the ground, could manually steer the telescopes toward desired targets with a joystick and television cameras. Using that process, one telescope observed a supernova Thursday night, said mission manager Jack Jones. Scientists planned to attempt additional observations through the night with the other telescopes. ``We've now got a way to operate,'' Jones said. But Jones could not say yet how well the new process would work or how many observations may be lost because of the latest problem. It was the latest in a series of blows to the mission, which was delayed six months by shuttle fuel leaks and suffered instrument failure within a few hours of Columbia's liftoff Sunday. The shuttle is to land Tuesday. ``I'm not sure whether to smile ear to ear or cry,'' said William Blair of Johns Hopkins University, revealing data of a supernova remnant that the school's telescope made before being shut down. The four astronomers aboard Columbia were forced to halt observations Thursday morning when a flight deck computer overheated and automatically turned off. Moments before, they had smelled a burning odor similar to one that filled the cabin Sunday when they lost the only other terminal for operating the observatory. The astronauts had been managing the Astro observatory's three ultraviolet telescopes with the one remaining terminal. When the first failed computer was disassembled Thursday, its air vents were found to be clogged with lint. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration tried to bring that terminal back on line, but the smell reappeared and astronaut Jeffrey Hoffman quickly turned the machine off. ``No joy on the test. Power is off,'' Hoffman said. Mission Control's James Hartsfield said there was no large release of harmful fumes and the crew's air was fine. The astronauts had their breathing helmets ready just in case. Before Thursday's computer failure, the astronauts have had to manually steer the telescopes because of nagging problems with the automatic pointing system, which was used sporadically. As a result of the slower, less precise manual method, many stars were dropped from the observing schedule. Astro was supposed to have begun examining galaxies, quasars and other high-energy objects late Sunday. Scientists scrapped more targets Thursday in light of the computer problem. Gull said he could not estimate how many of the planned 250 objects had been lost. ``I would be lying if I said I wasn't frustrated. I mean, I am frustrated,'' said Mary Jane Taylor, part of the University of Wisconsin telescope's team. ``But I don't think any of us thought that this was going to be error free,'' she said. ``I don't think anybody thought it was really going to go 100 percent smoothly.'' To salvage the rest of the mission, NASA planned to operate the telescopes via computer commands sent from the ground if neither flight deck terminal could be repaired. The astronauts, aided by the ground data, would use a joystick and TV monitors to steer the instruments in the open cargo bay toward desired stars. Johnson Space Center in Houston would control the instrument pointing system in bringing the telescopes back up one by one, assisted by astronomers at Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala. Ground controllers practiced moving the observatory Thursday afternoon. ``Acquisition is going to be difficult,'' Gull said. ``It's certainly going to be a close teamwork effort.'' Such a procedure was never practiced before the mission, Gull said. ``We anticipated that an individual instrument might need (to be) controlled from the ground. But we didn't anticipate that we might have to control all three instruments from the ground,'' he said. Astro's X-ray telescope was unaffected. The instrument is operated by computer commands sent from Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., and has its own pointing system. The X-ray telescope's observing schedule was being revamped, however, to take advantage of the ultraviolet instruments' idle time. Many of the targets were supposed to be viewed simultaneously by all four telescopes. Ultraviolet light and X-rays are absorbed by the atmosphere and thus invisible from the ground. Astronomers had been counting on Astro's results 218 miles above Earth to improve their understanding of objects that emit such radiation. While waiting for observations to resume, Columbia's seven-man crew photographed Earth and relaxed. ``We're just sitting here, you know, enjoying the view, doing a few other things,'' said astronaut Sam Durrance. The astronauts still planned to conduct a live science lesson Friday for more than 40 middle-school students at two NASA centers. The youngsters will be able to question two crew members.

DOC.HEAD: Montreal Remembers 14 Women Slain at College One Year Ago
DOC.TEXT: Catherine Bergeron looked up at the gray, stormy skies from the steps of Notre-Dame Basilica on Thursday and recalled it was much the same kind of day as a year ago - when her sister Genevieve and 13 other women were shot to death. The women, 13 of them engineering students, died and 13 were wounded when Marc Lepine stormed Ecole Polytechnique on Dec. 6, 1989, with a semi-automatic rifle. He said his fight was against ``feminists.'' His rampage ended when he turned the gun on himself. The basilica memorial service was one of many commemorative events planned across Canada to mark the anniversary of the massacre. ``It is hard that it is the anniversary, especially seeing that the weather is much the same as last year,'' said 20-year-old Ms. Bergeron. ``It is also good that it is the anniversary. Maybe it will be easier from now on.'' Dressed in a rust-colored coat, her auburn hair tied behind her head, she stood with friends under the massive arches of the basilica. Other family members and schoolmates of the victims streamed by to enter the service. Some wept. More were solemn. A few even managed to laugh. But everyone talked in hushed tones. Friends hugged as they met on the steps. A man carrying a bouquet of daisies and carnations walked up the steps. At the door, security guards checked identification cards and invitations. A few seats were reserved for journalists, but the service was intended to be private. About 1,000 people - family and friends of victims; students; school employees and politicians - filled the dimly lit, ornate cathedral. The hourlong Mass led by Msgr. Fernand Lecavalier included unveiling of a replica of the plaque now on the school's west wall, engraved with 14 names. Nathalie Provost, a former student who was wounded in the shooting, unveiled the replica. ``They will rest in our memories and in the memories of those who succeed us,'' she said. Many students joined the fight for tighter gun-control legislation after the tragedy. It was early evening when Lepine, a baseball cap on his head, walked into a classroom at the engineering school where students were presenting their projects before the Christmas break. He fired his rifle into the ceiling. With attention now fixed on him, he asked the men in the classroom to leave. Nine women remained. ``Do you know why you're here?'' he asked. ``No,'' one answered. ``I'm fighting against feminists,'' he said - and started shooting. Six of the women were killed, three wounded. Then he roamed the halls, firing at random. Finally he turned the rifle to his head and pulled the trigger, kiling himself. Ms. Bergeron said people have learned much from the tragedy. ``It has opened people's eyes to the violence against women in our society,'' she said. ``We - both men and women - have to take a long look in the mirror. It may be shocking at what we see but it has to be done.''

DOC.HEAD: Industry Urged to Monitor Japanese Technology
DOC.TEXT: The government should coax U.S. science and industry to monitor Japanese technology as it evolves and not just when Japan produces a new product, Congress was told Thursday. ``We have had great difficulty getting (U.S. business) to pay attention'' to Japanese innovations until they arrive in America in the form of imports, said Dr. William F. Finan, a former Commerce Department official now engaged in private research and consulting. ``As more and more of the major technological breakthroughs originate in Japan, the issue of gaining adequate access to Japanese research establishments will only gain in importance,'' Finan testified to the Joint Economic Committee. He and other witnesses said technology transfer should be a two-way street but U.S. industry seems passive about applying results of Japanese research. ``The burden of remedying any asymmetry in technology flow between our two countries falls largely to us,'' Finan said. ``It is essential for the U.,S. government to continue to jawbone the U.S. engineering and scientific establishment (to recognize) ... a national priority that we stay abreast of japan in key, strategic technologies.'' Finan disputed ``the belief that Japan only absorbs foreign knowhow but never supplies it in kind,'' declaring that major Japanese corporations such as Toshiba, NEC, Fujitsu, Hitachi and Mitsubishi ``have provided us literally with hours of time of their staffs at all levels.'' The government should encourage young American engineers visiting Japan to feel ``they are participating in a mission of national importance,'' he said, voicing hope that eventually ``our companies will value executives who have spent time in Japan to the same degree that Japanese executives see the path to the top requiring spending time in the U.S.''

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Held in Contempt over Interview with Murder Defendant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, `Brown said...' with six grafs to UPDATE with jailing to occur Friday, include earlier case, restore dropped courtesy title, include quotes from reporter and her editor. Pick up 6th graf, `The newspaper's ...' Jermarr in 2nd graf cq
DOC.TEXT: A judge Thursday ordered a newspaper reporter jailed because she refused to reveal all that she and a murder defendant discussed during interviews. Prosecutors want to enter as trial evidence articles written last month by Libby Averyt about Jermarr Arnold, 32. But the reporter and her newspaper - the Corpus Christi Caller-Times - maintain anything unpublished is nobody else's business. So State District Judge Eric Brown held her in contempt. Arnold is accused in the 1983 slaying of jewelry store clerk Christina Marie Sanchez in Corpus Christi. The 26-year-old reporter was expected to go to jail Friday. Brown ordered her to remain behind bars until she agrees to answer questions about the interviews with Arnold. It will be the second jailing of a Texas reporter this year. San Antonio television reporter Brian Karem was jailed for 13 days for refusing to reveal who arranged an interview between him and a murder suspect. Twelve times during a hearing Thursday Ms. Averyt refused to answer questions on First Amendment grounds. She specifically refused to reveal any details that were not published. ``I don't want to go to jail,'' Ms. Averyt said after the hearing. ``But my desire to avoid jail is outweighed by my duty to stand up for what I believe in.'' ``If reporters are allowed to be used as others' resources, a consequence may be that reporters will offer the public less and less information,'' said Larry Rose, the newspaper's executive editor. The newspaper's lawyer, Jorge Rangel, said he planned to appeal to the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals in Austin to keep the reporter free. ``Our position is that some of the questions call for disclosure of unpublished information,'' Rangel said Wednesday. ``We are asserting the reporter's qualified privilege under the First Amendment.'' The articles quote Arnold as saying that he shot jewelry store clerk Christina Marie Sanchez. Defense attorneys don't want the articles admitted into evidence. If they are allowed, the lawyers want Ms. Averyt to testify about the content of her interviews. Rangel says a reporter's unpublished material is protected by the First Amendment of the Constitution and similar provisions in the Texas Constitution. Last week, Brown ordered Ms. Averyt to testify. The judge gave Rangel until Wednesday to seek a ruling from the 13th Court of Appeals on the case. When the Corpus Christi appeals court refused to hear the case, Rangel took it to the Criminal Appeals Court. Rangel wanted the appeals courts to direct Brown to reverse his order requiring Ms. Averyt to discuss the unpublished information. Under order from Brown last week, prosecution and defense attorneys submitted a list of potential questions they may ask Ms. Averyt. Defense attorneys Carl Lewis and Constance Luedicke said last week they wanted to be able freely to cross-examine Ms. Averyt about information Arnold may have divulged that was not included in the articles. District Attorney Grant Jones said last week that the prosecution wants to enter the published articles into evidence because they contain information that Arnold did not reveal to law enforcement officers.

DOC.HEAD: Flight, Low on Fuel, Lands at Newark Instead of LaGuardia
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines officials were investigating why a company jet ran low on fuel, forcing it to make an emergency landing at Newark International Airport, an airline spokeswoman said Thursday. No injuries were reported when Flight 90 touched down at LaGuardia Airport Wednesday, authorities said. The flight from Minneapolis-St. Paul was bound for New York's LaGuardia Airport. The 183 passengers and seven crew members aboard the Boeing 757 were taken by bus to LaGuardia, about 20 miles away, said Northwest spokeswoman Christie Clapp in St. Paul. The plane was then flown back to Minneapolis, to be checked out by maintenance experts, she said. The incident came two days after two Northwest jets collided in heavy fog at Detroit Metropolitan Airport, killing eight people and injuring 24. In January, an Avianca flight en route to New York's Kennedy airport crashed on Long Island when it ran out of fuel, killing 73 people.

DOC.HEAD: Kahane's Followers Riot in Jerusalem, Officer Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf `The fracas...' to RECAST terminology re assassination. Picks up 4th graf, `The militant...'
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of followers of slain Rabbi Meir Kahane rioted in Jerusalem on Thursday, hurling flaming torches at police, who forcefully dispersed the angry extremists. Police detained about 25 Kahane supporters. One officer was beaten by rioters and taken to a hospital with slight injuries, Jerusalem police spokesman Aharon Elhayani said. The fracas came as Kahane supporters were holding a memorial ceremony for their leader, assassinated in New York on Nov. 5. The militant, Brooklyn-born rabbi was known as the founder of the radical anti-Arab Kach party, which advocates expulsion of Palestinians from Israel and the occupied territories. Earlier Thursday, the Supreme Court rejected a Kach party appeal to hold a rally in front of the Israel Television building in Jerusalem to protest what the movement sees as biased news media coverage. As the rally began in a downtown Jerusalem hall, Kach supporters hurled stones at journalists and TV crews. Kach spokesman Noam Federman blamed the Supreme Court for the outbreak of violence. After a three-hour rally, hundreds of Kach members, waving torches and shouting ``Kahane! Kahane!'' marched to the town's entrance and blocked the main Jerusalem-Tel Aviv highway, Israel radio reported. Mounted police charged at the crowd and police officers on foot used clubs to disperse the rioters, who responded by throwing torches at the officers. Some elderly participants were seen being dragged away to police vans, the radio said. An hour later, about 400 Kahane supporters gathered at a nearby square, raising pictures of Kahane, blue-and-white Israeli flags and the yellow flags of their movement, showing a clenched fist inside the Star of David. On a wall, a freshly spray-painted slogan declared: ``Revenge will come.'' Border police formed a human chain around the square but about 100 Kach activists managed to block the road again and were dispersed by force.

DOC.HEAD: Flight, Low on Fuel, Lands at Newark Instead of LaGuardia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `No injuries ...' to DELETE reference to plane touching down at LaGuardia.
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines officials were investigating why a company jet ran low on fuel, forcing it to make an emergency landing at Newark International Airport, an airline spokeswoman said Thursday. No injuries were reported when Flight 90 touched down Wednesday, authorities said. The flight from Minneapolis-St. Paul was bound for New York's LaGuardia Airport. The 183 passengers and seven crew members aboard the Boeing 757 were taken by bus to LaGuardia, about 20 miles away, said Northwest spokeswoman Christie Clapp in St. Paul. The plane was then flown back to Minneapolis, to be chekked out by maintenance experts, she said. The incident came two days after two Northwest jets collided in heavy fog at Detroit Metropolitan Airport, killing eight people and injuring 24. In January, an Avianca flight en route to New York's Kennedy airport crashed on Long Island when it ran out of fuel, killing 73 people.

DOC.HEAD: Governments, Relatives Welcome Announcement on Hostage Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to RECAST, UPDATE with Japanese reax, other. Picks up 14th graf, Irish Foreign ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western governments welcomed Saddam Hussein's announcement on Thursday that he is freeing all hostages, but said Iraq must still quit Kuwait. President Bush said in Santiago, Chile, that Saddam's announcement ``will not change my thinking on his need to comply 100 percent, without condition, to the U.N. resolutions'' calling for withdrawal. British Prime Minister John Major echoed the demand. ``Saddam Hussein still has to withdraw totally and unconditionally from Kuwait and the legitimate government must be restored,'' he said in London. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said in New York it was very good news, if confirmed, ``but I always need the proper official information about it.'' French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said Saddam's decision was ``going in the right direction. It's a good sign. Now we have to wait for this decision to be executed.'' A spontaneous celebration was held at the Al-Mansour Melia Hotel in downtown Baghdad, where several hostages were brought from strategic sites to meet with visiting family members. ``We did it at last and now we can go home for Christmas,'' said Susan Dring, who traveled to Baghdad last week to try to win her husband's freedom. Michael Dring stood behind her, celebrating with a can of imported beer. The reaction from hostage relatives around the world ranged from cautious optimism to uncontained joy. ``I'm over the moon. It's what we've prayed and prayed for,'' said Sue Dorrington, whose British husband is being held in Baghdad. ``I have been in tears all morning since I heard the news. I just hope it is true,'' said Linda Grant, part of a group of 30 women related to British Airways employees who planned to go to Baghdad this weekend. Relatives of Americans held in Iraq expressed delight. ``There were times I couldn't eat, I couldn't sleep,'' said Doris Whatley of Shreveport, La. ``All of a sudden I am a changed person... because my husband is coming home.'' Italy's foreign minister, Gianni De Michelis, said the announcement caused ``deep satisfaction for the Italian government and for me personally.'' He said he hoped it was a first step toward full compliance with U.N. resolutions demanding Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan said the crisis should be resolved fairly and peacefully, based on complete implementation of the U.N. resolutions. ``I hope that this measure by Iraq is the first step toward achieving that goal.'' Irish Foreign Affairs Minister Gerry Collins said in Dublin that he was very pleased by the report, but ``we are somewhat cautious and will be so until such time as the news is confirmed.'' Britain's Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said the embassy in Baghdad was seeking details on how the release would be organized. ``If President Saddam Hussein does not comply in full with the Security Council resolutions, then he will be forced to do so. If he does comply, then he will not be attacked,'' Hurd said in the House of Commons. Hurd said it was not known whether Saddam's announcement applied to 440 Britons known to be in hiding in Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2. There are nearly 1,200 Britons held in Iraq and Kuwait, and about 250 Irish citizens. Swiss Foreign Minister Andrea Reichlin said the government was reacting cautiously to the news. Switzerland has seven citizens detained in Iraq. At the London headquarters of the Gulf Support Group, which aids relatives of hostages, spokesman Andy Charles said the families were ``cautiously optimistic and cautiously delighted, but we've had a lot of similar announcements in the past which have not borne fruit.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Mulls Mideast Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7 grafs for 7-10 pvs bgng `However, on...' to UPDATE with Bush spokesman saying language of U.N. resolution under review, RESTORES dropped word that United States `not' pushing for conference. Picks up 11th pvs, `The release...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Security Council members Thursday held private talks on a draft resolution that contemplates a peace conference on the Palestinian problem - one of Iraq's key demands for solving the Kuwait crisis. In Baghdad, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein told his Parliament to free all foreign hostages. His announcement came just hours after the text of the draft resolution was leaked and widely reported, and the releases may begin as early as Saturday, officials said. Saddam said he made his hostage-release decision to ``respond to positive changes'' on the diplomatic front. On Friday, President Bush proposed diplomatic exchanges with Iraq. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will meet Saddam in Baghdad, while Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz will come to Washington to see Bush. Saddam has also noted the U.S. Congressional hearings on the Persian Gulf crisis, in which many senators and former U.S. officials have challenged the wisdom of military action against Iraq. In its deliberations on the Israeli-occupied lands, the U.N. Security Council has been considering steps to protect Palestinians. A scheduled meeting set for Thursday afternoon was suddenly postponed until Friday, and diplomats met in private and consulted with their capitals. However, on the eve of his arrival in the United States for an official visit, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said in London that Israel rejects a possible U.N. call for an international conference on peace in the Middle East. ``Israel will not agree to any foreign body deciding its future and fate,'' he said. The Bush administration, meanwhile, took pains to stress that is not pushing for any immediate peace conference. Bush, visiting Chile, said Thursday there is ``no linkage'' between an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait and Israeli withdrawal from Arab lands. The United States will not give Saddam ``some face-saving way out of something he shouldn't have gotten into in the first place,'' Bush told a news conference. Bush's spokesman said Washington was making changes in the language of the U.N. resolution. U.S. officials at the United Nations confirmed that report but said the changes di not alter the basic thrust of the draft. ``We're trying to work out language that is acceptable, that meets our policy. Obviously the U.N. wants to speak to this issue,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, who was in Chile with Bush. The release of all hostages is one of the key demands of the Security Council, which also insists that Iraq unconditionally withdraw its troops from Kuwait and restore the government of the emir of Kuwait. A week ago, the Security Council voted 12-2, with one abstention, to authorize ``all necessary means,'' including a military strike, to force Iraq to leave Kuwait unless it complies by Jan. 15. The five permanent Security Council members - the United States, Britain, Soviet Union, France and China - agreed in principle Wednesday on a text that contemplates a future Middle East peace conference. The approved ``working paper'' would have the council say that it ``considers that the convening at an appropriate time of an international peace conference on the Middle East, properly structured, with the participation of the parties concerned, would facilitate the achievement of a comprehensive settlement and lasting peace in the Middle East.'' The problem of a homeland for the Palestinians would be central to any such peace settlement. It is the first time the United States has approved of the council taking up the issue of a Middle East peace conference. An earlier draft proposal offered by Cuba, Yemen, Malaysia and Colombia would have said the council ``welcomes the calls for convening'' a peace conference. That language was diluted Wednesday. Saddam proposed on Aug. 12, just 10 days after his troops conquered Kuwait, that a solution to the Palestinian homeland question must be linked to any discussion of the withdrawal of his army from the emirate. The text that the Security Council is considering, however, contains so many caveats that the proposed Middle East peace conference could be years in the making, if it happens at all. The proposed resolution contains numerous loopholes that would allow Israel to delay or abort the process. The clause requiring ``the participation of the parties concerned'' gives Israel virtual veto power over the conference. With Shamir due to arrive Friday in the United States, the leak of the council's ``working paper'' sent U.S. officials into a flurry of denials that they were calling for a peace conference. Baker testified before Congress on Thursday, saying: ``This is certainly not the time for an international conference.'' ``We've taken the position for a long time that an international conference, properly structured, at an appropriate time, might be useful,'' Baker said. Baker also denied there was any linkage between the Kuwait situation and the Palestinian problem.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Says He Has Some Ideas About Reviving Peace Process
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Thursday he was going to the United States with ``several ideas'' for reviving the Israeli-Arab peace process, but added the gulf crisis must be resolved first. Shamir also thanked Secretary of State James A. Baker III for his pledge of American support in case of an Iraqi attack on Israel, but said the Jewish state must fight its own battles. ``We welcome (Baker's) remarks, but we never rely on anyone, even if he is the best friend of Israel,'' Shamir told reporters at Ben Gurion International Airport before leaving for a nine-day trip to Britain and the United States. On Tuesday, Shamir was scheduled to hold talks with President Bush on the Persian Gulf crisis and the Israeli-Arab conflict. Relations between the two leaders reportedly have been strained because of Shamir's rejection of U.S. compromises for starting peace talks. U.S. officials have demanded that Shamir bring ``creative ideas'' to his talks with Bush.
