Asked whether he had any new ideas, Shamir said: ``Concerning the effort that will have to be made - I assume after the resolution of this (gulf) crisis - in order to advance a settlement of the conflict between the Arab world and Israel ... I have several ideas on where to begin and how to continue, and very much hope we will succeed in this discussion.'' Baker had proposed holding preliminary peace talks in Cairo, but Shamir opposed the composition of the Palestinian delegation, saying it was an attempt to give the PLO a role in negotiations. Concerning the gulf crisis, Shamir said the world had a special obligation toward Israel. ``Israel is the most threatened, perhaps, among all the countries (threatened) by Iraq,'' he said. Asked whether a peaceful resolution of the Gulf crisis would leave Israel to fight Iraq alone, he said: ``I don't think we are facing such a situation but Israel is ready for every possible situation, and will have to act according to the conditions that arise.''

DOC.HEAD: Counselors Advise Tots On Handguns, Charges Dropped Against Family Friend
DOC.TEXT: Counselors warned students at a day care center Thursday of the danger of handguns after a teacher found a loaded gun in the jacket of a 3-year-old. ``He thought it was a toy, and he brought it to school, ready to play,'' said a kindergarten teacher, who gave her name only as Adrian. ``He thought he had a toy, and all of a sudden the cops came.'' The counseling sessions at the College Community Child Care Center in Brooklyn came after a school aide, walking her nursery charges to a playground Wednesday, noticed what looked like the butt of a gun protruding from the 3-year-old's jacket pocket. Police confirmed it was a .25-caliber Raven automatic, with one live round in the chamber and three in the clip. Gail Dubins, another teacher at the center, described the incident as ``an upsetting situation, yet we are thankful we were able to discover the gun and no one got hurt. There were no tears to be shed.'' Prosecutors refused to press charges against a 27-year-old family friend who drove the 3-year-old to school the day he showed up with the gun. Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes cited a lack of evidence. The boy, whose name was withheld because of his age, told detectives he found the gun inside the car of the family friend. The child was turned over to the Department of Child Welfare Services, then returned to his mother, said police spokeswoman Officer Kim Royster.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Juvenile Drug Enforcement Targets Minorities
DOC.TEXT: Police and prosecutors nationwide unfairly target minority offenders in juvenile drug cases, said a study released Thursday by the National Center for Juvenile Justice. The study said drug prosecutions of whites dropped 15 percent from 1985 to 1988, while prosecutions of non-whites jumped 88 percent in the same period. Researchers reviewed more than 300,000 records in the center's National Juvenile Court Archive. The records described drug and alcohol cases in 841 jurisdictions across 17 randomly selected states, officials said. The disparity between the number of cases against whites and those against non-whites was alarming, said Hunter Hurst, director of the Pittsburgh center, a non-profit research organization partially funded by the U.S. Justice Department. ``The juvenile justice system is rapidly becoming a system exclusively for minority offenders,'' Hurst said. ``This is one war we cannot win by focusing solely on minorities and the poor.'' The study said the number of drug cases involving all youths are on the rise. The rate of arrests per 1,000 youth increased 8 percent from 3.69 in 1985 to 4.12 in 1988. The total number of drug cases in juvenile court jumped 12 percent in the same period. ``A lot has happened in the past five years,'' said U.S. District Maurice B. Cohill Jr. of Pittsburgh, chairman of the center's board. ``Crack hit the streets and the federal government officially launched the war on drugs.'' Juvenile courts handled more drug possession cases than drug trafficking cases, the study said. The study showed the number of trafficking cases was quickly growing. The report said the number of juveniles arrested for murder increased 67 percent from 1985 to 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Maker of Expensive Schizophrenia Drug Could Cut Price
DOC.TEXT: The maker of an expensive drug used to treat schizophrenia said it will study alternative ways of monitoring its use that could cut costs and make it available to more people. The New York Times reported Thursday that the Swiss-owned drug company, Sandoz Pharmaceuticals, folded to congressional and public pressure and agreed to reduce the cost of clozapine. The drug costs $8,944 in the United States for a year's supply. A significant portion of the cost is believed to come from a monitoring system - required by Sandoz - that guards against potentially fatal side effects. An official for the East Hanover-based company said Wednesday the company agreed only to look for different ways to monitor the drug. ``It could change the overall price structure but we don't know how much at this point in time,'' said Dr. David L. Winter, vice president of scientific and external affairs at Sandoz. The Food and Drug Administration estimates 200,000 severe schizophrenics in the United States could benefit from the drug, but because of the cost only about 7,000 people are taking it. Many veterans hospitals and state programs refuse to use the drug because of its expense. They have said they could save millions of dollars by monitoring the drug themselves. Six states, led by Minnesota, have threatened antitrust lawsuits, and legislation has been introduced in Congress to make the drug more affordable. Patients taking clozapine are monitored for agranulocytosis, a potentially fatal side effect that reduces the level of infection-fighting white blood cells. Sandoz has a contract with Caremark Home Services, a national home health care firm, to operate a monitoring system in which all patients taking the drug are given blood tests weekly. The company withholds the following week's dosage if a patient's white blood cell count is down or if a blood test is not taken, Winter said.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysian Founder Tunku Abdul Razak Dead at 87
DOC.TEXT: Tunku Abdul Razak, who led Malaysia in winning independence from Britain in 1957 and served 13 years as this Southeast Asian nation's first prime minister, died Thursday night. He was 87. He had been in a coma at General Hospital since Wednesday as doctors tried to stem intestinal bleeding. The Tunku had been confined to a wheelchair for the past few years and had been hospitalized often, but remained active. Government chief secretary Ahmad Sarji Abdul Hamid announced plans for a state funeral and said all official celebrations Thursday were canceled. He said the Tunku will be buried according to Moslem rites at Langgar Royal Mausoleum in Alor Star, 240 miles northwest of Kuala Lumpur, in keeping with the Tunku's wishes. It was customary to refer to the prime minister as the Tunku, or prince, because of his royal ancestry. In 1946, the Tunku helped found the United Malays National Organization, or UMNO, which has provided all four of Malaysia's prime ministers to date. He recently took to calling Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad a dictator, however, and backed the opposition. The UMNO, under Mahathir, won the general elections in October. The Tunku resigned as prime minister in 1970 and became the first secretary-general of the Organization of Islamic Conference, comprising more than 40 Moslem nations, which was formed at his urging. He also served as chairman and columnist of The Star Daily newspaper and wrote books and movie scripts. Born Feb. 8, 1903, to the sultan of the Malay state of Kedah and his Thai wife, the Tunku studied at Cambridge University in Britain and many years later earned a law degree there. He liked fast cars and horse racing, enjoyed his daily brandy and mmoked, finding no conflict in this with his Moslem religion. ``One of my happiest days is when we got independence,'' he once said. ``My saddest day was May 13. I hope and pray it never happens again.'' He was referring to May 13, 1969, Malay-Chinese racial clashes that left hundreds dead in the streets of Kuala Lumpur. The Tunku began losing his political power soon after. Malay students felt he conceded too much to the Chinese.

DOC.HEAD: No Shoes, Few Signatures, Big Fame: Big Bucks
DOC.TEXT: A rare autograph of ``Shoeless'' Joe Jackson, the illiterate, banned baseball player whose legend has grown with the help of Hollywood, sold for $23,100 Thursday at auction. It was the second-highest price paid for a signature not attached to a document, and it makes Jackson's autograph worth more than Babe Ruth's, Ty Cobb's or even Abraham Lincoln's, experts said. The shaky writing is on a 4-inch by 1{-inch piece torn from a legal paper in 1936, said Herman Darvick, who staged the auction. The signature of Button Gwinnett, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, set the record for an unattached signature, selling for about $56,000, Darvick said. The signature, like other Jackson signatures made on legal documents in 1922 and 1937, is crude and belabored, Darvick said. He said Jackson's wife generally signed his autograph and the ballplayer signed only formal documents. Darvick originally estimated the signature would sell for $1,500 to $2,000. He said it was obtained by a collector of baseball autographs about 25 years ago. The collector, who thought it might be worth about $100, had obtained it from Jackson's family in Greenville, S.C., Darvick said. ``He had no idea of its value,'' he said. Jackson was recently memorialized in two movies, ``Eight Men Out,'' the story of how the Chicago White Sox sold the 1919 World Series to gamblers, and ``Field of Dreams,'' in which Jackson returns from the dead to play baseball in an Iowa corn field. ``Shoeless Joe'' hit .356, third highest in history, during a 13-year career that ended abruptly after the 1920 season when the commissioner of baseball banned him and seven others from the sport for life for accepting money to throw the 1919 Series to Cincinnati. On his deathbed in 1951, Jackson maintained his innocence.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Urges Release of All Hostages, Could Begin by Saturday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Washington developments, Dole comment, oil, gold prices. Picks up 15th graf, Baker said .. .
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY21,WX11,DHR1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq told the world on Thursday that all foreign hostages would be freed, some as early as this weekend, but President Bush said release of the thousands of hostages would not weaken U.S. resolve to get Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. In the United Nations, Iraq's U.N. ambassador said all the hostages, including an estimated 900 Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait since Iraqi forces overran the oil-rich emirate on Aug. 2, would likely be home by Christmas. ``Definitely, we would like to see everyone with his family by Christmas, because that is a very joyous and happy occasion, and it is time for family reunions,'' U.N. Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari said. Iraq officials late Thursday said foreigners can begin leaving Saturday, and that those in Baghdad, the capital city, can apply immediately for exit visas. Processing could take days, though, the officials said. The State Department said in Washington that the Voice of America was broadcasting a message Thursday night meant for U.S. citizens in Iraq and Kuwait, saying, ``We are making preparations to evacuate all U.S. citizens as soon as they are permitted to leave.'' Saddam Hussein's dramatic announcement signaled the removal of a major obstacle to resolving the Persian Gulf crisis. But Bush said Saddam should not have taken people hostage in the first place and insisted: ``The man must leave Kuwait without reservation, without condition'' before the standoff can end. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said in a statement Congress could take no credit for any release of hostages, and, ``It looks like Saddam is finally hearing the administration's tough message loud and clear.'' The news of Saddam's announcement sent oil prices plunging to their lowest level since August, when Iraq invaded its neighbor. The initial drop was more than $2 a barrel, but closed Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $26.40 a barrel, an 89-cent loss. Gold prices and the dollar, historically considered safe ways to protect money during times of political and economic travail, also ended with losses, which some trading professionals attributed to the prospects of peace. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $371.70 an ounce, off $2.50 from Wednesday. Several governments and relatives of hostages quickly welcomed Saddam's announcement, which the Iraqi leader called a response to the ``positive changes'' of recent diplomatic moves. ``It's an answer to our prayers,'' said Rande Vallekoop, whose husband has been stranded at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. ``We have been praying him home for Christmas ... and it looks like our answer is coming,'' she said from Minneapolis. One American detained in Baghdad was ``absolutely elated, thilled,'' at Saddam's decision; a British hostage popped open a can of imported beer in celebration. ``I feel delirious that I can leave,'' said David Farington, a British worker stranded in Baghdad by the Iraqi invasion. He became one of the foreigners Saddam kept captive to deter an attack on Iraq. Some were kept at strategic sites to serve as human shields against attack. There are hundreds of thousands of foreigners in Iraq and occupied Kuwait, but Saddam earlier said most Asians and Arabs - the majority of the foreigners - were free to leave. Baker said the United States had received official notification in Baghdad that the thousands of foreigners would be set free. It was unclear when. Saddam's announcement was made by the official Iraqi News Agency, which published a letter from him instructing the National Assembly to approve the release. ``I invite you to take a just decision to end the travel ban imposed on foreigners and restore to all of them the freedom to travel. We apologize to those who may have been harmed, and from God we seek forgiveness,'' the letter said. Saddam also said Iraq had completed its deployment in Kuwait, and therefore the hostages were not longer needed to prevent an attack. Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall estimated Thursday that more than 480,000 Iraqi troops now are in and around the conquered emirate, facing a nearly 400,000-strong multinational force in the gulf that includes 250,000 American troops. Saddam did not say when the foreigners would be freed, but parliament routinely accepts his recommendations, and the release was expected soon after the vote - which could come as early as Friday. Bush administration officials are trying to convince Congress that trade sanctions against Iraq will not force its withdrawal from Kuwait and that the lawmakers should support a possible military strike on Iraqi forces. Saddam's announcement appeared to be an attempt to influence those deliberations, and the direct U.S.-Iraq talks scheduled in Washington and Baghdad for later this month. Bush stressed that no secret deal with Saddam was in the works - or would be considered. ``The release of all hostages would be a very good thing, but the problem is the aggression against Kuwait, and the man must leave Kuwait without condition,'' Bush said of Saddam. ``No single hostage should have been taken in the first place, and I hope ... Saddam understands that his hostage policy has incurred the hostility of the whole world,'' Bush told a news conference in Santiago, Chile, his latest stop on a South American tour. Bush also discouraged efforts by several U.N. nations to set up a Mideast peace conference. He said there is ``no linkage'' between an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait and Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian territories, which Saddam has demanded as a condition for withdrawal. The United States will not give Saddam Hussein ``some face-saving way out of something he shouldn't have gotten into in the first place,'' he said. Last week, the U.N. Security Council authorized force against Iraq by Jan. 15 if it fails to withdraw from Kuwait. In Washington, Baker was pressing ahead with efforts to win congressional support for using force against Iraqi troops if they do not pull out of Kuwait soon. Baker told Congress that releasing the hostages ``does not lessen, nor should it, our determination that Iraq's aggression against Kuwait should be reversed.'' Britain, Spain and Ireland welcomed Saddam's move, and Western hostages and their relatives were jubilant. The wife of one detained American said her husband in Baghdad was ``absolutely elated, thrilled'' at Saddam's decision. ``I feel a little free now for the first time in months,'' said Doris Whatley of Shreveport, La., whose husband, Donald, called her from Baghdad after the announcement. Mrs. Whatley said her husband, an oil foreman held since the invasion, hoped to hurry home to visit his critically ill father. ``He told me he was just so happy because he would have a chance to see his daddy one last time,'' Mrs. Whatley said.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Replacement Worker Stabbed; Newspaper Offers Reward
DOC.TEXT: A Daily News replacement driver scheduled to appear before a grand jury probing strike-related violence was stabbed Thursday by an angry mob, the newspaper's publisher said. Publisher James Hoge announced a $100,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of those responsible for the stabbing in Irvington, N.J. The driver, Carlos Chacon, was stabbed in his buttocks and abdomen and his helper, Derrick Foster, was cut and bruised in the attack, police said. Chacon, 45, of Harrison, N.J., was hospitalized in satisfactory condition and Foster, 27, of Newark, N.J., was treated and released. The men, who were on a delivery route, told police they were surrounded by about 15 men armed with baseball bats, bottles and a knife. They reported that one attacker said, ``These people that work for the Daily News are taking my job. I'm going to kill you.'' Hoge said Chacon was to appear as a witness in a Queens grand jury's investigation of an Oct. 27 incident in which a striking Daily News driver, Carlo Costantino of Brooklyn alegedly smashed a delivery truck's headlights and windows with a baseball bat. ``The fact of this cowardly act is made all the more significant when one realizes that Chacon had been called as a witness in a grand jury proceeding which began yesterday,'' Hoge said Thursday. A law enforcement source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Chacon had not yet testified before the grand jury. It was not known if there was a link between the stabbing and his scheduled appearance. ``I think the attack is deplorable and none of the union members condone that sort of behavior,'' said Barry Lipton, leader of the Newspaper Guild. Nine of the newspaper's 10 unions have been on strike since Oct. 25.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: ``No single hostage should have been taken in the first place, and I hope ... Saddam understands that his hostage policy has incurred the hostility of the whole world.'' - President Bush, on Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's announcement he would free all foreign hostages. --- ``It's an answer to our prayers.'' - Rande Vallekoop, whose husband is stranded at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. --- ``As we wait, he will continue manipulating hostages, attempting to break the coalition.'' - U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III. --- ``I feel delirious that I can leave.'' - David Farington, a British worker stuck in Baghdad. --- ``The news is welcome, but we're not throwing a celebration. ... We'll celebrate when we see them coming out - and not before.'' - Margaret Williams, whose son and daughter-in-law are held.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Make Pilgrimage To View Image They Believe is Virgin Mary
DOC.TEXT: Thousands overran this tiny town Thursday in a growing pilgrimage to a church where each day since Thanksgiving an image many believe looks like the Virgin Mary has appeared on a wall. About 5,000 people waited in line for a look at the strange light. ``I think it's a miracle,'' said Marie Cammarota, 60, of Sacramento after making her way through St. Dominic's Church. The daily crush of visitors to the Roman Catholic church threatens to overwhelm this community of 1,000 people in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada range. The apparition appears each day for just one hour, from about 9:30 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. Many prayed as they filed through the church, which seats 200 people. Some wept. And some were skeptical. ``It was weird. ... I think it's what you want it to be. If you're into religion, then you see the Virgin Mary,'' said Tyler Palacio, 13. Everyone agreed they saw something. It started as faint, curved lines of red, blue, green, purple and pink light. The lines darkened and extended into a shape that looked like the top half of a figure. Then it faded away. The image always appears above a statue of Jesus on a wall facing the sun. It might be explained as the optical effect of a light fixture hanging from the roof. The fixture may be reflecting colored light coming through a stained-glass window and throwing it back onto the wall. The reflection theory is discounted by those who said the image has appeared even on cloudy days. Bishop Francis Quinn of the Sacramento Diocese, which includes Colfax about 45 miles east of Sacramento, said if the image persists he will establish a commission to investigate it. ``It could be the image of the Blessed Mary in a silhouette pose,'' Quinn said. As he sees it: ``She is holding the infant Jesus in her arms to the left side.'' Police Chief Bill Mintline said residents aren't bothered by the fuss. ``It's not like a rock concert crowd,'' Mintline said.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysian Founder Tunku Abdul Rahman Dead at 87
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for Obit-Tunku Abdul Razak, 1st Ld-Writethru, leading thruout to CORRECT name to Tunku Abdul Rahman sted Razak, UPDATE with Friday developments. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Tunku Abdul Rahman, who led Malaysia in winning independence from Britain in 1957 and served 13 years as this Southeast Asian nation's first prime minister, died Thursday night. He was 87. On Friday, thousands of Malaysians filed past his body, lying in state at the main hall of Parliament House in Kuala Lumpur. Doctors lost a two-day battle at General Hospital to stem intestinal bleeding and other problems. The Tunku had been confined to a wheelchair for the past few years and had been hospitalized often, but remained active. The Tunku, which means prince, was a son of the ruler of Kedah state. He was scheduled to be buried with full royal and state honors Friday evening at the Royal Mausoleum in Alor Star, 240 miles northwest of the capital. Alor Star is Kedah's capital and the prince was being buried there at his own request, Chief Secretary to the Government Ahmad Sarji Abdul Hamid told reporters. Malaysians affectionately referred to the Tunku as Bapak Merdeka, or father of Malaysia, because he won independence for the nation. The Tunku resigned as prime minister in 1970. He accused the present prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, of being behind student demonstrators who demanded his resignation. In 1946, the Tunku helped found the United Malays National Organization, or UMNO, which has provided all four of Malaysia's prime ministers to date. He recently took to calling Mahathir a dictator, however, and backed the opposition. The UMNO, under Mahathir, won the general elections in October. After resigning as prime minister, the Tunku became the first secretary-general of the Organization of Islamic Conference, comprising more than 40 Moslem nations, which was formed at his urging. He also served as chairman and columnist of The Star Daily newspaper and wrote books and movie scripts. He liked fast cars and horse racing, enjoyed his daily brandy and smoked, although some of his pursuits were proscribed under his Moslem religion. ``One of my happiest days is when we got independence,'' he once said. ``My saddest day was May 13. I hope and pray it never happens again.'' He was referring to May 13, 1969, Malay-Chinese racial clashes that left hundreds dead in the streets of Kuala Lumpur. The Tunku began losing his political power soon after. Malay students felt he conceded too much to the Chinese. The Tunku is survived by his wife, Sharifah Rodziah, and seven children, including five adopted children.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Bambi Fiance to Stand Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last two grafs to CORRECT name of Canadian policeman to Rozdolsky, sted Warkowski.
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered the fiance of convicted murderer Lawrencia Bembenek to stand trial after a Canadian policeman testified Thursday the man admitted helping her escape from prison. Judge Henry B. Buslee denied a motion by Dominick Gugliatto's attorney to bar news media from the Circuit Court hearing. Ms. Bembenek, known to her sympathizers as ``Bambi,'' fled July 15 from Taycheedah state prison, where she was serving a life sentencing for murdering her husband's former wife. She and Gugliatto were captured in October in Thunder Bay, Ontario, where she is fighting deportation. Buslee ordered Gugliatto, 35, bound over for trial on charges of aiding an escape. Gugliatto's lawyer Mary Lou Robinson said reporters should be kept out of the courtroom to ``respect the dignity'' of her client, a divorced Milwaukee factory worker who says he fell in love with Ms. Bembenek while visiting another inmate at the prison earlier this year. Buslee rejected the request, saying news media are an ``extension of the public.'' Gugliatto was released on $100,000 bond Sunday. Ms. Bembenek, 32, is a former Milwaukee policewoman, a calendar model and Playboy Club cocktail waitress. She married policeman Elfred O. Schultz, then was accused of murdering his ex-wife with his pistol because she disliked his paying alimony. A private detective working on her behalf says she was framed. She has appealed several times unsuccessfully to get a new trial. Ms. Bembenek, working as a waitress under an assumed name, was captured in Thunder Bay Oct. 17 after a customer recognized her from a television show that publicized her case. Andrew C. Rozdolsky, a constable with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, testified that Gugliatto admitted helping Ms. Bembenek escape from prison and establish a new identity in Ontario. Rozdolsky quoted him as saying: ``I'm guilty and I'm not going to go before a jury and say I'm not guilty.''

DOC.HEAD: Twelve Students to get Science Lesson from Columbia Astronauts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, 8th graf and last graf to CORRECT that 11 students participating, sted 12.
DOC.TEXT: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia will take time from their extra-terrestrial duties Friday to give a science lesson to 11 students and do a little space agency public relations. The project, dubbed Space Classroom by NASA, is designed to involve more students and teachers in shuttle science missions. Members of the seven-man crew of Columbia, which went into orbit Sunday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., will talk to middle school students about the electromagnetic spectrum and its relationship to their astronomy mission. After the lesson, the students will remain in a mission control room to participate in demonstrations and discussions of what they learned. Karen Widenhofer, a science teacher on temporary assignment with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, will do the teaching on the ground. The students will then ask questions of the orbiting crew. The youngsters also will talk with scientists and control team members at Marshall Space Flight Center, tour its facilities and take part in other science sessions. The space-to-earth astronomy school originally was scheduled for September but fuel leaks and telescope problems delayed the launch until this week. The 11 students, chosen from schools across the Southeast, are Denny Elkins of Snellville, Ga.; Willie Carter of Memphis, Tenn.; Karen Scott of Nashville, Tenn.; Jennifer Marple of Brentwood, Tenn.; Bart Doran of Glen, Miss.; and Cindy Hughey of New Hope, Christopher Battle of New Market, Julie Rodman Athens, Paula Montgomery of Huntsville, Eric Sweatt of Birmingham, and Mario Trimble of Montgomery, Ala. Columbia carries a $150 million Astro observatory intended to focus on about 240 high-energy objects in space, such as quasars, a supernova and a comet as Columbia orbits 218 miles above Earth. Prospects for using the observatory were dimmed by the loss Thursday of the only working computer terminal for operating the stargazing equipment. In connection with the Space Classroom project, called ``Assignment: The Stars,'' NASA is offering teachers sets of materials for classroom use, including a guide for lesson plans and student activities on the electromagnetic spectrum and a slide presentation describing the Columbia mission and concepts on the electromagnetic spectrum and astronomy. The 11 students, chosen because of their scientific aptitude, arrived at Marshall on Thursday and will go through various exercises before leaving Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: One Man Killed, Couple Wounded in Rifle Assault By Gunmen
DOC.TEXT: A motorist was killed and a couple injured Thursday when two men armed with an assault rifle sprayed a city street with gunfire, authorities said. Kenneth Wiggins, 46, died less than four hours after he was struck by a single bullet as he drove down a street before dawn, police said Police arrested Ronald Stokes, 40, and recovered an AK-47 rifle and ammunition clip, police spokesman Tom Santry said. Authorities searched for a second man. Stokes, a paroled convict, was charged with homicide and assault and battery with a dangerous weapon, Santry said. Stokes was arrested near the shooting scene after dropping the rifle and fleeing, police said. Kenneth Pounds, 45, had just left his house for work when he came running back inside fleeing the gunfire, said his wife, Bettie. She was shot as she tried to evade the gunfire, which pierced the door even after the couple closed it. Pounds was hospitalized at Brigham and Women's Hospital; his wife was treated and released. ``We have no beefs, no arguments or fights, with anyone,'' Mrs. Pounds said.

The Commerce Department approved more than 20 shipments of bacteria and other biological agents in recent years to Iraq and Syria, a congressional lawyer says. U.S. experts said that while the agents could be intended for medical purposes, they also could be used to develop biological weapons. Both countries are believed to be developing such lethal arsenals. As a result of the shipments, Iraq could end up using U.S.-supplied goods against American soldiers if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, said Ted Jacobs, chief counsel of the House subcommittee on commerce, consumer and monetary affairs. ``We never thought that Iraq would be so dangerous,'' said Peter Chalfont, secretary of the Wiltron Co. of Morgan Hills, Calif., which sold $45,000 in electronic test measuring equipment to Iraq in 1987. ``It's easy to say in hindsight that maybe the license shouldn't have been approved.'' ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Iraq is accepting President Bush's offer to hold talks on the occupation of Kuwait, but the gap between the two sides remains wide as Secretary of State James A. Baker III testifies on Capitol Hill. Baker plans to use his trip to Baghdad to reiterate three U.S. demands - that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait, free all foreign hostages and permit the return of the ousted Kuwaiti government. But Sadiq al Mashat, the Iraqi ambassador, told reporters Wednesday that the Palestinians' dispute with Israel is the ``backbone'' of Iraqi policy. ``It has to be addressed some way or another,'' he said. ``Let us negotiate and arrive at a peaceful settlement which would be in the interest of everybody in the region.'' ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - U.S. and Soviet negotiators, aiming toward an early 1991 summit in Moscow, are tackling the remaining obstacles to a treaty on strategic weapons. After clearing away three major roadblocks to the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, or START, officials say experts from both sides will meet Friday in Washington to work on remaining technical issues. They involve inspections to verify treaty compliance and telemetry data from ballistic missile testing. Those areas of disagreement still could block completion of the treaty, but one U.S. official said they ``are not enough for anyone to fall on their sword over.'' The negotiators have made significant progress over the past month by agreeing to limit Soviet Backfire bombers that would be outside the START treaty itself; to allow U.S. nuclear programs with Britain to continue; and to restrict the launch and payload weight of the Soviets' modernized, ground-based SS-18 missiles, said an official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Infertile couples are flocking to clinics, joining self-help groups and lobbying Congress for help. But contrary to popular perception, a new study says there is no infertility epidemic. ``The overall rate of infertility didn't change between 1982 and 1988,'' said William Mosher, a statistician who co-authored the federal report. ``This is another chapter in the life story of the baby boom, whose members have affected American society at every stage of their lives.'' One out of 12 women had an impaired ability to have children in both 1982 and 1988, a steady rate of 8.4 percent, according to the report by the National Center for Health Statistics. In 1988 that rate translated into 4.9 million women aged 15 to 44. The infertility rate for married couples actually fell from 8.5 percent in 1982 to 7.9 percent or 2.3 million couples in 1988. ---= SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) - California is looking for businesses willing to hire criminals, and only criminals, by the thousands. The new gang of factory workers won't have to commute. In fact, they'll be in big trouble if they try. And they won't be organizing unions, guzzling beer after work or chasing co-workers of the opposite sex. The jobs will be blue collar, literally - prison blue. Pressed by a rising prison population and tight budget, California voters decided to encourage businesses to set up shop inside prisons and put inmates to work so they can contribute to their upkeep and gain valuable job skills. ---= TEHRAN, Iran (AP) - Eleven years after the Islamic revolution forced women under veils and banned social contact between the sexes, President Hashemi Rafsanjani is championing a freer attitude toward sex and social interaction. ``We imagine that it is good if we suppress ourselves, endure frustrations and be patient in our sexual desires. This is incorrect. It is wrong,'' Rafsanjani said last week at Friday Prayers, an important forum for political statements. ``God has created certain needs in the human being, and he does not want them left unanswered,'' he said, addressing thousands of worshippers at Tehran University and millions of his countrymen listening on radio. The efforts are part of a broad political and social liberalization Ransanjani has pressed, despite sharp opposition, since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini died in June 1989. ---= ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP) - Miners are fighting congressional efforts to reform an 1872 law allowing them to claim public land for $2.50 an acre. Opponents say it's a relic of the Old West that makes modern land-grabbing easy. Supporters argue that changing the law could put thousands of miners out of work and cripple one of the nation's basic industries. ``The mining industry is in trouble. It's in deep trouble in the Congress of the United States,'' said Bill Grannell, executive director of the Western States Public Lands Coalition in Pueblo, Colo. The coalition of miners, logging interests and ranchers who use federal land, mostly in the West, has launched a petition drive to preserve the Mining Law of 1872.

DOC.HEAD: New Role in Eastern Europe: From Intellectual to Politician
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to add dropped date coding.
DOC.TEXT: A year after sweeping to power, Eastern Europe's intellectuals face a dilemma: how to mesh their old job of keeping the national identity with the new one of conducting practical politics. For 40 years, these men and women preserved the cultures of their nations in spite of Communist repression and guarded individuality against collectivism. Intellectuals have played a similar role for at least 100 years in the region, whose 19th century nationalist movements were founded by thinkers determined to find places for their nations apart from giant, alien empires. When the Soviet empire suddenly crumbled last year, politics fell in many cases to the dissidents and intellectuals, the only figures sufficiently untainted by communism. After a deluge of economl be swept out.'' A senior aide to President Vaclav Havel said, ``It's fun when you can work on the intellectual concepts, but it's not when you get caught up in schedules and routine.'' The aide, speaking on condition of anonymity, reflected a certain distaste for day-to-day politics that some commentators and foreign observers see as a serious flaw. ``It's sad, but there's almost no politician in sight,'' said Vladimir Mlynar, a former dissident who now is a journalist at the daily Lidove Noviny. Havel ``doesn't see this too well because his pet theory is that politicians have brought the world to ruin,'' Mlynar said. ``His problem is that, as a dissident, he made up this theory of moral politics. ... When he became president, he found out you must behave differently because your opponents behave like politicians. He would not admit this, but he's learning.'' The problem is perhaps most acute in Czechoslovakia, where Havel and other dissidents went in mere weeks from the underground to the presidential castle that dominates Prague's skyline. In Poland, intellectuals were able to ally with the workers 10 years ago in Solidarity. Even after Solidarity was suppressed, real politics continued underground. Change also was more gradual in Hungary, where some dissident opposition was tolerated. In 1985, the Hungarians held partially free elections for a Communist-dominated parliament. In Bulgaria, as in Czechoslovakia, everything seemed to happen at once. The ouster in a Politburo coup of Todor Zhivkov, who had led the nation for 35 years, caught both the opposition and much of the Communist Party by surprise. The party had never articulated its internal split between reformers and Stalinists, and the opposition had just begun to organize. They are still quarreling over who should rule. Only in Romania did key intellectuals stand aloof from politics, largely refusing to join either the technocrat-dominated National Salvation Front or the opposition. Their attempt to continue acting as the nation's conscience, however, drowned in the emotion and intrigues of everyday politics. One result of the sudden changes and the intellectuals' new role is a dearth of cultural interest across the region. ``We have lost our theme,'' said Alex Koenigsmark, a Czechoslovak playwright. Dodging the censors and Communist oppression used to unite spectators and artists in ``a kind of plot,'' he said. ``Now, we must search for new identity.'' Some intellectuals have been slow to abandon what Koenigsmark called the ``Stalinist warmth'' of the old system, which lured artists into conformity by offering the material comforts of special holiday homes or guaranteed fees. Tens of thousands of other intellectuals eked out livings in undemanding jobs. Their reward was plenty of free time to read and debate existential problems in a fashion that exhilarated Westerners absorbed in material gain. Financial needs also occupy Eastern brains these days. ``We have simply no time to read anymore,'' said Vasil Atanassov, a Bulgarian translator. ``Now, we have to make money.'' This means East European societies are stripped of the very people who, as Mlynar put it, should ``shove the mirror in politicians' faces ... so they cannot move outside certain boundaries.'' In Western societies, this role is played largely by the media. Free, independent media are slow to emerge in Eastern Europe, where most people know only totalitarianism. Especially in the Balkans, a torrent of emotional comment poses as free reporting. Even at Lidove Noviny, which existed in the underground, it often proves difficult for former dissidents to stand back from the petty intrigues of daily politics or to criticize friends in power. Collapsing economies add to the woes. Culture no longer enjoys heavy subsidies, meaning soaring ticket and book prices that drive audiences away. Western pop and pornography, long forbidden, are touted blatantly throughout Eastern Europe. The popular concept that freedom equals the absence of control makes it difficult to impose limits on such wares. Idealists, who could sketch the new identities for which society might strive, find such a climate unwelcoming. ``It's quite nice to have visions,'' wrote Jaroslav Weiss, a Lidove Noviny columnist, ``but you have to have money for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Takes Toll on Arab Cultural Showcase
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to add dropped date coding.
DOC.TEXT: The Institute of the Arab World, opened three years ago as a showcase of Arab culture, faces hard times as the Persian Gulf crisis chokes off donations from Kuwait and other major benefactors. The cultural center, which attracts about 5,000 visitors a day, occupies a stunning building beside the Seine. It was created to promote Western understanding, but turmoil in the Arab world has taken its toll. France paid most of the $100 million cost of construction for the institute, which contains a research center, auditorium and exhibition halls. It also has provided 60 percent of the $20 million yearly operating budget, or about $12 million last year. Under the institute's founding charter, members of the Arab League were to pay the remaining 40 percent. Edga Pisani, the institute director, said only half a dozen of the 21 counties had paid their share, resulting in an Arab debt of $30 million accumulated since 1987. Pisani said France would not take over the institute's entire cost and operation. To keep the center in operation, he has eliminated jobs, cut the budget for buying manuscripts and other materials, and refused to accept exhibitions or cultural events unless outside parties pay for them in advance. The newspaper Le Monde said one-fourth of the institute staff, about 50 people, had been laid off. Lack of money has been a problem since President Francois Mitterrand inaugurated the institute in 1987, but things have grown worse since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Le Monde reported that Kuwait, which once contributed $1.2 million a year, was paying nothing. It said other major debtors included Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Egypt, Libya and the United Arab Emirates. Political arguments also have plagued the institute. Insiders accused its first director of hiring a disproportionate number of Lebanese and not giving all member countries equal influence. ``Money is just a pretext; what's $30 million to a rich gulf state?'' said a Lebanese researcher who regularly makes use of the institute's facilities. ``The real problem is politics, the relations among the Arabs.'' ``The institute has no leadership or direction and it is not the research center it was supposed to be,'' he said, on condition of anonymity. Other research facilities in Paris have more Arabic manuscripts than the institute, he said. Others argue that because the institute depends on donors, it cannot be an authentic showcase of Arab culture. ``If the library does not have a work which attacks Algeria, even indirectly; if the film library does not have a certain movie that the Saudis don't like, then all is lost,'' Philippe Gardenal wrote in Liberation, a leftist newspaper. He said Paris could end up with a ``sanitized view of the Arab world, just another stop on the itinerary of hurried tourists rushing from the department stores to the Folies Bergeres.'' Saudi Arabia recently canceled an exhibition of photographs about the country, without explanation. Iraq demanded the removal of a Syrian caricature from an earlier display, on grounds the caricature resembled President Saddam Hussein. Plans had been made for 1991 to be the ``Year of Morocco.'' They were canceled when relations between France and Morocco deteriorated because of a best-selling French biography critical of King Hassan II. Some commentators have suggested the institute focus on France's Arab population. About 5 million Arabs live in the country, and many are out of touch with their own culture. Jean Nouvel of France designed the institute, whose sleek metallic facade curves along a bend in the Seine. It has been described as one of the most daring and beautiful buildings in Mitterrand's ambitious state-financed construction program. Other projects included the new Bastille Opera House and the Louvre Museum's glass pyramid. Nouvel said he was inspired by traditional Arab architecture. Space is defined by light and shadow. Sunlight filters dramatically through an interior facade composed of 25,000 metal diaphragms reminiscent of the intricate wooden screens on traditional Arab windows. The institute offers temporary exhibits, Europe's largest reference library on the Arab world, video facilities and electronic data banks, a 500-seat auditorium and a restaurant with a breathtaking view of the Paris skyline and Notre Dame cathedral.

DOC.HEAD: Costa Rica's Envoy on His Third Tour in Washington
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Ambassador Gonzalo Facio likes Washington. He keeps coming back again, and again, and again ... Facio doesn't so much pres several cruises aboard the presidential yacht down the Potomac. Facio first met George Bush in 1971 at the United Nations when he was Costa Rica's foreign minister and Bush was U.S. ambassador. The two joined to fight the expulsion of Taiwan from the world body. They lost to communist China and its allies, but Bush remembered Facio's help. When Facio came to present his credentials this summer, the president's first words were ``long time, no see.'' That day, too, will go down in history. Facio presented his credentials on Aug. 7, the day before Bush ordered U.S. troops to the Persian Gulf. ``The president,'' Facio said, ``looked tired.''

DOC.HEAD: PBS Documentary Tracks Record-Setting Everest Climb
DOC.TEXT: Last spring, veteran American climber Jim Whittaker made one of mountaineering's most difficult and dangerous endeavors look almost easy - his expedition put a record 20 climbers on the summit of Mount Everest. On Monday, PBS airs ``Three Flags Over Everest,'' an hour-long film account of the feat that, for Whittaker and his team of American, Soviet and Chinese mountaineers, was more than the challenge of the world's highest mountain. ``It wasn't just a climb to see if we could get to the top,'' Whittaker said in a telephone interview from his home near Seattle. ``It was more of a climb to see if people of different cultures could get together to work for a common goal. ``The message is of people doing things that are difficult for the good of the world.'' The idea for the International Peace Climb came to Whittaker six years ago in pre-glasnost days, when relations between the superpowers were chillier. Whittaker, a world-class mountaineer in 1963 when he became the first American to stand atop Everest, assumed the role of globe-trotting diplomat, shuttling between Beijing and Moscow looking for a commitment to the climb. ``When I was in China and approached the idea to the Chinese, they said, `We have not had Soviets in our country in 30 years,''' Whittaker said. ``And I said, `Yes, I understood that, but you had come to our country with ping-pong balls and ping-pong paddles and we'd like to come to your country with the Soviets with ice axes and crampons.'' The Americans - financed through Whittaker's lectures, individual and corporate contributions and support from the outdoor industry - supplied the cash and equipment to mount the $1.1 million expedition to the top of Everest, located on the border of Nepal and Tibet. Still, the Soviets and the Chinese were slow to agree, for fear the other nation would back out. They joined only after considerable negotiations. For the 61-year-old expedition leader, the climb had another symbolic goal beyond goodwill among the three nations. The mountaineers originally expected to be on the summit April 22, the 20th anniversary of Earth Day, a chance ``to highlight that we were going to clean the Earth from the top down,'' Whittaker said. Severe cold and 100 mph winds delayed the summit attempt for more than a week. But on May 7, the mountaineers awoke to perfect weather. Setting aside language differences and disputes over climbing styles, six climbers - two from each nation - made it to the 29,028-foot summit, the top of the world. During a remarkable four-day window of favorable weather, 14 more members of the expedition ascended. No previous expedition had put 20 people on the summit. In 1985, a Norwegian group had 17 reach the top. Whittaker, who did not try for the summit, knows his team, made up of the best climbers from each country, was lucky as well as skillful: No one died and no one was seriously hurt. In Everest history, for every two climbers who had been successful, one has died in the attempt. ``We ran into quite a bit of difficulty, but it always seemed to work out,'' Whittaker said. ``It seemed like the gods all said, `Let's give these guys a tough time because we don't want it to be easy.' In the end though, we had the good luck, right when we needed it.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... FROM THE WHO SAYS TV COMEDY IS JUST ONE INFINITELY VARIEGATED FORMULA? DEPT.: ``You Take the Kids,'' a new half hour comedy series starring Nell Carter and Roger E. Mosley, takes to the airwaves Dec. 15 on CBS. Carter, who starred for six years in the sitcom ``Gimme a Break!'' plays Nell Kirkland, ``a less-than-perfect mom who may not have all the answers but who is always ready with an opinion.'' That's what the publicity says. Honest. Mosley (who was sidekick T.C. on ``Magnum, P.I.'' for eight years) plays her husband, Michael, a school bus driver. You say all this series needs is a couple of cute kids? How about four? There's Raymond, the dreadlocked 16-year-old ``whose biggest concern is staying cool.'' There's Lorette, the 14-year-old ``who's in a big hurry to become an adult.'' Uh huh. Then there's studious 12-year-old Peter, ``who aspires to be a doctor and doesn't quite fit in.'' And there's Nate, ``a 10-year-old con artist forever planning his next scam.'' Could any sitcom viewer ask for more? Living in the basement is Nell's cantankerous mother (Leila Danette), ``who gets all her news from supermarket tabloids and is still in search of the perfect husband for her already married daughter.'' Aw, gimme a break! The series' executive producer is Paul Haggis, a two-time Emmy winner in 1988 for his work in ``thirtysomething.''

DOC.HEAD: Church Leaders Warn Against Military Offensive
DOC.TEXT: In times like these, a trenchant, old question gnaws at consciences: When should nations go to war, and for what? That is the moral issue troubling the nation's churches, and most are saying: No, not now. Not yet. Wait. Have patience. Seek talks. Negotiate. Pursue every just avenue to avoid the inevitable horrors of war. That burning, apprehensive note echoed through statements of Protestant, Roman Catholic and Orthodox church leaders as the United Nations, backed by the United States, authorized the use of force against Iraq if that nation does not withdraw from Kuwait by mid-January. The anxious, restraining plea had not been noticeable in the immediate aftermath of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. In that period, most churches strongly condemned the aggression, the abuse of civilians and taking of hostages, supporting the international embargo against Iraq, and the moves by the United States and others to defend Saudi Arabia. Mainly, church voices still hold those positions, but now indicate alarm at potential offensive tactics against Iraq. They want the United Nations to take a principal role, and remain hopeful that steady international pressure will bring a peaceful solution. But they bridle at talk of a military offensive. Expressing fear the crisis ``is leading our nation steadily toward war,'' heads of most of the country's main Protestant and Eastern Orthodox Churches last week declared, ``We are convinced that war as a means of settling international disputes is in conflict with the teachings of our faith.'' The group of 15 church leaders, including top Episcopal, Lutheran, Orthodox, American Baptist, Presbyterian, Reformed, United Church and National Council of Churches officers, said they want justice done in the area. They also reiterated condemnation of Iraq's aggression and support for the U.N. sanctions, but they urged the number of American troops there be reduced to those the United Nations requires to maintain ``peace and security.'' ``We believe that resorting to war to force a solution on the issue would be disastrous in its human and environnmental costs,'' the leaders said. Their stand was similar to that expressed in mid-November by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, although the bishops did not suggest a reduction of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, saying instead: ``We understand that a strong military presence can give credibility to a vigorous pursuit of non-violent solutions to the crisis.'' However, after a closed discussion in Washington by the bishops, their president, Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, wrote to President Bush urging him to stick to ``peaceful pressure and not resort to war.'' Noting that the church's criteria for ``just war'' require that it be a last resort after all peace efforts fail, that the goal outweigh the likely damage inflicted and that it minimize civilian casualties, the letter said: ``Moving beyond the deployment of military forces ... to the undertaking of offensive military action could well violate these criteria, especially the principles of proportionality and last resort.'' The National Council of Churches, including most major Protestant and Orthodox denominations, called for a halt to the buildup of U.S. forces in the region and also urged they be pared to those needed by the United Nations. The United States ``increasingly prepares for war, a war that could lead to the loss of tens of thousands of lives and the devastation of the region,'' the council's governing board said at a mid-November meeting in Portland, Ore. ``In the face of such reckless and imprudent behavior ... we have a moral responsibility publicly and unequivocally to oppose actions that could have such dire consequences,'' the church representatives added. In Cleveland, the Rev. Paul H. Sherry, president of the United Church of Christ, sent a letter to Bush, saying: ``The steady drumbeat of war messages from you and your administration have sent a shocking message ... ``We want you, in turn, to hear the clear message from the religious community: Do not lead the U.S. into war with Iraq. War is not the solution to Iraq's immoral invasion of Kuwait and will lead to severe suffering for untold numbers of people.'' The United Methodist Council of Bishops urged Bush ``as a manifestation of his faith in God as revealed in Jesus Christ'' to pursue every diplomatic avenue to solve the crisis rather than military action. Representatives of the three historic ``peace'' churches - the Brethren, Friends and Mennonites, want American troops withdrawn completely, telling Bush that ``Our own hunch is that you are talking us toward war'' out of economic interests. Advocating simpler lifestyles to conserve energy and development of alternative energy sources, the ``peace'' churches added: ``We fear there will be a growing tendency to go to war in the coming years over resources such as petroleum if we do not find ways to curtail our dependency on them.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Monday AMs, Dec. 17, and Thereafter ^French Immersion: A Major Tool in Striving For Bilingualism
DOC.TEXT: Only 4 million of this officially bilingual country's 26.5 million people are officially bilingual, and most of them are French Canadians who learned English. The main effort to remedy that situation and fulfill national policy is called French immersion, which now involves 7.3 percent of all schoolchildren. Every weekday, more than 250,000 English-speaking children troop to classrooms around the country and spend all or most of the day studying in French. Enrollment increases every year. ``Unlike French programs 20 years ago which graduated students who could not speak French, sometimes after nine years of studying the language, French immersion programs are producing functionally bilingual graduates,'' said D'Iberville Fortier, Canada's commissioner of official languages. Herns Pierre-Jerome, head of French immersion at Lawrence Park high school in Toronto, added: ``Students in the program not only have an opportunity to master a language, but in terms of learning, they are open to other dimensions.'' Ever since the British sneaked up on the French at Quebec in 1759 and defeated them on the Plains of Abraham, French speakers have been at a disadvantage. They make up a quarter of Canada's population, but their minority thrives only in the province of Quebec and in scattered pockets elsewhere. English Canada never troubled itself much with learning French. Then, in 1969, Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau pushed through the Official Languages Act. It declared French and English to be the official languages of Canada and obliged all federal institutions to provide services in both languages. The law put bilingualism at a premium, particularly for federal jobs, and made the dual nature of Canadian society official. Experiments with French immersion began in the 1960s. Programs blossomed in the 1970s and 1980s. Early fears that Children's English would suffer or that performance in other subjects would be affected have been allayed, for the most part. ``As an educational experiment, it's a resounding success,'' said Sharon Lapkin, a professor at the University of Toronto and researcher at the Modern Language Center of the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education. French immersion has its opponents, among them Hector Hammerly, a professor of linguistics at Simon Fraser University in British Columbia. This is how he describes the problem: ``It's not really immersion. They are not surrounded by French speakers. They are surrounded by 25 other children who speak French as badly as they do.'' Hammerly cited a study indicating that 52 percent of simple sentences written by immersion students had one or more errors in grammar or vocabulary. ``The immersion approach does not work and cannot work,'' he said. ``It forces children to communicate far beyond what they know. They make far more errors than a teacher can correct effectively.'' Lori Nash of Ottawa, head of a national group that favors a more traditional approach to learning French, said: ``They can't be taught, they can't learn and they can't explore in a second language as well as in their mother tongue.'' Claims by others that the program is elitist bring a more mixed response. ``Is the system elitist?,'' Ms. Lapkin asked. ``Yes. Should it be? No. Does it have to be? No. Are there places where it is less so? Yes.'' Pat Brehaut of Sherwood Park, Alberta, is president of Canadian Parents for French, one of the main organizations supporting French immersion. She agrees immersion may have been elitist in the beginning, when many of the children came from better-educated families of the professional and managerial class. ``I think now if you look at children going into the program, you see a balance of abilities and a balance of socio-economic backgrounds,'' she said. Demand continues to increase. In some parts of the country, parents line up to enroll their children in immersion programs. ``They are still waiting in Calgary, and there always have been waiting lists in Prince Edward Island,'' Mrs. Brehaut said. ``It has been growing since the day it started,'' she said. ``A year ago, CPF did a survey and we found that 69 percent of English-speaking parents wanted their children to learn French.'' Even the most vocal proponents of the program acknowledge shortcomings. According to Fortier, the federal languages commissioner, major problems include low participation at the secondary school level, teacher shortages, that the program does not work for all school districts and that immersion graduates do not have real fluency. How the success is evaluated depends on goals and definitions. Merrill Swain, head of the Modern Language Center, said the goals are to develop language skills better than those achieved by traditional French classes with no loss of mother-tongue proficiency and no loss in general academic achievement. She said immersion had achieved those goals. Does bilingualism mean speaking perfect French or just the ability to communicate effectively? ``You can't expect an anglophone child to become a francophone,'' said Marie-Antoinette Mantione, assistant coordinator for French as a second language at the Toronto Board of Education. Children working in totally English environments cannot be expected to become perfect speakers of French, but experts agree the major achievement is ``functionally bilingual'' children who are able to communicate and be at ease when speaking French. Ms. Swain said immersion is probably the most studied program in the history of education. Surveys have shown there is no long-term detrimental effect on the students' English, academic achievement is comparable to students taught in English and students acquire a high level of confidence in their ability to handle French. Another benefit is that the young English Canadians have a better understanding of their French-speaking compatriots from Quebec and elsewhere. ``These kids can speak French with an ease that is way beyond what could be done in a traditional program 20 years ago,'' said Roy Harvey, principal of Lawrence Park. ``What has that contributed to a general understanding and tolerance in this country? I would say a lot.''

DOC.HEAD: Sniping Continues Between Bankers and Farm Credit System
DOC.TEXT: If one sure thing emerged from the Agriculture Department's recent outlook conference, it was a feeling that bankers and cooperative lenders aren't hitting it off too well these days. The latest sniping concerns a report released last month by the American Bankers Association showing that a liberalization of Farm Credit System lending policies 19 years ago led to a land boom in the 1970s and a bust in the 1980s. Congress created the FCS more than 70 years ago to provide farmers with a dependable source of credit at competitive rates. Today, the system is a $60 billion network of farmer-owned lending institutions, which include federal land bank and production credit associations. According to the banker-financed study by Ely & Co. Inc. of Arlington, Va., the FCS ``fueled a financially unsupportable farmland price boom'' after Congress revised the Farm Credit Act in 1971 so the cooperatively owned system could liberalize its lending powers. The 1971 law, among other things, raised the system's collateral limit to 85 percent of the market value of farmland from the previous standard of 65 percent of its agricultural income-producing value. Peter C. Myers, president of the Farm Credit Council, the chiehing more powerful - a change in the American public opionion which will impose restrictions on the decisions and intentions of the evil ones, led by Bush, the enemy of God.'' But, despite this change, he said, the ``Iraqi armed forces should maintain the highest degree of alert and vigilance because the forces of aggression remain on our sacred soil in Saudi Arabia, fanning the flames of fire.'' Iraq banned foreigners from leaving in response to the allied troop buildup in Saudi Arabia. The United States has contributed 230,000 troops and promised another 200,000. Iraq has deployed 430,000 troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait. Saddam said that when the travel ban was first announced, Iraqi forces ``had not completed their mobilization in Kuwait to confront a potential military aggression. ``Now that the Iraqi military is battle ready,'' Saddam said, the foreigners should regain their ``freedom to travel.'' ``We deem it necessary that our National Assembly convene to take a final and irrevocable stand toward a humanitarian issue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Serving New Masters: Merging and Purging the East Germany Army
DOC.TEXT: Gone are the goose step, the old allies, the pledge to protect communism from the evil forces of the other side. Gone, too, is the other side. The East German soldiers who once stood on the Cold War front find the front has moved to their flank. What once was the enemy flag flies over their garrisons. Old foes are now commanders and comrades. Welcome to NATO, soldier. Your old mission with the Warsaw Pact is finished. So is the Warsaw Pact. Once pointed defiantly westward, the National People's Army now wears the uniform of a united German military, a more benign entity pointed nowhere in particular. Without firing a shot, the West German armed forces took over their eastern counterpart in a single day, then fired most of the officers and cut the force almost in half in a matter of weeks. What has been billed as a merger is essentially a purge. The remaining soldiers must apply to stay. If they are approved, they will undergo a two-year probation to determine whether they have the right ideological stuff to continue their careers. ``For old soldiers like me, the generals and commanders, it was right to dismiss them; there's a new command,'' said Gerhard Seifert, an ousted Communist general who led an engineering corps. ``But firing other professional soldiers - I think they moved too quickly.'' Seifert lives in Wildpark West, a village of large homes hidden in a forest outside Berlin and surrounded by a military complex once known as National People's Army Defense District No. 84. Before World War II, Wildpark West was an exclusive resort for some of Berlin's wealthiest people. After Germany was divided, it became home to top officers in the East German army. Now, Wildpark West is esentially a retirement community. Seifert, who spent 38 years in the army, warmly welcomed a visitor and displayed snapshots his wife took on Oct. 10, the day he relinquished his command. One shows him on a couch, in uniform, drinking cognac with Gen. Eckard Jantzen, the West German who took over the base outside Potsdam, 18 miles south of Berlin. ``For years, we were painted a portrait of the Western soldiers as the enemy,'' Seifert, 59, said jovially. ``But on that day, we were all military men.'' Seifert, who was 12 when he watched American planes bomb his native Chemnitz during World War II, said he had no animosity toward the West and realized the necessity of his nation's evolution. He expressed disappointment, however, that professional East German military personnel were dismissed so quickly. ``Career soldiers too young for pensions and too old for new work face a difficult future,'' Seifert said. The western army also is becoming smaller, but has not shrunk so dramatically. To get the four World War II allies who conquered Germany to agree to reunification, the nation must reduce its total forces to 370,000 by 1994. On Oct. 3, unification day, West Germany had 460,000 soldiers and the East had 110,000. Only 60,000-80,000 now remain in eastern Germany and the west has about 450,000, Defense Department spokesman Walter Reichenmiller said. Many soldiers in the east have quit or were conscripts who had their tours of duty reduced. About 25,000, most of them officers, were dismissed for being too close to old regime. Ultimately, the goal is 50,000 eastern troops and 320,000 in the west, Reichenmiller said. For the soldiers who remain, the biggest challenge will be thinking differently. East German soldiers promised to defend communism and were subject to rigid external discipline. West Germans, in a reaction to Nazi brutality, have been schooled in ``Innere Fuehrung,'' or moral leadership, a philosophy that teaches a code of honor, humanity, self-discipline and responsibility. ``One of our major concerns is to educate our eastern friends in the terms of how we think a military individual should relate to a community,'' Reichenmiller said. ``It's a formidable job. Certainly, it won't work with everybody, but there are enough people there who are young enough, tolerant enough to learn.'' Klaus Becher, a security analyst with the German Society for Foreign Politics in Cologne, said tensions had arisen because Western officers know little about the men they now command. ``It's uneasy, to say the least,'' he said. ``Some of the western soldiers look down on their colleagues.'' Bjorn Trauer, a 19-year-old native of Potsdam drafted in September, served one month in the National People's Army and now wears a western uniform. ``The western officers are much friendlier,'' he said, ``but I think it's a shame they had to fire so many of the old officers.'' Strangely, the part of the old East German army with the darkest past still remains. About 6,000 border troops, who had orders to shoot people fleeing the country, remain on duty. They are removing the border fortifications - land mines, watchtowers and electrical fencing - they once monitored. ``They will be dismissed once the job is done,'' Reichenmiller said. ``They have, of course, a rather bad reputation.'' For the East German soldier, the last year has been a jarring experience. Markus Nitschke, a former soldier from Potsdam, was drafted in September 1989 just as protests against the old government were beginning. He said soldiers were given training in riot control, including how to use nightsticks. Soldiers were asked to sign pledges promising to support the police. He and several others refused, Nitschke said, and that caused problems initially, but ``after Honecker fell, nobody cared any more.'' Communist Party chief Erich Honecker was forced out in October 1989. Nitschke, 20, now is a civil engineering student. East Germans elected a democratic government in March that made major changes, including the remarkable decision to appoint a pacifist preacher, Rainer Eppelmann, as defense minister. He cut the 3-year tour of duty in half, got rid of the goose step that had been the army's trademark and removed the inductee's pledge to protect communism. German unification eliminated the National People's Army altogether and is now causing the removal from German soil of its staunch ally, the Red Army. All 380,000 Soviet soldiers in eastern Germany must leave within four years. They are returning to an economically depressed, ethnically polarized country whose very existence is in question. There have been widespread reports of Soviet soldiers deserting, selling their guns and uniforms, even committing suicide. ``I worked with these men all my life,'' Seifert said. ``I was trained in Moscow. It's tragic what's happening to them.''

DOC.HEAD: West Gets Soviet Guns, Tanks, Ammo - and Those Spiffy MiGs
With BC-Germany-No More Sides
DOC.TEXT: In an odd side effect of German unification, NATO pilots streak across the skies in perhaps the finest fighter plane ever produced by the Warsaw Pact. The sleek and deadly MiG-29 is by far the most dazzling prize in the vast trove of weaponry that once belonged to the East German armed forces. The 24 twin-finned Soviet jets still are flown by eastern German pilots, who now wear the uniforms of what was once West Germany. ``It's absolutely unprecedented,'' said Walter Reichenmiller, spokesman for the Defense Ministry. When the two German nations reunited on Oct. 3, the former West German military suddenly was handed a large and varied collection of Soviet combat technology. How valuable is it, now that the Soviet threat has abated? The question of more immediate import may be: Will it give Germany's close ally, the United States, a clearer strategic picture of Iraq, which has much of the same Soviet-built hardware? ``If there were some windfall, it would not be very helpful to talk about it too much in the best interests of the United States,'' Reichenmiller said. ``Certainly ... some findings are very interesting.'' He and independent defense experts say, however, that little can be gleaned from East Germany weaponry that wasn't known already. ``Most of the equipment the East Germans have has been around a long time,'' said Andrew Duncan of the International Center for Strategic Studies in London. Reichenmiller said the most advanced tank Iraq and East Germany had in common, the T-72, was 18 years old. The MiG-29 is fairly new to both the Iraqis and the East Germans, who got it in 1988. Iraq is believed to have only about 30 among its hundreds of fighters, and they are so new the Iraqis may not have mastered them yet, Duncan said. Klaus Becher, a security policy analyst at the German Society for Foreign Politics in Cologne, said Iraq's MiG-29s may be slightly different versions than East Germany has - with different electronics systems, for example. The MiG-29 mystique is diminished somewhat by the fact that the Soviets have shopped the plane around to prospective buyers, including Israel. Presumably, Becher said, they also are making information about its capabilities available. He said the Soviets even let a reporter from a Western aviation magazine fly a MiG-29. ``Sure, it is useful to take these things apart, but the West always has had ways to do that,'' Becher said. The jet has an advanced radar system some experts believe may give it an edge on the American F-16. ``It's a pretty good aircraft,'' Reichenmiller said, adding that Germany routinely passes such information on to the United States. Right now, the 24 MiGs are being kept for research purposes. Reichenmiller said no decision had been made on whether to put the MiGs into active service, but that most of the East German arsenal - hundreds of tanks, older jet fighters, helicopters, guns and munitions - would be destroyed. The German armed forces must shrink to comply with the international terms of unification. Keeping much of the weaponry in service also probably would require Germany to buy replacement parts from the Soviets. Germany may keep the Soviet-made transport planes. Reichenmiller said the government has offered some to the United States for use in the Persian Gulf. He said Soviet transport planes were even being used for a daily shuttle service carrying government and military personnel from Bonn, the seat of government, to Berlin, the newly designated capital of the united country.

DOC.HEAD: Limited or Unlimited Terms: Who Can Tell Which Is Better?
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: According to Vice President Dan Quayle's sales pitch, there's not much wrong with Congress that couldn't be fixed by putting a 12-year limit on House or Senate service. To that, critics reply that some of the very ills Quayle cited would only get worse in a Congress populated by people who couldn't run again. It's a case neither side can prove in advance. Both sides agree that a constitutional amendment limiting terms would lead to more competitive congressional elections because it would force out incumbents and give newcomers a chance. They also agree that it is not going to happen any time soon. ``This is obviously going to come from outside the beltway,'' Quayle said the other day at a conference sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute. ``...It is not going to come through members of Congress seeing the light all of a sudden.'' He said it wasn't a partisan matter, but term limits would do a lot more for the Republican than for the Democrats, who have held control of the House for 36 years and have just extended it to 38. Forced retirements would open House seats and enhance GOP chances in future congressional elections. A term limit amendment was proposed in the last Congress and will be introduced again next year, but it won't get anywhere. Approval would take two-thirds votes in each house. Advocates could get only 15 senators to sign on last time, and two of them have since limited their own terms by retiring. So the strategy of Americans to Limit Congressional Terms, seeking to capitalize on the limits approved in three states this year, is to build pressure for national limits by trying to get the voters to impose them on state legislatures. They hope to get term limit measures on the ballots of at least 15 states in the 1992 elections. The group, which calls itself a grass-roots movement with more than 70,000 members nationwide, held its own conference this week to push its issue and plan the next campaign. But first, some of the limitation measures imposed this year will face challenges in the courts. That's a sure thing in the case of the Colorado limits, which reach beyond state legislators and officeholders to cover senators and House members as well. There also have been threats of court action against the state measure imposed in California and the city limits voted in Kansas City. President Bush has endorsed congressional term limits, but he hasn't pushed the issue. Quayle has, as vice president and when he was in Congress, learned first-hand, he says, about the abuses that can go with seniority. ``The longer one is in Congress, the more staff, the more subcommittees you acquire, and the more bureaucratic the government becomes,'' Quayle said. Critics countered that congressional newcomers lean more heavily on their staffs, and are more susceptible to special interest influences. ``Well, who do you think has the power right now?'' Quayle countered. ``...The special interest crowd likes the current system. It's comfortable. They know the people.'' He said the turnover produced by limiting terms would attract talent to Congress, lead people to vote with an eye on issues rather than on reelection and campaign fundraising, strengthen party discipline, encourage competition for committee chairmanships. Point by point, critical questioners told him the result could as easily be the reverse, arguing that those objectives can better be attained with election reform that would limit spending, staffs, free mailings and other advantages that make incumbents almost impossible to dislodge. Quayle said he doesn't look for real reform because incumbents would have to approve it, adding that the prospect of term limits might give reformers the leverage to force action. ``There is a voter revolt brewing,'' he said. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday Dec. 09
