DOC.HEAD: A Military Paradox: Trying To Shrink and Grow at Same Time
DOC.TEXT: At Marine Corps headquarters in the shadow of the Pentagon, Col. Russell Appleton shuttles between two desks. At one, he works to cut the active-duty roster. At the other, he tracks call-ups of military reserves. This seeming contradiction - getting smaller and bigger at the same time - points up one of the paradoxes lurking behind the scenes of the dramatic buildup in the Persian Gulf crisis. The uniformed services and their civilian overseers are orchestrating the largest U.S. military operation since Vietnam while simultaneously carrying out Congress' order to shrink the military by 80,000 people over the next 10 months. Can it be done? The Pentagon says ``yes.'' But there are growing indications that military leaders may ask Congress to set aside the troop cut goals. Appleton, head of manpower policy and planning for the Marines, may have to tuck away his ``force reduction'' files because, as he said in a recent interview, ``putting 200,000-plus soldiers, sailors, marines and airmen on the other side of the world ... isn't business as usual.'' Even more unusual is the challenge of adding yet another 200,000 troops as reinforcements for the original deployment, as ordered Nov. 8 by President Bush to get Iraq out f Kuwait. When the full contingency of perhaps 430,000 personnel is in place, nearly one-quarter of the entire American armed forces will be committed - more troops than the United States had in Europe at any time during the Cold War. Just a few months ago, Congress put the Pentagon on a path toward reducing troops by up to 500,000 over the next five years - part of the now-aborted drive to gain a quick ``peace dividend'' from the collapse of communism. Even in the seemingly unlikely event that the gulf crisis is resolved peacefully and soon, it may force Congress and the Bush administration to take a new look at how to restructure and reduce U.S. forces in the post-Cold War era. The Pentagon could ask Congress for permission to put off the troop reductions. But Pete Williams, the chief Defense Department spokesman, said in a recent interview ``we're still going to try to hit'' the targets set by Congress in October. The problem is seen most clearly in the colliding paths of reserve and active duty forces. Tens of thousands of reservists are being called out of their civilian jobs to join Operation Desert Shield at the same time many active duty career officers are being forced to retire. The military says it must cut officers and enlisted personnel to meet the force-reduction targets set by Congress, yet it can't prepare for a possible war against Iraq without adding more than 100,000 reservists to the active duty force. The reserves provide vital skills not available in the active-duty force, such as certain medical, transport, water purification and construction services. Somewhere in the sands of Saudi Arabia the paradox takes on real-life meaning. ``The fact is there's a reserve colonel standing out there next to a regular colonel (facing a forced retirement), and it can become a very, very emotional issue,'' Appleton said. The Army, which must absorb about half the 80,000 personnel cuts for the total U.S. armed forces by Sept. 30, has found a temporary solution to the conflicting demands presented by Congress and the gulf crisis. On Nov. 23, it froze all active-duty personnel in their positions. In effect it acknowledged - though not in so many words - that it could not continue cutting the force while putting roughly 200,000 Army personnel in Saudi Arabia. The other services might be forced to do the same if the gulf crisis erupts into war. ``If we go to hostilities then all bets are off because you then have casualties that you have to replace,'' Appleton said. ``It changes the calculus completely.'' Yet even now the Marine Corps, while officially preventing some of its personnel deployed for Desert Shield from leaving the service, is using retirement boards to decide which 100-plus active duty officers will be forced out of uniform. Such boards are used by the services to meet their troop-cut requirements. The Air Force plans to convene a retirement board this month to force as many as 750 colonels and lieutenant colonels out of uniform. The Army decision to freeze its force, made with the approval of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, meant that about 5,500 personnel per month who otherwise would have chosen to leave the Army will be kept in uniform indefinitely, according to an Army planner who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Army has not only stopped shrinking, but also has grown as a result of adding more than 68,000 National Guard and Reserve troops to its ranks as part of Desert Shield. Technically, the reservists are not counted in the total force level that the Army is legally required to reach by Sept. 30. The complications are especially great for the Army, which also is trying to manage the huge task of withdrawing 30,000 troops from Western Europe over the coming year, deactivating some Germany-based units, and maintaining its other worldwide commitments - including 40,000 troops in Korea and 50,000 in Japan. ``It's an unprecedented challenge,'' said Gen. Gordon Sullivan, the Army vice chief of staff and a central figure in long-term planning for restructuring the Army.

DOC.HEAD: Breaking the Rules, Lozenge Still a Big Seller
DOC.TEXT: His product tastes horrible, the package is all wrong, and the name sounds funny. Still, Greg Blazic has managed to build Fisherman's Friend into one of the leading coughlozenges in America. ``I had commission sales reps who were terrified of the product,'' Balzic said. ``I'd tell them, `You have to make the buyer taste the product,' and they say, `You're nuts! I was just getting in the door!' ``But so many of these drugstore chains make decisions by committee, and if a buyer went to committee with these and somebody else tasted it first, he wouldn't have a comeback when they said, `This tastes lousy!''' They look like flattened doggie treats, and the powerful taste of menthol, eucalyptus, licorice and pepper can leave you rolling your eyes and gasping for breath. But people keep buying their Fisherman's Friends. ``The reaction is, it tastes terrible, but it's unique because it's effective,'' said John Zarbatany, president and CEO of Peter P. Dennis Inc., a wholesale distributor in northwestern New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania. ``People either love it or hate it, and the people who love it swear by it,'' Zarbatany said. ``They've built a nice trade out among the consumer public, and they seem to be coming back from year to year. They've got a niche in the marketplace that they're going to maintain.'' In seven years since he started importing them, Blazic has managed to carve out increasing shares of the cough lozenge market, ranking third behind Sucrets and Chloraseptic with a sales volume of more than $6 million. The 125-year-old formula first was sold to English cod fishermen trying to cope with colds caught in the North Atlantic and hasn't been changed much since pharmacist James Lofthouse developed it. Lofthouse sold the lozenges, 19 at a time, in littl paper envelopes, still the way his family markets them. The family takes an old-fashioned approach to the export market, too, appointing one distributor for each country they target. Two distributors failed to catch on in the U.S. before him, Blazik said. ``They tried to sell them as candy,'' he said. In the U.S. market, Blazik thinks the strong taste and the old-fashioned packaging work for him. ``When you were growing up, wasn't it a belief of your grandmother that no medicine works unless it tastes bad? I think there's a psychology about that, for something to really work you have to pay your dues.'' Selling at 19 for 99 cents, the lozenges are among the cheapest on the market. ``So it's a good value, and it's got a name that easy to remember. You know, the recall factor is tremendously high, and anybody who's ever tasted one of these just forms an opinion, and they always remember it.'' Blazik & Associates was incorporated in January 1983, after the conglomerate he worked for decided to sell off its candy companies. He went into business with his savings and severance and an agreement from his wife. ``She'd support me for two years, and by the third year if the company had a 50-50 chance of making it, she'd give me another year. But she wouldn't have anything to do with the business at all, because it had to survive on its own. Surviving isn't easy in the world of big drug store chains, Blazik found out. If a product isn't selling, it's taking up valuable space that could be used to stock something that will make money. He had to convince some very tough buyers for drugstore chains. ``I was thrown out of so many places in the early years, it was incredible,'' he said. ``But the funny thing about this product is that nobody ever forgets. ``You call up and you only get one shot a year with a buyer for a chain. So I'd get shot down, and I'd know I can't come back for a year. So I call back a year later, and the guy would say, `Are you still trying to sell that stuff?''' Blazik started with a novel marketing idea: Put the packages in a plastic boat on a pedestal on the store's counter. The gimmick worked, although Blazik admits ``People bought because of the boat, not because of the product. The boat was cute.'' His company now has 14 employees, but Blazik estimates he still works 70 to 80 hours a week. Someday, Blazik's daughter may join the business - on one condition. ``She told me, `You know, Daddy, when I get older, I want to sell Fisherman's Friends like you do, but I don't have to eat them, do I?'''

DOC.HEAD: Forest Service Looking at Forest Instead of Trees
DOC.TEXT: Driven by the environmental battle over the northern spotted owl, the U.S. Forest Service is developing a new approach to logging that demands looking at the forest, not just the trees. Through the New Perspectives program, the Forest Service is looking harder look at what cutting down a tree means: to wildlife, plant life, biological diversity, erosion, sedimentation of steelhead and salmon spawning beds, and hiking and driving through the forest. New Perspectives is being showcased along Shasta Costa Creek in the Siskiyou National Forest in southwestern Oregon. By careful management, foresters hope to produce in 80 to 120 years the kind of old growth forest that took nature more than 200 years to create. ``We're looking beyond the trees,'' said Kurt Wiedenmann, program director for the project. ``We're looking at it from an ecological standpoint. Not just timber production.'' Shasta Costa Creek is a tributary of the Rogue River in the area where the Klamath Mountains join with the Coast Range. The watershed runs from an elevation of 200 feet at the creek's mouth o 5,300 feet at Brandy Peak. The watershed provides spawning grounds for salmon and steelhead, and nesting and hunting grounds for the spotted owl, which was listed as a threatened species this year. It also is home to pine martens, which have been proposed for federal protection, pileated woodpeckers, elk and deer. Only 2,000 of the watershed's 23,419 acres have been logged, making it a potential battleground between environmentalists who want to preserve old growth forests and the timber industry, which wants to keep mills rolling. As a result, the Forest Service has undertaken an environmental impact statement, rather than the less demanding environmental assessment, to plan how it will log the Shasta Costa. It is to be finished this spring. ``No two ways about it, the spotted owl issue was the big driver in the New Perspectives movement,'' said John Henshaw, the program coordinator for the Northwest. ``New Perspectives concepts offer a hope, not a promise, of an ability to continue both amenity- and commodity-based production on the national forests.'' In the past decade, scientists such as Jerry Franklin, professor of ecosystem analysis at the University of Washington and chief plant ecologist for the Forest Service, began questioning traditional forestry. They decided nature had some valuable lessons to teach when it came to harvesting and replanting forests. The concepts became known as New Forestry. ``What we see happening everywhere is an appreciation of the fact that a more structurally diverse managed forest probably can do a better job of providing other ecological values, like wildlife habitat,'' Franklin said. The concepts were embraced first at the grassroots level of the Forest Service and ran up to the top. Chief Dale Robertson thought they had merit, but thought the term New Forestry implied the old ways had been bad. So New Perspectives was born. On the Shasta Costa, New Perspectives can be described as logging the forest the way a forest fire would, in a mosaic of intensities that will grow back with the complex structure of old growth. It includes debris left on the ground to decompose, standing dead trees where birds can nest and find food, and big green trees that will become the top of a multistoried canopy that shelters spotted owls from predators. Henshaw said the program is spreading quickly throughout the Forest Service. But environmental groups and the timber industry aren't sold on the concept. ``I think New Perspectives has its roots in the notion that we ought to be able to manage everything,'' said Andy Stahl, forester for the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund. ``I would submit that there are some lands, some things, that nature does the best at, and one of those is old growth forests. I don't think the old growth they will grow in 80 years is going to compare with the old growth Mother Nature took 300 years to grow.'' Dennis Hayward, vice president of the North West Timber Association, said New Perspectives provides a way to manage lands that have been set aside from logging. But where he had hoped to see 17.5 million board feet of timber come out of Shasta Costa in the next three years, the Forest Service has proposed cutting 11.2 million board feet. ``Compared with what they started out with, their preferred alternative is a sleight of hand,'' Hayward said. ``They are using it politically to try to avoid a controversy for three years, and that is wrong.''

DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. launched a $90-a-share, $6 billion cash tender offer for NCR Corp., but NCR said it would fight a takeover unless the phone giant raised the price by $2.5 billion. AT&T made its direct offer to NCR shareholders Wednesday after a deadline passed for the nation's fifth-largest computer maker to respond to the takeover bid. NCR said it would enter into merger talks with AT&T if the phone company increased its takeover bid to $125 a share, for a total of about $8.5 billion. --- BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - Negotiators involved in 107-nation free trade talks reported failure in efforts to resolve a nasty fight over farm subsidies. Some trade ministers suggested the discussions might break down. The trade ministers emerged just before midnight Wednesday from a two-hour meeting in which they sought in vain for a compromise position on the expensive subsidies that developed countries pay to their farmers. If the talks are broken off, even for a brief time, it would put the entire four-year effort at trade reform in jeopardy. Talks were to continue Thursday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Factory orders for manufactured goods bounced up 2.8 percent in October, the government reported. But analysts said the jump mostly was due to the transportation sector and the higher cost of oil. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that orders for both durable and non-durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $250.7 billion after a revised 0.2 percent decline the previous month. The revision showed September orders even weaker than the 0.1 percent gain initially reported. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - American workers' productivity grew at a mediocre annual rate of 0.2 percent in the July-September period, while the nation's businesses trimmed the working hours of their employees, the government said. Analysts took the 0.2 percent falloff in hours - the first such decline since 1986 - as a sign that American businesses had been bracing over the summer for a recession, which many economists think has taken hold. The Labor Departmet's report Wednesday was not surprising because many American businesses have implemented large-scale layoffs in recent months. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A Federal Reserve survey shows the economy in all regions of the country were either declining or growing sluggishly at November's end. Both retail sales and construction activity were found to be weak in virtually all of the central bank's 12 districts in its so-called ``Beige Book'' assessment of the nation's economic pulse. The report, released Wednesday, was the latest piece of evidence that the economy has weakened in recent months. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The government's sale of real estate and other assets inherited from bankrupt savings and loans is drowning in red tape, costing taxpayers millions of dollars, a congressional report said. The report by the staff of the House Banking Committee was released Wednesday as the committee opened two days of hearings on the Resolution Trust Corp. It was scheduled to hear from more than a dozen agency critics but from none of the RTC's top executives. --- TOKYO (AP) - Japanese telecommunications giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone said it has developed a palm-size portable telephone that is the lightest and smallest in the world. The 8.1-ounce cellular phone, to be made by four Japanese electronics companies, can carry a continuous conversation for 45 minutes, NTT said on Wednesday. The phone is 9.2 cubic inches in size, compared with 13.5 cubic inches for Motorola Inc.'s MicroTac telephone, NTT said. --- DEARBORN, Mich. (AP) - Ford Motor Co. is recalling about 110,000 1990- and 1991-model Ford, Mercury and Lincoln cars to see if they were equipped with potentially defective air bags. Cars involved in Wednesday's recall are 1990 models of the Ford Taurus and Tempo, Mercury Sable and Topaz and Lincoln Continental along with 1990 and 1991 versions of the Ford Crown Victoria and Mercury Grand Marquis cars. The company said TRW Vehicle Safety Systems Inc., an air bag supplier, told it that about 3,000 potentially defective air bags had been shipped to Ford assembly plants. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Reader's Digest, a symbol of traditional American values for decades, will compete for a place near Russian hearths next year. Reader's Digest Association Inc. announced plans Wednesday for a two-year test of a Russian-language edition of its flagship magazine to be published in the Soviet Union beginning in August 1991. ---

The stock market swept ahead to a 12-week high Wednesday, extending its yearend rally as the price of oil tumbled. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 30.70 to 2,610.40. Bonds edged up. The dollar was mixed. Gold declined. Grain and soybean futures fell, livestock and pork futures climbed, and crude oil fell to its lowest futures price since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Charged in Bank Collapse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf pvs, ADDS 6 grafs to end to UPDATE with details, Bond denial; No pickup; Currency is U.S. dollars
DOC.TEXT: Alan Bond, the flamboyant businessman who bought a Van Gogh and bankrolled a stunning yachting upset, was charged today in connection with a government investigation of a collapsed investment bank. Bond, whose brewing and mining empire collapsed in a mountain of some $6 billion in debt, joins a growing list of fallen Australian high-flyers now facing criminal charges. He was accused of concealing information during an attempted 1987 rescue of the investment bank Rothwells Ltd. Police in Perth, Bond's hometown, said Bond was released on $77,000 bail. He was to appear in court on Friday. In a statement, Bond denied the allegations, saying he is ``absolutely innocent.'' Bond was charged in an investigation by a special government task force set up Rothwells collapsed in November 1988 with losses of about $200 million. Police last week charged former Rothwells chief Laurie Connell and casino boss Dallas Dempster for alleged illegal stock trading. Three others face trial on charges of falsifying accounts to make it appear the bank was making substantial profits. Prosecutors allege that large, undisclosed borrowing by Connell of up to $385 million was the main cause of Rothwells' failure. Bond joins bankrupt Hooker Corp. head George Herscu and Elders Resources managing director Geoff Lord as prominent Australian businessmen to face criminal charges. Herscu, one of Australia's 10 richest men until Hooker Corp. fell on hard times, was convicted Thursday of corruption charges for paying off a former state official. On Monday, Lord was charged with 37 similar offenses. The charge against Bond, a British-born former sign-painter, was the latest chapter in a long slide. Only three years ago, Bond bought Vincent Van Gogh's ``Irises'' from the auction house Sotheby's for a then-record $53.9 million. The same yeat he financed Australia's upset of the United States in the Americas's Cup yacht race. At its peak, Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd., the company he founded, included interests in brewing, media, resources and property. It had a gold mine and telephone company holdings in Chile, and brewing and other mining interests in the United States. Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke last year praised Bond as ``a great Australian.'' Bond rode out the 1987 stock-market crash on strong cash flow from his beer assets. But the man who built a fortune on borrowed funds continued to overextend and Bond Corp. eventually ran up estimated debts of more than $6 billion. A combination of heavy debts, rising interest rates and bad business decisions alienated bankers and creditors, put Bond's Australian brewing interests into receivership and forced him to sell assets ranging from a Hong Kong office development to a coal mine. In March, Bond sold the Van Gogh for an undisclosed amount amid reports he had taken a loss. In September, he resigned under pressure as chairman and director of Bond Corp., although he still holds a controlling interest through his private company, Dallhold Investments. Two days after the resignation, Bond Corp. reported a loss of $1.72 billion. Bond was charged under the Western Australia state Securities Industry Code with concealing an arrangement between Rothwells and Bond Corp. from another member of the ``rescue team.'' Under the deal, Bond Corp. was to contribute $13.1 million to a rescue package aimed at keeping Rothwells afloat after the October 1987 stock market crash caused a run on its funds. But Bond allegedly did not tell other contributors he was to receive a $12.3 million fee for helping to organize the rescue. The charge alleges that by concealing the arrangement, Bond induced Perth businessman Brian Coppin to contribute to the rescue through an underwriting agreement with Wardley Australia Securities Ltd. ``I deny absolutely that I acted dishonestly or concealed anything from Brian Coppin,'' Bond's statement's said. He said ``no fee was paid to me, Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd., or any company associated with me, in connection with the Rothwells rescue of 1987. I am absolutely innocent of any wrongdoing, and the charge will be strenuously defended.''

DOC.HEAD: Frugality Campaign is Centerpiece of South Korean Trade War
DOC.TEXT: A controversial campaign urging citizens to avoid luxury goods has helped create South Korea's worst trade frictions since Seoul joined the ranks of the world's top economies. At stake are millions of dollars worth of services, consumer goods and products from Europe, the United States and other nations that Korea's most important trading partners claim have been blocked in the Korean market. Foreign diplomats said that in the last year imports have been removed from stores, consumers buying large items such as automobiles have been threatened with tax audits and some goods are being held at customs under obscure regulations. Goods as diverse as candy-coated chocolates and luxury automobiles have been caught in the cross-fire. U.S. Ambassador Donald P. Gregg said recently that rising trade friction threatens to undermine political and economic relations between Washington and Seoul. The United States is South Korea's largest trading partner, and has been its chief ally for more than four deacades. ``We don't like it, particularly coming from Korea,'' U.S. Senator Frank Murkowski of Alaska, a frequent visitor to Korea, said. He said there is ``a growing concern ... and support for the merits of retaliation.'' Korean officials maintain that the campaign is an earnest desire by citizens to restore frugality and austerity in Korea's fast changing society. Government officials say they are hard put to stop it. Officials say the movement was not designed as a policy to discriminate against imports, but they admit privately that in implementation some imports and Korea's image as a fair trader have been hurt. ``I'm not going to deny there was some misinterpretation,'' said Kim Sam-hoon, director-general of the international trade bureau for the Foreign Ministry. ``But we have many people who are spending excessively and wastefully.'' The campaign is rife with cultural overtones: Western materialism and the right to sell to consumers vs. a tightly knit, homogeneous culture where conspicuous consumption is seen as moral decay. The movement has been described as an anti-import campaign, a consumer's crusade, an austerity campaign or a spiritual effort to restore basic Confucian thrift. Western trading nations see the campaign as an anti-import drive, secretly backed by the government and aimed at restricting access to foreign goods and services. Luxury Korean-made goods have not been targeted. The American Chamber of Commerce, which said the movement was targeted at imports, was attacked by a band of radical students and remains under guard by plainclothes riot police. The chamber said the campaign ``effectively reinstated a number of barriers to the importation of consumer goods ... and equated imported consumer goods with luxury goods.'' It said Korean consumers would benefit from more choices. ``At no time did we challenge other aspects of the campaign - frugality, austerity, cultural values, Confucian ethics,'' a letter to chamber members said. Koreans feel foreigners do not appreciate the campaign as an extension of Korea's Confucian culture stressing fruguality and moderation. They are offended by consumption-oriented Western societies they feel destroy harmony by allowing the rich to be different. ``The driving force behind this campaign is social discontent over the extravagant consumption of the rich,'' Deputy Prime Minister Lee Seung-yun said. He said misunderstandings have evolved because the campaign discourages buying unnecessary imports. ``The reasonable consumption of foreign goods with regard to quality and price should not be criticized,'' he said. Newspapers have warned that anti-Americanism will increase if the trade war continues. Radicals, farmers and dissidents have staged violent protests against imports and demanded an end to U.S. pressure to open markets. They say foreign goods and farm products will adversely affect the livelihood of Korean workers. British Ambassador David Wright said advertisements for foreign goods have been defaced. He said regulations hamstring banks and security companies that operate freely in other foreign markets. Most significant, he said, the Seoul government is showing signs of retrenching in its recent promises to liberalize its markets.

DOC.HEAD: Plan Offers $680 Million Over 20 Years To Compensate Workers
DOC.TEXT: In a key case in the nation's biggest worker health saga, Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. wants to provide up to $80 million over 20 years to compensate asbestos disease victims and avoid declaring bankruptcy. Eagle-Picher is widely viewed as a test case for dozens of companies saddled with huge liabilities stemming from the production and use of asbestos, the insulation material that causes lung cancer and other respiratory diseases. Two attorneys representing asbestos plaintiffs Wednesday proposed creating a trust that would begin making payments in November 1993. The trust would be funded with annual cash payments by Eagle-Picher and company stock. Under the plan, Eagle-Picher would pay $460 million into the trust over 20 years, $45 million for claims already negotiated and an estimated $178 million in proceeds from cash flow in company operations. The attorneys said Eagle-Picher, a Cincinnati-based industrial and auto parts manufacturer, needs to resolve the fate of more than 65,000 asbestos claims quickly or face a financial crisis and possible Chapter 11 filing. ``Eagle-Picher appears to be on the brink of bankruptcy unless its asbestos-related liabilities are promptly settled,'' attorneys Stanley Chesley and David I. Shapiro wrote in a 22-page recommendation to U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein. ``The evidence we have seen indicates that Eagle-Picher cannot generate enough cash from operations to pay its obligations as they mature,'' the lawyers wrote. But two other attorneys appointed by Weinstein to negotiate with Eagle-Picher are opposing the plan, saying it provides too little money to resolve existing claims and untold thousands of future claims. ``The obligations of the company are minimal in relation to the number of persons who have sustained serious injury by way of occupational exposure to its products,'' plaintiffs' lawyer Peter Angelos of Baltimore said. A hearing was scheduled for Friday on Eagle-Picher's request that Weinstein declare a class-action to resolve the claims on grounds the company cannot meet its asbestos liabilities. A similar request has been made by the Manville trust fund, the nation's largest asbestos resolution facility, which faces about 130,000 claims but has run out of cash to pay new claims. A proposal to restructure the trust is pending. Dozens of other former asbestos makers are watching the cases closely, and judges nationwide are hopeful for model plan to clear a backlog of 90,000 cases in state and federal courts. Payments to victims in some instances have been delayed for years, and many workers have died before receiving compensation. Weinstein and asbestos defendants support converting company's claims into single class actions to reduce legal fees they say are exhausting assets that could be used to compensate victims. Eagle-Picher has paid about $540 million in asbestos claims in the last five years. Court documents said the company no longer can sell assets, issue common stock and debt, or use tax refunds and insurance claims to meet its liabilities. Under the settlement plan, Eagle-Picher would create an independent trust to resolve claims. The company would contribute $30 million in the first year, $20 million per year for the next nine years and $25 million per year in the following 10 years, for a total of $460 million. In addition, the trust after five years would receive 25 percent of Eagle-Picher common stock if the company's meets the payment plan, and 50 percent if it does not. Eagle-Picher would set aside 6.75 percent of its net sales each year to provide for basic operations. The company's remaining cash flow would be split with the trust, for a estimated $178 million. About $45 million in claims already settled but held up by Weinstein would be paid within 18 months. Shapiro and Chesley said in the court papers that victims stand to receive more money faster if the company remains an operating entity than if it is forced seeks bankruptcy court protection. Eagle-Picher's claims stem from worker exposure to an asbestos-based pipe sealant the company made primarily for U.S. government ships from 1934 to 1971.

DOC.HEAD: Reader's Digest Plans Russian-Language Edition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Reader's Digest, a symbol of traditional American values for decades, will compete for a place near Russian hearths next year. Reader's Digest Association Inc. announced plans Wednesday for a two-year test of a Russian-language edition of its flagship magazine to be published in the Soviet Union beginning in August 1991. The monthly, which is already published in 15 languages in 39 countries, joins a growing list of American publications scrambling to gain a foothold in the largely untapped Soviet market. Business Week magazine launched a Russian-language edition this past summer. The Ladies Home Journal put a 32-page Russian-language insert in about 10,000 copies of its November issue that it sent to the Soviet Union. Rodale Press has announced plans to publish a magazine there in Russian called The New Farmer. The Journal of Commerce plans a monthly tabloid in Russian starting in January. The trade publisher International Data Group is producing a pair of Russian-language magazines, PC World-USSR and Manager. Officials of the Magazine Publishers of America said Scientific American and the inspirational magazine Guideposts are also planning Russian editions. Russell J. Melvin, an executive at the MPA who tracks international publishing developments, said these efforts ``hinge on hope'' that changes in the Soviet economic system will open the country to Western products and ideas. In the meantime, publishing ventures face ``nothing but problems in the short term'' in getting into the Soviet Union. Paper is in short supply. Printing operations are not up to Western standards. Distribution systems are questionable. The Soviet ruble can not yet be converted into other currencies. But Melvin said the Soviet Union is proving a powerful lure to publishers with its 300 million consumers who have been economically isolated for years. ``They have a great desire for the printed word. Virtually every magazine that is printed is gobbled up, '' Melvin said. Publishers who get in now will be ready to give advertisers a way to reach those readers once their products become available there, he said. George Grune, chairman of Reader's Digest, said the company has been studying the market and talking with Soviet officials for two years. He said the magazine has been assured complete editorial freedom and that there would be no censorship. The magazine will be published monthly with an initial distribution primarily on newsstands of 50,000, rising to 100,000 within two years. Following the format followed with other international editions, the cover will carry the title Reader's Digest in both English and Cyrillic. A typical edition will contain articles translated from the U.S. edition of Reader's Digest. The company is sending an editor not yet selected to Moscow to oversee the operation. The cover price, which will be in rubles, has not been determined. Subscriptions will also be sold. Each issue will be about 160 pages, which is about average for inrternational editions of the magazine, and will carry advertising. The charge for a four-color, two-page spread in all 12 issues is $35,000. The rate for a single page in four colors in the U.S. edition of Reader's Digest, which has a circulation of 16.25 million, is $131,000. Grune said that after the test period, the company will evaluate Soviet interest in the magazine and decide whether to continue doing business there. In the meantime, spokesman Bruce Trachtenberg said the company will bank the proceeds from its sales. Part of the money will be used to pay for translating, producting and distributing the magazine. If the test is successful, Trachtenberg said the company hopes to proceed with other publishing ventures in the Soviet Union. ``Reader's Digest celebrates the power of the individual. It gives people tools to live productive daily lives. Those are universal themes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: East European Market For U.S. Goods May Be Exaggerated: Study
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Europe may not be the boundless market for U.S. products that may manufacturers envision, a new study suggests. Consumers in the region want U.S. fast food and Japanese electronics but hope to purchase most other goods from Western European producers, according to a survey of 600 people in Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland, the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia. The study conducted by MAI, a London-based market researcher, contradicts a widespread notion that Eastern Europeans are eager to buy almost anything made in America, an official for the research firm said Wednesday. ``The point is that people there are not just sitting with bated breath waiting for products from U.S. sources,'' said Robert Kaden, president of MAI's Goldring & Co. division in Chicago. ``It will be necessary for most U.S. brands to build both goodwill and awareness before they begin selling.'' Some international trade experts said the MAI study reflects an overly simplistic view of the pan-European market, but they generally agreed with its conclusion that U.S. companies should look closely before leaping into Eastern Europe. ``It's very much a niche market,'' said management professor Michael Radnor, executive director of Northwestern University's International Business Development Program. ``There are opportunities there but you have to really have done your homework to see where there are possibilities.'' Experts also pointed out that some U.S. makers of consumer goods are positioned for doing business in Eastern Europe through subsidiaries or joint ventures. For example, Whirlpool Corp., the Michigan-based manufacturer of dishwashers, refrigerators and other home appliances, owns 57 percent of the large-appliance division of Philips N.V., a Dutch company that is well known in Europe. ``If this survey shows that Eastern Europeans want to buy appliances from Western European producers, we would say bravo. That would be ideal for Whirlpool,'' said spokesman T.R. Reid. The MAI survey quizzed people on brand name recognition and product preferences. Kaden said Pepsi Cola and Coca-Cola were the most recognized brands at 99 percent and 97 percent respectively. Levi jeans, McDonald's hamburgers and the Gillette and Palmolive brands also were widely recognized, he said. But when asked, ``Which of the following types of consumer products would you like to see more of in the shops and where would you like them to have been produced,'' North America dominated only in the fast-food category, Kaden said. Soft drinks were not included in the section of the survey on desired products, nor were Russians polled on product desires ``because they need everything,'' Kaden said. When asked where they would prefer to have their cars produced, Western Europe was the top choice of all countries except Yugoslavia, where Western Europe tied with Japan, Kaden said. People in all five countries indicated they would prefer major home appliances - washers, dryers and dishwashers - from Western Europe. Western Europe also was the unanimous top choice as a source of clothing and as a producer of small home appliances, although Polish subjects indicated an equal preference for Polish-made small appliances. Douglas Lamont, author of the recently published book ``Winning Worldwide: Strategies For Dominating Global Markets,'' said he was not surprised by the findings since West Germany has been a favorite trading partner of Eastern Europe, and the people are also familiar with French and Dutch-made products. ``In this country there is a notion we can sell our products into Eastern Europe but I think that notion is mistaken,' Lamont said in an interview from his office in north suburban Evanston. ``I think it will take substantive change on the part of Eastern Europeans to consider American products first on the list,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Earnings, Production and Sales Puts Industry in Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Car and truck production cuts, nose-diving sales and the specter of fourth-quarter financial losses suggest the auto industry is in a recession. If worst-case forecasts come true, the industry next month could be looking at a financial picture reminiscent of the dark days of the early 1980s, analysts said Wednesday. On Tuesday, the Big Three automakers reported sharp downturns in late-November car and truck sales. ``I think we have established a new lower level of car sales for a while,'' analyst Douglas Laughlin of Bear, Stearns & Co. of New York said. ``I think it is going to go into and probably through the first quarter (of 1991) unless we get a real break in interest rates,'' he said. ``There is a lot of caution out there,'' Laughlin said of potential buyers. ``It does look like at least for the auto industry, it is a recession.'' General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., which together held 68.2 percent of the total vehicle market in November, said sales of their North American-made cars and light trucks during the Nov. 21-30 period this year were 24 percent lower than the same time last year. That paints a gloomy picture when coupled with recent announcements of production cuts, forecasts for financial losses in the fourth-quarter, the general softening of the economy and the threat of war in the Middle East, analysts said. GM Chairman Robert Stempel said in a speech last week in Fort Wayne, Ind., that the largest automaker in the world had cut its December production schedule by 40 percent to 144,000 vehicles. Coincidentally, Ford announced new temporary plant idlings for December. Chrysler declined to release fourth-quarter production. Adjustments in production are common in the industry. But the size of the GM reduction was significant, especially coming so late in the quarter. As a result of the cut, Stempel said the company expected its fourth-quarter financial results ``will decline significantly relative to our ... third-quarter results.'' In the third quarter, GM said it earned $109 million. However, it took a $2.1 billion one-time charge for closing some of its factories, resulting in a $2 billion loss for the period. Wall Street analysts forecast that GM would lose somewhere in the neighborhood of $450 million during the final quarter of this year. Meantime, Ford Motor Co. finance Vice President and Treasurer David McCammon said in an interview published Wednesday in The Wall Street Journal that the No. 2 automaker would lose money in the October-December period also. Analysts estimated that Ford would lose around $230 million during the period and financially struggling Chrysler Corp. would lose about $35 million in the quarter. If those forecasts, which are subject to change, come true, the fourth quarter of this year would be the first that each of the Big Three have lost money since mid-1981, when the industry was affected by the national recession. But there are differences between then and now, analysts said. ``The magnitude of these (production) cuts would appear to be something in excess of the current selling rate,'' Laughlin said. ``There is a sincere effort here to avoid an inventory buildup.'' High inventories inspire big incentives, which slice directly into profits. ``The action appears to be preventative rather than reactionary,'' Laughlin said. He and other analysts said Tuesday's sales report gives a better picture of the industry's health than other recent 10-day reports, which showed a much less radical swing in this year's selling rate compared with a year ago. Those earlier reports, analysts have said, included large numbers of fleet sales to rental car companies and large corporations. Stripped of those figures, the retail sales rate is weak, they said. ``We don't know how many fleet sales are in the numbers,'' said analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan, Stanley & Co. in New York. ``Clearly people are taking a wait-and-see attitude toward a perceived economic crisis and a perceived (Mideast) military crisis. ``It's very hard to buy a car in this atmosphere.''

DOC.HEAD: Sears Freezes Salaries of 20,000 Employees
DOC.TEXT: Retailing giant Sears, Roebuck and Co. is freezing the salaries of 20,000 employees for one year in a cost-cutting move, a published report said today. All Sears' salaried employees at the company's Chicago headquarters will have their 1991 salaries frozen at 1990 levels, The New York Times reported. Store managers, sales managers and other salaried executives in the merchandising group also will be affected by the freeze, as will salaried employees in the catalogue and operations, according to an unidentified Sears spokesman. The company, which earned $1.45 billion last year, hopes to save $24 million to $35 million by imposing the wage freeze, the report indicated. The freeze does not include salespeople, who are paid on an hourly basis, or the company's financial services businesses, the Times said. Sears has about 500,000 workers, of which about 330,000 are in the merchandise operation.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Smoke Causes Lung Cancer In Nonsmokers, EPA Panel Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Smoking or Health correct in 3rd graf, bgng The Coalition
DOC.TEXT: An Environmental Protection Agency committee concludes that cigarette smoke causes cancer in nonsmokers and may be an important cause of bronchitis, pneumonia and asthma in children. The effect of passive smoking on children ``might have a greater public health impact than the increase in cancer,'' Morton Lippmann of New York University, chairman of the advisory panel, said Wednesday. The tobacco industry criticized the report's conclusions and the panel's deliberations. But the Coalition on Smoking or Health embraced the panel's conclusions. ``The committee action is a big win for the American people,'' said Fran Du Melle, head of the coalition and deputy director of the American Lung Association's Washington office. ``Given what we know about smoking and lung cancer, there should be no question that passive smoking can cause lung cancer in innocent bystanders,'' Du Melle said in a statement. The coalition is made up of the American Lung Association, the American Heart Association and the American Cancer Society. The EPA panel's acceptance of findings that had been reached in a draft report on passive smoking assures that those conclusions will survive in the final version of the report, agency officials said. The report will likely prompt the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to take steps toward possible adoption of restrictions on smoking in the workplace, said Roy Clason Jr., OSHA's policy director. ``The findings of this report are very important in the future direction OSHA will take,'' he said. OSHA has been planning for some time to establish rules on indoor air quality ``in which we would place a very high emphasis on the issue of smoking,'' Clason said. The draft EPA report was released on June 25. It concluded that tobacco smoke should be designated a class A carcinogen - a known cause of human cancer. It also estimated that passive smoking kills 3,700 Americans each year. And it found a link between passive smoking and increased incidence of bronchitis, pneumonia, wheezing and middle ear disease in children. The report concluded that the children of women who smoke also have impaired lung growth and development. But Brennan Dawson, a spokeswoman for the Tobacco Institute, said the human evidence did not support the classification of tobacco smoke as a class A carcinogen. She said she expected that ``anti-smokers will continue to use the document in its draft form to push for restrictions'' on smoking. The expert panel accepted the draft report's conclusion that ``environmental tobacco smoke,'' or ETS, causes lung cancer, Lippmann said. ``We are persuaded that the evidence exists ... for considering that ETS does cause lung cancer in nonsmokers,'' he said. But the panel raised questions about the report's estimate of 3,700 cases per year. Lippmann said that number would probably change by the time the report is revised in accordance with the panel's recommendations. He said he did not know whether the estimate would increase or decrease. Robert Axelrad, director of the EPA's indoor air division, said the panel's comments had been useful. ``These are all well-known and respected scientists. Their criticism will ultimately result in a stronger and better document,'' he said. Gary Giovino of the federal Office on Smoking and Health, which prepares the surgeon general's reports on smoking, said the EPA report validates conclusions reached in earlier studies by the National Research Council and the surgeon general. ``They've come to the conclusion that previous scientific bodies have, with more data,'' said Giovino. The EPA's report is a review and analysis of available research on the health risks of passive smoking.

DOC.HEAD: California Seeks to Pull License of Firm That Audited Lincoln Savings
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest accounting firm could be banned from doing business in California because of its audit work for Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings. Karen J. Scott, executive officer of the state Board of Accountancy, asked the panel to bar Ernst & Young from doing audits in California. A panel review concluded the company's audits of Lincoln and its parent, American Continental Corp., were ``grossly negligent,'' according to a board complaint filed last month. Scott's Nov. 16 request and the complaint were disclosed this week. Steve Miller, an attorney for Ernst & Young, said Wednesday the company stands by its audit and will contest the case at hearings before the Board of Accountancy. Experts say Lincoln's collapse will cost taxpayers $2 billion, the biggest thrift failure ever. Investigations have focused on how the S&L's finances could have been allowed to deteriorate so badly before it was seized in 1989. A year before the seizure, Ernst & Young's predecessor company, Arthur Young & Co., issued an unqualified opinion that Lincoln's upbeat financial statements for 1987 ``fairly represented'' its financial condition. A month later, the chief Arthur Young partner on the account was hired by American Continental, which tripled his salary. The Accountancy Board can clear Ernst & Young or impose probation, temporary suspension or a permanent ban, said Deputy Attorney General Michael Granen, who is handling the case for the board. Central to the case are eight Arizona desert land deals traded by Lincoln. The accounting board contends the deals shouldn't have qualified as profits because the buyers and sellers were related through complex business ties. Ernst & Young also is the target of a negligence lawsuit filed in June by state Attorney General John Van de Kamp. The lawsuit seeks to recover the losses of investors who purchased $250 million in now-worthless American Continental ``junk bonds'' at Lincoln branches. ``If investors had known the truth, no one would have invested a dime in these bonds,'' Van de Kamp said in announcing the lawsuit. ``But with Arthur Young standing behind them, their bonds sold easily.'' Eugene R. Erbstoesser, Ernst & Young's associate general counsel, questioned the timing of the attempt to revoke the firm's license. He speculated the attorney general could be trying to pressure the company to settle the earlier lawsuit. ``I believe this whole thing is totally unnecessary,'' Erbstoesser said. ``All of this is just making the firm's resolve more determined to clear its name.''

DOC.HEAD: Reorganization Guide, New Indictment Filed
DOC.TEXT: General Development Corp. looked ahead toward reorganization as federal prosecutors looked back at business practices that got the big-time developer into trouble. A consultant hired by the developer filed a reorganization outline in U.S. Bankruptcy Court on Wednesday, hours after a federal grand jury added two former executives and dozens of new charges in issuing a new indictment in the case that supersedes an earlier indictment. The Palmieri Co. proposed placing the assets of the public company in a private trust, which would sell General Development's 90,000 acres, utilities and other assets over eight to 10 years for the benefit of creditors. Conceding the difficulty of a short-term sell-off, the consultant said, ``The real estate market, the general economy, absorption rates and other factors require a relatively long-term horizon to maximize values.'' The consultant estimates General Development's assets could be sold now for $861 million to $986 million for a return of less than 40 cents on the dollar for unsecured creditors. Palmieri believes General Development, which settled its criminal fraud case with a plea bargain last week, could emerge from Chapter 11 proceedings with an approved reorganization plan by June 1. Meanwhile, arraignment was set for today for Tore DeBella, former GDC senior vice president of marketing, and Richard Reizen, former vice president of marketing. They joined ex-Chairman David Brown and ex-President Robert Ehrling as defendants in the criminal case against company executives. All four resigned last March within days of the original indictment. ``The increased number of counts, it seems to me, is a case of `That's what you get for not pleading guilty, pal,''' said Joel Hirschhorn, Ehrling's attorney. ``It's what lawyers call prosecutorial vindictiveness.'' Reizen said, ``I'm not guilty of anything that the indictment charges. My attorney and I will prove that at trial.'' The first 16-count indictment named the company, Brown and Ehrling, but the new one grew to 74 counts, added the two former sales executives and dropped the company because of its guilty plea to fraud conspiracy. The four are accused institutionalizing fraudulent and deceptive sales tactics that resulted in the sale of more than 10,000 homes at inflated prices from 1983 to 1989. Twenty-three charges claim the executives brought people to Florida to further the fraud by promoting ``Southward Ho!'' trips to induce purchases at General Development's nine planned communities. The defendants face possible $250,000 fines and 10-year prison terms on each count. The superseding indictment also includes one fraud conspiracy count and 50 mail fraud counts carrying a maximum five-year term on each charge. General Development was accused of routinely rigging appraisals and using deceptive ploys to entice people into buying and to keep them from finding out their new property wasn't worth what they paid. U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt accepted the company's third plea offer last Thursday with a guilty plea to one count of fraud conspiracy. Sentencing required a $1 million letter of credit to cover administration of a $160 million restitution plan for the victimized homeowners, 10 years of court supervision and five years probation. The company, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April, has halted sales and stock trading.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Higher at Midday on New Gulf Hopes
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were higher at midday Thursday on London's Stock Exchange, buoyed by the news that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein has called for the release of all foreigners held by Iraq. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 28.7 points, or 1.3 percent, at 2,181.3. Volume was 299.6 million shares. Traders said there was an immediate markup of prices on the news, boosting the main index over 10 points. The euphoria began subsiding quickly, however, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Week's Mail Brings 20,000 Job Seekers
DOC.TEXT: Miller Brewing Co. has received 22,000 applications for jobs at a brewery that won't open until next month and isn't expected to have more than 1,500 employees. Miller began advertising to fill the jobs a week ago. ``I think we've exceeded our expectations so far,' brewery spokeswoman Sandra Lewis said. ``We knew we'd get several thousand, based on what's happened in the past, but maybe not quite this many.'' Miller expects to start production at the $411 million brewery in July. The company has advertised in newspapers in Cincinnati, Dayton, Hamilton and Middletown for secretarial and clerical workers and for production workers. Applications came from Ohio, Kentucky and Indiana, Ms. Lewis said. She said Miller is not accepting applications by telephone or in person to avoid being mobbed by job seekers. Ms. Lewis said production would be phased in, starting with only the workers necessary to start up the plant. When the brewery reaches full capacity of 10 million barrels a year, it could employ up to 1,500 workers, the company has said. Miller has not said what the jobs will pay. There have been newspaper advertisements by union organizers who want to represent employees. The brewery was completed in 1981, but Milwaukee-based Miller never opened it, saying the production capacity was unnecessary because of declining sales. The company said last month that increased beer sales justify opening the brewery. Miller shipped almost 42 million barrels of beer last year, its largest year ever.

DOC.HEAD: Government To Allow Increased Foreign Ownership in Broadcasting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollars are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: The New Zealand government said Thursday it will allow foreign companies to increase their stake in radio and television companies. Communications Minister Maurice Williamson said legislation providing for up to 49.9 percent shareholding by foreign companies in New Zealand broadcasters will be introduced to Parliament before the end of the month. The current ratios are a maximum of 15 percent foreign ownership in television and up to 25 percent for radio. The main beneficiary of the move is expected to be the financially troubled private TV3 network, now operating in receivership. The network, launched just over a year ago as the first private competition to the two stations run by state-owned Television New Zealand, attracts an average 15 percent viewing audience. The National Broadcasting Co. of the United States owns 7.5 percent of TV3, after reducing its stake from 15 per cent. TV3 reported a $28 million million loss for the year ending March 31. Williamson told a news conference that TV3's current financial predicament had given urgency to the matter. Williamson said consideration had been given to a 20 percent ratio, as in Australia, or the United States figure of 25 percent, but neither would have been satisfactory. ``The existing overseas investment restrictions are now a serious impediment to the development of the broadcasting industry. Most large New Zealand companies and institutions have significant overseas shareholding and it is proving impossible for such companies to have a worthwhile shareholding in broadcasting enterprises,'' he said. ``The 49.9 percent figure will allow New Zealand broadcasters to seek equity partners overseas and, along with the equity, they will be able to seek expertise, which is probably just as important,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Rejects Lujan Request to Donate Yosemite Park Concession
DOC.TEXT: Entertainment giant MCA Inc. rejected a request by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. to donate its concession at Yosemite National Park to the government before its buyout by a Japanese firm is completed. Instead, the Yosemite Park & Curry Co. will be sold within a year to an American buyer as a result of Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.'s $6.6 billion buyout of MCA. ``We had hoped for better news,'' said National Park Service spokesman George Berklacy. MCA Chairman Lew R. Wasserman said the decision was in the best interests of shareholders as well as park visitors. MCA agreed to terms of the buyout by Matsushita last week. Lujan asked for the donation in a letter to Wasserman and Matsushita Executive Vice President Masahiko Hirata on Tuesday. But James Ridenour, director of the Park Service, said Wednesday that MCA and Matsushita attorneys told him that Curry Co. assets were ``made part of the deal with Matsushita'' and could not be given away. Because of concern toward a foreign firm owning a concession in a national park, MCA and Matsushita agreed last month to place the Curry Co. in escrow until a U.S. buyer could be found. In the meantime, Curry Co. profits will be donated to the National Park Foundation, a group that channels private money to the Park Service. ``We believe this is a generous gift which will further the work of the National Park Service,'' Wasserman said in a written reply to Lujan on Wednesday. The company owns about half the restaurants, stores and lodgings in Yosemite Valley. The National Park Service must approve any buyer of Curry Co. In his letter, Lujan asked the corporations to give the concession ``to the American people.'' ``Such a dramatic gesture would be recognized as a remarkably generous and public-spirited demonstration of the MCA-MEI commitment to the values of Yosemite National Park and what they stand for in the minds of the American people,'' he wrote. The Curry Co.'s contract with the Park Service expires in 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Stock Exchange To Open Early Next Year, Russian Minister Says
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow International Stock Exchange hopes to begin trading in a limited number of government bonds in January, Russian Finance Minister Boris Fyodorov said today. The government of Russia, the largest and richest of the 15 Soviet republics, was among 20 organizations and individuals which founded the exchange last month. ``We would like to take in the first place a very primitive step,'' Fyodorov said of the decision to start by trading bonds before gradually introducing securities. He spoke at a seminar on Russia's economic future. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued sweeping decrees in October permitting individual Soviets to buy stocks, bonds and other securities for the first time in 73 years. Trading in shares was outlawed following the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution and allowed only a brief revival during the 1920s before being abolished by Josef Stalin. The Russian-supported exchange is smaller and separate from the Moscow Stock Exchange founded in November by 187 companies. The Moscow Stock Exchange has not yet set an opening date, but has ambitious plans to open offices in the New York, Frankfurt, Tokyo and Singapore stock exchanges. Fyodorov said the Moscow International Stock Exchange has only 10 million rubles, or about $5.5 million, in capital, compared with 61.5 million rubles, or about $34.1 million, for the Moscow Stock Exchange. ``We hope that the first session will be in the beginning of January with the state bonds,'' he said. Bonds, usually issued by governments, are considered less risky than stocks because they pay the buyer a fixed annual interest rate and mature at a specified future date. Western advisers helping the Soviet government revive trading say bonds will also be easier for inexperienced investors to understand.

DOC.HEAD: NCR Says It Would Discuss Merger at $125 a Share
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `AT&T made ...,' to CLARIFY that NCR directors rejected bid before AT&T made tender offer; SUBS 15th graf pvs, `NCR's shares ...,' with 2 new grafs to UPDATE with today's trading.
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. is appealing directly to NCR Corp. shareholders to accept its $6 billion takeover bid for the nation's fifth-largest computer company. But NCR said Wednesday it would fight the $90-a-share cash tender offer unless the phone giant raised the price by $2.5 billion. AT&T made its direct offer to NCR shareholders after NCR's directors, who faced a 5 p.m. EST deadline to respond to the bid, rejected the offer as ``grossly inadequate.'' But almost simultaneously, NCR said it would enter into merger talks with AT&T if the phone company increased its offer to $125 a share, for a total of about $8.5 billion. AT&T disclosed that its chairman, Robert E. Allen, and NCR Chairman Charles E. Exley Jr. met Wednesday afternoon in New York at Exley's request. During the meeting, Exley presented the $125-a-share counterproposal. Allen, in a letter to Exley released by AT&T, rejected NCR's offer. ``We do not understand how you can maintain ... that a merger at $125 in AT&T stock would work, continue NCR's success and be a good deal for your shareholders, but a merger at $90 would be a strategic disaster,'' Allen wrote. `Chuck, all we have is a difference of opinion on price,'' he continued. ``We should let your shareholders decide. We believe that we are offering a full and fair price.'' AT&T, in a later statement, called the $125-a-share proposal ``outrageous and totally unjstified.'' The AT&T tender offer would provide NCR shareholders $90 in cash for each share, while AT&T's earlier offer to the company's board would have involved exchanging AT&T stock worth $90 for each NCR share. The tender offer is effective today and runs until midnight Jan. 4. As part of its offer to enter merger talks with AT&T at $125 a share, NCR also said the phone company must agree to enter into a confidentialty agreement and to refrain from further action on a takeover while the talks proceed. ``Please understand that if you cannot offer NCR shareholders this fair value, we will use every means at our disposal to protect our shareholders and other stakeholders against your attempt to deny them the inherent values of NCR,'' Exley said in a letter to Allen released by NCR. Last week, the board rejected an earlier AT&T offer of $85 a share. Daton, Ohio-based NCR said its board bolstered NCR's takeover defenses by lowering the threshold for a shareholders' rights plan to take effect. Under the change, the right of existing stockholders to buy special shares in NCR can be exercised after a company acquires 15 percent of NCR, down from 20 percent. The special shares are intended to make a takeover more difficult. Exley has said he is opposed to AT&T's bid on the grounds it would not make sense to combine NCR's well-regarded computer line with AT&T's disappointing computer business. He said he would quit NCR if AT&T's bid suceeded. This morning, NCR's shares began trading at $92.25, up $5.50, after a delayed opening due to an order imbalance on the New York Stock Exchange. On Wednesday, NCR shares rose $3.12{ to close at $86.62{ in heavy trading. News of AT&T's tender offer came after the close of the markets. AT&T shares rose 12{ cents in early trading to $30.25. On Wednesday, AT&T stock fell 25 cents as more than 5 million shares changed hands, topping the most-active list on the NYSE. Many industry analysts believed Exley's opposition to the takeover bid was just posturing, and that he was holding out in order to push up AT&T's offering price. Others believe Exley geniunely wants to fight to keep NCR independent. To battle AT&T's tender offer, Exley has several options, including seeking another merger partner, taking NCR private by buying its shares with borrowed money, or arranging a large payout to stockholders, again through borrowed cash. But analysts said the last two options seem unlikely in the current climate on Wall Street, where bank credit and bond financing for such deals have all but dried up. That leaves finding another merger partner the most likely course should NCR try to block AT&T's bid, experts say. Such a partner may offer more favorable terms than AT&T.

Hopes for an orderly resolution of the impasse in the Middle East helped propel stock prices sharply higher today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 32.67 points to 2,643.07 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 906 up, 184 down and 348 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 53.93 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The market's yearend rally picked up fresh momentum Wednesday after word came from the State Department that Iraq had agreed to hold talks with President Bush on the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Today, traders arriving at work were greeted by news that Saddam Hussein, Iraq's president, had urged his parliament to permit all foreign hostages stranded by the invasion of Kuwait last summer to leave. Those developments sent oil prices sharply lower, and interest rates fell in the credit markets. Brokers said stocks benefited in particular from hopes that efforts to pull the U.S. economy out of recession could proceed without the disrupting influence of the threat of war with Iraq. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up 1 at 50}; General Electric, up 1\ at 58\; International Business Machines, up 1] at 116, and General Motors, up } at 37~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.88 to 181.99. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 2.27 at 307.68. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 30.70 to 2,610.40, bringing its gain over the past four sessions to 91.59 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 1,064 up, 488 down and 449 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 205.82 million shares, up from 185.82 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Weak Economy, S&L Costs Will Keep Deficit High, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 3 grafs new with release of study; picks up 3rd graf pvs, The calculations ... Also moving on generral news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The weak economy and the mammoth costs of helping the savings and loan industry will soon push the federal deficit to records surpassing $300 billion per year, a congressional study said today. But by 1993, the newly enacted deficit-reduction law and an improving economy should begin shrinking the federal shortfall, the Congressional Budget Office said in a report presented to the House Budget Committee. ``The economy appears to be near a turning point - a time when predicting its course is particularly difficult,'' said Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office. The calculations are the first showing how the five-year, $496 billion deficit-cutting law will affect the federal budget over the next several years. The Bush administration is not expected to release its own figures until February. The report, obtained by The Associated Press in advance of the hearing, said that in fiscal 1992, for which the administration is planning its budget, the shortfall will be at least $337 billion, easily the highest ever. Fiscal 1992 begins next Oct. 1. But by the following year, the CBO expects the red ink to shrink to $252 billion and reach $143 billion by 1995, the last year for which the study contains projections. The report cautioned, however, that economic conditions have worsened since October, when the CBO made its calculations. Oil prices have remained high, the real estate market has been weak and many banks and corporations have had financial problems, it noted. ``Unless these factors are offset by other developments, a more pessimistic economic outlook will worsen the budget projections,'' the authors wrote. The budget office said it expects the government to spend $91 billion in fiscal 1991 - which runs through next Sept. 30 - bailing out the nation's savings and loan institutions. That figure will peak at $107 billion in 1992. But then, as the government begins selling S&L assets it has taken over, it will recoup some of its losses, actually earning $44 billion in 1994, the report said. The economy will also take its toll on the budget. As a rule of thumb, a weak economy means lower federal revenues and higher spending, and thus a bigger budget gap. Many of the CBO's expectations for economic performance have deteriorated since it released its last projections last summer. The budget office now expects the economy to grow at a weak 0.6 percent in 1991, down from its 2.5 percent estimate in July. The Bush administration is calling for economic growth at around 0.8 percent. The report also projected that inflation will increase by 5.3 percent in 1991, 1.1 percent higher than the CBO called for in July. And it forecast unemployment to be 6.4 percent in 1991, up from the 5.4 percent projected earlier. This year's budget gap should be $320 billion, the CBO said. The deficit for fiscal 1990 was $220 billion, just below the record $221 billion shortfall in 1986. But those figures cannot be directly compared with the $320 billion projection for next year because they include the huge and growing Social Security surplus, expected to reach $66 billion this year. Under new budget rules, that surplus is no longer included in federal deficit calculations. The fiscal 1990 budget gap would have been $277 billion had the Social Security surplus not been included in the deficit figures. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law sets new deficit ceilings for each of the next few years. If those targets are surpassed, automatic spending cuts can be triggered. But under the new procedures, the administration adjusts those targets to reflect changing economic conditions, so there is little threat they will cause the automatic spending slashes to occur. The CBO's numbers are advisory and are not officially used to measure the deficit. That task falls to the White House's Office of Management and Budget. Nonetheless, the CBO figures are widely respected on Capitol Hill.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Hits Lowest Prices Since Month of Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with New York prices, EDITING to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices tumbled even lower today to levels not seen since August after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said all of his foreign hostages should be released. Light sweet crude oil was down $1.79 per barrel to $25.50 at the New York Mercantile Exchange this morning on contracts for delivery in January. Crude for next-month delivery last settled below $26 per barrel on Aug. 29, when it was at $25.92, the exchange said. Unleaded gasoline for next-month delivery was down 3.34 cents at 65.50 cents a gallon by late this morning. It fell at one point to within less than a penny of the price it commanded on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait. Home heating oil was trading at 77.70 cents a gallon, down 3.44 cents, on contracts for delivery in January. The rapid plunge today followed crude's drop of $3.37 per barrel on Wednesday, which came amid speculation of peace in the Persian Gulf. ``Word came out that Hussein is releasing the hostages and it fell $1.50, just like that,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``We're seeing an erosion of the war premium.'' During the wild downturn that began on Wednesday, all of the petroleum futures hit levels they had not seen since the month of the invasion. ``It almost feels like we're reversing course,'' Hittle said. ``We're back in a period of uncertainty again.'' Oil for next-month delivery had not closed below $28 per barrel since Aug. 31, when it closed at $27.32, the exchange said. Wednesday's close for gasoline was the lowest since Aug. 2 and the close for heating oil was the lowest since Aug. 31. Prices also skidded today in frantic activity in London on the news of Saddam's statement on the hostages. January contracts for North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, fell to $25.60 a barrel from $27.35 late Wednesday. In the four months since Iraq seized Kuwait, speculation about a war-induced oil crisis has pushed prices as high as the $41 a barrel level. Many oil strategists have said the market will continue to act unpredictably until the crisis shows decisive signs of ending. The market swung wildly on headlines Wednesday. A brief rally led by saber-rattling from Secretary of State James A. Baker III failed to sustain any buying momentum. Prospects of peace soon took control and pushed prices down. The final shove came in the afternoon, when the U.S. government announced Iraq had agreed to top-level diplomatic meetings to discuss the desert standoff. ``Although the rhetoric from Bush and Baker is still pretty tough, at least now there's going to be some kind of discussion between the two parties and the ground rules are becoming clearer,'' said Christian Gohler, a broker at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 376.59 up 5.72 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Market Takes Steps To Ensure Smooth Trading Through Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Trading in crude oil futures would be temporarily suspended in response to large price swings, under a plan approved today by the New York Mercantile Exchange. ``For the first time, the exchange will be imposing trade cessations as circuit-breakers,'' President R. Patrick Thompson said. The proposed changes would allow crude oil futures to rise or fall by up to $15 per barrel each day, far more than they have ever moved. Exchange officials said they are not trying to predict movements that big, but rather setting up rules that will keep trading orderly through a crisis. The exchange also offers futures contracts for two refined petroleum products, unleaded gasoline and home heating oil, that will be affected. The possibility that war or peace in the Persian Gulf could lead to huge movements in oil prices has prompted some calls for tighter controls on the exchange. But exchange officials said in a news conference this morning that the proposed rules changes, which they expect to be approved by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission next week, were ``self-imposed.'' The exchange has nonetheless discussed the rule changes with the CFTC ahead of time. ``We were not goaded into this by any federal agency,'' Chairman Z. Lou Guttman said. ``We felt that this was a very responsible and necessary precautionary measure.'' Under the new rules, if oil prices swing $7.50 in either direction during a single trading session and stay at that level for five minutes, oil brokers will be told that trading will be halted in two minutes. After the market is stopped for an hour, trading will resume, with the swing in prices limited to $15 for the spot month and the month after that. If futures for unleaded gasoline and home heating oil move 20 cents a gallon, their trading would be stopped and then resumed with a 40-cent-a-gallon limit on moves for the rest of the session. Prices have never swung as wildly as the new limits would allow them to swing, and exchange officials emphasized they are not trying to predict the size of the swings that would be possible during a sudden oil emergency. The exchange came up with the price limits by figuring out what kind of swings the market could withstand while keeping trading orderly and fair, the officials said. Exchange officials said the hour's break in trading would give futures players time to take a closer look at world events that are pushing the price of crude.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: REPEAT FOR ALL NEEDING
DOC.TEXT: The stock market advanced broadly today, inspired by hopes for an orderly resolution of the impasse in the Midle East. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 30.70 points Wednesday, climbed 19.06 to 2,629.46 by 11 a.m. today. Gainers outnumbered losers by nearly 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 1,065 up, 288 down and 413 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 115.96 million shares at midmorning. The market's yearend rally picked up fresh momentum Wednesday after word came from the State Department that Iraq had agreed to hold talks with President Bush on the crisis in the Persian Gulf.
