Today, traders arriving at work were greeted by news that Saddam Hussein, Iraq's president, had urged his parliament to permit all foreign hostages stranded by the invasion of Kuwait last summer to leave. Those developments sent oil prices sharply lower, and interest rates fell in the credit markets. Brokers said stocks benefited in particular from hopes that efforts to pull the U.S. economy out of recession could proceed without the disrupting influence of the threat of war with Iraq. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up 1 at 50}; General Electric, up 1 at 58; International Business Machines, up ~ at 115{, and General Motors, up | at 37}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.42 to 181.53. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.82 at 307.23.

DOC.HEAD: House Report Blames Red Tape for Delaying Disposal of S&L Assets
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 8 grafs new with Bowsher testimony; Picks up 8th graf pvs, RTC spokesman ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Government regulators do not have an effective system to manage the consultants hired to sell real estate inherited from failed savings and loans, the head of the General Accounting Office said today. ``One of our key concerns is that the RTC (Resolution Trust Corp.) does not have an effective contractor oversight program,'' Charles A. Bowsher, head of the congressional investigative agency, told the House Banking Committee. ``Because of the large dollar value of assets to be placed under contractor control, we believe it is essential that an effective system be put in place as quickly as possible to assure proper contract management and oversight, and minimize RTC's vulnerability to fraud, waste and mismangement,'' he said. Bowsher's testimony came a day after the Democratic staff of the committee issued a report charging that RTC red tape is tangling the sale of S&L assets and costing taxpayers millions of dollars. ``Investors and would-be homeowners have encountered innumerable stumbling blocks in their attempts to negotiate purchases of RTC-held assets,'' said the report, released Wednesday. An RTC spokesman called the findings ``nonsense.'' The report conceded that the 16-month-old RTC ``has been assigned a difficult task in cleaning up the largest financial crisis in the nation's history.'' But it said the agency must develop a better sales effort if it is to succeed. ``Uncooperative property managers, difficulties in obtaining current and accurate appraisals, delays in contract negotiations, deteriorating condition of assets and a simple inability between RTC and many potential buyers to effectively communicate have delayed or prevented the closing of countless transactions, costing the federal government millions of dollars in carrying costs while billions of dollars worth of unsold properties continue to deteriorate,'' the report said. ``Congressional offices have been inundated with letters from frustrated investors, brokers and homebuyers who have found that purchasing property from the RTC is not a simple case of arriving at mutually acceptable terms of sale, but rather involves hours of sifting through paperwork and bureaucratic red tape, often leading to frustration and disappointment,'' it said. RTC spokesman Stephen Katsanos called the report ``nonsense.'' From the RTC's creation in August 1989 through Sept. 30, it has taken over 493 S&Ls with $251 billion in assets, he said. At the end of the period, it was left with 207 institutions and $142 billion in assets. ``We've moved assets roughly the size of Citicorp back into the private sector,'' Katsanos said. ``I think it's been a pretty productive year.'' He said some buyers may be frustrated because they want to privately negotiate a purchase at a bargain-basement price rather than compete against other bidders. ``That's not what Congress asked for in the legislation,'' the spokesman said. ``There are a lot of complainers out there, but there also are a lot of happy people who have bought stuff.'' However, Richard Buerkle, an Arlington, Texas, real estate executive, told the committee that lower-level RTC staff actually doing the agency's work complain they do not have enough authority to make decisions on properties, that too much paperwork is required and that top officials have little knowledge about how to sell real estate. Attempts by top policymakers to improve the sales effort are ``bureaucratic, more control, more documentation,'' he said. Bertram Lewis, a real estate executive who teaches at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, said RTC account officers who deal with sour loans and real estate on a day-to-day basis are either ex-regulators or former low-level bankers who ``seem to lack the experience, confidence, incentive, authority and temperament to make a deal.'' The agency has hired outside consultants who are dealmakers, Lewis said. ``Unfortunately, they cannot make decisions - only recommendations, which are then subjected to the red tape and time-consuming review of the bureaucracy.''

DOC.HEAD: Grand Met Posts 25 Percent Profit Gain, Thanks to Pillsbury, Burger King
DOC.TEXT: Grand Metropolitan PLC, the British food and liquor company, said Thursday its annual net profit jumped 25 percent, helped by the inclusion of Pillsbury Co. and Burger King's full-year results for the first time. Grand Met said net profit for the year ended Sept. 30 came to 634 million pounds, or $1.07 billion, compared with 508 million pounds, or $859 million, in the same period a year ago. Pretax profit rose 26 percent to 919 million pounds, or $1.55 billion, from 732 million pounds, or $1.24 billion. Revenue rose only 1 percent, however, to 9.394 billion pounds, or $15.9 billion, from 9.298 billion, or $15.7 billion. Grand Met blamed the small revenue gain on asset disposals, notably its retail betting and Berni restaurant operations. Revenue from its continuing businesses was up 19 percent, it said. The company did not report results for the latest quarter or second half of the year. It isn't required to under British law. Grand Met said part of the earnings gain for 1990 reflected the inclusion of full-year results from Pillsbury and Burger King, an increase from nine months of results included in 1989. Grand Met acquired Pillsbury, which owned Burger King, for $5.7 billion in early 1989. Profit before tax and other considerations for Grand Met's food operations rose 26 percent to 309 million pounds, or $522 million, in 1990. Pillsbury alone increased its contribution to 183 million pounds, or $309 million, from 117 million pounds, or $198 million. Trading profit from Grand Met's liquor division rose 22 percent to 473 million pounds, or $799 million, while the retailing division posted the fastest growth. The 29 percent rise to 278 million pounds, or $470 million, included a 64 percent jump in profit by Burger King to 125 million pounds, or $211 million, due partly to lower overhead costs and improved operating efficiency. All figures were converted at a company-provided exchange rate of $1.69 to the pound. ``The group has had another successful year; all sectors have overcome adverse economic conditions to report good growth,'' said Grand Met Chairman Sir Allen Sheppard. He noted that Pillsbury, including Burger King, had positive earnings in its first full year in the group, and said it continues to perform excellently. Sheppard said the company expects further earnings improvements in 1991, although he said it will be ``potentially a difficult year, with the translation impact of a weak dollar on our considerable U.S. earnings, fewer property disposals and an increased tax charge.''

DOC.HEAD: Hostage News Excites Markets But Action Slows by Midday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 new grafs to UPDATE with market easing further, adds details from Bush news conference, picks up 7th graf pvs ``Saddam's initiative ...''
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's call for the release of foreign hostages touched off an early rally in stocks and a decline in oil prices today, but the moves fizzled quickly as traders awaited more news on the Persian Gulf. President Bush told a news conference during a visit to Santiago, Chile, that he viewed the hostage report as a hopeful sign. But he said the United States had ``to keep the pressure on'' Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait as well as release the hostages. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks leaped more than 30 points in the first 15 minutes of trading, then fell back to the 2,613 level by noon EST, up about 3 points from Wednesday. Volume exceeded 163.3 million shares by midmorning in heavy trading. Oil prices plunged by more than $2 per barrel in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but edged back by noon to $26.30 per barrel for January delivery, down 99 cents from Wednesday's close. Gold, which had been a safe haven for some nervous investors, also fell by more than $4 per ounce to around $370, and the dollar was lower in foreign exchange dealings. Bond prices rose strongly with the Treasury's 30-year bond moving up about $3.75 per $1,000 face amount in the early going. But by noon, the advance was cut to less than $1.25 per $1,000. The yield on the bond, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 8.30 percent from 8.31 percent late Wednesday. Saddam's initiative heightened the markets' expectations for peace in the Persian Gulf, which has been in turmoil since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The market movesbegan earlier this week after Bush set a process in motion for talks with Iraqi leaders. Saddam called today for the release of all hostages, saying recent diplomatic moves had prompted him to ``respond to positive changes,'' according to the Iraqi News Agency. Saddam also said the hostages' presence was no longer needed to deter an attack because his forces were now fully deployed in Kuwait. There are thousands of Western hostages in Iraq and Kuwait, including about 900 Americans. Speculation about peace had sent oil futures to their lowest levels since August on Wednesday with crude for January delivery falling $3.37 per barrel to settle at $27.29 on the Mercantile Exchange. The Dow Jones average climbed 30.70 points on Wednesday to the highest point in 12 weeks.

The stock market gained ground in heavy trading today, inspired by hopes for an orderly resolution of the impasse in the Middle East. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 30.70 points Wednesday, climbed 10.89 to 2,621.29 by noontime on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 1,025 up, 415 down and 425 unchanged. The market's yearend rally picked up fresh momentum Wednesday after word came from the State Department that Iraq had agreed to hold talks with President Bush on the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Today, traders arriving at work were greeted by news that Saddam Hussein, Iraq's president, had urged his parliament to permit all foreign hostages stranded by the invasion of Kuwait last summer to leave. Those developments sent oil prices sharply lower, and interest rates fell in the credit markets. Brokers said stocks benefited in particular from hopes that efforts to pull the U.S. economy out of recession could proceed without the disrupting influence of the threat of war with Iraq. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up ~ at 50|; General Electric, up } at 57}; American Express, up \ at 23, and General Motors, up ] at 37{. NCR, which is opposing a $90-a-share takeover bid by American Telephone & Telegraph, rose 5 to 91|. AT&T shares slipped [ to 30. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .76 to 180.80. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.82 at 307.23. Volume on the Big Board reached 163.32 million shares by noontime, up from 93.77 million at the same point Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Cargolux Orders Three Boeing 747-400s
DOC.TEXT: Cargolux Airlines International of Luxembourg has ordered three Boeing 747-400 freighters and taken options on three others, an order worth a potential $1 billion, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Thursday. A statement issued by Boeing said engine selection would be announced later. Cargolux currently flies Boeing 747-200s on cargo routes linking Luxembourg with North America and the Middle and Far East. The 747-400 has a payload of 298,000 pounds, 44,100 pounds more than the 747-200F. The three firm orders are worth about $500 million, bringing Boeing's total for the year to $47.3 billion for 499 planes, compared with $46.6 billion for 883 planes in all of 1989, said Tom Cole of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group. Total orders for the 747-400, Boeing's biggest and most profitable plane, stand at 397, including 16 freighters.

DOC.HEAD: Hanson's After-Tax Profit Gains 19.4 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Hanson PLC, the British industrial conglomerate with extensive interests in the United States, said Thursday its annual after-tax profit rose 19.4 percent, thanks to healthy results from most of its operating units. After-tax profit for the year ended Sept. 30 reached 971 million pounds, or $1.64 billion, compared with 813 million pounds, or $1.37 billion, a year ago. Net profit fell to 501 million pounds, or $847 million, from 764 million pounds, or $1.29 billion. The company had an extraordinary credit of 288 million pounds, or $487 million, in 1989 for disposals of Consolidated Gold Fields properties. Hanson acquired Gold Fields for $5.9 billion in 1989, and the disposals have since generated some $1.91 billion. Hanson's pre-tax profit rose 21 percent to 1.28 billion pounds, or $2.16 billion, from 1.06 billion pounds, or $1.79 billion. Sales rose 2.3 percent to 7.15 billion pounds, or $12.1 billion, from 6.99 billion pounds, or $11.8 billion. The figures were converted at a rate of $1.69 to the pound, the average exchange rate in the year ended Sept. 30. The company did not report results for the latest quarter or second half of the year. It is not required to do so under British law. Company Chairman Lord Hanson forecast the good results will continue despite the worldwide economic downturn because ``our strategy to face these circumstances has been prepared for some time.'' He also said the company continues to be expansion-minded. ``Our large cash balances and borrowing capability mean that we have the resources,'' he said. ``Combining these with our expertise and knowledge of the market, we shall undoubtedly find an increasing number of acquisition opportunities.'' The company's U.S. unit, Hanson Industries, said trading profit rose 18 percent to 416 million pounds, or $703 million, on sales of 3 billion pounds, or $5.1 billion. ``Even in the difficult economic climate, some 20 individual (Hanson) companies reported record profits,'' said the unit's chairman, Sir Gordon White. The company's U.S. interests include SCM Chemicals, Jacuzzi whirlpool baths, Kaiser cement, Ames garden tools and Peabody Coal, which Hanson acquired control of in the spring.

DOC.HEAD: Pet to Close Frankfort Plant
DOC.TEXT: Pet Inc. said Thursday it will close its frozen pie factory in Michigan Feb. 3, the first of several plant closings the company expects to announce in coming weeks. The Frankfort plant's 115 employees will be offered a severance package, said plant manager Don Olney. Production of Pet-Ritz pies, cobblers and other goods will be moved to other factories. Pet's parent, Whitman Co., announced in September that it was spinning off Pet as a subsidiary and would consolidate Pet operations. Pet posted third-quarter income of $45 million, down from $63 million in the third quarter of 1989. Pet spokesman Les Landes said the food company, which has about 25 plants nationwide, has too much production capacity. More closings or consolidations will be announced in the next several weeks, Landes said. Olney said employees were shocked when he told them Wednesday afternoon that their jobs were being eliminated. ``It was a sad day yesterday,'' Olney said. ``Most of them are in shock. It's very hard for them to believe. This was their livelihood.''

DOC.HEAD: Deadline Extended on Free Trade Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with talks to continue; picks up 12th, At stake. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: An ambitious program of world trade talks was rescued from the brink of collapse today after the European Community showed a willingness to discuss greater cuts in farm subsidies. Officials attending the Uruguay Round of negotiations decided to continue their talks rather than suspending them immediately because of a bitter dispute between the Community and the United States over the subsidies. ``The meeting decided we should go to work ... that we should continue the negotiations,'' Frans Andriessen, the community's top trade official, said after an hour-long session of negotiators. He said the 12-nation trading bloc ``made some movement'' and it was sufficient for the bargaining to continue. The talks appeared near collapse earlier in the day because of the deadlock between the United States and European nations over farm issues. ``I definitely think a cooling-off period might help the (European Community) achieve a mandate,'' U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said after a round of morning sessions. There was a stalemate in agricultural issues, she said, ``and it would be very constructive if we had a quiet period.'' But the Europeans promised to show new flexibility and rejected the drift toward suspending the current Uruguay Round of world trade talks. While details on the Europeans' new offer were sketchy, it appeared they were offering to discuss a U.S. demand for across-the-board reductions in subsidies. ``The impasse was broken,'' said David Woods, spokesman for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the organization conducting the negotiations. Canadian Trade Minister John Crosbie, who earlier in the day had said chances for successfully concluding the talks appeared all but doomed, said: ``It's not a breakthrough. It's a reprieve.'' Canada is a member of the Cairns Group of 14 major exporting countries who along with the United States have been pushing the Europeans to agree to major cuts in subsidies. Australian Trade Minister Neal Blewett said the European proposal offered a ``glimmer of hope. Things are no longer terminal.'' The announcement that after four days of stalemate the talks had gained new life came suddenly following a closed-door session of the trade negotiators held to determine whether there was any use of proceeding further. The Europeans have offered to cut 30 percent from subsidies on major crops over 10 years, starting retroactively in 1986, in order to reduce their farmers' advantage over foreign producers and make imports more competitive. The United States' demand is for subsidy cuts of 75 percent to 90 percent over the next decade. At stake in the talks, convened by the 107-nation conference of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, are more access to world markets for poor and newly democratizing countries, protection against copyright theft, and extension of fair-trade rulesto agriculture, banking and textiles. By Washington's calculation, agreement could lead to a doubling of world trade by the end of the decade. Trade now amounts to $3.8 trillion annually. But in the corridors of the Heysel Palaces, where the talks are being held, delegates argued fiercely late Wednesday over who was responsible for the slide toward a collapse or suspension of GATT. More than 1,500 delegates, many of them Cabinet members including four from Washington, attended the conference that started Monday and was to end Friday. The talks are named the Uruguay Round after the country where they started in 1986 with the goal of liberalizing trade in 15 areas. Backed by agriculture-dependent countries in the Third World, the United States, Canada, Argentina, Brazil, Australia and others want the EC to make deep cuts in subsidies that have made the EC's 10 million farmers into potent exporters. The subsidies distort world farm trade, reformers argue. GATT was established in 1947 as a forum for promoting free trade. The current round of talks, the eighth since World War II, aims to extend free trade rules to areas not under current GATT rules, such as farm products, textiles and services such as financial services and construction.

DOC.HEAD: New Moscow Stock Exchange Hopes to Open Doors in January
DOC.TEXT: A new Soviet stock exchange founded with the help of the Russian republic hopes to start trading bonds in January, Russian Finance Minister Boris Fyodorov said Thursday. The Moscow International Stock Exchange is separate from a larger stock exchange founded in November. The two, possibly competing exchanges are the first to operate in the Soviet Union since dictator Josef Stalin banned them in the 1920s. The reform-minded Russian government was joined by 19 other organizations and individuals to found the newest exchange last month, Fyodorov told a seminar on economic reforms in Russia, the largest and richest Soviet republic. The exchange will start with bonds and later will begin trading shares, Fyodorov said. ``We would like to take in the first place a very primitive step,'' Fyodorov said. ``We hope that the first session will be in the beginning of January with the state bonds.'' Many Western experts advising the Soviet Union on how to revive and operate stock exchanges have recommended they start with bonds, rather than equities, to give the national and republic governments time to privatize factories and other means of production. Bonds, issued by governments and corporations, are considered less risky than stocks because they pay the buyer a fixed interest rate and can be redeemed at a specified future date. David Darbyshire, a partner in Arthur Andersen, the international services company that sponsored the seminar, said bonds are also easy to understand. He said the fledgling Soviet markets need some early successes to encourage confidence and investor interest. ``In the early stages of the exchange it will be critical that only those companies which have a fair chance of success should be allowed onto the marketplace,'' he said. Among those most frequently mentioned are the state airline Aeroflot, the Intourist travel agency and the oil and gas industries. Trading in stocks and bonds was outlawed following the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, forcing the closure of an active, 200-year-old exchange in St. Petersburg. A Moscow stock exchange and commodity exchanges were allowed a brief revival during the 1920s before being abolished. In October, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued sweeping decrees restoring Soviets' rights to buy stocks, bonds and other securities. The Moscow Stock Exchange was founded in November by 187 independent companies and without any government body. That exchange said it would hold a trial bidding session in the spring. It has has 61.5 million rubles, or $34.1 million, in capital. By comparison, Fyodorov said the Moscow International Stock Exchange has 10 million rubles, or about $5.5 million, in capital. Russia's role in forming the Moscow International Stock Exchange appeared to reflect the divergent economic agendas of the independent-minded republics. Latvia on Thursday passed its own law legalizing ``shareholder societies,'' something other republics also have done. Latvian lawmakers warned investors to adhere to Latvian, rather than Soviet, law, according to the independent news agency Interfax. Meanwhile, the new Moscow Commodity Exchange said this week it has hired an American grain expert to develop its grain and agricultural commodities section. It said Myron Laserson, former president of the North American Export Grain Association, will head a Soviet-American team to develop and implement an efficient trading mechanism. A Russian Commodity Exchange begn trading in Moscow this week and plans are in the works for both stock and commodity exchanges in Leningrad.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Fight to Save 1872 Law and Public Land Claims at $2.50 per Acre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, Sen. Dale, to CORRECT spelling to Bumpers. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Miners are fighting congressional efforts to reform an 1872 law allowing them to claim public land for $2.50 an acre. Opponents say it's a relic of the Old West that makes modern land-grabbing easy. Supporters argue that changing the law could put thousands of miners out of work and cripple one of the nation's basic industries. ``The mining industry is in trouble. It's in deep trouble in the Congress of the United States,'' said Bill Grannell, executive director of the Western States Public Lands Coalition in Pueblo, Colo. The coalition of miners, logging interests and ranchers who use federal land, mostly in the West, has launched a petition drive to preserve the Mining Law of 1872. The law allows hardrock miners to stake claims on public land, pay no royalties on extracted minerals and obtain title to claims for as little as $2.50 an acre. Hardrock minerals include gold, silver, uranium, copper, lead and zinc. The U.S. Bureau of Mines says there are about 130,000 active hardrock miners nationwide. The law was designed to promote mineral exploration and development on federal land, which covers 724 million acres, mostly in 11 Western states and Alaska. It applies to everyone from lone prospectors to major mining companies. Reform proponents say they will introduce legislation in Congress to make miners pay royalties similar to those paid by companies that lease land from the government to extract oil, coal and natural gas. Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., will submit a bill like one he pushed last session, and Rep. Nick Rahall, D-W.Va., will bring a similar bill to the House, aides said. The bills would end the so-called patent provision that allows miners to work the land and eventually obtain title to it at 1872 prices - $2.50 to $5.00 an acre. Under the current law, prospectors need to have spent $500 on a claim to qualify for a land patent. Critics of patenting cite a 1989 General Accounting Office report that cited abuses and huge private and corporate profits. In one example, holders of the title to 17,000 acres near Grand Junction, Colo., several years ago paid the government $42,500 for the land, then turned around weeks later and sold it to major oil companies for $37 million. The GAO said one 40-acre site near Mesa, Ariz., patented in 1983 for $100, is now valued at $400,000. The Bumpers bill also would charge miners royalty fees and require them to post large bonds to guarantee their ability to repair any environmental damage. Miners say boosting their costs that much would force many out of business. In 118 years, more than 6 million mining claims have been filed with the government, and 1.2 million are still active. Nevada has the most, 370,000. Arizona has 143,000, Utah 113,000, Colorado 80,255 and Alaska 32,000. Miners have obtained title to 84,000 acres in Colorado, mostly in oil shale deposits. They gained title to 11,158 acres in Nevada, 14,475 in Montana, 16,796 in Wyoming and 8,406 in Alaska. ``Mining is destroying a lot of public land in this country,'' said Laura Lapins of the Mineral Policy Center in Washington, which is pushing for reforms. The law enacted during the presidency of Ulysses S. Grant doesn't fit in a modern world where the wilderness is disappearing and environmental damage is mounting, said Dave Alberswerth of the National Wildlife Federation. ``That law is simply an anachronism in this day and age,'' he said. ``It is the last remaining land disposal act on the books.''

DOC.HEAD: Truck Maker Reports $7 Million Loss for Quarter; $11 Million Loss For Year
DOC.TEXT: Navistar International Corp. said Thursday it lost $7 million in the fourth quarter and reported a loss for the year, due to reduced demand for medium and heavy trucks. The Chicago-based truck maker said it lost 6 cents a share in the quarter ended Oct. 31, compared to a loss of $13 million, or 8 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1989. Revenues fell 4 percent, to $971 million vs. $1.01 billion. For the year, Navistar lost $11 million, or 16 cents a share, compared with net income of $87 million, or 23 cents per share, for fiscal 1989. Revenues were $3.85 billion, down 9 percent from $4.24 billion the previous year. James C. Cotting, Navistar's chairman and chief executive officer, said the principal factor behind both the lower demand for trucks and the company's losses was a slower U.S. economy. During the fiscal year, medium and heavy truck sales in North America totaled 281,800 units, down 15 percent from 331,500 units in 1989. Navistar said shipments of mid-range diesel engines to original equipment manufacturers totalled 100,700 engines for the year, down 6 percent from the 106,700 engines shipped in 1989. Despite the decline in sales, Cotting said Navistar was able to increase its industry-leading share of the medium- and heavy-truck market from 27.4 percent to 27.9 percent. He said the company's projections for 1991 anticipate continued weakness in demand for medium and heavy trucks. He said the company has adjusted its production schedules to the lower demand outlook, and will move to reduce costs to lower the company's break-even point.

DOC.HEAD: Expectations of Soviet Business Boosts Market
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed higher in light trading Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade on expectations credits soon will be extended to the Soviet Union to buy U.S. grains. Hearings Wednesday by a U.S. House Agriculture subcommittee indicated the Soviets could be offered credits of about $1.25 billion. William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago, said those reports, as well as rumors of increased bookings of ocean vessels for exports, helped fuel the gains in the market. Biedermann said the strong ocean vessel market was an indication the Soviets may be pricing grains for purchase. Also boosting the market was the improved tone in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks taking place in Brussels. The European Community showed a willingness to discuss greater cuts in farm subsidies, and officials attending the negotiations decided to continue their talks rather than suspend them. At stake in the talks are more access to world markets for poor and newly democratizing countries, protection against copyright theft, and extension of fair-trade rules to agriculture, banking and textiles. At the close, wheat was 1\ cents to 3 cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.46{ a bushel; corn was a \ cent to } cent higher with December at $2.26 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2 cents higher with December at $1.11} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in January at $5.97$ a bushel.

But after an initial burst of enthusiasm, investors seemed to sit back to await more concrete evidence that more peaceful times lay ahead. NCR, which is opposing a $90-a-share takeover bid by American Telephone & Telegraph, rose 5| to 92\. AT&T shares slipped [ to 30. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost .66 to 179.45. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .92 at 306.33. Volume on the Big Board reached 227.76 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Growth Slowing Overseas, Conference Board Says
DOC.TEXT: The world's leading industrial nations - with the exception of Germany - are expected to suffer economic declines in 1991 as credit tightens around the globe and trade subsides, the Conference Board said Thursday. The latest data show the leading economic indicators are flat or declining in nine of the world's top 11 industrial nations, the board said. While Germany is ``the only country that seems immune from the current rash of pessimism,'' Conference Board Chief Economist Gail Fosler noted that the unification euphoria ``will wear off once tax increases are announced to fund the rapidly escalating cost of east German econonic development.'' Fosler predicted growth in Japan will be about 3.5 percent next year, well off from initial estimates of 5 percent. In France, growth is ``expected to be as little as 2-2.5 percent,'' she said in a release. Canada and Australia are expected to register economic declines in the latter half of this year, while the verdict on Britain ``is still out'' after a third-quarter decline. Among the factors influencing the decline overseas are slowing investment growth and consumer spending in Europe; high interest rates and a falling stock market in Japan; banking, finance and real estate problems in many major countries; and a downturn in world trade. ``Interest rates must come down substantially outside the U.S. in order to preserve growth'' in world trade, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell on world currency markets Thursday as the prospects for war dimmed following Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's offer to release Western hostages. Gold prices also fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $371.70 a troy ounce, off $2.50 from Wednesday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold at $371, off $1.75. The market interpreted Hussein's offer ``as a sign war tensions were easing, and the dollar fell sharply,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the firm IDEA. The dollar typically is viewed as a safe-haven currency during times of world turmoil. But as the session wore on, Chandler said it became more clear to traders that Hussein was actually prepared for war and made the offer because his troops are now fully deployed in Kuwait. That assessment helped the dollar firm a bit around midday, but it then languished for the remainder of the session. ``The market was supporting the dollar on a war premium and took it down on a peace premium,'' said Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago. Also pressuring the dollar was anticipation over the release Friday of November unemployment data. Analysts expect the Labor Department report will show an increase in initial jobless claims and a higher overall unemployment rate for the month. ``That will further confirm the slowdown of the U.S. economy and add pressure on the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates,'' Chandler said. Lower interest rates erode the value of dollar-denominated securities and therefore decrease investors' need for the U.S. currency. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 134.05 Japanese yen from 133.42 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, it fell to 132.35 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 132.14 yen, down from 133.63 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9390 from $1.9225 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9400 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.9260. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.4885 German marks, down from 1.4993; 1.2710 Swiss francs, down from 1.2795; 5.0510 French francs, down from 5.0770; 1,122.25 Italian lire, down from 1,127.68, and 1.1621 Canadian dollars, down form 1.1630. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.4890 German marks, down from 1.5025; 1.2725 Swiss francs, down from 1.2835; 5.0540 French francs, down from 5.0898; 1.6805 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6955; 1,122.25 Italian lire, down from 1,130.75, and 1.1621 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1623. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $370.25 a troy ounce, from $372.65 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $369.50, from $374.50. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.80 to close at a bid $374.24. Silver prices also declined. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.121 a troy ounce, down from $4.148 on Wednesday. In London the metal was unchanged at a late bid price of $4.16 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Rose $1.02 Billion in Latest Week to New Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 533 money market mutual funds rose by $1.02 billion in the latest week to an all-time high of $424.89 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday came despite an easing of interest rates that generally tend to make money-market fund investments less attractive relative to stocks and bonds. The fund-asset total broke the record set the previous week, when the figure reached $423.87 billion. That total originally was reported as $423.76 billion but the institute subsequently revised it upward. ``Despite further moderate easing of yields offered by money market funds, their assets continued to climb,'' said Jacob Dreyer, vice president and chief economist of the institute, a Washington-based mutual fund trade group. ``So far, neither rising stock and bond prices nor the anticipation of future decliens in short-term interest rates had a discernible inhibiting effect on flows of assets into money market funds,'' he said. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 265 general purpose funds rose by $303.8 million to $150.32 billion; assets of 104 broker-dealer funds rose by $147.3 million to $166.53 billion; and assets of 164 institutional funds rose by $570.8 million to $108.04 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds in the week ended Tuesday was 7.27 percent, unchanged from the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.31 percent from 7.34 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 52 days, up from 50 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 5.98 percent as of Wednesday from 5.99 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was 5.07 percent, unchanged from a week earlier. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.50 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.53 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.60 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.62 percent; 7.70 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.73 percent; and 7.95 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 7.97 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Market Would Briefly Halt Trading During Big Price Swings
DOC.TEXT: Trading in crude oil futures would be temporarily suspended in response to large price swings, under a plan approved Thursday by the New York Mercantile Exchange. The plan, to be considered by federal regulators, would also limit the amount oil could rise or fall each day to $15 per barrel and the amount gasoline or home heating oil could rise or fall to 40 cents a gallon each day. Exchange officials told a news conference that the plan was developed to ensure orderly trading in volatile situations, such as a war in the Persian Gulf, which could push prices higher, or a sudden outbreak of peace, which could send prices into a steep decline. The officials denied bowing to any pressure from regulators or criticism that speculators were profiteering from wide swings in the futures market. ``We were not goaded into this by any federal agency,'' said Merc Chairman Z. Lou Guttman said. ``We felt that this was a very responsible and necessary precautionary measure.'' But oil market traders said the plan was aimed at heading off tighter regulation by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. ``Rather than have the CFTC close the exchange during war, we could claim there are circuit-breakers,'' said Christian Gohler, a broker at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``That's the only redeeming quality.'' David Geary, a CFTC spokesman, said the commission had not yet received the complete proposal from the exchange, but he said the matter would be considered quickly. Exchange officials said they expected the plan to be approved by next Wednesday. A prominent critic of oil pricing, Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman, D-Conn., said the exchange's plan was a small step in the right direction. But he said he would favor a government shutdown of the oil market if war broke out. ``A $15-a-barrel increase in one day is still huge and unacceptable,'' Lieberman said in a telephone interview. But Lieberman praised the exchange officials for acknowledging ``they have some obligation to try to limit the increases in the price of oil due to panic.'' Oil traders pointed out that any limits at the exchange would not stop a big move by crude, because there are no limits at the futures markets in London and Singapore or in the spot market where buyers pay cash for oil at loading docks. Many doubt the exchange's limits would ever come into play, because they are so wide. ``It's going to be in effect limitless trading, which is the way the free markets are supposed to operate,'' said Brian Tagler, an oil broker at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The largest one-day move oil futures have made in New York occurred on Oct. 22, when crude dropped $5.41 per barrel, largely in response to a rumor that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had a dream in which a prophet told him his missiles were pointed the wrong way. The oil market took that to be a sign of peace in the Middle East. Exchange officials said they were not trying to predict oil prices would move $15 daily after a war broke out. They said the figure set conservative limits for the normal functioning of the market. Beyond those limits, market participants might be unable to meet their obligations as buyers and sellers. Under the new rules, if oil prices swing $7.50 in either direction during a single trading session and stay at that level for five minutes, oil brokers would be told that trading would be halted in two minutes. After a trading halt of one hour, trading would resume, with the swing in prices limited to another $7.50 for a total of $15. The limits would affect contracts for the two nearest delivery months. Trading of unleaded gasoline and home heating oil futures would follow a similar pattern with a maximum move of 40 cents a gallon in either direction on the two nearest months. The exchange currently has no limits on moves made by contracts for next-month delivery of oil, although there are limits on outer months. Exchange officials said the hour's break in trading would give futures players time to take a closer look at world events that are pushing the price of crude.

DOC.HEAD: American General Rejects Bids for Partial Sale
DOC.TEXT: American General Corp.'s board of directors on Thursday rejected two bids for its home service insurance subsidiaries and took the units off the sales block. The board also authorized the resumption of its stock repurchase program suspended since talk of a possible sale began last May. Harold S. Hook, chairman and chief executive of the Houston-based financial services company, said the higher of the two bids opened Tuesday was $3.65 billion, of which $1.8 billion would cover the assumption of corporate debt. ``Under this proposal, American General shareholders would have received about $15 per share in a combination of cash and securities of the acquiring company,'' Hook said. ``The board concluded that this proposal fell short of the value of these operations.'' Trading in American General stock was halted temporarily on the New York Stock Exchange Thursday pending the announcement. It fell $1.50 for the day, closing at $28.87{ per share. American General, with $34 billion in assets, is one of the nation's largest providers of life insurance, retirement plans and consumer loans. The company put itself up for sale in May amid speculation it could be the target of a hostile takeover. When no potential buyers came forward to purchase the company as a whole, American General set a Dec. 3 deadline for bids for part of the company as well as the company as a whole. But by Tuesday it had received only two bids for the home service subsidiaries and none for the whole company. Hooks said after considering the proposals and the company's future, the board agreed that continuing the sale process ``is not likely to be productive'' and instead would be ``detrimental to the business of the company.'' American General has paid about $1 billion to repurchase about 20 percent of its stock outstanding as of April 1, 1987, when it initiated its repurchasing plan. The plan was suspended last May when the sale process was begun. Besides voting to resume the repurchase program, American General's board set a new annual common dividend rate of $2 per share in 1991, a 27 percent increase over the $1.58 annual rate in effect before May. In May, the company had set a rate of 80 cents per quarter to give shareholders an additional return while waiting for a sale to be completed. Torchmark Corp., a Birmingham, Ala.-based insurance firm, has been trying to acquire all or a part of American General since March, when it informally proposed more than $6 million. The offer was turned down by American General officials, who said the company was worth more.
