DOC.HEAD: Falls On News of Planned Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell for a second straight session Thursday to levels not seen for months, with the plunge based on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's promise to free all hostages. Light sweet crude oil dropped 89 cents to $26.40 per barrel at the New York Mercantile Exchange on contracts for delivery in January. Oil for next-month delivery had not been that cheap on the exchange since late August. Unleaded gasoline futures fell 2.24 cents to 66.60 cents a gallon for January delivery. At one point, gasoline was below 65 cents a gallon, within a fraction of a penny of the price it commanded on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait. Home heating oil was down 1.43 cents to 71.91 cents a gallon. A day earlier, all of the futures contracts dropped to levels they had not traded for since the month of the invasion. They kept falling Thursday, though not as sharply. ``We're seeing an erosion of the war premium,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``I think the market is just registering this change in the situation and trying to establish a new base.'' Oil had fallen even farther in early trading Thursday, but it regained some ground during the afternoon. Traders were responding in part to continued harsh rhetoric from U.S. officials, but some began buying oil again when they decided crude must have hit bottom, at least for the time being. The oil market has been overwhelmingly bearish since last Friday, when President Bush offered to hold diplomatic meetings with ranking Iraqis in an effort to convince Saddam that he must get his troops out of Kuwait. Analysts have said the demise of much of the war premium has been accentuated by increased oil production that has some countries stuck with millions of barrels of crude they cannot immediately sell. But the threat of war still carried some weight in the oil pits. Crude had been down more than $2 a barrel before President Bush held a news conference in Santiago, Chile, that was construed as bullish. Bush said release of the thousands of hostages would not weaken American resolve to get Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. That sparked a rally, but it was unable to pull oil all the way back up. Natural gas, which is not directly affected by the turmoil in the Middle East, also dropped Thursday. It closed down 5.1 cents at $2.351 per 1,000 cubic feet on contracts for January delivery.

DOC.HEAD: Gold, Energy Continue to Take Cues from Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Developments in the Persian Gulf crisis continued to control the direction of the precious metals and energy markets Thursday. They both lost ground as the rhetoric by world leaders waxed both conciliatory and bellicose. Gold futures for February delivery plunged $4.10 a troy ounce in early trading before recovering somewhat, while energy futures followed the same pattern. On other markets, livestock and pork futures were mixed, and grains and soybeans were higher. Gold on New York's Commodity Exchange opened sharply lower on word the Iraqis will release foreign hostages held since the occupation of Kuwait, said William O'Neill, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Futures Inc. in New York. O'Neill said gold futures began to show improvement after President Bush's comments that Iraq must leave Kuwait ``without reservation, without conditions'' before the gulf crisis can end. Gold settled $2.30 to $2.60 lower with the contract for delivery in February at $373.20 a troy ounce; silver was 2.7 cents to 3.5 cents lower with January at $4.136 a troy ounce. Brian Tagler of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York said the energy market mirrored gold's movement. ``The market was counting on Bush to be unbending and figured that would send the market back up, and he was,'' he said. Tagler said that while the Persian Gulf crisis is primarily controlling the movement of energy prices, he noted that there is an underlining bearish tone to the market. He noted that Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states have more than made up for the loss of Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil production. ``There is a lot of crude out there, and demand is soft,'' Tagler said, adding that in the long term, energy futures will continue to be pressured. Light sweet crude was 23 cents to 94 cents lower with January at $26.40 a barrel; heating oil was 1.16 cents to 3.55 cents lower with January at 79.71 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.80 cents to 3.13 cents lower with January at 66.50 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices closed higher in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade on expectations that credits soon will be extended to the Soviet Union to buy U.S. grains. Hearings Wednesday by a U.S. House Agriculture subcommittee indicated the Soviets could be offered credits of about $1.25 billion. William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago, said those reports, as well as rumors of increased bookings of ocean vessels for exports, helped fuel the gains in the market. Biedermann said the strong ocean vessel market was an indication the Soviets may be pricing grains for purchase. Also boosting the market was an improved tone early on at world trade talks in Brussels. The European Community had shown a willingness to discuss greater cuts in farm subsidies, and officials attending the negotiations decided to continue their talks rather than suspend them. Later on, however, after the markets closed, the EC rejected a last-minute compromise proposal to make significant subsidy cuts, and the talks were close to collapse. At stake in the talks are more access to world markets for poor and newly democratizing countries, protection against copyright theft, and extension of fair-trade rules to agriculture, banking and textiles. Wheat was 1{ cents to 3{ cents higher with December at $2.47 a bushel; corn was 1\ cents lower to 1 cent higher with December at $2.25} a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2 cents higher with December at $1.11} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 5{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in January at $5.97\ a bushel. Livestock futures were mixed and pork futures mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle futures were boosted by high cash prices, which are trading at a premium to futures, said Charles Levitt, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in Chicago. Pork futures were pressured by the steady marketing of hogs by farmers, and the heavier than normal weight of hogs being slaughtered. The heavier hogs mean more pork is available to the market than normally is the case, Levitt said. Live cattle were .02 cent to .30 cent higher with December at 79.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .50 cent higher with January at 88.22 cents a pound; live hogs were .62 cent lower to .12 cent higher with December at 49 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.02 cents to 1.25 cents lower with February at 62.85 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Production Mixed This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 181,859 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 174,315, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 215,143 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 119,021 cars this week, compared with 109,151 a week ago and 129,088 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 62,838, compared with last week's 65,164 and last year's 86,055. Canadian automakers were to build 26,398 cars this week, up from 26,035 a week ago and up from last year's 24,446. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 17,049, compared with 13,090 a week ago and 20,840 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Expands
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Nov. 26, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,324.5 billion from a revised $3,319.1 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,089.7 billion from a revised $4,082.7 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $825.5 billion from $823.7 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 3.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.4 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,320.0 billion, a 3.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,089.9 billion, up 1.0 percent, while M1 rose 5.2 percent to an average of $821.5 billion. In other reports: -The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $112 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $184 million the previous week. -The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $319.9 billion in the two-week period ended Nov. 28, up from $318.7 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: NEC Strengthens Overseas Supercomputer Marketing
DOC.TEXT: NEC Corp. said Thursday it will create new sales divisions in Germany and Japan to boost its overseas marketing of supercomputers. While NEC and two other Japanese supercomputer makers, Fujitsu and Hitachi, together have sold more than 200 supercomputers, the vast majority have been ordered in Japan. NEC's new European supercomputer division, based in Cologne, Germany, hopes to sell 30 of the company's new SX-3 supercomputers over the next four years, company officials said. That would approximately double the number of Japanese supercomputers in place overseas. NEC says the SX-3, which it recently began shipping, is the world's fastest computer in some benchmark tests. It plans to sell 120 of the multimillion- dollar machines worldwide, including 40 outside Japan. NEC has sold only one supercomputer in the United States, and some officials charge that Japanese machines have been unfairly excluded from U.S. government procurement programs. A U.S. trade official negotiating access for U.S. supercomputers to Japanese procurement programs said earlier this year that Japan should ``do as we say, not as we do'' regarding open government purchasing. He also said U.S. supercomputers, made primarily by Cray Research Inc., still had an overall performance advantage. But many industry analysts believe that gap has greatly narrowed, and some believe it has disappeared. In the United States, NEC will continue to market its supercomputers through its HNSX Supercomputers sales subsidiary, the official said. The new marketing division in Tokyo will provide worldwide sales and technical support, NEC said. Supercomputers are high-speed computers designed to handle large numbers of repetitive scientific calculations in areas such as car design, weather forecasting, aerospace and defense.

DOC.HEAD: VCR Maker Challenges MCA Buyout on Antitrust Grounds
DOC.TEXT: The $6.6 billion buyout of MCA Inc. by a giant Japanese electronics company is being challenged in an antitrust lawsuit by a small Arizona manufacturer of a dual-deck videocassette recorder. Go-Video Inc., of Scottsdale, contends Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.'s pending deal is part of a conspiracy with Sony Corp. and oher Japanese companies to monopolize the world market for electronics hardware - VCRs, televisions, and audio gear. The lawsuit, filed Thursday, asks the federal court in Phoenix to block the buyout on grounds it violates U.S. laws designed to encourage competition. The action grows out of earlier lawsuits by Go-Video, which is counting on sales of its patented, dual-deck VCR-2 for survival. It began selling the machine, billed as the world's first such device, last July. The lawsuit touches on the sensitive issue of how Japan has taken control of the consumer electronics business from the United States. The primary objective of the Japanese companies is to dominate the yet-to-emerge high-definition television market, said Joseph M. Alioto, a lawyer for Go-Video. ``These guys are looking 20 years down the road,'' Alioto said in a telephone interview from San Francisco. Matsushita spokeswoman Joele Frank declined immediate comment, saying the company's lawyers hadn't finished reviewing the lawsuit. MCA spokeswoman Christine Hanson said the company never comments on lawsuits. Much has been made of the fact that the purchase of MCA, the parent of Universal Studios, would give Matsushita movies, television shows and recordings to complement its consumer electronics products. Sony Corp. used the strategy last year in purchasing Columbia Pictures for $3.4 billion. The Korean electronics giant Samsung Group was reported Thursday to be interested in a similar purchase of Orion Pictures. Alioto said the Japanese companies intend to use their domination of both sides of the entertainment business to ensure that ``Go-Video's products will not play their software, and anybody else (outside Japan) who makes HDTV won't either.'' Go-Video already is pursuing its conspiracy claim in an earlier lawsuit against Matsushita and its Panasonic division; Victor Co. of Japan Ltd. and its JVC Corp. subsidiary; Sanyo Electric Co. Ltd.; Sony; and NEC Corp. Go-Video contends the companies have formed a cartel to control the consumer-electronics market. In an unrelated development, MCA said it would sell its Yosemite Park & Curry Co. to an American buyer rather than give the national park concession to the U.S. government before the buyout by Matsushita. MCA Chairman Lew R. Wasserman turned down a request by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. for donation of the company, which has the concession contract at Yosemite National Park until 1993 and owns about half of the restaurants, stores and lodgings in Yosemite Valley. James Ridenour, director of the Park Service, said Wednesday he had been told that Curry Co. assets were ``made part of the deal with Matsushita'' and could not be given away. Because of the foreign ownership issue, MCA and Matsushita agreed last month to place the Curry Co. in escrow until a U.S. buyer could be found. In the meantime, Curry Co. profits will be donated to the National Park Foundation, a group that channels private money to the Park Service. ``We believe this is a generous gift which will further the work of the National Park Service,'' Wasserman wrote to Lujan.

DOC.HEAD: Union Rallies Against Nordstrom Labor Practices
DOC.TEXT: Members of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union rallied in Seattle and other cities Thursday to protest what they called labor abuses by the retailer Nordstrom Inc. About 90 union members and supporters gathered at a downtown Seattle park before marching six blocks to hand out leaflets in front of the clothing retailer's flagship store. UFCW Local 1001 President Joe Peterson, whose union has been battling Nordstrom for more than a year and a half, told the gathering, ``We're here today to let Nordstrom employees know we're fighting for their right to earn a living under decent working conditions.'' Few current Nordstrom workers attended the Seattle rally. Peterson said Nordstrom employees didn't turn out because they are afraid of being harassed by the company. Peterson outlined what he said were past and present abuses by the company. The allegations include forcing employees to perform services without pay, discriminating against workers over 40, pregnant women and blacks, trying to deny unemployment benefits to former workers, and seeking to limit information to employees and the news media about its treatment of workers. Nordstrom spokesman Tim Doke called the union's allegations ``nonsense.'' Doke said union rallies were reported in Los Angeles; San Francisco; Portland, Ore.; and in Tyson's Corner, Va. near Washington, D.C. Local 1001 represents about 1,700 workers at six Seattle-area stores. Nordstrom employs more than 30,000 people at 62 stores in Washington, Oregon, Alaska, Utah, California, Virginia and New Jersey. Two Nordstrom workers who attended the rally in Seattle were Diane Aldrich, who works at the Seattle Northgate mall store, and Kathleen Sargent, from the downtown Seattle store. Both said they are members of Nordstrom Employees Opposed to Union Representation, an employee group seeking a vote to decertify UFCW representation. Aldrich said most of the allegations mentioned by the union had been settled. ``I couldn't be upset with what I heard today because it's all old news,'' she said. Aldrich said she didn't understand the union's allegations about discrimination. She said she works with blacks and pregnant women at Northgate, and that ``I'm 44 and I've only worked there a year.'' Last month, the National Labor Relations Board rejected appeals by Local 1001 to overturn settlements reached by Nordstrom and the federal agency. In the settlements, Nordstrom agreed to post notices promising not to penalize employees for union activity, not to bargain with workers directly and not to withhold information sought by the union for negotiations. After the notices have been posted 60 days, Nordstrom may be found in compliance with the settlement, the NLRB said. At that point, employees could start circulating petitions for an election on whether to retain the union. Peterson, however, has said the decertification effort would be blocked by the filing of new unfair labor practice charges. Action on petitions to decertify a union are barred while any unfair labor practice charges are pending. Peterson has said that fewer than half the workers represented by his local are union members. Local 1001's contract with Nordstrom expired July 31, 1989, after company negotiators refused to accept renewal of a provision requiring employees covered by the contract to belong to the union. Last winter, the union filed suit seeking more than $300 million in back pay for Nordstrom employees nationwide. A separate but similar union complaint resulted in a state Department of Labor and Industries ruling in February that Nordstrom failed to pay some workers for attending company meetings, writing thank-you notes to customers, making deliveries and performing other functions on their own time.

DOC.HEAD: Financial World Turns Skeptical on Hostage Freedom Decree
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's offer to free foreign hostages jolted financial markets Thursday, inciting a brief rally on Wall Street and a drop in oil prices on hunches of a breakthrough in the 4-month-old Persian Gulf crisis. But President Bush's skeptical response and insistence that the Iraqi leader's troops vacate Kuwait doused the initial enthusiasm. Many strategists said it was premature to conclude war had become a remote possibility. ``I think the market feels we're taking a step closer to peace,'' said Gary N. Ross, president of consulting activities at Petroleum Industry Research Associates in New York. Nonetheless, he said, ``you've got to expect the market is going to continue to be volatile. Peace isn't necessarily at hand.'' The Iraqi leader said all foreign hostages would be freed because of what he called diplomatic advances in resolving the crisis that began after he seized Kuwait Aug. 2. That invasion led to United Nations sanctions and a major U.S. military deployment that has threatened to escalate into war. Bush, at a news conference during a trip to Santiago, Chile, said Saddam should never have taken hostages and that he must withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally before the crisis can end. By the end of the day the price of oil, which initially plunged more than $2 a barrel on the hostage-freedom offer, ended with an 89 cent loss at $26.40 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks, the best-known barometer of Wall Street, finished down 7.92 points to 2,602.48. The average had been up over 30 points in the first 15 minutes of trading. ``I was sort of stunned that we ended down, 40 points essentially,'' said John Eberley, a stock trader at the Chicago Corp. investment company. ``My guess is that Bush's posture, nothing less than absolutely withdrawal, spooked some people.'' In the bond market, a sensitive barometer of interest rates and the economy's direction, the key 30-year Treasury bond also ended with loss after rising sharply on the Iraqi hostage announcement. Gold prices and the dollar, historically considered safe ways to protect money during times of political and economic travail, also ended with losses, which some trading professionals attributed to the prospects of peace. ``The dollar's advantage as a safe haven currency is the reason for its unfortunate demise, at least temporarily,'' said Zlatko Glamuzina, chief currency dealer at the New York branch of the Banco di Sicilia. ``The war premium is down,'' Glamuzina said. ``If I am an investor, the dollar is not the greatest currency to park my money.'' In the precious metals market, gold prices, which lately have been following the behavior of the oil market, fell about $2.50 a troy ounce to about $372, but that is considered an insignificant drop. Some strategists said the decline in gold would have been greater if the Iraqi leader had begun freeing hostages instead of simply suggesting they would be released at an unspecified time. ``If he does the release the hostages, he loses a major chip,'' said Nelson Colton, president of the precious metals group at A-Mark Precious Metals, a leading wholesaler based in Los Angeles. ``The general opinion is when he does it, we'll believe it.'' Others said the financial market behavior reflected other influences, particularly signs of weakness of the American economy that is discouraging U.S. investments. ``People are using any opportunity, any good news out of the Persian Gulf to lighten up,'' said John Hickey, treasurer at the New York branch of Kansallis-Osake-Pankki, a Finnish banking company.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted CenTrust Chairman Fights Bond Payment
DOC.TEXT: Ousted CenTrust Chairman David Paul went back to court Thursday in an effort to get out of posting a $30.8 million bond that would cover lavish spending by the failed thrift. The Office of Thrift Supervision ordered Paul to put up the cash, and Paul failed Tuesday to persuade a judge to throw out the order. Paul's attorneys responded by asking for a stay of the ruling and filing notice of appeal late Thursday, which could eventually put the case before the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. ``Since we expect the government to do whatever it can to hurt David Paul, contempt or whatever, we are trying to get the ruling stayed,'' attorney Sanford Bohrer said. After the government seized CenTrust in February, regulators questioned spending that included $29 million for paintings, $15 million on a legal defense fund for officers and directors, $5 million for Paul's retirement and a laundry list of ritzy equipment and furnishings for the 47-story CenTrust tower in downtown Miami. Paul also spent $129,000 in bank funds to bring French chef Paul Bocuse and other notables to prepare a banquet at his Miami Beach mansion, and CenTrust insured a clambake against rain at Paul's Connecticut home, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Radioactive Waste Handler Accused of Stock Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge in Texas froze a Houston company's assets Thursday after regulators charged it had bilked investors out of at least $350,0000 with false claims about a deal to dispose of low-level radioactive waste in Africa. Houston-based FMF Corp. also falsely claimed to have had a deal with a pharmaceutical company to dispose of 30,000 tons of contaminated waste, according to a civil lawsuit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. In the lawsuit, filed at federal court in Houston, the SEC accused FMF Corp. and three top officers of fraud scheme in which they either deliberately misled investors or recklessly disregarded whether the information they supplied was true or false. Under the recently passed Securities Enforcement Remedies and Penny Stock Reform Act, the stock market watchdog agency is seeking a court order to freeze the defendants' assets and make them pay restitution to investors and fines to the government. William McLucas, head of the SEC's Enforcement Division, said the action was the first brought by the agency under the new law which empowers the SEC to seek fines for securities crimes other than insider trading. He said the law allows the SEC to seek up to $500,000 in fines from a company for each alleged violation, although the agency has not quantified how many violations allegedly occurred. Named as defendants in the suit in addition to the company were: FMF's chairman, Abraham A. Greenspan, and its president, B.F. Winborn, both of Houston; and the company's vice president of operations, Charles W. Brandes, of Sealy, Texas. There was no one in FMF's offices to provide comment Thursday afternoon. U.S. District Judge Sim Lake in Houston has issued a temporary restraining order freezing the corporation's assets and prohibiting further sale of any more interests until the suit is resolved. Lake set a Dec. 17 hearing. Among the false information allegedly supplied investors, the SEC charged the defendants said: - the United States had a treaty with Equitorial Guinea allowing the storage of low-level radioactive waste in the West African nation when no such treaty exists. - FMF had a concession from Equitorial Guinea to bury up to 2 million tons of ``radon gas impregnated'' waste within its borders when Equitorial Guinea has not given that permission to anyone. - FMF had a contract with Indianapolis-based Eli Lilly & Co. to dispose of 30,000 tons of contaminated material in Africa when Lilly has never done business with FMF. ``It is our belief and our allegations that they never engaged in this business at all. This appears to be a total sham to us,'' said Therese D. Pritchard, an SEC attorney handling the case. SEC officials said the case was referred to them by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The SEC also charged that FMF did not tell investors, as required under securities law disclosure rules, that Greenspan, the FMF chairman, was barred from practicing law in Texas in 1980, was convicted of fraudulently obtaining a $1 million bank loan in 1989 and filed for personal bankruptcy in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Talks Near Collapse After EC Rejects Farm Subsidy Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Washington saying it would accept a compromise, new proposal for renewing talks later; details, minor editing. No pickup; Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Talks among 107 nations trying to draft an ambitious global trade pact neared collapse Thursday night after the European Community rejected a last-minute compromise making significant cuts in farm subsidies. Trade ministers suggested the EC's action virtually dooms any chances for reaching a trade agreement this week in Brussels. However, many said they will campaign Friday for holding more discussions after a cooling-off period. However, such a strategy runs a high risk of failure, given tight deadlines imposed by the U.S. Congress for approving any final outcome under so-called ``fast-track authority.'' The battle between the United States and its trade allies on one side and the 12-nation European Community on the other turned out to be the biggest stumbling block to getting an overall agreement in the trade talks. In a last-ditch attempt to rescue the negotiations, Swedish Agriculture Minister Mats Hellstrom, chairman of the farm negotiating panel, put forward a proposal that represented a compromise between the drastic cuts in farm subsidies being sought by the United States and the minimal offer of the EC, which was trying to protect its 10 million mainly small farmers. The talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where they began in 1986, had stalled in what was to have been the final week of bargaining. The talks are being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, also known as GATT. Hellstrom suggested across-the-board cuts of 30 percent in internal farm supports, export subsidies and market barriers over a five-year period. But the Hellstrom proposal brought strong objections almost immediately from Community officials. Other countries who objected the proposal were South Korea and Japan, which would have been forced to open its closed rice market to foreign imports under the proposal. ``You will find that among ministers, opinion strays from `monstrous proposal,' `shocking paper,' `twice what the community has agreed to,''' said EC Agricultural Commissioner Ray MacSharry. Talking to reporters, he refused to be specific about what other cuts the EC was willing to make. U.S. negotiators are pushing for cuts of 75 percent in internal price supports and market barriers and 90 percent reductions in export subsidies over a 10-year period. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills suggested the United States would be willing to accept smaller percentage reductions as long as it obtained binding commitments from the EC to make reductions in all three areas. The United States and some other major exporting countries, including Canada, have been pushing the Europeans to relent and agree to major cuts in subsidies. Without movement on agriculture, it is likely the trade talks will be suspended, perhaps for up to a month. Neal Blewett, the Australian trade minister, said it is now time for the countries to turn their attention to trying to rescue the overall trade package by setting up a fall-back meeting, possibly in January. The United States had insisted such a strategy was risky, given a March 1 deadline imposed by Congress for submitting a complete deal and the necessary time to put the nearly 300-page document in shape. The reduction in farm subsidies is being pushed hard by the Bush administration. Washington sees the change as a boost to American farm exports as well as those of many farm-based Third World nations, which cannot compete with the huge subisidies offered by the developed world. More than 1,500 delegates, including four members of Bush's Cabinet, have been taking part in the negotiations, which began on Monday and were scheduled to end on Friday. GATT was established in 1947 as a forum for promoting free trade. The current round of talks is the eighth since World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Sue Continental Over Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT spelling of Pohlad
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines officials made misleading comments about the troubled carrier's plans to seek bankruptcy protection in an effort to prop up its stock value, according to a lawsuit filed Thursday. Former chairman Frank Lorenzo and others artificially inflated the market price of Continental stock by denying in interviews with the news media that the nation's fifth-largest airline was considering filing for bankruptcy protection, according to the lawsuit filed on behalf of shareholders. Continental disputed the allegations. ``As far as this airline is concerned, that suit is utterly without merit,'' spokesman Art Kent said from Houston. ``In no way were our shareholders or the public misled by any statements that were made. At the time those statements were made, we had no intent to file for protection under Chapter 11.'' Continental filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors on Monday, saying it was forced into bankruptcy court by soaring fuel costs and mounting interest payments on its $6.2 billion debt. The shareholders lawsuit, a class action filed in U.S. District Court, was brought on behalf of investors who purchased Continental stock between Oct. 24 and the airline's bankruptcy filing. The shareholders said that during this time period, airline officials publicly denied their intention to seek bankruptcy protection even though ``such action was continually under consideration as a solution to Continental's worsening liquidity and other financial problems.'' The lawsuit accuses the airline officials of violating securities laws and seeks unspecified damages because of losses on investments. According to the lawsuit, Continental stock fell from $3.62{ per share to $2 per share after the bankruptcy filing. In addition to Lorenzo, the lawsuit names Jan Carlzon, chairman of Scandinavian Airlines System, Continental's largest shareholder; Continental chairman Carl R. Pohlad; and Hollis Harris, president and chief executive officer of Continental.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Files Suit to Eliminate Obstacles in NCR Takeover Attempt
With AM-AT&T-NCR, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has filed federal lawsuits in Maryland and Ohio seeking to block NCR Corp. from fighting a hostile $6.1 billion takeover attempt by the telephone giant. AT&T spokeswoman Paula Horii said the lawsuit filed Thursday in U.S. District Court in Columbus, Ohio, seeks to prevent NCR from stalling AT&T with requests for information. The Baltimore action, filed late Wednesday in U.S. District Court, also names NCR, which is chartered in Maryland, and Maryland Attorney General J. Joseph Curran, who has opposed corporate takeovers. AT&T asked a federal judge to bar NCR and Curran from using the Maryland Business Combination Act or other state laws to stop AT&T from acquiring enough NCR stock, or shareholder proxies, to take over the Dayon, Ohio-based computer maker. The Maryland law would impose a five-year moratorium on acquiring enough stock or proxies to force a takeover. AT&T has issued a tender offer of $90 per share for NCR common stock, which the lawsuit said is ``a premium of nearly 90 percent over the market price of NCR's common shares.'' NCR Chairman Charles E. Exley has told AT&T his company would not consider a tender offer of less than $125 per share. NCR spokeswoman Connie Olasz said the company has not yet seen the lawsuits and could not comment on them. Olasz said NCR's board of directors on Wednesday voted to opt out of a Maryland state law in an attempt to block AT&T from calling a special meeting of NCR shareholders to vote on the tender offer.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Capital Investment Withdrawals Rise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Friday in lede is cq
DOC.TEXT: Faced with rising local wages and other problems, foreign corporate investors withdrew $110 million from South Korea in the first nine months of 1990, the Finance Ministry said Friday. Approvals on new foreign capital investment in South Korea from January to September totaled $632 million, down 26.9 percent from the same period last year, ministry officials said. The total amount of foreign capital investment remaining in South Korea was listed at $5.66 billion at the end of September. Withdrawals of direct foreign investment from the country totaled $75 million in 1989 and $48 million in 1988. It was not known how many foreign businesses were involved in the capital withdrawals in the past three years. The declines were attributed to worsening investment conditions such as steep local wage hikes, labor unrest and a slowdown in local economic growth. Even many Korean businesses in recent years have relocated manufacturing and other operations to other countries where labor is available at lower cost without unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Steel Company Presents Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. on Thursday asked a federal judge to confirm a reorganization plan to keep the company in business by giving $600 million in cash to creditors. Executives of the nation's 10th-largest steelmaker said at a hearing before U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz the plan will allow the company the remain competitive with other steel companies. Under the proposed reorganization, unsecured creditors would be paid 72 cents per $1 of debt. The remaining challenger to the plan is a joint interest of the U.S. Farmers Home Administration and Equibank, which is owed $44 million. Bentz on Thursday dismissed a claim by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, which sought to force Wheeling-Pittsburgh to place pollution-control devices on its mills. The agency wanted Wheeling-Pittsburgh to place cash in an escrow account for the machinery, but Bentz said the agency would have to sue in another court for such an order. The plan before the judge would create two corporations - a holding company, Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corp., chaired by New York investor Ronald LeBow, who purchased 86 percent of secured debt; and an operating company, Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. Liquidating the company's assets would be unsound, said James T. Gibbons, Wheeling Pittsburgh's director of reorganization and planning. Gibbons estimated the value of a liquidated Wheeling-Pittsburgh at $860 million to $870 million. In contrast, the reorganized company would be worth at least $1.1 billion, he said. Gibbons told Bentz that Wheeling-Pittsburgh is a leaner, more competitive company than the one that filed for protection from its creditors in 1985. A major step toward recovery was the closing of the Monessen steel mill, which was operating at 30 percent capacity, Gibbons said. The mill was sold in 1988 to other steel makers. Wheeling-Pittsburgh employs 7,100 people in Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania.
